taxonomicNotes: Appeared on IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic name Hieremys.
Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001).

Lepus castroviejoi was described relatively recently, being separated from L. granatensis, a split supported by genetic evidence. While the range of L. castroviejoi partially overlaps that of L. granatensis and L. europaeus on the Iberian Peninsula, no hybridization has been detected with these forms. Recent studies have shown that instead, based on ecological, molecular and morphological characteristics, it is most closely related to L. corsicanus; some believe these two are conspecific (Alves et al. 2008, Acevedo et al. 2014, Ballesteros 2018). Additionally, two different occurrences of introgression of mtDNA from L. timidus into L. castroviejoi have been documented – indicating that these two forms have come into contact and hybridized two different times in the past, most recently during the last deglaciation (Melo-Ferreira et al. 2005, 2012; Ballesteros 2018). No subspecies or geographic variation in L. castroviejoi have been described (Flux and Angermann 1990, Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Ballesteros 2018).

Seven subspecies are generally accepted (TTWG 2017):

Malaclemys terrapin terrapin (Schoepff, 1793) - Northern Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin centrata (Latreille in Sonnini and Latreille, 1801) - Carolina Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin littoralis Hay, 1905 - Texas Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin macrospilota Hay, 1905 - Ornate Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin pileata (Wied, 1865) - Mississippi Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin rhizophorarum Fowler, 1906 - Mangrove Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin tequesta Schwartz, 1955 - Eastern Florida Diamondback Terrapin

These subspecific designations of terrapins were based on morphological characteristics (Carr 1952). However, molecular studies indicate that the morphological subspecific designations do not match well with the range-wide genetic differentiation, suggesting fewer independent lineages. Lamb and Avise (1992) first suggested two subpopulations that diverged near Jacksonville, Florida. More recent work using microsatellites suggested that five genetically distinct terrapin management units exist throughout the range (Hart et al. 2014). One unfortunate consequence of the previous heavy trade and farming of terrapins was the transport of individuals among populations, and the genetic signature of those translocations can still be detected today (Hauswaldt and Glen 2005; Converse et al. 2017; Converse and Kuchta 2018). A more thorough range-wide molecular study using more populations and loci is sorely needed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships and update the taxonomy of Malaclemys.

Lindholm (1929) recognized Testudo tornieri Siebenrock, 1903 as the type of a new genus, for which he established the name Malacochersus. The genus is monotypic, with only one species currently recognized. Genetic studies have demonstrated that Malacochersus is most closely related to Asian Indotestudo and Eurasian Testudo (Le et al. 2006; Parham et al. 2006; Fritz and Bininda-Emonds 2007). Phylogeographic studies of the species have not yet been realized, but are clearly needed in view of its disjunct distribution. Vernacular names used for the species in East African Kiswahili are Kobe ya Mawe and Kobe kama Chapati.

There are populations of "golden" mantellas that might belong to other species. The taxonomy of this group is uncertain but the definition of Mantella aurantiaca is clear and there seems to be little genetic subdivision within the species (M. Vences pers. comm.).
De la Riva (2005) resurrected Telmatobius sanborni from the synonymy of Telmatobius marmoratus on the basis of differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
This species was confused with Bolitoglossa pesrubra prior to its naming (Wake et al. 2007). It has been determined by mtDNA phylogeny to be part of the B. subpalmata clade (Boza-Oveido et al. 2012).

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.

Oreobates lehri was initially ascribed to two distant populations, one in Cordillera Vilcabamba, which is now considered typical O. lehri, and one in the Andean hills of the Kosñipata Valley, to which is now assigned to O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012). This is a restricted concept of O. lehri following the split of the broader concept into this and O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012).
Generally considered to consist of at least two morphologically distinguishable lineages.

Two subspecies are recognised: Cuora mouhoutii mouhotii (Gray, 1863) and C. m. obsti (Fritz, Andreas & Lehr, 1997).

Traditionally placed in the monotypic genus Pyxidea until Honda et al. (2002) demonstrated that mouhotii is genetically nested inside Cuora. Hybrids of C. mouhotii with Cuora galbinifrons or C. bourreti gave rise to specimens that were erroneously described as a separate species, Cuora serrata.

Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Previously considered to contain just a single, variable species, Cyclemys remains subject to ongoing taxonomic investigations which rearrange the taxonomy and nomenclature on an ongoing basis. Key references: Fritz et al. 1996, 1997; Iverson and McCord 1997; Guicking et al. 2002.

Previously assigned to the genus Geochelone, following Loveridge and Williams (1957), the species has more recently been placed in Centrochelys Gray 1872, following Bour (1980), as subsequently recognized by Devaux (2000), TTWG (2017), and Petrozzi et al. (2020b), but not by Fritz and Havas (2007). There is very little morphological (Lambert 1993) or genetic (mtDNA) variation in this species; however, there is some divergence between eastern and western subpopulations of C. sulcata based on the presence of two haplotypes (Livoreil and Van Der Kuyl 2005), but subspecies are not recognized.
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

Pelochelys bibroni was redescribed and separated from Pelochelys cantorii and restricted to the southern lowlands of New Guinea by Webb (1995), based partly on Rhodin et al. (1993). The genetic divergence of P. bibroni from Asian P. cantorii was confirmed by Engstrom et al. (2004), but it has yet to be compared genetically with P. signifera (Webb 2003), a morphologically distinct species from northern New Guinea. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named.
The taxonomy of sea lions in New Zealand (Phocarctos) and Australia (Neophoca) was confused until it was resolved in a paper by King (1960).
Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Its status compared to C. pulchristriata needs validation.
Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Its status compared to C. atripons needs validation.

This taxon was originally assigned by Mertens (1954) to the genus Geoemyda, and described as a subspecies of G. punctularia (as G. p. diademata) but later reassigned to Callopsis by Smith et al. (1974). Pritchard (1979) elevated it to full species and transferred it to the genus Rhinoclemmys. Although initially some authors did not recognize its status as a species (e.g., Ernst 1981, Paolillo 1985) this is currently not questioned (TTWG 2021). Most phylogenetic hypotheses have recovered R. diademata as the sister species of R. punctularia and both in turn as sisters to a clade containing R. melanosterna and R. funerea (e.g., Carr 1991, Spinks et al. 2004, Le and McCord 2008, Thomson et al. 2021). Although Vargas-Ramírez et al. (2013) recovered contradictory relationships for these four species between their mitochondrial and nuclear phylogenies, they argued that their results suggested past gene flow among the species.

In the past, specimens of softshell turtles collected from New Guinea were all originally assigned to what was considered to be a widespread Australasian species, Pelochelys bibroni (Owen 1853), until Rhodin et al. (1993) and Webb (1995) defined P. bibroni as being restricted to southern New Guinea, and separate from the previously described P. cantorii (Gray 1864) in the rest of Asia and northern New Guinea. Subsequently, Webb (2003) described the northern New Guinea softshell as the new species Pelochelys signifera. This taxonomy has been accepted since then (TTWG 2017). Pelochelys signifera was described largely based on characteristics of a juvenile specimen and coloration and texturing of the carapace to distinguish it from P. cantorii. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named. Phylogenetic relationships with P. cantorii and P. bibroni warrant further investigation.
Accepted as Rhampholeon acuminatus in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia vosseleri in Mariaux et al. (2008).
Accepted as Rhampholeon temporalis in Tilbury et al. (2006).
Accepted as Nadzikambia mlanjensis in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007). Populations of chameleons on nearby mountains in Mozambique do not represent this taxon (Branch and Tolley 2010).

Accepted as Rhampholeon platyceps (Tilbury 2010). Populations of Rhampholeon on Mt. Chiperone, Mabu and Namuli are separate taxa and should not be confused with R. platyceps (Branch et al. 2014). In addition, molecular phylogenetic analysis shows that the sub-species, R. platyceps carri is not valid (Branch et al. 2014).

authority: Menegon, Tolley, Jones, Rovero, Marshall & Tilbury, 2009
taxonomicNotes: Accepted as Kinyongia magomberae in Menegon et al. (2009).
Accepted as Kinyongia matschiei in Mariaux et al. (2008). Populations occur in the East Usambara Mountains, and these were formerly confused with K. fischeri.
Accepted as Rhampholeon beraduccii in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia tenuis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). The status of the Shimba Hills population as belonging to this taxon needs to be confirmed.
Accepted as Kinyongia excubitor in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Two morphologically distinct subspecies, corresponding to a northern and southern distribution within the Cameroon mountain chain, are traditionally recognized, the southern T. q. quadricornis (Mertens 1968) and northern T. q. gracilior (Barej et al. 2010). Molecular data supports this division, although suggests a very recent split between these taxa (Barej et al. 2010). Klaver and Böhme (1992) suggest that the assignment of Mt Kupe specimens to T. q. quadricornis requires verification, and that these records may in fact represent a separate, isolated lineage. Barej et al. (2010) also supported the finding by Pook and Wild (1997) that the morphologically divergent and geographically disjunct Eisentraut's chameleon (T. eisentrauti) should be treated as a subspecies of T. quadricornis on molecular grounds, and formally made this change. Accepted as Trioceros quadricornis in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). Glaw (2015) recognizes three subspecies: Trioceros quadricornis quadricornis, Trioceros quadricornis eisentrauti, and Trioceros quadricornis gracilior.
The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Accepted as Trioceros pfefferi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), Tolley and Herrel (2014), and Glaw (2015).
Accepted as Kinyongia multituberculata in Mariaux et al. (2008) and Tilbury (2010).

Cnemaspis indraneildasii was described from Gund, North Kanara, Karnataka (Bauer 2002). The forms belonging to Cnemaspis kandiana (Kelaart 1852) (in part) from northern Western Ghats as reported by Smith (1935) are now included under Cnemaspis indraneildasii Bauer, 2002 following Das (2003).  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated. It is likely that C. indraneildasii is a junior synonym of C. goaensis, based on molecular evidence that the two species exhibit "minimal genetic distances" (Sayeed et al. 2018).

Mabuya clivicola was described based on three specimens collected from Ponmudi, Thiruvananthapuram District, Kerala (Inger et al. 1984). Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002) this taxon is presently included within Eutropis Fitzinger 1843.
Oligodon brevicauda was described by Günther in 1862 based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Western Ghats in Coimbatore District, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943).
Melanophidium bilineatum was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Waynaad, Kerala (Smith 1943).

Uropeltis phipsonii was described as Silybura phipsonii by Mason in 1888 based on type series collected from the Bombay Ghats between Bombay (=Mumbai) and Pune, Maharashtra, India (Boulenger 1890, Smith 1943). The specific epithet is sometimes erroneously listed as 'phipsoni'. Uropeltis phipsonii has been treated as a synonym of Uropeltis rubrolineatus (Günther,1875) by Gans (1966) and revalidated by Rajendran (1985).

Dasia subcaerulea was described by Boulenger in 1891 as Lygosoma subcaeruleum based on a specimen collected from Bodanai-Kannur, Travancore (presently Bodinayakanur in Theni district of Tamil Nadu), India (Smith 1935). Joshua and Sekar (1984) assigned Indian specimens they collected to the Sri Lankan endemic D. haliana, and a number of additional records of this species have since been reported from India (see Wickramasinghe et al. 2011). Examined material of Indian "D. haliana" has recently been found to represent D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011, using the incorrect nomina Dasia halianus and D. subcaeruleum). The specimens collected by Joshua and Sekar (1984) were apparently not preserved and so cannot be examined, and in the absence of evidence to the contrary all records of D. haliana from India are considered to belong instead to D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011).

Cnemaspis jerdonii was described by Theobald in1868, however, no type locality was mentioned in the type description (Smith 1935, Das and Bauer 2000). The taxon scalpensis, which was described from Sri Lanka (Ferguson 1877) and long considered a subspecies of Cnemaspis jerdonii, has been elevated to species level (Wickramasinghe and Munindradasa 2007).  As with the other members of the genus Cnemaspis, populations north and south of the Palghat Gap need taxonomic revalidation.  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated.

Cnemaspis goaensis was described from Ponguinim, Canocona Taluka, South Goa, Goa (Sharma 1976). It is likely that C. indraneildasii is a junior synonym of C. goaensis, based on molecular evidence that the two species exhibit "minimal genetic distances" (Sayeed et al. 2018).
Cnemaspis wynadensis was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Wayanad.

Ahaetulla perroteti was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in in 1854 as Psammophis perroteti based on specimens collected from India (Smith 1943). No specific type locality has been assigned so far.
This is a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic revision (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

Cnemaspis indica was described as Goniodactylus indicus by Gray in 1846 based on specimens collected from Madras Presidency (Smith 1935), now mostly in Tamil Nadu, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  The populations north and south of Palghat Gap should be re-evaluated.  However, for the purposes of this assessment the known distributions are considered to represent C. indica. The record from Nadukani (~300 m asl) in Thrissur Distrct, Kerala (Das and Whitaker 1990) needs validation as it was based on a juvenile specimen from outside the known elevational range of the species.

Rhinophis travancoricus was described by Boulenger in 1892 based on specimens from Vembayam in Thiruvananthapuram district, Kerala, India  (Boulenger 1892, Smith 1943). The common name Tamil Nadu Earth Snake is a misnomer, as this species has been reported from Kerala and the specific epithet 'travancoricus' refers to 'Travancore' as the region where the type locality is present. However, the erstwhile kingdom of Travancore included most of southern Kerala, the Kanyakumari district and some parts of the present day southwestern Tamil Nadu (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm.2011).

A morphological study of records attributed to this species from India suggests that the Indian records of Dasia hailiana instead represent the Indian endemic D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011, using the incorrect nomina Dasia halianus and D. subcaeruleum).

Eurylepis poonaensis was described by Sharma (1970) as Eumeces poonaensis based on a specimen collected from Katraj Ghat, Poona (now Pune District), Maharashtra, India. Griffith et al. (2000) and Schmitz et al. (2004) opin that Eurylepis poonaensis (Sharma 1970) belongs to Eurylepis taeniolatus group.  Further molecular work is needed to establish the relationship between this species and E. taeniolatus (Griffith et al. 2000, M.S. Khan pers. comm.)
Research is needed to clarify whether records from the two known localities represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).
Otocryptis beddomii was first described by Boulenger in 1885 basing on specimens collected from Sivagiri Ghats in Cardamom Hills in Southern Kerala (Smith 1935).

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all the banded iguanas were lumped as a single species. The Fiji Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula) is now recognized as distinct from the Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus). Most previous references pertaining to iguanas in central Fiji are now attributed to B. bulabula.

Morphological data from recent surveys suggest there may be more than one taxa within the bulabula group. On two islands north of Vanua Levu (Mali and Cikobia), iguanas show marked variation in adult body size and some scale counts when compared to southern populations, for example, Makodroga and Kadavu. However, more samples and DNA analysis is needed to develop detailed comparisons (R. Fisher and P. Harlow pers. comm. 2011).

Conolophus marthae was recently described. No prior reference exists in the taxonomic literature as the species was not known before its description (Gentile and Snell 2009). The description was based on morphological, genetic, and behavioural diagnostic traits. The holotype is a free-living adult male tagged with a subcutaneous electronic marker, branded, and released. Further genetic evidence supporting separate taxonomic status of the Galápagos Pink Land Iguana prior to the species description is found in Gentile et al. 2009 and Tzika et al. 2008. Gentile et al. (2009) disclaims the name ‘‘rosada’’ for nomenclatural purposes (Articles 8.2 and 8.3, International Code of Zoological Nomenclature 1999).

There has been considerable debate of the specific states of the San Esteban Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (part, Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha conspicuosa (Lowe and Norris 1955).

There has been considerable debate over the species status of the Nolasco Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha nolascensis (Smith 1972). The iguana was most recently recognized at the species level by Grismer (1999a). Genetic components of two lineages have been detected within the island (Cryder 1999, Davy et al. 2010, Reynoso et al. 2010).

Morphological data places Sauromalus klauberi as sister to S. slevini, with that clade being sister to S. ater (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data places it with peninsular S. ater (Petren and Case 2002). Sauromalus klauberi was designated as a subspecies of S. ater by Soulé and Sloan (1966) without comment until Murphy (1983) elevated it back to species status. The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998).

The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998). Morphological data places Sauromalus varius as sister to all other Sauromalus (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data groups S. varius in a clade with S. hispidus (Petren and Case 1997, 2002).

Prior to its description this species was considered to belong to a widespread form, Callulina kreffti (Loader et al. 2009). C. kreffti as now understood is a restricted-range species that may be endemic to the East Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2010, 2014).

authority: Barej, Rödel, Gonwouo, Pauwels, Böhme & Schmitz, 2010
taxonomicNotes: The two known populations of this species are morphologically indistinguishable but genetically divergent. Barej et al. (2010) consider that the two populations conspecific. These authors caution that males are unknown from Mt. Nlonako, and a future discovery that males of the two populations are morphologically distinct may therefore justify recognizing two species. Some of the populations in central Cameroon, the Manengouba Mountains, Gabon and Equatorial Guinea that Barej et al. provisionally assign to P. aff. parkeri (included in the P. parkeri assessment) may represent this species.

authority: Barej, Rödel, Gonwouo, Pauwels, Böhme & Schmitz, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Pope (1935) suggested that Oligodon hamptoni and O., lacroixi may be conspecific, and the lack of material for both species has since left this issue unresolved. Redescriptions of both species (Orlov et al. 2010, Lee et al. 2021) and improved knowledge of O. lacroixi enabled Lee et al. (2021) to conclude that the two species are distinct.

Because of the wide distribution of the king cobra, many herpetologists believe that Ophiophagus hannah represents a species complex (Das 2002). Work has been underway to clarify the systematics of the group, and following sampling across most of the range Gowri Shankar et al. (2021) identified four independently evolving lineages based on mitochondrial DNA sampling. Their subsequent morphometric analysis found morphological differences corresponding to these groups, which have geographically apparently non-overlapping ranges, and they formally proposed four "Confirmed Candidate Species". They do not apply the name Ophiophagus hannah to any specific lineage, however the type locality falls within the range of their "Indo-Chinese" lineage (Candidate Species 2, ranging through most of mainland South and Southeast Asia north of the Isthmus of Kra); the other three lineages occur in the Western Ghats (CS1), Luzon in the Philippines (CS4) and the remainder of Southeast Asia south of the Ishtmus of Kra ("Indo-Malay", CS3).
Further molecular and morphological research is needed to clarify whether these candidate species represent independently-evolving lineages or simply reflect variation within a widespread species (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2022), as well as to resolve the relationships of populations not sampled by Gowri Shankar et al. (2021) (particularly in the Philippines south of Luzon, and Sulawesi).

Genetic studies by Vargas-Ramirez et al. (2006, 2007a, 2012) and Restrepo (2008) have shown that P. lewyana has low levels of genetic variability and no evidence of genetic population structure on a micro or macro-geographic scale, in addition to some level of inbreeding on a local scale.

A previous assessment of this species included Anolis heteropholidotus within A. sminthus following a suggestion by Fitch and Siegel (1984), since although more recent work had treated the two species as distinct their precise relationship remained unclear. This assessment recognizes A. heteropholidotus as distinct following more recent usage, and its validity was confirmed by Hofmann and Townsend (2017).
Both molecular and morphological evidence suggest that Hemidactylus scabriceps may be a complex of at least two species (Srikanthan et al. 2018).

For more than a century the name Cnemaspis kandiana was used as a "catchall" for a group of Cnemaspis taxa widely distributed in South and mainland Southeast Asia, and the islands of the Andaman and Nicobar groups (Maramendra-Arachchi et al. 2007, Das and Grismer 2003) Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007) redescribed this species and found, based on a morphological comparison with South Asian forms, that it should be considered endemic to Sri Lanka.

These authors did not use comparative material from Southeast Asian or island populations in their study and do not discuss the affinities of these forms. Consequently, although the species is no longer listed in most guides to Southeast Asian reptiles (e.g. Das 2010), it is not clear whether names are available for these populations. Chan-ard et al. (2015) use the name for a population found in Chumphon and Ranong Provinces in northern Peninsular Thailand. D. Mulcahy (unpubl. data) follows these authors in using C. kandiana as a working name for records recently taken in Lenya, in the neighbouring Tanintharyi region of southern Myanmar, although he reports a divergence of 8% in the ND2 gene from an available Sri Lankan sequence (Gamble et al. 2012).

Pending resolution of the systematics of Southeast Asian populations, these records are not considered to represent C. kandiana sensu stricto and this assessment follows the species concept applied by Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007).
The southern subpopulations require taxonomic revision (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
The genus Bokermannohyla was erected to accommodate several species groups formerly placed within Hyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Previously placed in the genus Trionyx, euphraticus was placed in the resurrected genus Rafetus by Meylan (1987), and this has been widely accepted as such (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

Myers (1991) provisionally included this species within Colosthethus chocoensis. It was recognized as a distinct species by Grant et al. (1997), but was not formally described; and was finally described by Myers and Grant (2009).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhaebo haematiticus (Mueses-Cisneros 2009).
This species is closely related to Trimeresurus macrops. Older literature references to T. kanburiensis are likely to refer in fact to this taxon (Uetz et al. 2020).
The species was described in 2004, although specimens are known since 1962 (Leong & Grismer 2004).
The species is known from the type series of six specimens and one doubtful record from Singapore (Grandison 1978). This uncertain record has not been included in the current assessment.

This species has long been placed in the genus Elaphe. It was transferred to Orthriophis by Utiger et al. (2002) and then back again to Elaphe by Chen et al. (2017). 

Subspecific divisions have been subject to debate and have been considered to fall within two subspecies complexes - a northern (Indochinese) and a southern (Indomalayan) clade - within the broader concept of E. taeniura (Schulz 1996). Messenger (2021) provides a summary of 9 recognized subspecies, while cautioning that distribution limits between these must be considered provisional pending more comprehensive taxonomic research.

authority: Kuch, Kizirian, Truong, Lawson, Donnelly & Mebs, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This small reddish brown snake is the sole member of its genus.
The species was recently described to science (Slowinski and Wüster 2000).

Populations of Callulina from the Nguru Mountains were historically assigned to C. kreffti, as then understood a widespread East African montane species and the sole member of the genus. Menegon et al. (2008) recognized four distinct species among Nguru Mountains Callulina, two of which have since been formally described (Loader et al. 2010). One of these, C. kanga, appears to be restricted to the Kanga Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The remaining three species are confined to blocks within the Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The name C. hanseni refers to "Callulina sp. 2" of these authors (Loader et al. 2010); the remaining populations are included within the Red List account for C. kreffti pending further research.

This species, first recorded in 2004, was first reported in the literature by Menegon et al. (2008), who listed it as "Callulina sp. 4"; it was also referred to as such, referencing this then-unpublished paper, in the technical report by Doggart and Loserian (2007).  Populations of Callulina from the nearby Mkingu Nature Reserve, now found to represent three distinct species, were originally included within the presumed widespread, monotypic C. kreffti (Loader et al. 2010). In contrast, the Kanga Forest Reserve form appears never to have been explicitly included within this species concept, having only been discovered after doubts arose concerning the monophyly of C. kreffti (de Sá et al. 2004).
Cnemaspis otai was described based on specimens collected from Vellore, Tamil Nadu (Das and Bauer 2000).

Hemidactylus albofasciatus was described by Grandison and Soman in 1963 based on specimens collected from Dorle, Rajapur taluk, Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra, India (Grandison and Soman 1963). This species was included in the genus Teratolepis (Kluge 2001, Das 2003), presumably based on the presence of enlarged scales on the tail and narrow digital lamellae. However, a recent molecular phylogenetic analysis by Bauer et al. (2008, 2010) and Bansal and Karanth (2010) reveals that Teratolepis is embedded within the tropical Asian clade of Hemidactylus.
Campbell et al (2010) described the populations of Bolitoglossa hartwegi as this new species B. xibalba.

Members of this genus have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected a new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus ruthae (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus ruthae by Hedges et al. (2008), but further work suggests it is likely a synonym of E. ruthae (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
Formerly recognized as subspecies of Eleutherodactylus schmidti (Schwartz 1971), Hedges et al. (2008) formalized the species status of this taxon.

This species was split from Eleutherodactylus audanti (Hedges et al. 2008). On the basis of preliminary molecular data, Díaz et al. (2018) suggested that E. melatrigonum may be conspecific with E. notidodes.
This species was formerly recognized as subspecies of Eleutherodactylus schmidti (Schwartz 1971), Hedges et al. (2008) formalized the species status of this taxon.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus ruthae (Hedges et al. 2008).

There has been some ongoing debate over the last couple of decades on whether this is a distinct species. It was removed from synonymy of Nanorana yunnanensis by Dubois (1992), synonymized again by Chen (2011), and then revalidated once more by Huang et al. (2016). N. liui has been made a junior synonym of this species (Huang et al. 2016).

authority: Heinicke, Duellman, Trueb, Means, MacCulloch & Hedges, 2009

taxonomicNotes: This species exhibits low levels of genetic differentiation from Lepidodactylus gardneri (P. Oliver et al. 2020).

This species was originally described as a Raratonga population of Emoia trossula. Its appropriate taxonomic rank is unclear. Although it was originally described based on its molecular differentiation from other island populations of E. trossula (Zug et al. 2011), unpublished genetic results confirm its close relationship to E. trossula and it has been suggested that it may warrant subspecific rank within E. trossula (R. Fisher pers. comm. 2012). This account considers E. tuitarere a valid full species pending any formal taxonomic action to change its taxonomic status and to clarify the taxonomy of E. trossula, which Zug et al. (2011) imply may be a species complex.
This is considered to be a species complex, and it is likely that the population from Rotuma is a separate species.

Molecular and morphological evidence indicates that this newly-discovered phenotype belongs to the "Madascincus polleni species complex", rendering M. polleni as defined by Miralles et al. (2011) paraphyletic with regard to this species and Madascincus stumpffi. It is treated here as a distinct species following Miralles et al. (2011), as it is morphologically distinct and strongly genetically divergent from the other three clades identified for this complex.

Parvoscincus beyeri was described as Sphenomorphus beyeri from a single specimen by Taylor (1922), and although it has subsequently been regarded as valid subsequent authors were cautious about referring morphologically new material from Zambales to this species (summarized in Brown et al. 2010), although the Zambales subpopulation (and unpublished records from additional localities) was referred to this species in a previous Red List assessment (Brown et al. 2009). Following the collection of new material from the type locality, Brown et al. (2010) clarified the taxonomy and distribution of this species, as well as the identity of the other subpopulations referred to this species in Brown et al. (2009) (which they recognized as the distinct species now known as P. boyingi, P. hadros and P. igorotorum).

This very recently-described snake is a member of the Python curtus species complex (with P. curtus, P. brongersmai, and P. breitensteini), and was briefly considered to represent a disjunct record of P. brongersmai (Zug et al. 2011).
Telmatobius rubigo was previously referred to as Telmatobius marmoratus (Barrionuevo and Baldo 2009).

This species has been elevated from being a subspecies of Eleutherodactylus zugi (Hedges et al. 2008). Its taxonomic status, however, remains uncertain. Díaz and Cádiz (2008) treated this taxon as a subspecies of Eleutherodactylus zugi. However, this assessment follows Frost (2021) in recognizing it as a valid species.
Two of the subspecies of Eleutherodactylus varians (olibrus and staurometopon) have been elevated to the species level.
Two of the subspecies of Eleutherodactylus varians (olibrus and staurometopon) have been elevated to the species level.

In the Eleutherodactylus alfredi species group according to the original description (Canseco-Márquez and Smith 2004). This species has since been transferred over to the genus Craugastor (Frost 2011). The holotype was originally considered to be a specimen of E. spatulatus (Canseco-Márquez and Smith 2004), although it does not seem to have been considered in the latter species' 2004 assessment.

Populations of Callulina from the Nguru Mountains were historically assigned to C. kreffti, as then understood a widespread East African montane species and the sole member of the genus. Menegon et al. (2008) recognized four distinct species among Nguru Mountains Callulina, two of which have since been formally described (Loader et al. 2010). One of these, C. kanga, appears to be restricted to the Kanga Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The remaining three species are confined to blocks within the Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The name C. hanseni refers to "Callulina sp. 2" of these authors (Loader et al. 2010); the remaining populations are included within the Red List account for C. kreffti pending further research.
This species is presently under revision (C. Murthy pers. comm. 2019).

McCranie and Wilson (1996) regarded C. atitlanensis as a synonym of C. bivittatus. Characteristics of recently acquired specimens from extreme southwestern Honduras (J. R. McCranie) also suggest that the two taxa may be conspecific (L. Porras, pers. comm. 2013).
Recent molecular work sequencing Jamaican species of Celestus has confirmed the validity of this species (S.B. Hedges unpubl. data).
Prior to its description by Köhler (2009), this species was referred to as a population of Anolis altae.

No reports of Trachyboa gularis have appeared in the scientific literature since the species was first described, and it has rarely been mentioned. The name has, however, been used in pet trade articles ( Arnett 1992, Burger 2017) to refer to a species from coastal Ecuador that "does well" in certain captive conditions, suggesting a known extant population. The basis for this is not clear and no diagnosis is provided to clarify whether this represents "true" T. gularis. It is probable that any animals in trade marketed as T. gularis in fact belong to T. boulengeri.

The holotype of this species was for some time transferred to an American institution in Washington DC before being returned to Bogota by J. Lynch, and it is possible that reports of a second record refer to the holotype in two separate collections (C. Arredondo, J. Daza and R.Caicedo pers. comms. 2013)
This species was previously considered to belong to Tantilla taeniata (McCranie 2011).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Barej et al. (2010) elevated the former subspecies to species rank based on molecular and morphological differences from the nominate taxon. Accepted as Trioceros perreti in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Mertens (1940) synonymized Chamaeleon (=Chamaeleo) serratus within Chamaeleo wiedersheimi on the basis that specimens examined, including those from the Bamenda Highlands, were indistinguishable from a C. wiedersheimi paratype from the same locality. This view was subsequently supported with reference to additional material and the original description (Mertens 1968, Klaver and Böhme 1992). The holotype of C. serratus, with the unspecific locality "Südkamerun", is lost, and was probably destroyed during World War II (Klaver and Böhme 1992), so has never been available for comparison. Combined morphological and molecular research by Barej et al. (2010) found that Bamenda specimens belong to a clade separate from Trioceros wiedersheimi. Designating a neotype for T. serratus, these authors therefore resurrected this name for the newly-recognized species, fixing the type locality as Belo, Mt Oku, and removed it from synonymy with T. wiedersheimi. The two species are, however, difficult to distinguish morphologically, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).
Previous records of this species from Putre, Parinacota Province, Chile, have been assigned to T. marmoratus based on phylogenetic analyses (Sáez et al. 2014).

Two subspecies are currently recognised, with the previously recognised subspecies hercegovinensis synonymised with T. h. boettgeri by Fritz et al. (2006):
  • T. h. hermanni: northeastern Spain, southeastern France, the Balearic Islands (Spain), Corsica (France), and Sardinia (Italy).
  • T. h. boettgeri: the Balkan region, a restricted part of southwestern Romania, and northeastern Italy, with the boundary with T. h. hermanni being the Po River valley.

Two further subspecies have been proposed but are not currently recognised (TTWG 2021);
  • T. hermanni ssp. undetermined: Italian Peninsula, Sicily (Biello et al. 2021, Chiocchio et al. 2022).
  • T. hermanni ssp. undescribed: southern Peloponnesus, Greece (Bour 2004).

Anderson (1875) described it as Trionyx nigricans from the pond at the Hazrat Sultan Bayazid Bostami Shrine in Nasirabad near Chittagong, Bangladesh. Subsequent authors believed that the species either became extinct in the wild (Pritchard 1979, Groombridge 1982) or that it ‘descended from introduced individuals of the more widespread Trionyx gangeticus’ (Groombridge 1982, Khan 1987) or of N. hurum (Rashid 1990). Using mainly skull osteology as well as coloration and pattern characters, Praschag and Gemel (2002) recognized it from northeast India as Aspideretes nigricans. Based on molecular data, Engstrom et al. (2004) and Praschag et al. (2007) transferred the genus Aspideretes Hay, 1903 into synonymy of Nilssonia (Gray, 1872). See Praschag and Gemel (2002) for discussion of taxonomic distinction from other large Asian softshell species.

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar.
Was under Iguanidae.
This species is the sole member of its genus.

The Mona Rhinoceros Iguana is currently recognized as a distinct species, Cyclura stejnegeri (ITWG 2016). Prior to 2000, it was considered a subspecies in the group including Cyclura cornuta cornuta from Hispaniola (Dominican Republic and Haiti), Cyclura cornuta stejnegeri from Mona Island, Puerto Rico, and Cyclura cornuta onchiopsis, which presumably went extinct on Navassa Island in the mid-19th century (Powell 1999).

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all the banded iguanas were lumped as this single species. The Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus) is now recognized as distinct from the Fiji Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula). Most previous references pertaining to iguanas in central Fiji are now attributed to B. bulabula. This taxonomic change includes references to the introduced population on Vanuatu, now described as B. bulabula (Bauer 1988, Keogh et al. 2008). The introduced population on Tonga remains as B. fasciatus.

 

Recent unpublished data finds some morphological and colour variability between islands in the Lau Group, but genetically these populations have less inter-island variability than within the other two species of Brachylophus. The systematics of the iguanas on the islands in the northern Lau Group (north of Tuvuca) is unknown, but for now they will be retained within this taxon.

Recent genetic data (Keogh et al. 2008) have shown that each subpopulation (island) of this species is genetically unique.  This data, along with many morphological characters, clearly define this species, although the observed genetic inter-island variability might be consistent with subspecific differences after further assessment.

Carettochelys insculpta is the only surviving extant member of the genus Carettochelys and the family Carettochelyidae, a formerly widespread turtle family dating back to the Eocene and previously occurring across Asia and much of the rest of the globe. As such, it is considered a deep phylogenetic lineage with high-priority conservation needs, a so-called EDGE species (Evolutionarily Distinct, Globally Endangered). The common name in Indonesian Papua is Kura-kura Moncong Babi and the common name in Papua New Guinea is Piku.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Heosemys and Geoemyda.

Le et al. (2014) concluded that the Yangtze and Red River subpopulations of Rafetus swinhoei do not show significant genetic divergence and do not warrant recognition as separate evolutionary significant units for conservation management. However, it appears that Le et al. (2014) did not actually have any samples from the Yangtze subpopulation, only samples from the Vietnamese and Chinese parts of the Red River catchment. Chen (2015) found two distinct mtDNA lineages of R. swinhoei which are roughly 2.8% divergent from each other (Cytochrome B and NADH dehydrogenase 4), one represented by Red River specimens and the second one by a Shanghai museum specimen of unknown origin. In the meantime, tissue samples from the male of Suzhou Zoo and the female of Changsha Zoo proved to be concordant with the Shanghai museum specimen (H. Chen pers. comm.). This points to a possibility that the Yangtze and the Red River subpopulations may represent separate taxa at least at the level of subspecies. In that case the Yangtze subpopulation would represent the nominate form Rafetus swinhoei swinhoei and the Vietnamese and Chinese Red River subpopulation the subspecies Rafetus swinhoei leloii.

Was treated under the generic name Geoemyda in the 1996 IUCN Red List. The genus was changed to Heosemys in the 2000 IUCN Red List. Now reassigned to a new monotypic genus, Leucocephalon (A. Rhodin pers. comm.).

Originally described as a subspecies of the Cuban Rock Iguana (Cyclura macleayi lewisi Grant, 1940; Cyclura nubila lewisi sensu Schwartz and Thomas, 1975), this iguana was elevated to species-level by Burton (2004), supported by Malone et al. (2000) and S. Funk (unpublished data 2008).

Chelodina pritchardi is a distinct and recognized species, with an adequate description and diagnosis (Rhodin 1994, Georges et al. 2002, Georges and Thomson 2010, TTWG 2017). No subspecies or geographic variations are recognized, but it has not yet been genetically analyzed. It can be confused with the morphologically similar Chelodina novaeguineae, but the species do not occur sympatrically.

Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001). Previously included tentoria and circumdata as subspecies.

Three subspecies are currently recognized, Lissemys punctata punctata (Bonnaterre, 1789), L. p. andersoni Webb, 1980, and L. p. vittata (Peters, 1854), following the most recent taxonomic review by Praschag et al. (2011), which also split off the Sri Lankan populations as a separate species, L. ceylonensis (Gray, 1856).
Barrington Land Iguanas appear to be sister to a clade composed of the western (Isabela and Fernandina) populations of Conolophus subcristatus (Gentile et al. 2009).

The western (Isabela and Fernandina) populations of Conolophus subcristatus appears to be sister to the Barrington Land Iguana (Conolophus pallidus; Gentile et al. 2009). Further analysis (Rassmann et al. 2004, Gentile et al. 2009) shows that these western populations and the central island populations of C. subcristatus form two separate clades, consistent with the pattern of morphological differentiation described in Snell et al. (1984). Tzika et al. (2008) suggest that some populations of C. subcristatus may deserve recognition as species, on Plaza Sur in particular, based on their genetic differentiation within the genus.

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). The species has a variable appearance and color and pattern are poor diagnostic characteristics for identification of this species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Some subpopulations have a very yellow color, resembling Atelopus zeteki, which is why both Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki are sometimes referred to as golden frogs in Panama (Estrada et al. 2014). Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA reveals support for recognizing A. varius and A. zeteki as separate clades, but sorting of haplotypes was imperfect and Costa Rican samples sorted into a third outlying group (Richards and Knowles 2007). Genetic examination of the phylogeny of this group would be helpful, but the extreme declines of this group will make sourcing of fresh, genomic quality tissues challenging.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Leptophryne javanica (Hamidy et al. 2018).

Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009) reviewed the systematics of the Venezuelan subpopulations of Hyalinobatrachium orientale, and based on phylogenetic analysis, and morphological and bioacoustics data they resurrected H. orocostale for the population distributed in the Serranía de Interior and considered the synonymy of this species by Cannatella and Lamar (1986). Jowers et al. (2015) reanalyzed the phylogenetic relationships of this species including, for the first time, specimens from Tobago island. Venezuela and Tobago populations diverged ≈ 3 mybp, and based on the genetic distance between the mainland and island populations – with some level of differentiation but not enough for complete lineage sorting – plus the geographic isolation, Jowers et al. (2015) proposed revalidation of the subspecies H. orientale tobagoense (Hardy 1984).

Morales (2002 "2000") noted that earlier records from Ecuador, Suriname, Venezuela, French Guiana, and Peru apply to other species. Frogs known as Allobates brunneus from northern Orinoco in Venezuela have been separated as A. pittieri (La Marca et al. 2004). All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019). Records of this species from Mount Duida, Venezuela is probably applied to an undescribed species (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009). Reports from the Guianas and Brazilian state of Paraná, probably refer to other species (Santos-Pereira et al. 2018).

It has been suggested that this species is not native to Martinique, but is synonymous with another species from South America (M. Breuil pers. comm., Breuil 2009); however, following its rediscovery in October 2012 (Dewynter et al. 2012), new genetic material and phylogenetic analysis confirmed that it is nested within a clade of lowland Amazonian Allobates but nonetheless distantly related to any known species of the group (Fouquet et al. 2013). In addition, the arrival of the species in Martinique likely corresponds to an overseas dispersal from South America during the late Miocene, as previously hypothesized for Bothrops lanceolatus and Leptodactylus fallax, two other species endemic to Martinique and surrounding islands (Fouquet et al. 2013).

At present, this species is considered to be a complex of several taxa and is currently undergoing taxonomic revision (T. Grant pers. comm.). The identity of frogs assigned to S. nubicola in the mountains along the Colombia-Panama border is equivocal (Grant and Myers 2013).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Genetic distances suggest that more than one species might be combined under this name (Faivovich et al. 2018). Specimens from the Serranía de Tabasará may represent a distinct species (Hertz 2015).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).
Although this species has often been confused with Leptopelis kivuensis (see Schiøtz 1999), Roelke et al. (2011) clarified the difference between the two species.
Molecular data suggest that there is more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Genetic data indicate that this is a complex of species occurring in isolated, montane areas, each highly threatened (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).

Records from the Cordillera Central in the Dominican Republic previously assigned to this taxon belong to Eleutherodactylus melatrigonum and the former subspecies notidodes has been split off and raised to species-level (Hedges et al. 2008).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The current taxonomic concept probably contains several cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013; R. Ibanez pers. comm June 2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Two new species were described from the species group to which Craugastor coffeus (C. laticeps group) belongs, it is possible, albeit unlikely based on distinguished external morphological characteristics, there is additional taxonomic change yet to be determined (McCranie 2018).

There is doubt about the validity of this species as it was described from a single specimen based on a variable trait (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
A specimen recorded from Forêt des Pins National Park in Haiti may belong to this taxon, but further research is needed to clarify this (C. Martínez Rivera pers. comm. 2020).

Recent DNA and morphological studies suggest that this species belongs in its own monotypic genus, Mecistops (McAliley et al. 2006).  This finding has been supported by all subsequent phylogenetic studies (e.g., Hekkala et al. 2011, Meredith 2011, Oaks 2011,Shirley et al. 2013) and Mecistop has gained wide use and acceptance in the literature and is hence used here.

A recent study (Shirley 2013, Shirley et al. 2013) has found significant molecular and morphological support for two divergent taxa in this genus - one distributed entirely in West Africa and the other in Central Africa. Formal taxonomic revisions and recognition of these two unique taxa are expected soon.
Schwartz and Henderson (1991) considered some subpopulations of this species to refer to Eleutherodactylus darlingtoni, but Hedges (1992) redefined the range, and this definition is used here.

The only known extant population of C. siamensis outside mainland Southeast Asia, located in East Kalimantan Province (Indonesian Borneo), is genetically distinct and considered an ‘Evolutionarily Significant Unit’ (Gratten 2003).

The species was named by Schmidt in 1935 from specimens from Najuan Lake, Mindoro. The species has been considered a subspecies of Crocodylus novaeguineae but currently it is accorded full species status on the basis of unique morphology, distribution and genetic separation (see Uetz et al. 2016).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Genetic analysis of animals in the captive collection may represent disparate cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013).
This taxon is presently considered valid, but is very likely to be a junior synonym of Eleutherodactylus weinlandi based on genetics and morphology (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
The following species were previously considered to be subspecies of Eleutherodactylus ruthae but have since been recognized to be full species: E. aporostegus, E. bothroboans and E. tychathrous.
This taxon is very likely a junior synonym of Eleutherodactylus glandulifer (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020; S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Formerly this species included Eleutherodactylus diplasius and E. sommeri as subspecies, both of which have now been elevated to full species status (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species was included within Oreobates considering that it shares morphological characters with species of this genus (Hedges et al. 2008).

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
There are questions around the taxonomy of this concept and it could comprise several cryptic species (E. Lehr and A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
A specimen collected by J. Cadle in the 1980s (MHNSM 960) from Chorro Blanco in the province of Santa Cruz, was later assigned to this species.
Leptolalax eos and L. nyx were split from this species by Ohler et al. (2011).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Megophrys elfina (Poyarkov et al. 2017).

This species has become Megophrys, following Ophryophryne becoming a subgenus of Megophrys (Mahony et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Ophryophryne without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
The northernmost part of its range has been attributed to A. vallani by Vences et al. (2010).

We follow Poynton (2003b) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering Probreviceps rungwensis to be distinct from P. macrodactylus. In addition, we follow Mkonyi et al. (2004) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering Probreviceps loveridgei to be distinct from P. macrodactylus. Furthermore, molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under the P. macrodactylus name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
We follow Frost (2020) in placing this very poorly known but highly distinctive species in the genus Quasipaa. It was previously placed in the genus Yerana.
This species is often confused with Rana chensinensis and R. amurensis (Borkin 1985).

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana (now Nidirana okinavana) is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011). 

Lyu et al. (2020) revised the taxonomy of Nidirana and determined that populations from Taiwan, Province of China, previously assigned to this species are actually N. adenopleura. However in this study, the sampling is limited and the possibility remains that N. okinavana is still present in Taiwan, Province of China (M. Matsui pers. comm. September 2020).
Specimens refered to this species from Ponmudi and surroundings in India, are now included in the newly described species, Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi Hills' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

Allozyme data (Shaffer 1984) seem to confirm the original morphological description of this as a distinct species (Dixon 1963); mitochondrial DNA sequence data indicate a very close relationship to several Mexican populations of Ambystoma velasci (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).
This species is under taxonomic review and it is likely to be split into five species (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).

The previous assessment of the Turks and Caicos Rock Iguana (Gerber 2004) recommended additional genetic studies to fully evaluate the subspecific designation of Cyclura carinata bartschi (Cochran 1931) on Booby Cay, located 0.5 km off the east end of Mayaguana Island, The Bahamas. Two independent population genetic studies have now demonstrated that iguanas on Booby Cay are not genetically different from C. carinata in the Turks and Caicos Islands, and therefore should not be considered as a separate subspecies (Bryan et al. 2007, Welch et al. 2017). Further, the Booby Cay population is genetically most similar to populations from the eastern side of the Caicos Bank, rather than the most geographically proximate populations on the western and northern sides of the Caicos Banks (Welch et al. 2017). Since it is likely that humans introduced iguanas to Booby Cay, this population is not included in the species’ extent of occurrence.

Welch et al. (2017) describe the existence of two distinct Evolutionary Significant Units (ESUs, sensu Moritz 1994) for C. carinata: one inhabiting islands on the western end of the Caicos Bank, and one inhabiting the remaining islands of the Caicos Bank and islands of the Turks Bank. Multiple management units (MUs) are also identified within each ESU (Welch et al. 2017). Considering the severe geographic and genetic fragmentation of iguanas across the archipelago these authors recommended the two ESUs be elevated as different subspecies.

Fossils from Puerto Rico were originally described by Barbour (1919) and named Cyclura portoricensis. These and additional fossils from Puerto Rico were re-examined by Pregill (1981) and attributed to Anegada Rock Iguanas, Cyclura pinguis.

Prior to 2000 three subspecies were commonly recognized: Cyclura cornuta cornuta from Dominican Republic and Haiti, Cyclura cornuta stejnegeri from Mona Island, Puerto Rico, and the extinct Cyclura cornuta onchiopsis from Navassa Island (Schwartz and Carey 1977). That taxonomy has subsequently been followed by some authors (for example, Malone et al. 2000, Pérez-Buitrago et al. 2007, and references therein). However, all three taxa are now recognized as species (ITWG 2016).

Based on traditional morphological characters Vipera monticola was recognized - first as a subspecies, and subsequently as a full species - as a distinct form occupying the High Atlas Mountains, with remaining North African members of the group retained within V. latastei.

Following research that found this arrangement to be inconsistent with genetic results (Freitas et al. 2020), Martínez-Freiría et al. (2021) revised the taxonomy of this group using an integrative analysis based on phylogenetic, morphological and ecological evidence. The resulting species concepts restricted Vipera latastei to the Iberian Peninsula, with all North African lineages referred to V. monticola, and this arrangement was supported with later genomic evidence (Dufresnes et al. 2024).

The resulting concept comprises three subspecies: V. m. monticola (central Moroccan High Atlas); V. m. atlantica (Western High Atlas); and V. m. saintgironsi in the remainder of the range (Martínez-Freiría et al. 2021).
We follow Campbell (1998) in considering Tantilla cuesta to be a synonym of this species.
Without knowledge of calls or habitat this species cannot be readily separated from Eleutherodactylus gossei (Schwartz and Fowler 1973).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. duncanensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments    

This species from Pinzón (Duncan Island) was included on IUCN Red Lists before 2007 under the name Geochelone nigra ssp. ephippium. However, this name was interpreted by Pritchard (1996) to actually refer to Chelonoidis abingdonii, the Pinta Giant Tortoise, and therefore was replaced by the name duncanensis Pritchard, 1996, a recommendation accepted by Fritz and Havas (2007) as well as TTWG (2007, 2014). While the name duncanensis is used here, as it has been on the Red List since 2007, a genetic analysis of the ephippium type specimen is planned, which will determine whether the name change is indeed warranted. Many researchers (e.g., Jensen et al. 2015), including most of the Assessors on this account, continue to use the name C. ephippium for the Pinzón Tortoise, and we await genetic analysis for a final determination as to the correct name to use.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Geoemyda and Heosemys. No subspecies or synonymised data.

The Desert Tortoise was previously considered to be a single wide-ranging species, Gopherus agassizii (sensu lato), inhabiting the Mojave and Sonoran Desert regions of the southwestern USA and northwestern Mexico (Iverson 1992). The species was eventually found to be polytypic, and Murphy et al. (2011) split out the morphologically and genetically distinct Sonoran Desert subpopulations as Gopherus morafkai, the Sonoran Desert Tortoise. Further analysis demonstrated that G. morafkai was also polytypic and therefore split further to separate and describe the Sinaloan Thornscrub Tortoise further to the south as G. evgoodei (Edwards et al. 2016). This taxonomy of three species of desert tortoises has been accepted by TTWG (2017) and Berry and Murphy (2019).

The taxon Hardella indi (Gray, 1870) was traditionally considered a subspecies, Hardella thurjii indi, but was most recently synonymized as insufficiently distinct from the typical form to warrant recognition (Praschag et al. 2007).
The current taxonomy is probably incorrect, with Philippine populations referred to M. wetmorei suspected to represent a separate species (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006).

Recent genetic exanmination has led to the separation of the 'species' into three distinct evolutionary lineages that may each deserve specific status.  Osteoleamus osborni has been resurrected as a valid name (insert ref) for the westernmost parts of the distribution in the Congo river drainage and another distinct genetic clade occupies the eastern end of the range with O. tetraspis between them.

authority: Baran, Kumlutaş, Lanza, Sindaco, Ilgaz, Avci & Crucitti, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This taxon has previously been recognised as a subspecies of Phrynocephalus helioscopus.
This species has sometimes been included in Montivipera raddei.
We provisionally follow Melnikov et al. (2008) in considering Phrynocephalus horvathi to be distinct at the species level pending additional taxonomic studies.
This species was elevated to species status from Vipera ursinii anatolica by Nilson and Andrén (2001).
Domergue (1984) erected the subspecies Pararhadinea melanogaster marojejyensis for the apparently isolated Marojejy subpopulation, known from a single specimen.

Crottini et al. (2009) considered Cryptoscincus, of which C. minimus was the only member, a junior synonym of Paracontias based on molecular evidence. Specimens from Baie de Sakalava, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as needing further study to verify their assignment to this species, have now been confirmed as P. minimus (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).

There is uncertainty about the number of species represented under the names Uroplatus fimbriatus and U. giganteus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Raxworthy et al. (2008) consider U. giganteus to be a synonym for U. fimbriatus; however it has also been argued that additional undescribed species may be revealed within U. giganteus and/or U. fimbriatus by future molecular study (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011), and the population of U. cf. giganteus at Marojejy may warrant separate specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007). The scheme followed here is that of Glaw et al. (2006), which considers this group to consist of two species, U. fimbriatus and U. giganteus, which correspond to the southern and northern clades of U. fimbriatus respectively (Raxworthy et al. 2008; F. Glaw, pers. comm. January 2011). Due to the geographical proximity of the U. fimbriatus type locality, Nosy Mangabe, to genetic U. giganteus, further research is needed to establish whether the assignment U. fimbriatus to the southern clade treated here under that name is valid, or whether this name should instead be applied either to a single species including both presently recognized clades, or to a northern form presently included under the name U. giganteus (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).
F. monoceras is considered a junior synonymn of F. rhinoceratus (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A subspecies Palleon (formerly Brookesia) nasus pauliani is recognized from high-altitude sites at Andringtra, but it was not found during the most recent surveys and its taxonomic status remains unresolved (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996).

This species was synonymized with B. dentata by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995). This synonymy was questioned by Glaw et al. (1999), and the validity of this species was supported by Townsend et al. (2009)

This species was until recently thought to be known only from the holotype (Glaw and Vences 2007); however animals found in the Fort Dauphin area are considered to represent this species (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011). This requires clarification, and the taxonomic status and relationships of this skink are in need of further study (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Stenophis guentheri was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.

Genetic data reveal that U. ebenaui is a complex of several species and a full taxonomic revision is required (Glaw and Vences 2007, Greenbaum et al. 2007, Raxworthy et al. 2008). Subpopulations from Marojejy, Tsaratanana and Montagne d'Ambre may warrant specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007).

Nagy et al. 2010 removed Stenophis tulearensis from synonymy with this species (where it had been placed by Vences et al. 2004).The same authors elevated the subgenus Phisalixella to a full genus. The taxonomic identity of both P. tulearensis and P. variabilis requires further clarification (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
The taxonomy of this species is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Alain has data on this species - include him in the reassessment.

Records of this species from northern Madagascar, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as requiring further taxonomic study, may represent C. parsonii, C. oshaugnessyi or, in Montagne d'Ambre, C. ambreensis (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011), although there are no confirmed records of true C. oshaugnessyi from northern Madagascar (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011). A record from Tsaratanana requires further investigation to clarify its specific identity (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).
Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995) classed Brookesia legendrei as a junior synonym of B. ebenaui.

This chameleon was formerly considered a subspecies of C. gastrotaenia, but was elevated to species status by Böhme (1997). Individuals from Andohahela in the southeast require additional study to verify their taxonomic status (Andreone et al. 2001, Glaw and Vences 2007).

The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Previous records of this species from the Menabe Region appear to be a previously undescribed taxon (Raselimanana 2008).
Stenophis inornatus was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.
Specimens resembling this species have been recorded from near Makira at approximately 50 m asl., but these require  confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011).

This poorly-known species is in need of taxonomic investigation to clarify whether known subpopulations all represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011), and its relationships to other Amphiglossus species are unclear (Schmitz et al. 2005).
This species shows a strong similarity to B. thieli (Andreone et al. 2009). The B. thieli/B. lineata complex is in need of revision and may contain several new species (Andreone et al. 2009).

A population from Montagne d'Ambre formerly considered a subspecies of Calumma oshaugnessyi has been given specific status in recent literature, as C. ambreense (Glaw and Vences, 2007; Andreone et al. 2009).

Calumma hilleniusi has variously been considered either a full species or a subspecies of C. brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). The identity of southern subpopulations currently assigned to this species requires verification (Vences et al. 2002).

This species resembles, but has long been recognized as distinct from, Calumma brevicorne,  being noted as C. sp. aff. brevicorne when first collected (Brygoo 1978). It was formally described only when Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006) clarified the taxonomy of this species group.

Glaw and Vences (2007) note that a population resembling P. petiti occurs at Tsingy de Bemaraha, but this form is not known from any specimens and is not considered to belong to this species. The Tsingy de Bemaraha form is not considered in this assessment.

Recently-discovered specimens from Baie de Sakalava are provisionally assigned to X. grandidieri, a species previously known only from a single specimen with the type locality "Madagascar" (Glaw and Vences 2007; F. Glaw pers. comm.April 2011), on the basis that two other restricted-range species described by Mocquard have been found at the same locality, providing evidence that collections took place within or near this site (F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). These records were treated as belonging to X. mocquardi in Glaw and Vences (2007). Xenotyphlops mocquardi is itself likely to be a junior synonym of this species, as it falls within the range of variation observed within more recently-collected Baie de Sakalava specimens assigned to X. grandidieri (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011; F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). If this is the case, this will represent a slight range extension to the south (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

This species is clearly distinct from any other Malagasy Lygodactylus. It is presumed that the village of Mandritsara where the species has been recorded represents the type locality. However, as the type locality is given as "Mt. Mandritsara, northwest Madagascar" in the original description (Pasteur, 1965), and no mountain exists near the village (which is in northeast Madagascar), this cannot be verified with certainty.

Zonosaurus maromaintso may be a colour variant of Z. boettgeri (Glaw and Vences 2007). Genetic data is needed to confirm the relationships of these taxa. Specimens of Z. boettgeri from the island of Nosy Be (the type locality) are also distinct from those of the nearby mainland and require additional study to clarify their specific status (Raselimanana et al. 2009); should this subpopulation prove to be distinct, the mainland form would therefore require a different name.

Following the recent description of Blaesodactylus ambonihazo, which is expected to be more widespread than is currently known, further morphological and genetic study is needed to clarify the southern limit of B. boivini's distribution and to verify the specific identity of records south of Ankarana (Bauer et al. 2011).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
Very closely related to E. innominata and E. jagorii with very similar morphology and DNA, they may even be conspecific.

There is some debate as to whether L. schistorynchus is a separate species, or a subspecies of L. semifasciata, due to similarities in venom chemistry (Guinea et al. 1983, Tamiya et al. 1983) and morphology (McCarthy 1986). This is disputed by Cogger and Heatwole (2005).

The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Pseudolaticauda.
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Aipysurus fuscus is a small to moderately sized venomous snake, typically reaching a length of 60 cm and maximum total length of 98 cm (Cogger 2014, Francis 2006, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Storr et al. 2002). Adults are brown, blackish-brown or purplish-brown, but often have obscure, paler cross bands on the lower flanks. Sometimes the lateral scales will have a darker patch at the centre, resulting in faint, longitudinal striations; younger snakes are typically lighter and dark banded.

Aipysurus fuscus can be differentiated from closely related A. laevis by its smaller size, darker colouration and by the number of scales on belly and mid-body (155 – 172 ventral scales and less than 21 scale rows around the midbody). Other scale features used in taxonomy of A. fuscus include: head shields are regular with some fragmentation of scales occasionally (prefrontals, frontal and supraoculars) especially the parietals; upper labials six to nine, with the first three or four sometimes divided horizontally; anal scales are divided, while ventral scales are broad with a medium keel and no posterior notch. Body scales are smooth with some lowest rows weakly keeled in males. Body scales are imbricate (overlapping) and there are typically 19 scale rows around the neck and 19 around the mid-body. Females have between 24 to 33 subcaudal scales, while males have 30 to 37 subcaudal scales (Francis 2006, Rasmussen et al. 2014).

Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population(Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype, revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group.
