Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
Genetic and morphological data suggest that this is a complex of various species (M. Vences pers. comm.).

authority: Gehring, Pabijan, Ratsoavina, Köhler, Vences & Glaw, 2010
taxonomicNotes: Genetic data needed to confirm the identity of four specimens reported from the south (Christian Randriantondro, unpubl.) (Adrian's paper - add citation)
A photograph of the only known specimen of this species was included by Glaw and Vences (2007) as Paracontias hildebrandti, with the note that this identification was tentative.

It is likely that an unidentified species reported from the Ankarana Massif in the 1980s represents P. roesleri, but this is not known from specimens and so its identity cannot be confirmed (Glaw et al. 2010).

This taxon is clearly a complex of several species, and its taxonomy remains very confused and unresolved, and so it is treated here as a single species. Several subspecies or possibly synonyms have been treated as full species by some authors.

The subspecies cyrenaica and soussensis were elevated to full species by Vetter (2002) without supporting information, a move supported by J. Perälä (pers. comm. 2004). Testudo flavominimaralis is usually treated as a synonym of Testudo graeca graeca, and it was not accepted as valid by Iverson (1992) and Schleich et al. (1996); nor was it discussed in detail by Pieh (2000:110). Its taxonomic status and distribution are uncertain, and it is treated here as a synonym of T. graeca, though it has not been formally synonymised. Testudo nabeulensis from Tunisia and northwestern Libya is usually treated as a synonym of Testudo graeca, but Pieh (2000:110) who took the view that it is a valid taxon within the Testudo graeca complex. Testudo anamurensis, from the southern coastal region of Turkey, was described as a subspecies of Testudo graeca and is treated as such by most recent studies (Pieh et al. 2000, Perälä 2002b:35), but it was implied to merit full species status by the phylogenies presented by Perälä (2002b:38-39) and is presented as such by Perälä (2002c:87) and Iverson (TTWG checklist update manuscript). It is reported to occur in micro-sympatry with T. ibera at Side by Bruekers (1997).

Testudo antakyensis from the southern Anamos Mountains region of southern Turkey southwards to northern Israel and northwestern Jordan, was described as a separate species but might be a variant of T. graeca based on mitochondrial DNA sequences, and is treated here as a synonym pending further information. Testudo armeniaca, from northeastern Turkey, southern Armenia, northwestern Iran, and possibly Azerbaijan, was originally described as a subspecies of Testudo graeca, and has been treated as such by most recent studies (Pieh et al. 2000, Perälä 2002b:35), but it was implied to merit full species status by phylogenies presented by Perälä (2002b:38-39) and it was presented as such by Iverson (Checklist update MS).

Testudo buxtoni, from the southwestern Caspian Sea shore of northern Iran, was previously treated as a synonym within the Testudo graeca complex, specifically of T. ibera, but was considered 'likely to be a valid taxon' by Perälä (2002c:84), following a hint by Chkhikvadze and Bakradze (1991). Testudo floweri, from the Levantine coastal plain and inland lowland areas in Israel and Lebanon, is usually considered to be a synonym of T. graeca, but might merit species status. Testudo ibera, from southeastern Europe to Iran (depending on the taxonomy followed), is usually treated as a subspecies of T. graeca, but the elevation of the 'ibera-group' to species level was proposed by Gmira (1993) and Perala (2002c). Testudo nikolskii, from the northern Black Sea coast, has recently been considered to merit species rank, but its distinctness from T. ibera was questioned by Leontyeva et al. (2002). Testudo pallasi, from the northern and eastern Caucasus, was described as a subspecies of T. graeca, but was elevated to species level by Iverson (TTWG checklist update manuscript), but is currently retained as a synonym (TTWG 2021).

Testudo perses, from southeastern Turkey and much of Iran, was previously would have been considered part of the Testudo graeca complex, specifically related to T. ibera and/or T. zarudnyi, but was described as a separate species by Perälä (2002c:81). Testudo terrestris, from the northern Mesopotamian region, has a confused nomenclatural history, but the elevation of the 'terrestris-group' to species level was proposed by Gmira (1993) and Perälä (2002). Testudo whitei, possibly from Algeria, is generally considered to be a synonym of T. graeca (Buskirk et al. 2001), but it was elevated to species status by Highfield and Martin (1989) and Ballasina et al. (2002); it was considered a nomen dubium by Pieh (2002:110). Testudo zarudnyi, from eastern Iran, was traditionally treated as a subspecies of T. graeca, but was treated as full species by Perälä (2002c:83). A full taxonomic review of this species required from across its entire range to identify those lineages that have diverged sufficiently to merit full species status.

Thamnophis hammondii, T. gigas, and T. atratus (including subspecies hydrophilus and aquaticus) formerly were included in Thamnophis couchii but now are recognized as distinct species (Rossman et al. 1996; Crother et al. 2000, 2003; Ernst and Ernst 2003).

Was under the family Iguanidae.

Based on electrophoretic analyses, Adest (1977) concluded that Uma scoparia, Uma notata, and Uma inornata comprise a single species (Uma notata) (Adest 1977). Stebbins (1985, 2003) maintained the three taxa as distinct species. Phylogenetic relationships inferred from mtDNA sequences indicate that Uma notata rufopunctata is more closely related to Uma inornata than to Uma notata notata (Wilgenbusch and de Queiroz 2000, Trepanier and Murphy 2001). Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy.

This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999). Further taxonomic research is needed to clarify the validity of this species (W. Böhme pers. comm.). It may represent a synonym of M. xanthina (see Schatti et al., 1991), however recent electropheoretic analysis of blood-sera (Göçmen in press) support the recognition of M. albizona at the species level.
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with V. raddei (see McDiarmid et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).

Groves (2001) and Meijaard and Groves (2002a, b) proposed to upgrade the three extant subspecies of Babyrousa to species level: B. celebensis from northern Sulawesi; B. togeanensis from the Togian islands; and B. babyrussa from Buru and the Sula Islands. A single skull from central Sulawesi may or may not represent the species known otherwise only as a subfossil from the southern peninsula, B. bolabatuensis. The taxonomic identity of the individuals from central, eastern and southeastern Sulawesi was left undecided. Until further studies have brought clarity all individuals occurring on Sulawesi, Muna, Buton and Lembeh are treated as Babyrousa celebensis.   A large taxonomic study based on skull and tooth morphology as well as molecular genetic analyses is close to completion.

Neas and Hoffmann (1987) recognized four subspecies: B. t. bedfordi, B. t. taxicolor, B. t. tibetana, and B. t. whitei. This taxonomy seems to be accepted by both western (Grubb 2005) and Chinese scientists (Wang et al. 1997, Zheng et al. 2003). In a recent analysis of the mtDNA control region, Li et al. (2003) identified three clades that corresponded generally with the three Chinese subspecies sampled.
This species was originally described from the Western Ghats of India; more recently it was synonymized with I. forstenii but has since been resurrected as a full species (Pritchard 2000).
Sarcophilus laniarius has also been used recently in light of comparisons between a fossil specimen, S. laniarius (named prior to the naming of S. harrisii), and the extant species (Werdelin 1987).

Gambelia sila was previously placed in the genus Crotaphytus. Except in recent literature, the spelling of the specific name usually has been given as "silus". See Jennings (1995) for an explanation of the spelling change. An isolated population of putative hybrid (G. sila x G. wislizenii) origin has been reported in the Cuyama River drainage system southwest of the southern end of the San Joaquin Valley; apparently hybrids are no longer extant, as a result of habitat loss and local extirpation (Jennings 1995).
Elgaria panamintina was formerly included in the genus Gerrhonotus (see Good 1988).
Synonyms = Ctenosaura quinquecarinata (in part) sensu Bailey, 1928 and other authors before 2001; Enyaliosaurus quinquecarinatus (in part).
Coelops hirsutus was previously considered a subspecies of Coelops robinsoni (Corbet and Hill 1992), however, we follow L. Heaney (pers. comm. 2007) in considering it to be a distinct species.
This species is closely related to the Acanthodactylus pardalis (Lichtenstein, 1823) complex.

Records of this species from Israel refer to Acanthodactylus beershebensis, and records from Jordan refer to A. ahmadisii (Y. Werner pers. comm). Records from Algeria refer to another species.

Identification of many historical records should be considered "tentative at best" due to the difficulty in morphologically separating many members of this genus, and Libyan material has not been included in the most recent phylogenies of this group (Bauer et al. 2017). This assessment restricts the Libyan distribution to the area mapped by Bauer et al. (2017), who regard reports from outside this area as either misidentifications or in need of confirmation.
The validity of this species is uncertain, as it may be a striped morph of Chalcides colossii, a species known from nearby areas that differs only in patterning (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019).
This species is likely to need taxonomic revision, with true Chalcides manueli likely to be restricted to areas north of the western end of the High Atlas (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019).
This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999).

authority: Moravec, Baha El Din, Seligmann, Sivan & Werner, 1999

taxonomicNotes: This species exhibits high intraspecific genetic diversity based on a small number of specimens (Mendes et al. 2017).
Animals from Jordan might belong to a separate subspecies. More taxonomic work is needed on the fragmented populations of this species.

The name Trapelus savignyi was coined by Andouin (1827) for a gecko, and has been a junior synonym of Stenodactylus sthenodactylus or S. petrii for more than a century (Wagner and Crochet 2009). Due to the potential for confusion following the transfer of Agama savignii Duméril & Bibron, 1837 to Trapelus, Wagner and Crochet (2009) assigned a neotype to resolve this issue.

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of Bactrian Camel under Camelus ferus, while the domestic form is considered under Camelus bactrianus (see Gentry et al. 2004).

Grubb (2005) lists ferus as a subspecies of bactrianus, contrary to most authors.

One-humped camels (Camelus dromedarius) and Bactrian camels (Camelus ferus) can produce viable hybrids (Camelus dromedarius hybridus J. Fischer 1829, unavailable), but hybrid males are thought to be sterile (A.P. Gray 1972).

Samples of skin taken from the remains of dead wild Bactrian Camels have been sent to scientists for genetic DNA testing. The results have been remarkable. Each skin sample has shown two or three distinct genetic differences to the domestic Bactrian camel and a 3% base difference. This answers the charge that the wild Bactrian camel is a domestic runaway.
This species was originally allocated to A. depii.

Specimens from Bemaraha differ in some scale characters from the specimens originally described as Pseudoxyrhopus kely, but as these differences are not diagnostic according to the current species concept these records are considered to represent P. kely (A. Raselimanana pers. comm. July 2011).
Molecular data support recognition of the family Anniellidae as a monophyletic group (Macey et al. 1999).

Pituophis ruthveni formerly was included in P. melanoleucus. In recent years many authors have regarded the gopher snakes and bullsnake as a species (P. catenifer) distinct from the Pine Snake (P. melanoleucus) and Louisiana Pine Snake (P. ruthveni). This classification, though not unequivocally supported by available data, has been adopted in this database.

Reichling's (1995) analysis led him to concur that ruthveni is phenetically distinct and is a valid evolutionary species, though he referred to it consistently as P. m. ruthveni, probably in acknowledgment that the status of the nominal Pituophis subspecies still need further study.

Rodriguez-Robles and De Jesus-Escobar (2000) examined rangewide mtDNA variation in Pituophis and found two divergent, allopatric segments: (1) the lodingi-melanoleucus-mugitus eastern pinesnake clade and (2) the affinis-annectens-bimaris-catenifer-deserticola-sayi-ruthveni-vertebralis clade. These two clades were recognized as distinct species (P. melanoleucus and P. catenifer). The taxon ruthveni was also recognized as a distinct species because it is a diagnosable allopatric entity. However, it has strong genetic affinities to sayi - some ruthveni are more closely related to sayi than to other ruthveni. Thus P. ruthveni may not be monophyletic, which calls into question its status as a distinct species. Nevertheless, Crother et al. (2000) and Collins and Taggart (2002) accepted P. ruthveni as a distinct species. In contrast, Ernst and Ernst (2003) treated ruthveni as a subspecies of P. catenifer, emphasizing the closer relationship between ruthveni and catenifer than between ruthveni and P. melanoleucus.

Tantilla oolitica is morphologically similar to Tantilla coronata of northern Florida; it is geographically separated from coronata by the less similar T. relicta. Some have questioned whether T. oolitica warrants recognition as a distinct species, but it has been consistently treated as such in recent publications.
This species formerly was regarded as a subspecies of Sceloporus graciosus (see Degenhardt et al. 1996). The specific name was misspelled "arenicolous" in the original description.
We follow Wiens et al. (1999) in recognizing S. oberon at the species level.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been used for the Mexican species.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.
This may be a species complex (L. Canseco-Márquez pers. comm.)

Grismer and Galvan (1986) described Xantusia henshawi gracilis on the basis of morphological, electrophoretic, and ecological differences from other subspecies. Lovich (2001) used mtDNA data to examine the phylogeography of X. henshawi populations in southern California and concluded that the allopatric subspecies Xantusia henshawi gracilis should be recognized as a distinct species, Xantusia gracilis. This conclusion is supported by previously published allozyme data (showing fixed allelic differences) and a compatible historical biogeographical scenario.
This is a species complex that is currently under revision.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).

Freiberg (1973) separated Chelonoidis chilensis into three species: C. chilensis, C. petersi and C. donosobarrosi. Late authors have not consistently recognized C. petersi as valid based on syntopic occurrence and lack of consistent morphological differentiation of populations attributed to C. petersi vs. C. chilensis (Richard 1999; Fritz and Havas 2007). Afterward, Fritz et al. (2012), using sequence data of the mitochondrial Cyt b gene and length polymorphisms of 10 microsatellite loci, concluded that only one species is valid, C. chilensis (Gray 1870), with C. donosobarrosi (Freiberg 1973) and C. petersi (Freiberg 1973) as its junior synonyms. Only negligible differentiation with decreasing genetic diversity was found from north to south. A posterior study carried out by Sánchez (2012) using the complete Cyt b gene and a part of the tRNA-Thr gene (both together totaling 1200 bp) agreed with Fritz et al. (2012) that C. chilensis is the only valid species. Sanchez (2012) also validated the Cyt b gene sequence by using five additional Control Region sequences of the mitochondrial DNA obtained from tortoises opportunely sequenced for the Cyt b gene. This procedure confirmed the same results and showed two divergent and well-supported clades that coincide with two eco-regions in Argentina, the Monte of Plains and Plateaus (MPP) and the Dry Chaco (DC) (eco-regions according to Morello et al. 2012). The divergence between both haplogroups occurred about 2.47 million years ago (Sánchez et al. 2017). Tortoises of both Cit-b haplogroups presented distinct kariomorphs: A and B; they coincide, in general, with the DC and the MPP eco-regions, respectively (Sánchez et al. 2015). Morphology appears to vary independently of the cytomorph variation (e.g., tortoises from both Cit-b haplogroups having either the chilensis, the petersi, or the donosobarrossi morphology, and even mixed chilensis-petersi morphs may present the kariomorph A. Kariomorph B may be present in tortoises having the chilensis, the donosobarrosi, and even mixed donosobarrosi-chilensis morphs (Sánchez et al. 2015). Both cytomorphs are syntopic in the Salinas Grandes region where the MPP and the DC eco-regions meet and integrate (E La Rioja, SE Catamarca, NW Córdoba, SW Santiago del Estero, Argentine provinces).

Olson and David (2014) conducted a taxonomic review and proposed a change to the species’ name. They suggested that the specific name of the species formerly known as Chelonoidis denticulata should be modified to Chelonoidis denticulatus. This alteration was made based on the understanding that the generic name Chelonoidis is grammatically masculine, necessitating a corresponding change in the specific name. Henceforth, it is recommended that the species be referred to as C. denticulatus in the IUCN database and IUCN Red List to align with the updated taxonomic classification. This species has no known subspecies (Pritchard and Trebbau 1984; TTWG 2021). Phylogeographic analyses using the mitochondrial marker cytochrome b (cyt-b) suggest that C. denticulatus, despite its extensive geographical range, appears to be a genetically homogeneous species. There is no evidence of cryptic diversity within it since genetic divergence between geographically distant populations is very low, there is no clear phylogenetic structure among the sampled populations, and its haplotypes are weakly differentiated (Vargas-Ramírez et al. 2010).

The Nilgiri Tahr was first described by Gray from a drawing and notes of General Hardwicke, and they were said to have been sent from Nepal and from Chittagong. However, it has hitherto only been found on the Neelgherry and adjacent hills, extending south along the Western Ghats nearly to Cape Comorin. The specific name given by Gray was the Tamul, word for rock or precipice goat. It was called Ibex by sportsmen in Madras (Jerdon, 1874).  Later, Rice, (1984) provided a detailed description on the taxonomic history of Tahr. The Nilgiri Tahr was first named Kemas hylocrius by (Ogilby, 1838). Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Ropiquet and Hassanin (2005) proposed the name Nilgiritragus hylocrius for the species as it is claimed that the three species of Tahr (Himalayan, Arabian and Nilgiri) have had different lineages.

We follow Ropiquet and Hassanin (2005)in removing this species from the genus Hemitragus, and placing it in the monotypic genus Nilgiritragus, based on analyses of four molecular markers. No subspecies are recognized.

Molecular studies have indicated that the disjunct South African subpopulation is not substantially divergent from subpopulations to the north (W. Wüster and A. Barlow unpubl. data, 2007). The South African subpopulation is also morphologically similar to the closest subpopulation in Zimbabwe/Mozambique (e.g. Broadley 1990). The lack of genetic differentiation suggests that Bitis gabonica once had a large and continuous distribution that was fragmented only relatively recently, resulting in various isolated subpopulations such as the one in southern Africa. This subpopulation should be considered regionally important in terms of the overall conservation of the species and the maintenance of genetic variability. Bitis rhinoceros of West Africa is now treated as a full species and not a subspecies of B. gabonica, rendering the latter monotypic (Lenk et al. 2001).
Gongylomorphus fontenayi was previously treated as a subspecies of G. bojeri.

authority: Evans, Greenbaum, Kusamba, Carter, Tobias, Mendel & Kelley, 2011
taxonomicNotes: It is considered to be the sister taxon to Xenopus vestitus (Evans et al. 2011).
Because this species was described relatively recently, it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura palearis or Enyaliosaurus palearis, the sister species that it was split from.

Phipps (1774) first described the Polar Bear as a distinct species and named it Ursus maritimus. Other names were suggested including Thalassarctos, Thalarctos, and Thalatarctos. Erdbrink (1953) and Thenius (1953) ultimately settled on Ursus (Thalarctos) maritimus because of interbreeding between Brown Bears (Ursus arctos) and Polar Bears in zoos. Based on the fossil record, Kurtén (1964) recommended the Phipps (1774) name Ursus maritimus, which was promoted by Harington (1966), Manning (1971) and Wilson (1976) and is used today (see DeMaster and Stirling 1981, Amstrup 2003, Wilson and Reeder 2005).

The identity of two records from Santa Cruz in Bolivia, assigned to this species by Harvey (1999), based on two specimens that these authors acknowledged differ from the holotype, remains uncertain. Entiauspe and Lema (2015) concluded that these represented Apostolepis christineae based on photographs of the museum specimens, but did not examine the specimens to confirm this identification and A. christineae is so far known with certainty only from the Brazilian type locality. Pending direct examination of the specimens it is considered speculative to assign these records to either species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), and they are consequently excluded from this assessment.

Passos et al. (2010) synonymized Atractus kangueryensis within A. thalesdelemai, based on their finding that a re-examination of the holotype of the latter showed no reliable morphological differences between the two taxa.

authority: Franco, de Carvalho Cintra & de Lema, 2006

taxonomicNotes: McCranie (2011) proposed elevating Cubophis canthigerus brooksi to specific status following the recognition by Hedges et al. (2009) that Cayman Island populations also previously included within C. canthigerus are genetically distinct from this species. Although Hedges et al. (2009) did not consider the status of the Honduran population, McCranie (2011) notes that it is geographically closer to the Cayman Islands than to Cuban C. canthigerus, and so it is implausible that C. canthigerus and C. brooksi are conspecific.
Groves in Wilson and Reeder (1993) treats this as a synonym under M. murinus. There is a problem with the typification of this taxon.

This is a monotypic species, believed to be closely related to the African endemic genus Nectophrynoides. This hypothesis is supported by the findings of Frost et al. (2006). Though the conclusions of relationship among those taxa closely related to D. sjostedti have come into question (compare Frost et al. 2006 to Van Bocxalaer et al. 2009), the identity and distinctiveness of this species is clear and uncontroversial.
The supopulation in Atewa, Ghana is most likely a separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
Broadley et al. (2006) indicate that this species was included within the concept of Melanoseps loveridgei applied by Spawls et al. (2002) (but not earlier authors).
This species is in the Arthroleptis poecilonotus species complex (Blackburn 2010).
Phrynobatrachus schioetzi was found to be conspecific with a juvenile specimen from the Obudu Plateau previously thought to be P. werneri (Blackburn and Rödel 2011).
The current assessment includes both Nimbaphrynoides occidentalis and the previously recognized (now synonymized) Nimbaphrynoides liberiensis.

It is possible that Sclerophrys djohongensis is a synonym of this species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.). However, this synonymy is not universally accepted (D. Blackburn pers. comm. August 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
Records of this species from Tchabal Mbabo refer to Cardioglossa alsco.
Wolterstorffina parvipalmata is a species complex and, according to a forthcoming paper, will be split into three lineages (M. Barej and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
This species is part of the Hyperolius tuberculatus Group within the H. viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999).

So far, this is the only species in the recently erected genus Morerella (Rödel et al. 2009). The population reported from southern Taï National Park is known only from photographic evidence which has not been seen by the describing authors, and neither its taxonomic status nor its locality can be verified (N.G. Kouamé pers. comm. December 2010).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and P. jimzimkusi (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is a tetraploid species (Kobel et al. 1980).
A study has confined this species to forests of the West Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2011).
This species was separated from Callulina kreffti by de Sá et al. (2004).

We follow Poynton (2003b) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering this to be a species distinct from Probreviceps macrodactylus. Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (Loader, et al. 2014).
Further taxonomic investigations are required on this species as more than one taxon may be represented.
It is possible that the different subpopulations attributed to this species are taxonomically distinct.

Molecular data suggest that this nominal species may comprise two or more distinct taxa and its presence in the Gughe mountains is questionable based on a possible previous misidentification (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comms. June 2012).
Molecular data confirm that the subpopulation in Saja (Kaffa) forest pertains to this nominal form (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

We follow Mkonyi et al. (2004) and Channing and Howell (2006) in treating this taxon as a species separate from Probreviceps macrodactylus. Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

We follow Poynton (1997) in considering Mertensophryne mocquardi and M. nairobiensis as distinct from this species. However, M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi.
Ongoing taxonomic investigation may demonstrate that there are several taxa associated with this name.
Ongoing investigations have shown that this name represents several taxa (see Lawson 2010; Pickersgill 2007). The naming of these species is awaiting further investigations.

Böhme and Rödder (2011) recorded Ptychana nana from the type locality, Arussi mountains, ninety years after its description. Furthermore, they discuss the taxonomic relationships of Ptychadena cf. nana from the Bale Mountains. A record referrable to Ptychadena nana was reported and questioned by Largen (2001) from south of Ketama, west of the Rift Valley, but this has yet to be confirmed or validated.

The systematic status of this species in relation to Crotaphatrema tchabalmbaboensis is uncertain as they could be the same species; more research is needed to clarify this relationship (T. Doherty-Bone pers. comm. October 2012).

authority: Radespiel, Ratsimbazafy, Rasoloharijaona, Raveloson, Andriaholinirina, Rakotondravony, Randrianarison  & Randrianambinina, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. July 2024) with the type locality East Usambara retaining the name H. rogersi.
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. July 2024) with the type locality Ulugurus retaining the name H. uluguruensis.
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (Loader, et al. 2014).
This species is possibly a subspecies of Hyperolius mitchelli (Schiøtz 1999).
H. ukwiva has recently been split from this species (Loader et al. 2014).
The emendation by Schiøtz (1999) from Hyperolius tanneri to H. tannerorum was considered unjustified by Dubois (2007).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. July 2024) with the type locality Udzungwa mountains retaining the name A. yakusini.

Arnold (2000) elevated the former subspecies Nactus serpeninsula durrelli (emended to durrellorum by Michels and Bauer 2004) to specific status, restricting N. s. serpeninsula to Serpent Island. Although Arnold (2000) elevated this taxon to a full species without comment, his taxonomy is accepted by researchers and conservationists working with this taxon and is consequently applied here.

This species was described as a subspecies of the Serpent Island Night Gecko Nactus serpensinsula under the name N. s. durrelli (Arnold and Jones 1994), and elevated to specific status by Arnold (2000). The species was named in honour of both Gerald and Lee Durrell and hence the specific name should be plural; consequently Michels and Bauer (2004) emended it to Nactus serpensinsula durrellorum. This work unfortunately neglected the action of Arnold (2000) elevating this taxon to specific status, and consequently the correct combination Nactus durrellorum has so far been used only in grey literature such as technical reports. Although Arnold (2000) elevated this taxon to a full species without comment, his taxonomy is accepted by researchers and conservationists working with this taxon and is consequently applied here.

Three subspecies are currently recognized: Phelsuma borbonica borbonica Mertens,1966, P. b. mater Meier, 1995 and P. b. agalegae Cheke, 1975. P. b. agalegae, only present on Agalega islands, is a very poorly known subspecies.

Due to the limits of the taxonomic descriptions of subspecies and more recent developments of systematic methods, a systematic revision of Phelsuma borbonica is necessary (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). A genetic study has shown that two distinctly differentiated evolutionary lineages with a high level of genetic differentiation between populations exist on Réunion Island (Thébaud 2013).

Bour et al. (1995) elevated the the subspecies Phelsuma ornata inexpectata to species rank, based on coloration and biological criteria. Phylogenetic studies confirm that this taxon is well-differentiated from Mauritian P. ornata (Austin et al. 2004), and it is currently accepted as a full species by most herpetologists.

Unpublished genetic work suggests that the record of this species from Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008) probably belongs to an undescribed species (M. Menegon pers. comm. 2015). An Agama population from the Udzungwa mountains appears to be morphologically referable to A. montana, but this too is thought to represent an undescribed species (M. Menegon pers. comm. 2015). Neither of these populations is included in this assessment pending further research to clarify the taxonomic status of the new records.

The taxonomy of night monkeys (Aotus spp.) has been debated and still does not provide a complete picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterised 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially followed the early revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms. Recent molecular studies have made valuable contributions towards the understanding of night monkeys taxonomy and phylogenetic relations (Plautz et al.2009; Menezes et al. 2010).

Reviewing the entire taxonomy and distributions of the night monkeys, Aotus, Ford (1994) carried out multivariate analyses of craniodental measures and pelage patterns and color, and also took into consideration chromosomal data and blood protein variations. Ford (1994) concluded that there was “good support” for just two species north of the Río Amazonas: A. trivirgatus (Humboldt, 1812) east and north of the Rio Negro, and the polymorphic A. vociferans to the west of the Rio Negro. Aotus vociferans, as such, would include all the forms north of the Río Amazonas/Solimões in Brazil (west of the Rio Negro), Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the Chocó, northern Colombia and Colombian Andes, and Panama: brumbacki, lemurinus, griseimembra, and zonalis.

Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) restricted both lemurinus (Colombian Andes, elevations from 1,000 to 1,500 m up to 3,000–3,200 m) and griseimembra (northern lowlands, Santa Marta mountains, west to Río Sinú, Río San Jorge, lower Río Cauca and lowlands of middle and upper Río Magdalena) to Colombia, while recognizing the form zonalis as the night monkey of north-western Colombia (Chocó) and Panama. Hershkovitz (1983) recognized lemurinus and griseimembra as distinct, but considered them to be subspecies of a single species; he made no mention of the name zonalis, but as he ascribed Central American night monkeys to A. lemurinus lemurinus, by implication he was regarding it as a synonym of this latter form. Groves (2001) followed Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) in recognizing zonalis as the form in Panama, and listed it as a subspecies of lemurinus along with griseimembra and brumbacki Hershkovitz, 1983. Defler et al. (2001) concluded that the karyotype of Aotus hershkovitzi Ramirez-Cerquera, 1983 (from the upper Río Cusiana, Boyacá, Colombia; 2n = 58) was in fact that of true lemurinus, and that the karyotypes which Hershkovitz (1983) had considered to be those of lemurinus were in fact of zonalis. Defler et al. (2001) and others (Defler 2003, 2004; Defler and Bueno 2003) concluded that Aotus lemurinus of Hershkovitz (1983) is in fact three karyotypically well-defined species, and that the night monkeys of the lowlands of Panama and the Chocó region of Colombia belong to the species A. zonalis, and those of the Magdalena valley to A. griseimembra, while those above altitudes of 1,500 m should correctly be referred to as A. lemurinus. For a review of the taxonomy of the night monkeys of Panama and northern Colombia see Rylands et al. (2006).

Defler and Bueno (2007) discussed the karyology of the grey-necked night monkeys and reaffirmed the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis.

It is doubtful that the current taxonomy provides a true picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterized 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially follows the revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms.

Reviewing the entire taxonomy and distributions of the night monkeys, Aotus, Ford (1994) carried out multivariate analyses of craniodental measures and pelage patterns and colour, and also took into consideration chromosomal data and blood protein variations. Ford (1994) concluded that there was “good support” for just two species north of the Río Amazonas: A. trivirgatus (Humboldt, 1812) east and north of the Rio Negro, and the polymorphic A. vociferans to the west of the Rio Negro. Aotus vociferans, as such, would include all the forms north of the Río Amazonas/Solimões in Brazil (West of the Rio Negro), Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the Chocó, northern Colombia and Colombian Andes, and Panama: brumbacki, lemurinus, griseimembra and zonalis.

Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) restricted both lemurinus (Colombian Andes, elevations from 1,000 to 1,500 m up to 3,000–3,200 m) and griseimembra (northern lowlands, Santa Marta mountains, West to Río Sinú, Río San Jorge, lower Río Cauca and lowlands of middle and upper Río Magdalena) to Colombia, while recognizing the form zonalis as the night monkey of north-western Colombia (Chocó) and Panama. Hershkovitz (1983) recognized lemurinus and griseimembra as distinct, but considered them to be subspecies of a single species; he made no mention of the name zonalis, but as he ascribed Central American night monkeys to A. lemurinus lemurinus, by implication he was regarding it as a synonym of this latter form. Groves (2001) followed Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) in recognizing zonalis as the form in Panama, and listed it as a subspecies of lemurinus along with griseimembra and brumbacki Hershkovitz, 1983. Defler et al. (2001) concluded that the karyotype of Aotus hershkovitzi Ramirez-Cerquera, 1983 (from the upper Río Cusiana, Boyacá, Colombia; 2n = 58) was in fact that of true lemurinus, and that the karyotypes which Hershkovitz (1983) had considered to be those of lemurinus were in fact of zonalis. Defler et al. (2001) and others (Defler 2003, 2004; Defler and Bueno 2003) concluded that Aotus lemurinus of Hershkovitz (1983) is in fact three karyotypically well-defined species, and that the night monkeys of the lowlands of Panama and the Chocó region of Colombia belong to the species A. zonalis, and those of the Magdalena valley to A. griseimembra, while those above altitudes of 1,500 m should correctly be referred to as A. lemurinus. For a review of the taxonomy of the night monkeys of Panama and northern Colombia see Rylands et al. (2006).

Defler and Bueno (2007) discuss the karyology of the Gray-necked Night Monkeys and reaffirm the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis.

Lawrance (1933) originally recognized the howlers from Belize, north and eastern Guatemala and the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico, as to distinct taxa, within Aloutta palliata (A. p. pigra and A. p. luctuosa). Regarding A. p. pigra she mentioned “The differences, however, are so definite that they unquestionably indicate a separate subspecies; indeed, if it were not for the form found at Mountain Cow [A. p. luctuosa] which seems to be intermediate between this and typical A. p. palliata, one might be justified in calling it a distinct species” (Lawrance 1933, p. 334). Smith (1970) analysed pelage coloration patterns, and cranial and dental features of 238 specimens from across the range of A. palliata (including those studied by Lawrence, 1933) and compared them with a population sample of two sympatric forms of howler monkeys from the state of Tabasco, Mexico. He determined that the two (partially sympatric) forms from his sample constituted two well-differentiated species, and thus recommended A. pigra to be considered full species and separated from A. palliata. He considered A. p. luctuosa Lawrence, 1933 as junior synonym of A. pigra. Most authors have considered A. pigra as the single species of Black howler in Central America (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005; Rylands et al. 2006). Napier (1976) discussed that A. pigra was in fact A. villosa (Gray 1845), and Brandon-Jones (2006) argued that Alouatta pigra Lawrence, 1933 is a junior synonym. However, due to the poor condition of the type specimen of A. villosa, the lack of compelling evidence (genetic or otherwise) to ensure that this is in fact the same taxon as A. pigra, and in pro of taxonomic stability, Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015a) continue to call this taxon A. pigra until further studies are completed. Using mtDNA markers, Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2003) confirmed that A. palliata and A. pigra comprise reciprocally monophyletic groups, justifying their separation into distinct species. Nonetheless, as pointed out by Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015a) “the validity of A. pigra luctuosa from the Cayo District in Belize has yet to be evaluated with genetic data.”

The taxonomy of spider monkeys (Ateles spp.) is based on Kellogg and Goldman´s (1944) seminal review, and more recently complemented by morphological and molecular analysis of Froehlich et al. (1991), Collins and Dubach (2000), Nieves et al. (2005) and Morales-Jimenez et al. (2015). In all studies, brown spider monkeys (Ateles hybridus I. Geoffroy, 1829) form a monophyletic clade, justifying full species status following the molecular studies conducted by Collins (1999) and Collins and Dubach (2000). These studies found that brown spider monkeys form an ancient clade within the spider monkeys, separated from white-bellied spider monkeys (Ateles belzebuth) approximately 3 mya. This classification was reinforced by Nieves et al. (2005) using chromosomal and molecular markers. Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) and Defler (2004) argued for the validity of two distinct forms: brunneus Gray, 1872 from the western bank of the Magdalena River, and hybridus from the eastern bank of the Magdalena River in Colombia and Venezuela. Nonetheless, recent molecular studies using two mitochondrial markers suggest that there has been substantial gene flow between both populations and that both taxa do not represent monophyletic clades (Link et al. 2015). Thus, brown spider monkeys are currently considered a single taxon without subspecific divisions.

The lion tamarins, Leontopithecus spp., are listed as separate species following Della Serra (1951), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), Snowdon et al. (1986), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Natori (1989) and Rylands et al. (1993). Leontopithecus chrysopygus and L. chrysomelas have been listed as subspecies of L. rosalia by Coimbra-Filho (1969), Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier (1972, 1973), Hershkovitz (1977), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Forman et al. (1986) and Seuánez et al. (1988), the latter two publications on the basis of identical chromosome morphologies. Coimbra-Filho (1990) has suggested that L. caissara was a subspecies of L. chrysopygus, which was not supported neither morphologically (Burity et al. 1999) nor molecularly (Perez-Sweeney et al. 2008). A molecular phylogeny recovered three obvious clades: L. chrysomelas, L. caissara and L. chrysopygus / L. rosalia, where L. chrysomelas is the first to diverge from the other three (Perez-Sweeney et al. 2008). Here we follow the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012).

Saimiri vanzolinii Ayres 1985 was described based on 13 specimens collected at the confluence of the Solimões and Japurá rivers and deposited in the Museum of Zoology at the University of São Paulo. The type locality is the northern shore of Lake Mamirauá, Amazonas, Brazil. Ayres (1985) allocated S. vanzolinii in the species group "Saimiri boliviensis" (Roman group), based on the taxonomic arrangement of Hershkovitz (1984). Saimiri vanzolinii was referred by Hershkovitz (1987) as a subspecies of S. boliviensis. Although no specimen was examined, Costello et al. (1993), based on the data described by Ayres (1985), considered S. vanzolinii as a junior synonym of S. sciureus. All subsequent authors followed Ayres (1985), considering S. vanzolinii as a valid species. Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) analysed biogeographical and mitochondrial molecular data for the genus and concluded that S. vanzolinii is a valid species. More recently, Mercês (2018) performed an extensive morphological review of museum specimens of Saimiri species from throughout the Amazon basin; she also employed RAD-seq to sequence nuclear genomic markers to construct a Saimiri phylogeny. The nuclear genetic and morphological analyses by Mercês (2018) both provide strong evidence to place Saimiri vanzolinii as a distinct taxon and the sister species to Saimiri boliviensis.

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

See Rylands et al. (2006) for a discussion of the taxonomy of the Central American squirrel monkeys.

There is a single record of a hybrid Red-shanked Douc (Pygathrix nemaeus) X Grey-shanked Douc (P. cinerea) in northeastern Cambodia (Rawson and Roos 2008). Current knowledge of the zones of transition between the three douc taxa is unclear, with limited information mostly based on brief field views (Timmins and Duckworth 1999, Nadler et al. 2004, Rawson and Roos 2008). There may be a zone in Viet Nam with sympatry (and possibly hybridization) between the three taxa (Lippold et al. 2011). Both Black-shanked Douc (P. nigripes) and Grey-shanked Douc were previously considered conspecific with Red-shanked Douc

In the past this taxon has been considered either a subspecies of Pygathrix nemaeus, or a hybrid of P. nemaeus and P. nigripes (Nadler 1995). Other studies on the genetics of doucs show that P. cinerea and P. nemaeus are sister taxa (Roos and Nadler 2001). There is strong evidence that this taxon hybridizes with Red-shanked Doucs (P. nemaeus) in a small sympatric distribution area of Quang Nam Province (Nadler 1997) and possibly in northeast Cambodia (Rawson and Roos 2008).

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Semnopithecus entellus (Molur et al. 2003).

Pocock described the species in 1928 as Pithecus entellus ajax. In his 1939 review, W.C.O. Hill subsumed the taxon as a subspecies of S. schistaceus. Brandon-Jones (2004) followed with designating ajax as a subspecies of entellus. Within the group, at a same place fur coloration might change based on age and hierarchy, for example subadults fur is slightly whiter than an adult which is greyish but this needs to be studied further.

authority: Geissmann, Ngwe Lwin, Saw Soe Aung, Thet Naing Aung, Zin Myo Aung, Tony Htin Hla, Grindley & Momberg, 2011
taxonomicNotes:
This is a recently described species of Snub-nosed Monkey from the high altitudes of northeastern Kachin state, northeastern Myanmar. Descriptions are based on a skin and skulls of four specimens obtained from local hunters. The new species is geographically isolated from other Snub-nosed Monkeys and separated from them by two major barriers the Mekong and the Salween (Thanlwin) rivers.

It is closely related to Rhinopithecus bieti
Groves in Wilson and Reeder (1993) also treats this as a distinct species but under the genus <Pygathrix. There is now good support to keep it in Rhinopithecus see Novak (1999).
This species was formerly considered to be in the genus Pygathrix.

Grubb et al. (2003) list two subspecies: Colobus satanas satanas from Bioko, and C. s. anthracinus from the mainland.

Groves (2001, 2007) listed Colobus satanas anthracinus from Gabon (see Gautier-Hion et al. 1999) as a junior synonym of Colobus satanas (which occurs on Bioko Island). Groves (2005) and Grubb et al. (2003), however, listed it as a valid subspecies. Oates et al. (2000) found that the loud calls (roar pulse rate) of the two forms were significantly distinct (lower in C. s. satanas).

Booth (1954), Oates and Trocco (1983), Groves et al. (1993), Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003) considered Dollman’s Black-and-White Colobus monkey, Colobus polykomos dollmani Schwarz, 1927, from areas between the Sassandra and Bandama Rivers in Western Côte d’Ivoire to be a hybrid of C. vellerosus × C. polykomos. Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) and Grubb et al. (2003) listed dollmani as a junior synonym of C. vellerosus. The question of the validity or otherwise of this form was raised by Gonedelé Bi et al. (2006) who, carried out surveys in 2003–2004 in three forest reserves and Marahoué National Park in search of Colobus polykomos dollmani between the Sassandra and Bandama Rivers and found just one group in Bolo Forest Reserve. But reviewing the evidence, Oates and McGraw (2009) opined that dollmani is a Colobus polykomos x Colobus vellerosus hybrid and should not be considered as a subspecies. Gonedelé Bi et al. (2014) subsequently conducted a survey in 2012 in the same region, but Bolo-Dassiéko-Niégré complex had been converted into a cocoa plantation. They found one group in Grébouo I Forest Grove, which is in close proximity to Bolo, where they found that the monkeys had a similar pelage as Colobus vellerosus, but in one vocal aspect, they were similar to Colobus polykomos. However, modest vocal data analysed by these authors produced more complex results. In one parameter (duration), the roar was similar to Colobus vellerosus; whereas it was more similar to Colobus polykomos than to Colobus vellerosus in the number of roars or subunit calls. Hence, Gonedelé Bi et al. (2014) were reluctant to draw definitive conclusions based on vocalisations.

This account follows the taxonomic arrangement of Groves (2001), Grubb et al. (2003) and Bocian and Anderson (2013) in recognition of subspecies, with the exception of Colobus angolensis sharpei which is here reinstated as a subspecies based on new molecular evidence (McDonald and Hamilton 2010).
Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005) both recognise two subspecies: Cercopithecus erythrotis camerunensis (from between the Cross/Benue and Sanaga Rivers), and C. e. erythrotis (endemic to Bioko).
Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003) recognize two subspecies: Cercopithecus erythrogaster erythrogaster and C. e. pococki. It belongs to the Cercopithecus cephus species group.

This species hybridizes with Macaca ochreata, M. maura and M. hecki in areas where their ranges overlap (Groves 2001). Molecular research did not find evidence that the so-called "Balantak Macaque" from the Togean Islands constitutes a distinct species, but it did indicate that the western and eastern populations are genetically distinct, and therefore, should be managed separately  (Evans et al. 2001).

This species was once considered a subspecies of Macaca nigra. It is believed to hybridize with M. nigra on the western side of Mount Padang, and with M. hecki east of the Bolango River and near Bolaangitang (Groves 2001). In 1969, J. Fooden found substantial difference between M. nigra and M. nigrescens to classify each as a separate species. There were no intergradations found then. In 1980, Groves saw intergradations in the ‘zone of intergradation’ between M. nigra and M. nigrescens on the western tip of Bogani Nani Wartabone (formerly Dumoga Bone) National Park in the downstream region of Onggak Dumoga River, therefore placing M. nigrescens as subspecies of nominate M. nigra. Corbett and Hill (1992), in the review of The Mammals of the Indomalayan Region, followed Groves’ 1980 classification scheme. However, in 2001 Groves reviewed the classification, readdressing the previous schemes and redressing M. nigra and M. nigrescens. Despite the genetic and morphological similarity, the macaques are considered distinct and as members of the silenus group of macaques.

Morphology, genetics and taxonomic variation in northeastern Indian macaques, including this taxon, is very poorly known (Sinha et al. 2006a, Chakraborty et al. 2007). Further taxonomic research is required in order to better understand its relationship to Macaca assamensis and M. thibetana.

This species hybridizes with Macaca tonkeana and possibly with M. nigrescens in areas where their ranges overlap (Bynum 1995). These hybrid zones, however, appear to be disappearing owing to human encroachment (M. Richardson pers. comm.). Mitochondrial DNA studies suggest sister relationship with M. nemestrina, M. nigrescens, M. nigra, and M. tonkeana. (Evans et al. 1999)

Siberut Macaques were initially thought to be a subspecies of the southern pigtail macaque - Macaca nemestrina pagensis (Fooden 1975) and then of the Mentawai/Pagai macaque of the southern Mentawai Islands - M. pagensis siberu (Fuentes and Olson 1995). More recently, genetic and morphological studies led to their classification as a distinct species (Kitchener & Groves 2002, Roos et al. 2003), showing that this primate is more closely related to M. nemestrina on Sumatra and Malaysia than to M. pagensis on the neighboring Mentawai Islands (Ziegler et al. 2007, Richter et al. 2013). Along with M. pagensis, M. leonina, M. nemestrina and M. silenus, it belongs to the ‘silenus group’ (Roos et al. 2003).

Until relatively recently, Macaca pagensis included M. siberu (Roos et al. 2003). It is now considered a separate species from M. siberu due to genetic and morphological difference. Earlier it was considered as a subspecies of M. nemestrina until established as a separate species.

Individuals with intermediate characteristics, presumably hybrids, have historically been seen along the border of this species' range and that of Macaca nigrescens (although this contact zone may no longer exist; Sugardjito et al. 1989). The zone of intergradation is the downstream region of the Onggak Dumoga River and Groves (1980) placed M. nigrescens as a subspecies of M. nigra. Despite the morphological and genetical similarity, M. nigra and M. nigrescens are still distinct and therefore classified as distinct species (Groves 2001). Macaca nigra belongs to the silenus group including M. pagensis, M. siberu, M. leonina, M. silenus, and M. nemestrina.

Aside from the two previously recognized forms, a third subspecies, M. s. opisthomelas, is also now also recognized by primate field biologists in Sri Lanka, which is assessed separately here. There is some inter-gradation between the three subspecies (Groves, 2001; Dittus, 2013).

The taxonomy of Macaca sinica:

The species belongs to the sinica group (Groves, 2001). Three subspecies are recognized and assessed here:

  • Macaca sinica sinica (Linnaeus, 1771)
  • Macaca sinica aurifrons (Pocock, 1931)
  • Macaca sinica opisthomelas (Hill, 1942)

In addition to the two previously recognized forms, a third subspecies, M. s. opisthomelas first described by Hill (1942), is confirmed by primate field biologists in Sri Lanka (Dittus 2013; Eisenberg and McKay 1970; Phillips 1935, 1980). It is a distinct phenotype apical in the higher elevations of the montane zone. It is not a type intermediate (in morphology or geographic distribution) between M. s. aurifrons and M. s. sinica as had been suggested by Brandon-Jones et al. (2004) and Groves (2001) following the suggestion by Fooden (1979). It was first assessed in 2003 (CAMP 2003, Molur et al. 2003, Dittus et al. 2008) and is updated here along with the other macaque subspecies. A fourth population M. s. longicaudata has been described by Deraniyagala (1965) but its status is uncertain and has been considered as a variant of M. s. sinica (Eisenberg and McKay, 1970).  There are some intergradations between the three subspecies where their respective areas of occupancy overlap (Groves, 2001).
Macaca silenus is a member of the silenus group. The other phylogenetic sister species in this group include M. leonina, M. siberu, M. nemestrina, M. pagensis and the seven Sulawesi species.

Two subspecies are recognized, distinguished on the grounds of both morphological (Macaca radiata radiata is dark bellied and M. r. diluta is pale bellied), and behavioural differences (females largely disperse between groups only in M. r. diluta, while males disperse in both the subspecies; M. Singh pers. comm.).

Mandrillus was regarded as a subgenus of Papio by Dandelot (in Meester and Setzer 1972) and Wolfheim (1983), but recent molecular and chromosomal analyses suggest that Mandrillus is closer to the terrestrial mangabeys Cercocebus spp. (Disotell 1993, Fleagle and McGraw 2002). Two genetically distinct populations have been noted, north and south of the Ogooué River (Telfer et al. 2003).

Formerly placed by some in the genus Papio (Wolfheim, 1983), genetic analyses shows Mandrillus is more closely related to Cercocebus than to Papio (Disotell et al. 1992, Disotell 1994); morphological research concurs (Fleagle and McGraw 1999, McGraw and Fleagle 2006).

There are two subspecies: M. l. leucophaeus on the mainland, and M. l. poensis on Bioko (Zukowsky 1922). Grubb et al. (2003) commented that on present evidence the two forms appear very similar.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Nasalis. Recent molecular analysis suggest a close relationship between Simias and Nasalis, however, current classification still places Simias concolor in its own genus (Whittaker et al. 2006). To date, two subspecies are recognised, primarily based on slight differences in pelage colouration: S. c. concolor, which is found in Indonesia on the islands of Sipora, North Pagai, as well as South Pagai, and S. c. siberu, which is exclusively found on the island of Siberut (Miller 1903, Chasen and Kloss 1927).

Currently, five sub-species are recognised on the IUCN Red List though the basis for this split appears to be arbitrary and all must thus be listed as DD.

•      Presbytis rubicunda rubicunda

•      Presbytis rubicunda rubida

•      Presbytis rubicunda ignita

•      Presbytis rubicunda chrysea

•      Presbytis rubicunda carimatae


Subspecies are disputed as there is much inter-gradation between them, as well as variation within them. The separation is to do with the shape of the crescent and the extent of the whorl on the forehead, and the extent of black(ish) hair around the hands and feet, for the separation of P. rubida and P. rubicunda. P. chrysea and P. ignita are more obviously different because of their hair colour, moving to orange-red upwards along the north-south gradient. P. carimatae has an orange nape. Most of the justification for this split is based on pelage rather than differences in call or genetic data. These morphological subspecies are currently not supported by genetic data.
Possibly referebale to P. comata.

All of the former subspecies of Presbytis melalophos are now recognised as distinct species. However, the species has colour morphs: the ‘foxy-red nobilis’, ‘less-reddish ferruginae’ and ‘golden buff aurata’, black chested, white tail tipped and the hands and feet black. A fourth form ‘fluvialtilis’ described in 1940 by N.F. Chasen of Palembang, Sumatra is also accounted for.
Presbytis potenziani is now monotypic and the former subspecies P. p. siberu is now a distinct species.
Semnopithecus frontatus S. Muller, 1838, Indonesia, south-eastern Borneo. Restricted by L. Medway in 1965 to south eastern Kalimantan, Murung and Pulu Lampy, near Banjarmasin, Pematang, Kuala.

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Presbytis femoralis and P. melalophos. The number of subspecies is disputed. In addition to the two generally recognized forms (Presbytis chrysomelas chrysomelas and P. c. cruciger) there is an additional, isolated population found only in a small area of southeastern Sarawak (Betong, Saribas; Nimong; Batang Lupar) that probably represents an as yet undescribed subspecies (Groves 2001).
This species has been variously considered a subspecies of Presbytis siamensis, P. femoralis and P. melalophos.
Grubb et al. (2003) included this species in Cercocebus galeritus, but Groves (2005) and Kingdon (2001) considered it distinct.

Cercocebus chrysogaster is poorly known. There are no detailed studies of the species, which is documented by fewer than 20 specimens (Ehardt and Butynksi 2013). The species has alternately been assigned as a subspecies of Cercocebus agilis or Cercocebus galeritus but retained as a separate species by Groves (2005). The species range currently consists of two allopatric populations. The western population and eastern population are reported to have differences in pelage (Groves 1978). Photographs suggest that western animals are more brightly coloured than eastern animals (J. Hart unpublished data 2010). Occurrence of outliers in the original description of the species’ range may be attributed to records of captive animals that originated from other areas (Groves 1978, Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).

Mitochondrial DNA studies now classify Trachypithecus johnii and Trachypithecus vetlus under the genus Semnopithecus (Osterholz et al. 2008, Wang et al. 2012). Semnopithecus johnii hybridizes as a brown hybrid with Semnopithecus priam where they are parapatric.
There is some interbreeding of released Francois’ langurs with Trachypithecus leucocephalus south and east of the River Zuo in Guangxi, China (Groves 2001).

This taxon was formerly considered as a subspecies of Trachypithecus francoisi. The taxon was elevated to species level by Brandon-Jones (1984) and Groves (2001), the later conclusion being supported by molecular genetic studies (Roos 2003, 2004) and parasitological findings (May 1994).

This taxon, here considered monotypic, was regarded in the 1960s–1990s as conspecific with Trachypithecus francoisi (Steinmetz et al. 2011). A variety of later classifications have been suggested, all based on inadequate primary information for confidence in their value. For example, Roos et al. (2007) proposed the species T. laotum to contain also the subspecies T. l. hatinhensis (with T. [auratus] ebenus as provisionally synonymous with T. l. hatinhensis). It is here considered a distinct species (as per Roos et al. 2014), though its classification in relation to T. ebenus and T. hatinhensis cannot be resolved without additional primary information.

Mitochondrial DNA studies now classify Trachypithecus vetlus and Trachypithecus johnii under the genus Semnopithecus (Osterholz et al. 2008, Wang et al. 2012). Four subspecies of Semnopithecus vetulus are recognized, namely: vetulus, monticola, nestor, and philbricki. An additional subspecies, S. v. harti, is also recognized by some experts, but is here included as a synonym of S. v. philbricki (Groves 2001).

  • Southern Purple Faced Langur, Semnopithecus vetulus vetulus (Erxleben 1777): Southwestern Sri Lanka in the Wet Zone, from Kalu Ganga (River) to Ranna in the south up to an elevation of 1,000 m.
  • Highland Purple Faced Langur, Semnopithecus vetulus monticola (Kelaart, 1850): Central Sri Lanka (1,000-2,200 m).
  • Western Purple Faced Langur, Semnopithecus vetulus nestor (Bennett, 1833): Western Sri Lanka in the Wet Zone North of Kalu Ganga (River), up to 1,000 m elevation.
  • Northern Purple Faced Langur, Semnopithecus vetulus philbricki (Philips, 1927): Northern and Eastern Sri Lanka in the Dry Zone, up to 1,500 m.

Formerly considered comprising two subspecies, Trachypithecus poliocephalus poliocephalus Trouessart, 1911, and T. p. leucocephalus Tan, 1955 (Groves 2001, 2005; Roos et al. 2007), Groves (2007) and Nadler (2013a,b) considered leucocephalus to be a full species (Roos et al. 2014). Now, T. poliocephalus (formerly T. p. poliocephalus) is a monotypic species

This was formerly part of Semnopithecus cristatus, but it is not clear what the current concept includes. It may or may not have been partially included within Trachypithecus auratus cristatus, which is confined to Indonesia according to D. Brandon-Jones. Ardith Eudey (in litt. 2000) believes that he may have assigned the remainder of the species to T. obscurus.

Despite a confusing history of taxonomic classification (Khajuria and Agrawal 1979), a recent genetic study supports the classification of Trachypithecus barbei as a monotypic species distinct from the similar, and closely related, T. obscurus (Geissmann et al. 2004, Osterholz et al. 2008). Evidently, there are a few rather well-defined morphs associated with this species, though no actual subspecies. Two morphs are identified in this species namely the silvery argenteus and ashy-grey holotephreus. T. barbei is of the obscurus-group which includes T. obscurus, T. crepusculus and T. phayrei. It is sympatric with T. germaini.

Seven subspecies are currently recognized: Trachypithecus obscurus carbo, T. o. flavicauda, T. o. halonifer, T. o. obscurus, T. o. sanctorum, T. o. seimundi, and T. o. styx. It may be that the blackish insular subspecies (carbo, halonifer, seimundi, styx) represent a distinct taxon which has been entirely replaced on the mainland by the contrastingly toned T. obscurus.
Originally included in Trachypithecus pileatus, T. shortridgei was recognised as a separate species by Groves (2001).

Africa's most recently discovered (2003) and described (2006) genus of monkey (Davenport et al. 2006). Originally allocated to the genus Lophocebus (Jones et al. 2005), but later placed in the monotypic genus Rungwecebus by Davenport et al. (2006) on the basis of molecular and morphological data. The genus to which R. kipunji belongs was questioned by Ehardt and Butynski (2006), but considerable further evidence supports the phylogenetic position and taxonomic status of Rungwecebus (Olson et al. 2008, Roberts et al. 2009). The evolutionary implications of Rungwecebus being a sister taxon to Papio are considerable (Olson et al. 2008, Davenport 2013).

First collected from sites in SE Tanzania (near Newala, Makonde Plateau, in 1953, and Rondo Plateau in 1955) and provisionally identified by R.W. Hayman (in litt.) as Demidoff’s galago Galago demidovii and later Galago demidovii orinus (Jenkins 1987, Honess 1996) due to its small size and morphology. First recognised and described as a species, based on differences in vocalisations and morphology by Honess and Bearder (1996) and subsequently accepted by Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003).

A phylogenetic analysis of the lorisiform primates by Pozzi et al. (2015) showed that Galagoides demidoff and G. thomasi comprise a clade entirely separate from the remaining species currently placed in the genus Galagoides: G. rondoensis, G. orinus, G. zanzibaricus, G. cocos and G. granti. This latter group is sister to Galago É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire 1796, with the two lineages diverging about 15 mya, and has been attributed to a separate genus Paragalago Masters et al. 2017. Galagoides is now restricted to the western forms: demidoff (G. Fischer, 1806), thomasi (Elliot, 1907), and kumbirensis Svensson, Bersacola, Mills, Munds, Nijman, Perkin, Masters, Couette, Nekaris and Bearder, 2017.

This taxon is monotypic (Geissman et al. 2002; T. Geissmann pers. comm.). Although it as been suggested that there is evidence for two genetically distinct Javan gibbon populations (Andayani et al. 2001), a review of the molecular evidence and a comparison of morphological and vocal data casts doubt on this claim (Geissman et al. 2002, Dallmann and Geissmann 2009, T. Geissmann pers. comm.).

This species forms a narrow area of sympatry and hybridization with H. lar in Khao Yai National Park, Thailand (Brockelman 1978, Brockelman and Gittins 1984, Marshall and Brockelman 1986, Marshall and Sugardjito 1986), specifically in the headwaters of the Takhong-Mun-Mekong River system (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). Until at least 1925, an area of sympatry apparently existed in the region of Sriracha, about 80 km southeast of Bangkok. Therefore, a large zone of overlap in the distribution of the two species may originally have existed. In most parts of this hypothetical zone, gibbon habitat appears to have been destroyed, with the Khao Yai Park possibly representing the last remnant of the once large contact zone (Geissmann 1991).

This taxon was traditionally classified as a subspecies of H. agilis, but Groves (2001) proposed it be considered a distinct species based on diagnostic pelage characteristics. Subsequent cytogenetic and molecular genetic analyses confirm the separation between H. agilis on Sumatra and H. albibarbis on Borneo (Hirai et al. 2005, 2009). H. albibarbis hybridizes with H. muelleri in a wide area of central Borneo (Marshall and Sugardjito 1986; Mather 1992, 1999).

This species forms a narrow area of sympatry and hybridization with H. pileatus in Khao Yai National Park, central Thailand (Brockelman 1978; Brockelman and Gittins 1984; Marshall and Brockelman 1986; Marshall and Sugardjito 1986), and with H. agilis in northern Peninsular Malaysia (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). Until at least 1925, an area of sympatry apparently existed in the region of Sriracha, about 80 km southeast of Bangkok. Therefore, a large zone of overlap in the distribution of H. lar and H. pileatus may originally have existed. In most parts of this hypothetical zone, gibbon habitat appears to have been destroyed, with the Khao Yai Park possibly representing the last remnant of the once large contact zone (Geissmann 1991). These zones demonstrate that reproductive isolation between the species is incomplete, although they do not freely interbreed in the wild where they are in contact (Brockelman and Gittins 1984).

The subspecies of Hylobates lar, although numerous and well-distributed latitudinally, are not highly distinct, in general. They are based largely on relatively minor body color variation and the degree of polychromatism of the fur (Brockelman 1985, 2004; Groves 2001; Woodruff 2005) The validity of H. l. yunnanensis as a subspecies is doubtful; it requires comparison with H. l. carpenteri (C. Groves and T. Geissmann pers. comm.). The only geographically well-separated subspecies is H. l. vestitus, which is found on Sumatra; despite its (relatively recent) isolation, however, it is not highly distinct phenotypically (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). The taxonomic status of all the H. lar subspecies, and specifically yunnanensis, requires further investigation.
Genetic and vocal data suggested little difference in population across the islands and, therefore, Hylobates klossii is considered monotypic.

There is debate as to the validity of the subspecies. The general consensus seems to be that this species is monotypic (Hirai et al. 2009; Roos et al. 2014), though some experts recognize two subspecies on Sumatra: H. a. agilis to the west, and H. a. unko to the east (these may possibly correspond with "mountain" and "lowland" forms, respectively). All this is not to be confused with the two main color morphs found throughout the species' range, though in general the pale morph is more common in the Barisan Range of Sumatra, while in the eastern lowlands and in the Malay Peninsula black predominates (Marshall and Sugardjito 1986).

The mainland (Symphalangus syndactylus continentis) and Sumatran (Symphalangus syndactylus syndactylus) forms have been considered distinct subspecies; however, no subspecies are recognized in the most recent Asian primate taxonomy by Roos et al. (2014).

This taxon is now considered monotypic; it was formerly considered conspecific with Hoolock leuconedys. The previous generic name, Bunopithecus, was changed by Mootnick and Groves (2005) to Hoolock (Haimoff et al. 1984).
This taxon is monotypic; it was formerly considered a subspecies of H. hoolock. The previous generic name, Bunopithecus, was changed by Mootnick and Groves (2005) to Hoolock (Haimoff et al. 1984).

Previously four subspecies were recognised (N. c. concolor, N. c. furvogaster, N. c. jingdongensis and N. c. lu) (Ma and Wang 1986), however N. c. furvogaster of south-western Yunnan, west of Mekong River and N. c. jingdonensis of west central Yunnan, China are now considered synonomous with the nominate form while N. c. lu is recognised as a valid subspecies (Thinh et al 2010a,b).

This taxon was variously considered a subspecies of N. concolor, N. leucogenys and N. gabriellae. It was believed that N. siki might be a natural hybrid of N. leucogenys and N. gabriellae but this is due to missing information in the past. Genetic and acoustic data clearly show that this taxon is a valid species (Thinh et al. 2010a, Thinh et al. 2010b, Thinh et al. 2011).

The recent discovery of N. annamensis and the extended southward distribution of N. leucogenys have largely reduced the distribution of the species. The limits of distribution of this species are not finally settled, both with regards to N. annamensis in the south and N. leucogenys in the north. Similarly, phenotype information for the type locality of N. siki (Thua Luu, Thua Thien Hue province, central Viet Nam) is contradictory (Geissmann et al. 2000; Thinh et al. 2010b). Though the holotype represents N. siki morphologically, the type locality falls in the range of N. annamensis (Thinh et al. 2010a). Recent genetic data of the N. siki holotype clearly confirm that this specimen is N. siki (C. Roos pers. comm.). Unfortunately, information about whether Jean Delacour and Pierre Jabouille collected the specimen in the wild near Thua Luu or whether they obtained the gibbon at a market or from a poacher is not traceable. However, since Thua Luu is close to the coast and along the Vietnamese national railway line and the national road no. 1, and considering the morphology and genetic data of the holotype, the specimen most likely originated from a place other than Thua Luu.

This taxon was previously considered a subspecies of N. concolor (Groves 1972). The limits of the distribution of this species are from Ba River, 13°00’-13°10’N in Gia Lai and Phu Yen provinces and Sre Pok River in North to Nui Ong Nature Reserve in 11°01’N in Binh Thuan Province in South, and South East Cambodia (East of Mekong River). Populations that occurs south of Thach Han River in central Viet Nam, southern Lao and northeastern Cambodia differ in their song from N. gabriellae in the south (e.g. Konrad and Geissmann 2006) and was separated from N. gabriellae as a distinct species, namely N. annamensis (Thinh et al. 2010).

Previously, Nomascus hainanus was variously considered either a species in its own right or as a subspecies of N. concolor or N. nasutus; it is here recognized as a distinct species based on molecular, vocalization and pelage differences (Geissmann et al. 2000; Mootnick 2006; Roos and Nadler 2005; Roos et al. 2007; Thinh et al. 2010, 2011).

Nomascus nasutus has been variously considered either as a species in its own right (sometimes as conspecific with N. hainanus), or as a subspecies of N. concolor; it is here recognized as a species distinct from N. hainanus and N. concolor, based on differences in vocalizations and fur colouration as well as genetic evidence (Mootnick and Fan 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010, 2011; Feng et al. 2014).

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang, but was elevated to species level by Roos (2003) and Chen et al. (2006). See also Nekaris and Jaffe (2007). The smallest of the Indonesian slow lorises (350 g-600 g), it is not only distinguished genetically from the others, but also by its pale golden to red fur, virtual lack of markings on its head, and consistent absence of a second upper incisor (Groves 1971, 1998; Ravosa 1998; Chen et al. 2006; Nekaris and Jaffe 2007). Nycticebus menagensis is very pale with a light contrasting facemask and round or diffuse-edged upper circumocular patch.
