Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). Additional analyses identify phenotypic and genetic differentiation consistent with proposed Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs), and support the status of Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki as separate species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Atelopus zeteki distribution is limited to the vicinity of El Valle de Anton and Cerro Campana.
The identity of a record from Limón, Costa Rica (see Savage 2002) is uncertain (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Incilius peripatetes following the split of the broader concept into this and Incilius majordomus (Savage et al. 2013).

Ecuadorian records have been allocated to "Anomaloglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) confusus (Myers and Grant 2009). 

Panamanian records have been allocated to "Anomaglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) isthminus and "Anomaloglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) astralogaster by Myers et al. (2012).

Since its description, the identity of this species has been debated, being frequently confused with other Central and South American dendrobatoid species (Savage 1968, Grant 2004), a confusion complicated by the loss of the type specimen (Barbour and Noble 1920, Savage 1968). As summarized in Ibáñez et al. (2017), Savage (1968) designated a female specimen (National Museum of Natural History specimen USNM 50198) collected from Cana (= Santa Cruz de Cana), Darién Province, Panama as the neotype. Grant (2004) examined museum specimens from the Serranía de Pirre that agreed with the neotype and concluded that the neotype was probably collected from the highlands above Cana. It is doubtful whether or not the lost Colombian holotype of Colostethus latinasus was conspecific with the Panamanian neotype and specimens that agree with the neotype have yet to be found in Colombia (Grant 2004).

The taxonomic relationship between Gastrotheca cornuta and G. ceratophrys needs to be clarified (L.A. Coloma pers. comm. 2007). It is possible that the specimen collected from Manta Real, Ecuador, represents a new species (A. Almendáriz pers. comm. 2007). Overall, while there appear to be variations between the Central American and South American individuals, Duellmann (2015) noted that they are insufficiently distinguished based on physical characteristics alone and that no clear pattern exists between the variations.

This is a restricted concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus following the split of the broader concept into this, H. kaylockae, H. panamensis, and H. elioti (Hill et al. 2018).

Trueb (1974) highlighted the uncertainty of the type locality, presumably from somewhere in Ecuador. According to Hill et al. (2018), a specimen of Hemiphractus cf. fasciatus (KU 200261) from Nariño province, Colombia, does not appear to match the holotype of H. fasciatus. It is possible that this specimen does not represent H. fasciatus, and there is uncertainty surrounding its taxonomic status.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). A re-evaluation of the taxonomic status of this "subspecies" of I. pseudopuma, strongly suggested that this taxon should be recognized as a full species based on morphological differences described by Duellman (2001). A molecular study by Faivovich et al. (2018) confirmed that the species is genetically well-distinct from I. pseudopuma and warrants its status as a full species.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was later moved to the genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) found a high genetic diversity among different specimens. It is doubtful that the subpopulations between Monteverde in Costa Rica and western Panama are the same species (A. Hertz pers. comm. June 2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005).
Genetic analysis has revealed potential cryptic lineages within this species (Crawford et al. 2013), however, further taxonomic work is required for verification.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus rugulosus (Campbell and Savage 2000).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Records from Colombia required taxonomic verification (B. Gratwicke pers. comm. May 2018).

The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. Genetic analysis suggests that this species may be conspecific with Bolitoglossa biseriata, however, further work is required for verification (A. Batista pers. comm. August 2019).
There may be more than one distinct species within this taxon, but this needs to be verified through taxonomic research (Hertz 2015, Panama Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
It is possible that this species is a complex, with at least three distinct species in Panama (Hertz 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken, Wake and Savage 2005).

authority: Mendelson, Savage, Griffith, Ross, Kubicki & Gagliardo, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Ecnomiohyla veraguensis.
There is an ongoing debate on the genus placement of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Ptychohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was subsequently moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The form occurring in El Salvador and Honduras is considered a separate species, Plectrohyla psiloderma (McCranie and Wilson 1999a).
Juvenile specimens collected from the eastern part of the Sierra de las Minas (MVZ collection) are not thought to belong to this species (J. Campbell pers. comm. August 2019).
The forms that occur in Honduras have been separated to form the species Plectrohyla exquisita (McCranie and Wilson 1998).
This species was removed from synonymy of Ptychohyla euthysanota by Campbell and Smith (1992).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Quilticohyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Additional taxonomic work is needed to decisively confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Further taxonomic studies are needed to confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.)
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Craugastor gutschei (McCranie 2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species requires taxonomic revision (M. Acevedo pers. comm. August 2019).
The subpopulations from the Sierra de Chuacus may represent a distinct species of uncertain taxonomic affinity (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2007).

Specimens obtained from Finca Planada de Margot on the eastern side of the Sierra de Las Minas were previously reported to all represent B. helmrichi, but have now been determined to represent both B. helmrichi and B. zacapensis (Rovito et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of Bolitoglossa meliana following the split of the broader concept into this and B. tenebrosa (Vázquez-Almazán and Rovito 2014).
This species was originally confused with Bolitoglossa striatula.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision, and it is likely that the distribution of this species will be restricted in the future (Townsend et al. in review March 2019).

Cryptotriton xucaneborum was confused with this species prior to its naming. This is a restricted concept following the recognition of Cryptotriton xucaneborum as a separate species, thereby removing localities within the Sierra de Xucaneb (Rovito et al. 2015).

Both Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were included within Dendrotriton rabbi in the past; however, this species is now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010). There may be an undescribed species within this species concept (C. Vásquez Almazán pers. comm. August 2019).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nototriton nelsoni and N. oreadorum (Townsend 2016).

The taxonomy of this species is confused (Wake pers. comm.). The Brodie et al. (2012) descriptions of Oedipina chortiorum and O. tzutujilorum from Guatemala calls into question the identity of the Honduran salamanders previously identified as O. ignea. There appear to be discrete differences between the salamanders from mesic broadleaf forest in Ocotepeque and those from open pine forests in Intibucá and La Paz (McCranie pers. obs.). Further morphological and genetic study of the Guatemalan topotypic O. chortiorum and those of the Honduran Intibucá and La Paz subpopulations (ca. O. ignea) would likely reveal that either the Ocotepeque subpopulations or those from Intibucá and La Paz need a new name. Another nominal form to consider in this problem is the Brodie et al. (2012) description of O. tzutujilorum from a mesic broadleaf forest on the Pacific versant of Guatemala (McCranie 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Recently separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).
Craugastor chingopetaca can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Köhler and Sunyer 2006).

Separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).

Further taxonomic studies are needed to better understand the relationship between this species and Incilius epioticus (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species represents a population previously assigned to Cryptotriton veraepacis (Vásquez Almazán et al. 2009).

Subpopulations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).

authority: Sunyer, Lotzkat, Hertz, Wake, Aléman, Robleto & Köhler, 2008
Sunyer, Lotzkat, Hertz, Wake, Aléman, Robleto & Köhler, 2008
Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Likely previously confused with Oedipina taylori, according to the original publication (Brodie et al. 2012).

Recently-discovered museum specimens from Peru exhibit minor differences in scalation from typical Ecuadorian Bothrops lojanus. These do not correspond to diagnostic characters identified in the original description of B. lojanus, and "in the absence of additional information" Carrasco et al. (2016) opin that these do not warrant the recognition of Peruvian specimens as a different species. These authors did not however conduct any integrative analysis to demonstrate that the Peruvian and Ecuadorian populations are conspecific, and multiple biogeographic barriers within the intervening area - and the trans-Andean distribution the Peruvian records imply - suggests that while they are closely-related they may not belong to the same species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2019).

Maximum likelihood analysis of a combined morphological and allozyme dataset confirmed that, as suggested by Thomas (1997), Pseudalsophis slevini sensu stricto is endemic to Pinzon island and is more closely-related to P. steindachneri than to populations from the  western islands Fernandina, Isabella and Tortuga (Zaher et al. 2018). Zaher et al. (2018) described the western form as the new species P. darwini.

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Jeremčenko and Panilov (1999) elevated Phrynocephalus helioscopus saidalievi to specific rank, and this has subsequently been followed by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) and Solovyeya et al. (2014). While Solovyeva et al. (2011) considered this action premature, the lead author's later molecular work concluded that "Genetic isolation of Ph. h. saidalievi from other subspecies is considerable (p = 9.53%– 10.29%) and comparable with the species level of differentiation" (Solovyeva et al. 2014). The subspecies P. s. takirnoy has been described from northern Tajikistan; its validity is unclear and has apparently rarely been referenced in literature.

Some Vietnamese specimens previously referred to M. annamensis have recently been described as a separate species, M. marmorata (Bain and Nguyen 2004), and the Ha Tinh, Thai, and Cambodian specimens should be compared to M. annamensis, M. pulverata, and M. marmorata for confirmation of identity.
Micrurus mertensi and M. catamayensis may be synonyms (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014). Micrurus peruvianus may also be part of this clade.

authority: Zachariah, Dinesh, Kunhikrishnan, Das, Raju, Radhakrishnan, Palot & Kalesh, 2011
Zachariah, Dinesh, Kunhikrishnan, Das, Raju, Radhakrishnan, Palot & Kalesh, 2011
Zachariah, Dinesh, Kunhikrishnan, Das, Raju, Radhakrishnan, Palot & Kalesh, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species is poorly-studied as it was recently-described from a largely inaccessible region based on a limited number of characters (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). It appears to belong to the taxonomically complex Liolaemus elongatus-kriegi group, within which species delimitation is in need of further study (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). Medina et al. (2017) provided support for the continued recognition of L. carlosgarini. In common with earlier work by Medina (2015) these authors found, however, that haplotypes within this species were shared between L. carlosgarini and other species, and that the species showed no clear molecular differentiation from L. smaug or from an undescribed candidate species.

Langstroth (2011) found that specimens attributed to Liolaemus reichei from near Tacna in Peru were instead attributable to L. poconchilensis, extending the range of this species into southern Peru and confining L. reichei (which this author synonymized with L. stolzmanni) to northern Chile.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) consider Phymaturus dorsimaculatus to be a junior synonym of P. vociferator, in which case this species would also occur in the Province of Neuquén, Argentina (Avila et al. 2013); however, Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy and their scheme is followed here. M. Vidal (pers. comm. 2016) notes that no studies have been conducted that demonstrate this proposed synonymy. While Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) referred to previous work suggesting that the two taxa may be conspecific based on overlap between morphological traits (Pincheira-Donoso 2004), these authors provided no new data to support this conclusion and so the systematics of these taxa remains unresolved.
Rivero and Serna (1993 "1991") doubted that specimens from Valle del Cauca, Colombia, were correctly assigned to this species.

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Grismer, Wood, Jr., Mohamed, Chan, Heinz, Sumarli, Chan & Loredo, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Gastrotheca monticola by Duellman et al. (2014), which is restricted to Peru.
Information from faunal surveys indicates that the Masbate subpopulations which have been synonymized with this species still need to be re-examined.
This is a species complex comprised of at least two evolutionary lineages (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

Due to observed morphological, bioacoustic and ecological differences, subpopulations of this species between 300-600 m asl are thought to belong to Platymantis polillensis (Siler et al. 2011), although this needs to be verified.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hylarana luzonensis by Brown et al. (2000), and it was subsequently moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).
This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Philautus juliandringi (Dehling 2010).

This is a restricted concept of Philautus everetti (as Rhacophorus everetti) following the split of the broader concept into this and Philautus macroscelis by Hertwig et al. (2012) and genetic evidence showed unequivocally that it belongs to Philautus.

authority: Nuñez, Veloso, Espejo, Veloso, Cortes & Araya, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Was under Iguanidae.

Records presently assigned to this species from Argentina are very unlikely to represent this species, as the Argentinian and Chilean populations are separated by mountains up to 5,000 m high, and the Argentinian records are themselves from valleys more than 400 km from one another (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). Resolution of this issue is complicated as the few known Argentinian specimens are poorly-preserved (L. Avila pers. obs.). For the purposes of this assessment L. gravenhorstii is considered to be endemic to Chile.
A taxonomic review to resolve the status of the species complex is needed (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

This species was tentatively assigned to the Hypsiboas punctatus group in the original publication, diagnosed by its morphological, ecological and advertisement call features (Kok 2006); it was previously moved to the genus Boana by Dubois (2017), and has now been moved to Myersiohyla by Pinheiro et al. (2018).

This species was formerly classified in a distinct genus as Przewalskium albirostris, however, morphological, behavioural and genetic analyses align this species with the Red Deer clade (Wilson and Mittermeier 2011). No subspecies are recognized.

This is a well defined species (Grubb 1982, 2005; Groves et al. 1995). The form sifanicus was included in M. moschiferus as a subspecies by Ellerman and Morrison-Scott (1951) and considered an independent species by Gao (1963). However, Groves et al. (1995) included it in M. chrysogaster as subspecies. The chrysogaster of Cai and Feng (1981) is subspecifically or specifically distinct, and the available name for this taxon may be leucogaster Hodgson, 1839 (Groves et al. 1995, Grubb 2005). Some Chinese authors continue to recognize M. sifanicus as a full species (e.g., Yang et al. 2003, Zhou et al. 2004).

Currently, two subspecies are recognized in China:

1) M. c. chrysogaster (Hodgson, 1839) in southeastern and southern Tibet;
2) M. c. sifanicus (Büchner, 1891) in Qinghai, Gansu, Ningxia, western Sichuan and northwestern Yunnan.

There does not appear to be documentation of a clear delineation between these two forms.

Moschus saturatus Hodgson, 1839 may be a prior name for this species. Gao (1985) treated fuscus as a subspecies of M. chrysogaster, i.e. M. chrysogaster fuscus. But Groves et al. (1995) considered it as valid species; Su et al. (2001) demonstrated its phylogenetic status as a valid species by analysis of Cytochrome b.

This species was revised by Sokolov and Prikhod'ko (1997, 1997-1998). Five subspecies are currently recognized: M. m. moschiferus (Siberia and Mongolia); M. m. turovi (Russian Far East); M. m. arcticus (Verkhoyansk Ridge); M. m. sachalinensis (Sakhalin); and M. m. parvipes (Korea). M. chrysogaster (Central China) and M. leucogaster (Himalayas) are now treated as separate species (Sokolov and Prikhod'ko 1997, 1997-1998).

This taxon is sometimes treated as a Himalayan subspecies of Alpine Musk Deer M. chrysogaster (e.g. Grubb 1990), but it was separated by Groves and Grubb (1987) and by Groves et al. (1995) on the basis of different skull proportions.

This taxon was recently separated by Meijaard and Groves (2004) as a species distinct from Tragulus napu, in agreement with Sanborn (1952) and Rabor (1977). The population of Pulau Bangi (Malaysia), which lies mid-way between Balabac and the Bornean mainland, and which was almost certainly (and perhaps repeatedly) connected to both by former (late Pleistocene) land bridges (Heaney 1986), might belong to this species and requires further taxonomic studies.
This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Moschus berezovskii and Moschus moschiferus, but is now regarded as a valid species (see Li et al. 1999, Su et al. 2001ab)

This species was originally described as a subspecies of Alpine Musk Deer M. chrysogaster. It is very similar to Himalayan Musk Deer M. leucogaster, but Groves et al. (1995) suggested that it might be a separate species, a course followed by Grubb (2005) and it is so treated here.

This species was synonymized with Brookesia minima by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995) but later resurrected (Schimmenti and Jesu 1996, Glaw et al. 1999). The taxonomy of the B. minima group is in need of revision and the distribution of all species needs to be re-evaluated following thorough morphometric and molecular studies.
Genetic data indicate that Eleutherodactylus principalis is nested within one of the four lineages of E. auriculatus and a thorough taxonomic revision of this group is needed (Rodríguez et al. 2010).

Taxonomy of Cuban bromeliad frogs need to be revisited since populations of Eleutherodactylus ionthus and E. guantanamera could be confused at some localities; thus, even distributions must be reassessed in the future. The advertisement call as it was originally described is difficult to distinguish between both species (L.M. Díaz pers. comm. 2020). Colouration pattern is not a completely diagnostic character for these and other species of the E. varians group (Díaz and Cádiz 2008).
Some historic records of Eleutherodactylus pinarensis might refer to juveniles of E. klinikowskii, and so are not included here (L. Díaz pers. comm.).
This is a restricted concept of Eleutherodactylus zugi following the split of the broader concept into this and E. erythroproctus (Hedges et al. 2008).

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: It was thought that the species was probably also found in parts of Bolivia, but taxonomic studies suggest that Bolivian populations may well represent undescribed species, as allopatric speciation may be prevalent in this group of rare and habitat-restricted lizards (Rodrigues et al. 2007, 2008) .

H. castaneus and H. constellatus were recognized as recently diverged and distinct species by Greenbaum et al. (2013). The subspecies H. c. submarginatus from the Kabobo Plateau was transferred to the synonymy of H. constellatus, but the status of the unsampled subspecies H. c. rhodogaster, described from mid-elevations of the western Itombwe Plateau, remains problematic (Greenbaum et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999).

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1990), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.
Jiang, Hu and Zhao (1987) considered this species to belong to the genus Buergeria, rather than Rhacophorus, and this is now widely accepted.
Amolops daiyunensis was considered a synonym of A. hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei et al. (1999), Jin et al. (2005) and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.
Amolops liangshanensis was assessed in 2004 as a separate species, but is now considered to be a synonym of A. loloensis  (Lu et al. 2014, Zhang 2015, Lyu et al. 2019).
This is a restricted concept of this species which excludes subpopulations which are now assigned to other segregate species in the Amolops monticola group (Patel et al. 2021).
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
Although originally described as a subspecies of Xenophrys minor, this taxon was treated as a full species by Delorme et al. (2006).
This is a restricted concept of Rana longicrus following the split of the broader concept into this and R. jiemuxiensis (Yan et al. 2011).
Hynobius yunanicus has been synonymized with this species by Xiong et al. (2007).
This is a restricted concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus following the split of the broader concept into this and Pseudohynobius jinfo (Wei et al. 2009).

Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus was considered to be a synonym of this species by Zhao and Hu (1983) and Zhao and Wu (1995), but is considered a valid species by Ye et al. (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).
Inger et al. (1990) considered Oreolalax puxiongensis to be synonymous with O. schmidti.
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Oreolalax major but did not give any reason.
Zhao and Adler (1993) regarded this species to be synonymous with Scutiger ruginosus (= S. mammatus) without discussion.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pachytriton granulosus and Pachytriton inexpectatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011). Paramesotriton ermizhaoi has also been synonymised with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2011).
We consider Cynops chenggongensis to be separate from C. cyanurus, following Zhao and Adler (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).
This is a restricted concept of this species following Hypselotriton yunnanensis being removed from synonymy by Dubois and Raffaëll (2012).
Rana multidenticulata has been synonymized under this species by Hsu et al. (2011).
There is a nomenclatural problem with this species, and the name might change (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Tylototriton pulcherrima has been synonymized with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2013).
The Yuexi subpopulation of Tylotriton wenxianensis has been described as T. anhuiensis according to Qian et al. (2017).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
Inger et al. (1990) regarded this taxon as a junior synonym of Batrachuperus pinchonii. It was removed from the synonymy of B. pinchonii by Ye et al. (1993).
This species was first described by Tian, Gu, Sun and Li (1998), who are the valid authors of this species. It was redescribed by Tian, Li and Gu (2006).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species is endemic to China and records of this species from Tibet are in fact Nanorana chayuensis (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Quasipaa courtoisi, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Dubois and Ohler 2009).

This species requires further taxonomic work as it may be a species complex (Yu et al. 2016).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nanorana sichuanensis and the revalidation of N. phrynoides (Huang et al. 2016). Nanorana bourreti has been synonymized with this species (Che et al. 2009, Chen et al. 2011, Huang et al. 2016).
Available information (Bourret 1942) indicates that this taxon closely resembles Rhacophorus verrucosus.

authority: Taylor, Stoffberg, Monadjem, Schoeman, Bayliss & Cotterill, 2012
taxonomicNotes: In previous Red List assessments (2008), this species was included within Rhinolophus hildebrandtii. Taxonomic changes, based on molecular systematics and differences in morphology, echolocation call frequencies and biogeography, have taken place within the R. hildebrandtii complex. R. hildebrandtii was revised in 2012 (Taylor et al. 2012) and R. cohenae recognised as one of the four newly described species from this species complex.

authority: Taylor, Stoffberg, Monadjem, Schoeman, Bayliss & Cotterill, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This species formerly was included in Rhinolophus hildebrandtii, but acoustic, biogeographical, morphological and molecular data show it to be a distinct species (Taylor et al. 2012).

authority: Schargel, Rivas, Makowsky, Señaris, Natera, Barros, Molina & Barrio-Amorós, 2010

taxonomicNotes: The Maud Island population was previously considered to belong to this species, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). However, Holyoake et al. (2001) considered them to be evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences, although no formal taxonomic change was made as a result of this study. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.

This species was previously considered to belong to L. hamiltoni, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). There is ongoing discussion over the taxonomic status of these two species, which were subsequently declared evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences (Holyoake et al. 2001) although no formal taxonomic changes were made. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.
This species is genetically and morphologically distinct from the closely related Neoromicia brunnea (Monadjem et al. 2013).
This form might be confused with Gephyromantis thelenae, G. blanci and G. leucocephalus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
This species occurs in sympatry with Gephyromantis eiselti from which it is distinguished mainly by its call, so museum records might confuse these two species (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).
This species' taxonomy is unclear.
Was under Iguanidae.

authority: Ndriantsoa, Riemann, Vences, Klages, Raminosoa, Rödel & Glos, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Originally described as Mantella pollicaris by Boettger (1913), and later synonymized with Anodonthyla boulengerii (Noble and Parker 1926). Removed from this synonymy by Vences et al. (2010) on the basis of molecular and acoustic data.

authority: Penny, Andreone, Crottini, Holderied, Rakotizafy, Schwitzer & Rosa, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Castro and Tobar-González (2014) suggested there may be differences between high-elevation and low-elevation populations of this species on Cantillana, but had access only to lower-elevation specimens that agree with their recently-collected specimen.

Liolaemus stolzmanni is a member of a poorly-characterized radiation of species whose systematics have long been complicated by restricted access to the remote areas where these lizards occur (Langstroth 2011). Confusion has surrounded the correct attribution of records from northern Chile and adjacent regions of Argentina, Bolivia and Peru) to either Liolaemus stolzmanni or Liolaemus reichei, the oldest available names for taxa from this region, due to inadequacies in or misunderstandings of the original descriptions by subsequent authors (Langstroth 2011). This situation was further complicated by the descriptions of multiple additional taxa from Chile, Peru and Bolivia, with several specimens previously reported as L. reichei being properly attributable to L. poconchilensis and Bolivian material described as L. stolzmanni having been referred to L. pachecoi (Langstroth 2011). Examining photographs of the type series of L. stolzmanni, Langstroth (2011) synonymized L. reichei (as now understood, a species restricted to northern Chile) with this older name and proposed emending the type locality from "Hoch-Peru" to "Deserts of Iquique, Tarapaca Region, Chile", on the basis that this species is not known to occur anywhere within the territory of modern Peru and indeed appears to be endemic to this area of northern Chile.
We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016), and retain this species as Litoria as per Menzies and Riyanto (2015) and Frost et al. (2006).
Brown (1965) described two subspecies within Platymantis parkeri: P. p. parkeri from Bougainville; and P. p. bukanensis from Buka.

The subspecies Alsophis antiguae sajdaki is thought by some to represent a full species (Hedges et al. 2009), which would render A. antiguae extinct. There is however evidence against this proposition from a study of more than 400 live specimens from Great Bird Island which concluded that, apart from some geographical variation in ventral counts, the proposed diagnostic characters represented sexual dimorphism. On this basis this account considers that A. antiguae is still extant, represented by the surviving form A. a. sadjaki (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2010, 2015).

There are currently two recognized subspecies:
A. hyporissor hyporissor
A. hyporissor leberi.

This species has two subspecies: A. sanctonum sanctonum Barbour, 1915 and A. s. danforthi Cochran, 1938. Zaher et al. (2009) recognized A. danforthi as a distinct, separate species, but this was a broad molecular treatment of advanced snakes with an emphasis on South America and did not provide detailed justification for this assignment. The subspecific arrangement has been retained by subsequent authors (Wallach et al. 2014) and is preferred pending a phenotypic and genetic review of snakes from Iles des Saintes (R. Gomes pers. comm. 2019).

Two subspecies are recognized:
S. torrei spielmani Grant, 1958
S. torrei torrei Barbour, 1914.

Two subspecies are recognized:

Sphaerodactylus streptophorus sphenophanes Thomas & Schwartz 1983
Sphaerodactylus streptophorus streptophorus Thomas & Schwartz 1977

Helgen et al. (2009) suggested that two different species were previously considered as 'Mountain Coati' N. olivacea; one endemic to Colombia and Ecuador, N. olivacea, and one restricted to Venezuela, N. meridensis.

Mivart (1890) distinguished two species of Cuon, the northern Dhole (C. alpinus) and the southern Dhole (C. javanicus), based on differences in body size and the second upper and second lower molars. Dholes were later recognized as a single species (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1966), but separated into as many as 11 subspecies based on differences in coat length and colour (Durbin et al. 2004). The validity of many of these subspecies is doubtful, and a genetics study found no clear subspecies distinctions (Iyengar et al. 2005). However, samples used by Iyengar et al. (2005) came exclusively from the southern half of the Dhole distribution, so the genetic distinctiveness between northern and southern Dholes remains unknown. Examination of the auditory bulla showed at least one northern subspecies, from the Tian Shan Mountains, to be morphologically distinct from other subspecies (Ivanoff 2007). Further research is needed to clarify the morphological and genetic differences between northern and southern dholes, especially because conservation efforts would need to employ different strategies for the two groups, as they occupy vastly different habitats and prey on different species.

The putative northern-Dhole group historically occurred throughout East Asia to as far south as the Himalayan Mountains and the Yangtze River, and would include the following five subspecies described by Durbin et al. (2004): C. a. alpinus, C. a. primaevus, C. a. laniger, C. a. hesperius, and C. a. fumosus. The putative southern-dhole group would include the remaining six subspecies described by Durbin et al. (2004): C. a. lepturus, C. a. dukhumensis, C. a. adjustus, C. a. infuscus, C. a. sumatrensis, and C. a. javanicus. Within the southern-Dhole group, Iyengar et al. (2005) found two major phylogeographic genetic groupings on the mainland, and stated that the subspecific status of Dholes on Sumatra and Java was unclear and requires further study.
This species was originally described from pre-Hispanic and subfossil remains. It was subsequently discovered alive (Wetzel et al. 1975; Wetzel 1977a, b, 1981).

Bawean Deer has sometimes been included in Hog Deer Axis porcinus (Haltenorth 1963), but is better considered a full species (Groves and Grubb 1987, Grubb 2005). With Hog Deer it was often placed in the genus Cervus (e.g. Chasen 1940, van Bemmel 1944), until Groves and Grubb (1987) strongly argued for placement in Axis. The most recent analyses indicate that these two species, together with calamianensis, constitute a genus distinct from Axis, Hyelaphus (Meijaard and Groves 2004, Pitra et al. 2004). The species name is sometimes mis-spelled kuhli, but the correct original spelling, which must be used today, is kuhlii.
Gracixalus waza has been synonymised with this species (Nguyen et al. 2020).

authority: (Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014 )
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
(Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014)

taxonomicNotes: This species was split from the broader concept of Leptopelis modestus (Portillo and Greenbaum 2014). It is part of the Leptopelis modestus complex, together with a currently unnamed species, the sister taxon of Leptopelis modestus sensu stricto, according to the original publication.
This species was split from the higher elevations of Raorchestes tinniens (S.R. Chandramouli and S.R. Ganesh pers comm. October 2020).

This is a restricted concept of Hylarana temporalis following the split the broader concept into this and H. flavescens, H. intermedia and H. montana (Biju et al. 2014).

This species was moved from Hylarana to Indosylvirana by Oliver et al. (2015) and then back again to Hylarana by Dubois et al. (2021).
Biju et al. (2014) recognized the species as distinct from Indirana temporalis.

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Senevirathne & Meggaskumbara, 2014

taxonomicNotes: It is possible that there is another species existing under this concept in the northern Western Ghats (A.D. Padhye pers. comm. September 2020).

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Indosylvirana aurantiaca (Biju et al. 2014).

Chaitanya et al. (2018) assigned to Micrixalus cf. adonis specimens found in Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary, although precise recording sites were not provided and they are not included in the distribution map or extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work has been carried out.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Micrixalus sali (Biju et al. 2014). According to Biju et al. (2014), subpopulations from Siruvani and surrounding regions now belong to M. thampii.
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus nudis (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus saxicola (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split into this and Micrixalus herrei (Biju et al. 2014).
This species has been removed from the synonymy of Micrixalus fuscus (Biju et al. 2014).

Wallach et al. (2014) follow Henderson and Powell (2009) in recognizing Boa orophias and B. nebulosa as full species, however, some other authors (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2015) still treat both as subspecies of Boa constrictor.

Reynolds (2016) summarizes evidence from mitochondrial DNA and biogeography that Anolis ernestwilliamsi represents a very recent adaptation from the widespread Anolis cristatellus found on neighbouring islands. He suggests, based on evidence that the species exhibits a low or nonexistent level of ecological separation from a nearby population of A. cristatellus and that observed morphological differences are likely to reflect a combination of genetic drift and very recent adaptations to a non-natural substrate, that the Carrot Rock population is unlikely to be sufficiently divergent to justify continued recognition as a distinct species (Reynolds 2016 and refs therein).

This species has been treated as a subspecies of Leiocephalus carinatus, but is treated as a full species in recent literature (McCranie 2011, 2015, 2018; Hedges et al. 2019). McCranie (2018) notes that the species exhibits diagnostic features which do not overlap with other members of the L. carinatus group, supporting its recognition as a full species.

Hecht (1951) treated Aristelliger nelsoni as a subspecies of A. praesignis in a distribution map of the species' range but provided no supporting justification. This scheme has nonetheless been widely followed since, although distinct morphological differences between A. nelsoni and the nominate form were highlighted by Bauer and Russell (1993). McCranie (2018) corroborated this finding, and noted that the deep sea separating the Swan Islands from the Cayman Islands and Jamaica further supports the recognition of the two taxa as distinct species. This author recommended treating A. nelsoni as a full species pending molecular research to clarify its status, a recommendation that had previously been followed by Powell and Henderson (2012). On this basis, and noting that the proposed subspecific status has never been adequately justified, this account follows McCranie (2015, 2018) in treating A. nelsoni as a full species.

Records from Hellshire have been sequenced and identified as a separate, undescribed species (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), confirming that Tropidophis stullae is known only from Portland Ridge and likely to be endemic to this area.
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).
This is a new concept split from the broader concept of Barygenys exsul (Kraus 2013).

There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

Larsen et al. (2012) indicate that the historically recognized subspecies Myotis martiniquensis nyctor is genetically and morphologically distinct from M. martiniquensis, warranting recognition of a third Caribbean endemic, Myotis nyctor. Additional voucher specimens with genetic data are needed to test for a close genetic relationship between Myotis from Barbados and Grenada. If deemed conspecific, then the distribution of M. nyctor would include Grenada; however, the morphological distinctness of the Grenada population likely would warrant subspecific recognition (Larsen et al. 2012).
This species was recently found to belong in the genus Anhydrophryne rather than Arthroleptella (Dawood and Stam 2006).
A question hangs over the taxonomic significance of disjunct populations of this species (A. Channing pers. comm.).

Reports of this species occurring between Agulhas and Wilderness, the westernmost record of Sclerophrys pardalis (Minter et al. 2004) remain unconfirmed.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species is closely related to Afrixalus spinifrons (Cope 1862). Species boundaries in this complex are uncertain and taxonomic studies using calls, morphology and genetics are necessary.
The relationships between this and other species without toe discs requires a detailed taxonomic study using molecular and morphological methodologies.
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
A deep genetic split characterises the disjunct distribution of this species.

There are serious taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.
This is a restricted concept of A. opisthomelas following the split of the broader concept into this and A. cassidyhornae (Amézquita et al. 2013).

No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14781,"3":{"1":0,"3":1},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica Neue","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Bidau 2015).
The species needs taxonomic revision (O. Lessa pers. comm.)
Known as Tympanoctomys loschalchalerosorum (Dunnum 2015).

Originally described as Otomys typus, the taxonomy of this species is tenuous and requires further analysis (Taylor et al. 2011). Although placed in synonymy with O. orestes by Carleton and Byrne (2006), Taylor et al. (2011) considers O. thomasi provisionally to be a distinct species, based on the geographical barrier of the eastern Rift Valley, and morphological differences, such as observed size and colour.

Otomys thomasi is endemic to Kenya and occurs in Afro-alphine grasslands, scrubs and heathland at higher altitude. It has been recorded from higher elevation at the Mau escarpment (2 450-2700 m a.s.l) and the Uasin Gishu Plateau W of the Rift Valley (Monadjem et al., 2015, (Musila et al., 2018))

authority: Taylor, Lavrenchenko, Carleton, Verheyen, Bennett, Oosthuizen & Maree, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Previously described as Otomys typus, this species is the smallest representative from of the O. typus complex (Taylor et al. 2011) with a relatively short tail (Bryja et al. 2019). Although similar to O. simiensis, Yalden’s Vlei Rat can be distinguished by its smaller external and craniodental size (Taylor et al. 2011). Although, its phylogenetic position remains unresolved (Bryja et al. 2019), it is believed that the split between O. yaldeni and O. simiensis resulted from the division of the Ethiopian Plateau by the Great Ethiopian Rift Valley (Lavrenchenko and Bekele 2017).
This is a restricted concept of Crinia riparia following the split of the broader concept into this and Crinia flindersensis (Donnellan et al. 2012).

A genetic study by Donnellan (2008) identified a northern and southern lineage of this species that apparently meet in the Barrington Tops region of central coastal New South Wales. The divergence between these two lineages is greater than levels of divergence observed among other Mixophyes species (Donnellan 2008), which suggests the likelihood that more than one taxon currently exists within this species. Hunter and Gillespie (2011) recommend that "until this taxonomic issue is resolved, the northern and southern lineages of the Stuttering Frog should be given the highest level of conservation priority and managed independently".

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Litoria daviesae was separated from L. subglandulosa by Mahony et al. (2001).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Litoria watsoni (Mahony et al. 2020).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognized. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognized. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

There is currently uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species. It occurs in two disjunct isolates separated by 500 km, but the most recent taxonomic study by Thomson et al. (1996) suggests that they represent one species. More recently the genetic distinctness of this species from closely related Litoria species, in particular L. raniformis, is also being questioned and additional taxonomic research is required (Voros et al. 2010 in Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2019). For the purposes of this assessment, the species is considered to be valid and contain a northern and southern subpopulation, pending further taxonomic resolution.
The northern and southern populations could comprise different species (Penman et al. 2004, Hunter et al. 2018), but this requires further taxonomic research.

Zozaya and Hoskin (2015) discuss the taxonomic status of this species relative to Pseudophryne major, and recommend a phylogenetic analysis be done to resolve whether or not it may be a synonym of this wide ranging species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This is a restricted concept of Assa darlingtoni following the split of the broader concept into this and Assa wollumbin (Mahony et al. 2021). A. wollumbin is restricted to only one mountain, and the two species are separated by only about 15 km. The original description of A. wollumbin also includes some localities for which the identity of specimens are still uncertain. For this assessment they have been kept within Assa darlingtoni.

Litoria daviesae was separated from L. subglandulosa by Mahony et al. (2001).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Previously recognised as an outlying population of frogs in the Litoria phyllochroa group – specifically L. pearsoniana and L. barringtonensis (Hoskin et al. 2013).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Rulyrana saxiscandens, Cochranella croceopodes and Rulyrana tangarana are considered to be synonymous based on available morphological, bioacoustic, and phylogenetic evidence (Twomey et al. 2014). Under the Principle of the First Reviser of the ICZN (article 24.2.2) precedence is given to saxiscandens, rendering R. tangarana and C. croceopodes junior synonyms of R. saxiscandens.
This is a restricted concept of Batrachoseps relictus following the split of the broader concept into this and B. altasierrae (Jockusch et al. 2012).

Specimens from the Upper Kern River were originally assigned to Batrachoseps simatus by Brame and Murray (1968), who noted that there were morphological differences. Jockusch and Wake (2002) and Jennings (2004) treated these specimens as an undescribed lineage, until Jockusch et al. (2012) described them as B. bramei. Additionally, subpopulations from Breckenridge Mountain that were tentatively assigned to this species by Stebbins (1985) are now recognized as B. relictus (Jockusch et al. 2012).

Crossodactylus boulengeri was removed from the synonymy of this species and C. werneri was split from this species by Pimenta et al. (2014). A single specimen from 1961 in the Argentinean province of Misiones previously assigned to this species is now recognised as Crossodactylus schmidti (Pimenta et al. 2014, Ferraro et al. 2018). Records from Itatiaia in Pimenta et al. (2014) are now treated as belonging to C. werneri (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Rana luteiventris was previously included in this species before being elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyloxalus italoi and Hyloxalus yasuni (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010). Specimens from Colombia are provisionally assigned to this taxon pending future taxonomic revision to clarify their status.

The Kyushu populations formerly assigned to this species have now been described as new species; Hynobius amakusaensis, Hynobius osumiensis and Hynobius shinichisatoi by Nishikawa and Matsui 2014. Hynobius hirosei, from Shikoku, was removed from the synonymy of this species by Nishikawa et al. 2007.

This taxon is a complex currently under revision. Records of this species from Anjanaharibe and Tsaratanana (Raxworthy et al. 1998), Andringitra (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996), and Ambolokopatrika (Andreone et al. 2000) are highly likely to refer to other species, e.g. R. ornata, R. tany, R. vaventy and other undescribed species (Scherz et al. 2014). In the framework of ongoing revision of the Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014, 2015), all available specimens of this complex in European and Malagasy collections have been examined and found only a single specimen was found to correspond to the R. serratopalpebrosa holotype and it is thus considered to be restricted to Marojejy. For this reason, we exclude all uncertain records of this species (F. Glaw and M.D. Scherz pers. comm. November 2015). Records from further south in Madagascar might refer to Plethodontohyla coronata.

authority: Veloso, Sallaberry A., Navarro, Iturra-C., Valencia, Penna & Díaz, 1982

taxonomicNotes: There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes pehuenche, despite resembling this species (C. Correa and D. Vásquez unpubl. data). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, these records are not included within this species' distribution map.

Its tadpole was briefly described as belonging to Telmatobius montanus (Cei and Roig 1965), but was later re-assigned as this species (Cei 1976).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes hugoi, despite resembling this species (Correa et al. 2018). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, it has not been included within this species' distribution map.

It is possible that Argentinean subpopulations of Alsodes from the forests of Neuquén and Río Negro Provinces might belong to A. verrucosus, although until this can be verified these records have not been included in attempts to map its range.

Only the biological subpopulation at the type locality is known for certain as Eupsophus contulmoensis (C. Castro and F. Rabanal pers. comm. 2015). Biological subpopulations outside of the type locality have varying morphs and their identity is unclear. However, for the purposes of this assessment and until such time as these subpopulations' identities are resolved, they are considered under the nominal form of Eupsophus contulmoensis.

It was removed from the synonymy of Eupsophus roseus by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), where it had been placed by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017).
Removed from the synonymy of Eupsophus roseus by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), where it had been placed by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017).

Diagnosis of Telmatobius chusmisensis is based on external morphology and osteology of adults, external morphology of tadpoles, karyotype, chromosomal C-banded patterns and Ag-NOR (nucleolar organizer region) position (Formas et al. 2006).
Adenomus dasi has been synonymized under this species by Meegaskumbura et al. (2015).

The taxonomy of untufted capuchin monkeys (Cebus spp.) has recently been debated and although there is a better understanding of its phylogeny, some phylogenetic and biogeographical aspects of this genus remain unresolved (Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2010; Boubli et al. 2012; Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012). The Santa Marta white-fronted capuchin (Cebus malitiosus) comprises of all populations of untufted capuchins that occur in the north-western region of the Sierra Nevada de San Marta, in northern Colombia (Defler 2003, 2004). Both Hershkovitz (1949) and Hernadez-Camacho and Cooper (1976) consider the Santa Marta white-fronted capuchin a subspecies of C. albifrons, while Groves (2001) considers it as one of the six forms of varied white-fronted capuchins (Cebus albifrons versicolor) in northern Colombia. The only molecular study that has included a single sample of capuchin monkeys from the northern region of Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta found that C. malitiosus had a completely different haplotype compared to those from other northern Colombian populations (C. a. versicolor, C. a. pleei and C. a. cesarae) and actually nested in a basal branch with capuchin monkeys from the Colombian and Peruvian Amazon (Ruiz-García et al. 2010). The validity of C. malitiosus as a separate species on the northwestern foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta still needs further validation.

The taxonomy of gracile capuchin monkeys (Cebus spp.) continues to be debated and despite increasing understanding of its phylogeny, many phylogenetic and biogeographical aspects of this genus remain unresolved (Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2010, Boubli et al. 2012, Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012, Lima et al. 2017). Genetic analyses by Boubli et al. (2012) have indicated that the following forms of white-fronted capuchins that were recognized as subspecies of Cebus albifrons by Hershkovitz (1949) should be provisionally considered distinct species: albifrons, yuracus, unicolor, cuscinus, cesarae, malitiosus, leucocephalus, trinitatis, aequatorialis, and versicolor. The Varied White-fronted Capuchin (Cebus versicolor) comprises all populations of gracile capuchins that occur in northern Colombia in the Cauca-Magdalena interfluvium, on both banks of the Magdalena River and in the middle Magdalena River valley, excluding those populations on the western slope of the Eastern Andes and east of the eastern Andes Mountains into Venezuela (Cebus leucocephalus) and those in northern Cesar department and north to the Rio Ranchería (Cebus cesarae) and the Magdalena Department northern coast (C. malitiosus). An alternative hypothesis, by Hernandez-Camacho and Cooper (1976), considered a C. versicolor “complex” to include three taxa proposed by Hershkovitz (1949): C. albifrons versicolor, C. a. pleei (described from Mompos in Bolivar department) and C. a. leucocephalus, primarily because those authors had observed one population of capuchins in the Barrancabermeja region of the middle Magdalena with individual variation that seemed to encompass morphotypes of all three described subspecies; this points to one of the ongoing challenges of taxonomy for capuchin monkeys, the extreme individual morphological variation even within a single population (Rylands et al. 2005). However, mitochondrial genetic analyses support Cebus cesarae as the sister taxon to C. versicolor, with C. leucocephalus as a separate lineage (Lima et al. 2017). Ruiz-García et al. (2010) using mtDNA analyses also found that C. a. versicolor, C. a. cesarae, and C. a. pleei were genetically closely related to one another.

Here we note that the holotype (and only known locality) for Cebus albifrons pleei (sensu Hershkovitz, 1949) is found within our distribution of C. versicolor; the phenotype of C. pleei is more similar to C. versicolor than to C. cesarae, however, the genetic evidence is currently inconclusive to whether C. a. pleei should be synonymized with C. versicolor or instead with C. cesarae, extending the latter’s range south. Here we consider C. a. pleei a junior synonym of C. versicolor. We also note that the holotype for Cebus leucocephalus falls at the eastern edge of our C. versicolor range, and the C. versicolor holotype is listed as Bogotá, which is outside its distribution. These discrepancies are subjects of current research.

Previous formal taxonomy of this genus recognized the existence of only two species: S. teuszii in the Atlantic Ocean and S. chinensis in the Indo-Pacific Oceans (Committee on Taxonomy-Society for Marine Mammalogy 2009). However, recent morphological and molecular studies have shown the genus is composed of four species including: S. teuszii (Atlantic Ocean), S. plumbea (Indian Ocean), S. chinensis (eastern Indian and western Pacific Oceans) and a newly described species S. sahulensis found in the waters of the Sahul Shelf from northern Australia to southern New Guinea (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Mendez et al. 2013).

The Australian Humpback Dolphin can be visually differentiated from the other species of the genus by the following combination of morphological characters: 1) the body is typically more dark grey in colour, 2) a diagonal cape line running from just above the eye and neck down to the urogenital area separates the dark back and lighter belly, 3) dorsal fin is lower in size, triangular in shape, and has a wide base without a visible dorsal hump and 4) white scarring and dark flecking on the head, back, dorsal fin, and tail stock are common in adult animals (Jefferson & Rosenbaum 2014). Seven diagnostic mtDNA characters and a single nuDNA character distinguish Sousa sahulensis from other species in the genus.
This is a newly described species belonging to the Rhinolophus maclaudi group (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013).
This is a newly described species belonging to the Rhinolophus maclaudi group (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. becki as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.    

Chelonoidis becki has generally always been considered a distinct taxon based on its isolated occurrence on Wolf Volcano on northern Isabela, consistent also with prior recognition of the other tortoise populations on central and southern Isabela volcanoes as distinct taxa: microphyes, vandenburghi, guntheri, and vicina. However, as population morphologies were considered, the dome-shaped central and southern Isabela populations were merged by Pritchard (1996) into a broader vicina taxon, into which microphyes, vandenburghi, and guentheri [= guntheri] were synonymized. Later genetic analysis demonstrated that all southern Isabela populations are very closely related to each other, with C. becki more closely related to C. darwini from Santiago (Poulakakis et al. 2012, 2015).

Chelonoidis becki includes two distinct genetic lineages, each of which occurs in nearly separate ranges: one on the eastern and northern slopes of Wolf Volcano associated with Piedras Blancas and the other on the southwestern slopes associated with Puerto Bravo (Garrick et al. 2014).Both of these lineages derived from tortoises from Santiago (C. darwini, Caccone et al. 1999, 2002; Garrick et al. 2014).

Genetic data indicate the presence on Wolf Volcano of hybrid individuals from species from distant islands (C. niger [Extinct], C. abingdonii [Extinct], and C. hoodensis), as well as the presence of hybrid individuals with species from the same island. The first ones, and possibly all, are likely to have arrived on Wolf Volcano because of human activities, while those from other volcanoes of Isabela are the possible results of sporadic tortoise dispersal events from one volcano to the next by land (from Darwin Volcano) or by sea from the central (Alcedo Volcano) or southern (Sierra Negra and Cerro Azul) Isabela volcanoes (Beheragaray et al. 2007).

The carapace morphology of Wolf Volcano tortoises is quite variable, with carapace shapes ranging from domed to intermediate to saddlebacked Given that the ancestor of this species is C. darwini from Santiago (Caccone et al. 1999; Caccone et al. 2002; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2013; Garrick et al. 2012, 2014), a species with an intermediate carapace shape, we assume that this is the ancestral carapace shape for C. becki, whereas the presence of domed and saddlebacked individuals is likely the result of past mating events with individuals from other islands (see above).

Cryptobranchus guildayi synonymized with this species by Bredehoeft and Schubert (2015).

There are likely multiple species currently retained within this concept (T. Pierson pers. comm. June 2021). It is necessary to investigate this species complex and elucidate the taxonomic identity of its members.
This is a restricted concept of H. ornatus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. japi (de Sá et al. 2015).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. chathamensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

Pritchard (1996) restricted the name chathamensis to the now-extirpated tortoise populations of southwestern and central San Cristóbal, but excluded the eastern San Cristóbal population, considering this population to represent a possibly distinct subspecies for which no name was available. For purposes of this Red List Assessment, the eastern San Cristóbal population is considered part of chathamensis until taxonomic clarity emerges.

Testudo wallacei Rothschild, 1902, was described with type locality “Chatham Island?”, but its type locality was designated Jervis Island [Rábida] by Van Denburgh (1914); Rábida tortoises were hypothesized to be an introduced population (Pritchard 1996), later confirmed by genetic analysis (Poulakakis et al. 2012) to represent tortoises from southern Isabela, and the name wallacei is considered a nomen dubium and synonym of C. vicina (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. hoodensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. porteri as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The name C. porteri now refers only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). A second tortoise species on eastern Santa Cruz Island from the Cerro Fatal region has recently been described as C. donfaustoi (Poulakakis et al. 2015), thus separating what was formerly considered one species into two. A third very small group of tortoises occurs in the northwestern region of Santa Cruz near Cerro Montura. The tortoises found at Cerro Montura have been identified as genetically indistinguishable from the Pinzón tortoise, C. duncanensis (Russello et al. 2005), and it is considered that they were probably introduced from Pinzón to Santa Cruz by humans.

Some recent literature suggests that the valid name for the Western Santa Cruz tortoise may be C. nigrita (e.g., EMBL database). However, the Tortoise and Freshwater Turtle Specialist Group follows the nomenclature of Pritchard (1996), Fritz and Havas (2007), TTWG (2014), and TEWG (2015), who concluded that nigrita is a nomen dubium and placed it in questionable synonymy under C. porteri.

There is unpublished morphological and genetic data supporting the suggestion by Cogger (2014) that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Christinus guentheri.

Recent genetic analysis indicates that disjunct records from the Monaro Tablelands in New South Wales represent a distinct population (Scott and Keogh 2000, Melville et al. 2007), but no formal taxonomic action has yet been taken. Records from the Darling Downs in Queensland have been described as the distinct species Tympanocryptus condaminensis (Melville et al. 2014).

The name Tympanocryptis condaminensis was erected by Melville et al. (2014) for the subpopulation of T. pinguicolla found in the Darling Downs, on the basis of genetic evidence that the two taxa are specifically distinct.

The taxonomy of Varanus timorensis and V. auffenbergi from Roti Island is unresolved, and the occurrence of V. timorensis on this island is in need of clarification (E. Arida and S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). Unpublished data suggest that V. auffenbergi represents a subspecies of V. timorensis (A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).
This taxon could be considered a subspecies of Varanus melinus due to its morphological similarity and parapatric distribution (A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).

The relationship between this species and Boophis microtympanum has not yet been clarified. Boophis laurenti might simply be a colour morph, but a distinct call has been recorded. More species could be involved, and the whole complex needs revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).

Molecular data indicate the existence of at least two different management units for conservation in this species, corresponding to the north and south of its distribution range (Andreone et al. 2006, Vieites et al. 2006).

Records of Mantella expectata or M. betsileo from the arid west and southwest Madagascar (including from from Tsingy de Bemaraha) probably refer to a separate, undescribed, species that is not characterized by blue legs (F. Andreone pers. comm., Rabemananjara et al. 2007). Here we consider as Mantella expectata to refer only the populations from Isalo and the thin band further south (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species is genetically very closely related to Mantella baroni (Vences et al. 2004).
This species is closely related to Mantella pulchra (F. Glaw pers. comm.).

This species and Mantella crocea might represent colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm. August 2016, Chiari et al. 2004). Subpopulations with intermediate characteristics between M. crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).
This species was redefined, and two new species, Mantidactylus charlotteae and M. zipperi, were described by Vences and Glaw (2004).
