This species belongs to the Gephyromantis asper group and was split from it prior to its first assessment in 2004. The population from Manongarivo is genetically distinct (F. Glaw pers.comm. November 2015).

This recently described species is similar to Spinomantis peraccae and S. elegans. There is confustion regarding the taxonomy of this Group (additional species might be involved), and a revision is needed.
This species was revised by Glaw and Vences (2001) who described two sibling species: Gephyromantis tandroka and G. tschenki.
Records from Tsingy de Bemaraha now refer to Gephyromantis atsingy, records from Analavelona and the Kelifely Plateau are in need of confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

This species was revised by Vences et al. (2002).

It was described from Nosy Be Island over 100 years ago and never seen there again (many species have Nosy Be as their type locality because an important port was situated there, but those species never actually occurred on the island and this record of G. horridus was suspected to one such mistake; however, the natural history museum in Vienna traced a specimen collected by Brancsik in 1890 from the island confirming that the species actually occured on Nosy Be (Glaw and Vences 2011).
The taxonomic distinction between Mantidactylus madecassus and M. pauliani has recently been corroborated on the basis of genetic studies (M. Vences pers. comm.).

The specific name was emended to massorum by Vences et al. (2003). However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.2, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2008: http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php).
This species is here considered to belong to the genus Spinomantis, rather than Boophis, following Glaw and Vences (2006).
This species was previously included in Gephyromantis malagasius (Vences et al. 2002).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus biporus by Glaw and Vences (1999) and tentatively redefined by Glaw and Vences (2007). However, additional candidate species have been identified by Vieites et al. (2009) demonstrating that the taxonomic identity of the species is still uncertain and in need of further revision. Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
Scaphiophryne spinosa has been separated from this species by Vences et al. (2003). The western subpopulations have also been separated as S. menabensis (Glos et al. 2005).

This species was synonymized with Stumpffia psologlossa by Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc (1991). However, we follow Glaw and Vences (1994) in treating it as a separate species. D'Cruze et al. (2007) recorded Stumpffia cf. roseifemoralis from Montagne des Français; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating this species from Mantidactylus curtus.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in removing this species from the synonymy of Mantidactylus brevipalmatus.

authority: Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species was originally considered by Hill (1959) to constitute a subspecies of Rhinolophus arcuatus Peters, 1871. Based on morphological analyses with other specimens of R. “arcuatus” from throughout its range, Patrick and co-workers (2013) suggested that the taxon on Borneo be raised to species status.

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Afrixalus uluguruensis. However, molecular data show that this might represent more than one species (S. Loader pers. comm. Oct 2015).

Pickersgill (2000, 2005) considers this form to be a subspecies of Afrixalus stuhlmanni, with which it hybridizes as forests are cleared. We follow Schiøtz (1999, and pers. comm.) in considering it to be a valid species. However, we follow Pickersgill (2005) and K. Howell (pers. comm.) in considering it to occur in the coastal areas of Tanzania, as well as in the Shimba Hills in Kenya.

This tube-nosed bat is closely related to Murina chrysochaetes from southern China and northern Vietnam (Son et al. 2015) suggesting that both species are relics within of the former large distribution range of their ancestor. Previously this bat was once attributed to as M. aurata Milne-Edwards, 1872 (Borissenko and Kruskop 2003).
Nyctophilus corbeni was split from Nyctophilus timoriensis (Parnaby 2009).

Most 19th and 20th century sources placed the Sambar in the genus Cervus, as C. unicolor, but Grubb (1990) resurrected the genus Rusa for this and allied species. This was followed by Groves (2003) and Grubb (2005). Groves (2006) pointed out that Chinese Sambar has not traditionally been separated, even at a subspecific level, from Indomalayan R. u. equinus, despite karyotype differences (Groves and Grubb 1987) and some clear pelage differences, indicating that taxonomic revision may be forthcoming. Later still Groves and Grubb (2011) divided Sambar into two species, Southeast Asian Sambar C. equinus of SE Asia (including NE India) and southern China, and residual Indian Sambar C. unicolor of South Asia, based on a variety of morphological differences (no mention was made of ‘Chinese Sambar’). They gave no sample sizes or information on animals in the area where the two forms abut, making it difficult to assess the validity of the proposal. This warrants priority investigation because the distributions of the two species mean that the western form is relatively secure, with large subpopulations in many well-managed protected areas, whereas the eastern form has very few apparently secure subpopulations and would, if assessed separately, warrant a Red List Category at least one level more threatened than that for the western form.


Throughout at least Indochina there is a predictable flow of reports of ‘novel’ variation in large deer, with the implication that a new species may be involved (e.g. Pham Trong Anh et al. 1996 and, particularly, surveys through local people by overseas consultants); these stem from Sambar (often young animals) with unbranched antlers.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This taxon is probably a complex of 2–3 species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. January 2021).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was mistakenly reported as Pristimantis cabrerai by Kattan (1984).
Lynch (1996b) notes misidentifications in earlier accounts.

Records from the western slope of the Serranía de los Paraguas in Chocó Department and Valle de Cauca Department (Castro-Herrera and Vargas-Salinas 2008) might actually refer to another species, P. molybrignus (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018), and therefore are excluded from this species' extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work is carried out.
This species was redescribed by Lynch (1970).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Following genetic and morphological studies, this species was moved from Pristimantis to the newly described Tachiramantis (Heinicke et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This is the sister species of Pristimantis bellona according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996b).
The records reported from Chocó Department are not reliable and require confirmation (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).
According to the original description, some records of Pristimantis cruentus from western Colombia and western Ecuador might actually be this species.

Due to a typographic error on the title of the paper describing this species (Lynch 1995), the name was given as P. lasallorum. However, the correct spelling is P. lasalleorum. Lynch (1995) gives the correct spelling elsewhere in the original description.
This taxon has previously been confused with Pristimantis calcaratus (Lynch 1998). It was previously assessed under the name Pristimantis kelephas; this was an incorrect subsequent spelling.

Duellman (1981) originally placed the taxon in the genus Centrolenella, which was subsequently designated to Cochranella by Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) based on the absence of humeral spines in males from specimens collected at Campamento Chancos, Valle del Cauca. However, Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006) verified the presence of humeral spines in the material described by Duellman (1981), thus combining the taxon with Centrolene; the Colombian material reported by Lynch and Ruiz-Carranza (1996) were therefore presumed to be of a distinct lineage (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006). The lack of clarity regarding Colombian specimens is reflected in many published accounts (e.g. Acosta-Galvis 2000, Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007, Guayasamin and Frenkel 2018).

Later, in a monographic revision of the glassfrog family, Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) underscored the difficulty of substantively designating the taxon at the generic level, and regarded the taxon as incertae sedis within the subfamily Centroleninae. Finally, after incorporating mitochondrial sequences into a phylogenetic analysis of the family, Guayasamin et al. (2019) determined its placement within Nymphargus based on recent material from the Río Manduriacu Reserve, Imbabura, Ecuador (Maynard et al. 2020). New material for N. balionotus from Colombia has not been reported in recent decades. Thus, it is not currently possible to resolve whether or not the subpopulation from Campamento Chancos is representative of a distinct lineage from those in Ecuador, as suggested by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006). However, it is plausible that this scenario is correct based on available information; in addition to lacking humeral spines, the records from Campamento Chancos are well separated from, and substantially lower in elevation than all other specimens (Maynard et al. 2020).
Guayasamin et al. 2009 considered this species to be incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007) noted that this species may occur in Ecuador.

Given the morphological similarity of Nymphargus garciae with N. nephelophila and N. oreonympha, it is possible that they are the same species with phenotypic geographic variation (Guayasamín et al. 2018).
Named as Cochranella punctulata by Ruiz-Carranza and Linch in 1995, the genus has then been reviewed and replaced with Sachatamia by Guayasamin et al. in 2009.
Taxonomic status of the subpopulation on Gorgona Island should be reviewed, as it probably corresponds to a different species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2016)

This species is regarded as an incertae sedis within Centroleninae by Guayasamin et al. (2009). The species is very similar to Rulyrana susatamai and further taxonomic research is needed to determine the species boundaries (M. Rada pers. comm. February 2017).
This is the sister species of Rhinella acrolopha, according to the original description.
Subpopulations of the south and the dry coast are believed to correspond to another undescribed species (M. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2020).
This species has not been included in phylogenies based on molecular characters, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2018).

This is a species complex that requires formal subdivision (Guayasamín et al. 2006, 2020; Amador et al. 2018). Amador et al. (2018) provided molecular evidence that nominal Centrolene buckleyi is composed of at least three species, none of which is each other's closest relative, one in southern Ecuador, two (including Centrolene buckleyi sensu stricto) in northern Ecuador, and another in central Andean Colombia, with the edges remaining unknown (Frost 2021).

Two specimens from Huancabamba in Piura Department in northern Peru (Duellman and Wild 1993) previously assigned to this species are actually metamorphs of another species (Amador et al. 2018; D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). All records of this species from Venezuela formerly assigned to this taxon are now assigned to Centrolene venezuelense.
In spite of its Amazonian type locality, this species is in fact known only from the Andes.
This species was considered to be a synonym of Hylopsis platycephalus Werner, 1894, by Lynch (1981b), but this was not accepted by McDiarmid and Savage (1984).
It may be a complex of more than one species (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2010).

The Colombian subpopulations have different skin texture and some morphological differences compared to Ecuadorian subpopulations. More research is needed to determine whether or not this is in fact two separate species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).
The form is the sister species of Pristimantis appendiculatus according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996).
This species was considered a synonym of Hyloxalus fuliginosus by Edwards (1974b).
This species is considered to be a derivative of Oophaga histrionica by Myers and Daly (1976).

Lötters (1992) doubted the distinction of this species from Oophaga histrionica.

Records from the Serrania de Baudo and Alto del Oso in the Department of Chocó that were previously questioned to belonging to this species have now been verified and assigned as Oophaga solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
The validity of this species was previously in question (Lynch pers. comm; Grant and Myers 2013). However, Grant et al. (2017) recognize this taxon as a distinct species.
There is ongoing debate about whether this is a valid species or whether it is a synonym of Hyloxalus pulchellus (T. Grant pers. comm., G. Pisso pers. comm. October 2018).
This is likely a species complex and requires taxonomic revision (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This form is probably a complex of several species. Brazilian populations assigned to this species presumably belong to another species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018). It is probably a synonym of Hyloscirtus lindae.

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) noted that one of the paratypes of this species is referable to Hyloscirtus palmeri.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This taxon, previously included in the genus Hyla, has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). In the Hyloscirtus bogotensis group based on its mtDNA phylogenetic relationships (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might represent a species complex.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
Bolitoglossa tatamae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Acosta and Hoyos 2006).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species' genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

authority: Amézquita, Márquez, Mejía-Vargas, Kahn, Suárez & Mazariegos, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of A. opisthomelas (Amézquita et al. 2013).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis zoilae was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis colonensis was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).

Colostethus ucumari can be distinguished from other Colostethus by means of morphological differences and colour patterns; it is also the second species of Colostethus known to possess skin toxins (Grant 2007).

Páez-Moscoso and Guayasamin (2012) suggested that this taxon is part of an Osornophryne bufoniformis species complex that is poorly elucidated (Frost 2021). It has been suggested that this species is actually a junior synonym of O. bufoniformis (L. Coloma pers. comm. 2019).
This is a complex of at least two species (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019).

This species has been sometimes been included in Martes flavigula (e.g., Corbet and Hill 1992), but has been separated as a valid species by other authors (e.g., Pocock 1941, Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951, Anderson 1970, Rozhnov 1995).
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhinella crucifer (Roberto et al. 2014).
This species has been assigned to the Scinax catherinae clade (Cruz et al. 2011).

Species described in 2015, allocated in the group of Brachycephalus pernix, a group composed of 18 formally recognized species (Monteiro et al. 2018). Based on molecular data they confirmed the species delimitation (Firkowski et al. 2016). However, Condez et al. (2017) discuss the need for a taxonomic re-evaluation of B. mariaeterezae, due to problems in its diagnosis and original description. Pie et al. (2017) refute the arguments in Condez et al. (2017).

authority: Teixeira, Recoder, Amaro, Damasceno, Cassimiro & Rodrigues, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species has been assigned to the Scinax catharinae group (Cruz et al. 2011).
This form requires taxonomic reassessment due to problems in the original diagnosis and description (Condez et al. 2017).

The Crossodactylus dispar complex is thought to contain may microendemics, such that subpopulations assigned to this species but recorded outside Santa Teresa Massif (e.g. Cachoeiro de Itapemirim), probably belong to other undescribed species (J.V. Lacerda pers. comm. 2021).
Removed from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Pombal Jr. and Izecksohn (2011).
Removed from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Pombal (2010).

According to Conndez et al. (2017), this species belongs to the Brachycephalus pernix group and requires a taxonomic reassessment due to errors present in the original diagnosis and description considering the use of doubtful diagnostic characters, such as body colour and skin roughness; characteristics that can vary intra-specifically as a consequence of a polymorphism or even be an artefact of specimen preservation.

This is a split from the broader concept of Crossodactylus dispar (Pimenta et al. 2014). Records from Teresópolis, Rio de Janeiro are misidentifications of C. aeneus (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

authority: (Pombal, Menezes, Fontes, Nunes, Rocha & Van Sluys, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This species has been moved to the genus Nyctimantis by Blotto et al. (2021).

Pristimantis sp. “J” from the summit of Mount Roraima in Venezuela (see McDiarmid and Donnelly 2005) could be P. aureoventris, but tissue samples and specimens are necessary to corroborate this assumption (Jablonski et al. 2017).
Removed from the synonymy of Crossodactylus dispar by Pimenta et al. (2014).

authority: Fouquet, Souza, Nunes, Kok, Curcio, Carvalho, Grant & Rodrigues, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species was provisionally allocated to Aparasphenodon when first described by de Assis et al. (2013). Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.

Bokermannohyla napolii is a newly described species on the basis of adult morphology, morphometrics, and mainly vocalizations. Adult specimens of B. napolii are most closely related to those of B. luctuosa and B. circumdata.

Further molecular work is required to better understand the relationship between Brachycephalus crispus, B. guarani, B. pitanga, and B. toby, as it is possible that these represent a single species (T. Condez pers. comm. 2021).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species was reported as Leptobrachium pullum by Inger et al. (1999).
This is a split from the broader concept of Limnonectes kuhlii, for which it was previously confused (Matsui et al. 2014).
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).

authority: Ohler, Deuti, Grosjean, Paul, Ayyaswamy, Ahmed & Dutta, 2009

taxonomicNotes: This species was split from Eleutherodactylus audanti (Hedges et al. 2008). On the basis of preliminary molecular data, Díaz et al. (2018) suggested that E. melatrigonum may be conspecific with E. notidodes.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).

Specimens recorded at Estação Biológica de Boracéia, in the municipality of Salesópolis, São Paulo State, were assigned to Paratelmatobius gaigeae by Heyer et al. (1990). Later, Pombal and Haddad (1999) reallocated these specimens to P. poecilogaster (1990).
This species was split from Incilius valliceps and Incilius macrocristatus (Mendelson III et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Thorius schmidti (Rovito et al. 2013) where it had been placed by Hanken and Wake (1998).

Leptopelis grandiceps was resurrected from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis and L. usambarae was transferred from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis to the synonymy L. grandiceps by Gvoždík et al. (2014). It is likely to represent multiple species (S. Loader pers. comm. December 2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Raorchestes hassanensis (Abraham et al. 2015).

Up until recently this species was known only from the type series collected in 1882. It was rediscovered and published as a new species, R. emeraldi, by Vijayakumar et al. (2014), but Abraham et al. (2015) determined that these new specimens actually belonged to this species that had not been recorded for over 100 years.
This is a split from the broader concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015).

authority: Abraham, Jobin, Cyriac, Zachariah, Raju & Zachariah, 2015

taxonomicNotes: It has been suggested that this species is a synonym of Phrynobatrachus acridoides, but recent surveys indicate that it differs both in vocalizations and ecology (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.). Phrynobatrachus nigripes, described by Pickersgill (2007), is in fact a synonym of this species (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.).

In the Rhacophorus calcaneus group of Orlov et al. (2012), who noted extensive confusion with Rhacophorus robertingeri in the literature and who discussed previous confusion in the range. Rhacophorus chuyangsinensis was also synonymised with this species by Orlov et al. (2012).
We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.

The taxonomy of genus Gazella is complex and several different arrangements have been proposed, but several issues remain unresolved.

Gazella arabica was originally described from a single specimen: a skin and a skull obtained on the Farasan Islands off the coast of Saudi Arabia (or at least labelled as such). This became something of a mystery taxon and is different from the gazelles currently found there. Bärman et al. (2012) extracted DNA from the type specimen and showed that this was not a single specimen, assigning the skin to G. g. cora and the skull to gazelles of the northern type (G. g. gazella).

Wronski et al. (2010) showed that Gazella gazella, in fact, consists of two monophyletic lineages, a northern clade (represented by samples from the Golan Heights) and a southern clade (based on samples from the Arabian Peninsula including the southern Arava Valley), based on mtDNA markers. Lerp et al. (2012) produced similar conclusions using nuclear markers and including samples from Central Israel. A morphological and genetic study of genus Gazella (Bärmann et al. 2013), and a genetic study of gazelles in the southern Levant (Hadas et al. 2015) all further support the existence of two monophyletic lineages: a northern clade (Gazella gazella), and a southern clade (provisionally named G. arabica on the basis that this name takes precedence over cora).

This arrangement is now followed by the IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group, with G. gazella replacing G. g. gazella in the former arrangement, and the name G. arabica provisionally retained for the southern clade, pending a ruling by the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN). So G. arabica, as understood here, comprises all the gazelles formerly considered under G. gazella, from the southern Negev through the Arabian Peninsula.

Several subspecies have been named under G. gazella and have previously been evaluated for The IUCN Red List: acaciae; in the southern Arava Valley; cora in most of the Arabian Peninsula; farasani on the Farasan Islands; and muscatensis on the Batinah coast of Oman. Genetic research by scientists at King Khaled Wildlife Research Centre (Saudi Arabia) and Zoological Society of London (ZSL) has confirmed the existence of some intraspecific variation, but there is no agreement on the validity of these named subspecies and they are not assessed separately for the time being, until a definitive analysis has been produced. All of the above are included in G. arabica here.

The relationship between G. arabica (as here) and two other 'mystery' species, G. erlangeri and G. bilkis awaits confirmation.

Sufficient Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), morphological, and morphometric data now exist to rank the two subspecies of Funambulus sublineatus (obscurus and sublineatus) as separate species (Dissanayake and Oshida 2012). Data reveal a clear difference in pelage and body measurements. However, it is recommended that the reliability of the mtDNA signal observed be established to more accurately determine the evolutionary relationships between the two species (Dissanayake and Oshida 2012).

There is also apparent mitochondrial genetic affinity between F. obscurus and F. layardi which suggests a close evolutionary affinity of these species, with analysis revealing F. layardi is considered a sister group to F. obscurus (Dissanayake and Oshida, 2012).

The true relationships of F. obscurus remain opaque, with morphology suggesting sister relationship to allopatric F. sublineatus, but mtDNA doing likewise to sympatric F. layardi (Dissanayake and Oshida 2012).

Reynolds and Foster (1992) indicated that Atelopus rugulosus is a synonym of A. tricolor. Subsequently, Lötters and De la Riva (1998) confirmed this and pointed out that in evaluating the types of A. rugulosus from south-east Peru, and A. wilimani from Bolivia, both are synonyms of A. tricolor.
This species was considered to be a subspecies of Rhinella limensis by Leviton and Duellman (1978).

The nominal form formerly referred to as Ranitomeya fantastica was found to be a complex of three closely related species: R. fantastica, R. benedicta and R. summersi (Brown et al. 2008). Ranitomeya fantastica is herein reassessed considering this change in taxonomic concept.

This species is comprised of a well-supported monophyletic group and shows higher levels of genetic divergence among its populations than those of Ameerega hahneli from the same region (Roberts et al. 2007).
This species is very similar to Ameerega petersi. There might be a need to re-examine the relationship between these two taxa.

The status of Ameerega rubriventris as a valid species is still in dispute by some, though the unusual ventral colors and genetic distinctness suggest that this species is indeed different from A. altamazonica (Twomey and Brown 2017).
Prior to the official description in 1979, this species was known to many people but under incorrect names, such as Phyllobates bicolor.
This genus moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Two subspecies are recognized: Ceratophrys stolzmanni ssp. scaphiopeza in Ecuador, and C. stolzmanni ssp. stolzmanni in Peru.
Pristimantis vermiculatus is considered to be a junior synonym of Pristimantis petrobardus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).
The record from Mitobamba, Cajamarca Department, Peru, provided by Duellman and Lehr (2009) might represent an unnamed species.
According to Lehr and Catenazzi (2009), Psychrophrynella bagrecito (Lynch 1986) seems to be related to Noblella rather than to Psychrophrynella (Lehr 2006, De la Riva et al. 2008).
The specimen from Cajamarca, Peru previously attributed to Lynchius parkeri by Lehr (2006) has been assigned to Lynchius oblitus based on phylogenetic analyses (Motta et al. 2016).

Reflecting some taxonomic uncertainty, Pristimantis simonsii has been included in other genera over the recent past. Currently, there is apparent consensus that the species should be in the genus Pristimantis.
Lehr (2006) synonymized Phrynopus laplacai under Microkayla wettsteini.

The biological identities of some of the Peruvian subpopulations need to be clarified (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2014). Until such time, all subpopulations currently allocated to Telmatobius timens are encompassed in this assessment.

In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus mixomaculatus is diagnosed from other similar glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Guayasamin et al. 2006).
Atelopus pyrodactylus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas and Barrio 2006).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis albertus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007).
Microkayla boettgeri can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Lehr 2006).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to AmphibiaWeb (2008). Pristimantis wagteri is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas 2007).
This species was reassigned from Phrynopus to Oreobates by Padial et al. (2012).

In the Eleutherodactylus (Eleutherodactylus) orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis cordovae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
This species was first described as Colostethus insulatus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was formerly included within Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010

taxonomicNotes: The phylogenetic position of Centrolene charapita might change as more molecular and/or phenotypic data are analyzed, or if more species are included in the genus (Twomey et al. 2014)

authority: Catenazzi, von May, Lehr, Gagliardi-Urrutia & Guayasamin, 2012
(Köhler, Koscinski, Padial, Chaparro, Handford, Lougheed & De la Riva, 2010)

taxonomicNotes:
Historically, there has been some doubt over the distinctiveness of this taxon from Rhinella spinulosa (Gorham 1974, Córdova 1999). However, it is considered a distinct species from the broader concept of Rhinella spinulosa (Cei 1972, Cei 1980). 

Morphological and molecular studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Rhinella in southern Peru (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018).
Named as Philautus decoris by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.
Groves (2002) provisionally listed two subspecies of Grevy's Zebra. However, Groves and Bell (2004) concluded that the species is indeed monotypic. Reviewed by Churcher (1993).
Formerly included in the genus Salamandra, this taxon was assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

Morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are two major clades further subdivided in several lineages (Beukema et al. 2010, Ben Hassine et al. 2016, Bouzid et al. 2017, Merabet et al. 2016a, Beddek et al. 2018, Dinis et al. 2019, Hernandez and Escoriza 2019), which are recognized as five distinct subspecies: S. a. tingitana (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003), S. a. splendens (Beukema et al. 2013), S. a. spelaea (Escoriza and Comas 2007), S. a. algira (Bedriaga 1883), and S. a. atlantica (Hernandez and Escoriza 2019).
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from synonymy of Craugastor punctariolus (Campbell and Savage 2000).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. Chelonoidis donfaustoi is a recently described species (Poulakakis et al. 2015), previously included within C. porteri. The name C. porteri is now restricted only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). This Red List assessment treats this newly described taxon, C. donfaustoi, as a full species.
This species may be a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (K.O. Chan and E. Quah pers. comm. January 2018).

This species was previously thought by Berry (1975) and Kiew (1975) to include Limnonectes tweediei. However, Dring (1979), Grandison (1982) and Leong Tzi Ming (pers. comm.) consider the two forms to be distinct.

authority: (Rowley, Stuart, Neang, Hoang, Dau, Nguyen, & Emmett, 2015)

taxonomicNotes: In Hylarana signata complex, this is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana siberu (Chan et al. 2014). Currently known as Pulchrana centropeninsularis after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

The validity of this species was questioned by Golubev in Ščerzbak (2003), who considered it an isolated population attributable to Phrynocephalus maculatus. According to Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007) P. golubewii is presently considered a valid species. It was treated within P. maculatus by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008), who however, noted that it appeared to be well-separated in the phylogeny provided by Arnold (1999).

Verified records of this species come only from Peninsular Malaysia. Records from other countries are either misidentified or misattributed. Records from peninsular Thailand and Borneo are referrable to Microhyla perparva and M. petrigenea according to Manthey and Denzer (2014).

authority: (Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: This species was assessed in 2008 as a subspecies of Cercocebus atys, but is now raised to a species. This species was also formerly treated as a subspecies of C. torquatus.

This species was formerly treated as the nominate subspecies when it was assessed in 2008, however, because the former subspecies lunulatus is now treated as a good species, the nominate subspecies has now become the more restricted concept of the species.

Groves (2001), Grubb et al. (2003), and Kingdon et al. (2008) treat Erythrocebus patas as a monotypic species in a monotypic genus. Schwarz (1927), Isbell (2013), and De Jong and Butynski (2018) recognize baumstarki as one of the three subspecies within E. patas (patas, pyrrhonotus, baumstarki). Verheyen (1962), Hill (1966), Napier and Napier (1967), Dandelot (1968, 1974), and Kingdon (1971, 1997, 2015) recognize an additional subspecies, E. p. villiersi.

Erythrocebus baumstarki was described by Matschie (1906) as a species (type locality: Ikoma, western Serengeti, Tanzania). Here, baumstarki is, once again, treated as a species. This restoration to species status is based on baumstarki’s considerable geographic isolation and distinctive coloration and pattern of the pelage. The distance between the nearest confirmed E. baumstarki record (Northern Extension of Serengeti National Park, north central Tanzania; G. Schaller pers. comm.; number 15 in Figure 1 and Table 1 of De Jong et al. 2009) and the nearest confirmed E. p. pyrrhonotus record (Kiganjo, central Kenya; H. Douglas-Dufresne pers. comm.; number 47 in Figure 2 and Table 3 in De Jong et al. 2008) is ca. 260 km. There are, however, several records between these two localities for Erythrocebus that have not been identified as to species (De Jong et al. 2008). It appears that these two species are separated by a forest barrier and by very dry habitat in the Eastern (Gregory) Rift Valley (De Jong et al. 2008, 2009, De Jong & Butynski 2014, Butynski & De Jong 2017). Erythrocebus baumstarki is also phenotypically distinct (e.g., black nose, lack of white moustache, pale red crown, white neck, and dark grey upper limbs, whereas pyrrhonotus has a white nose, white moustache, dark red crown, rufous neck, and lacks dark grey on the upper hind legs). Resurrecting baumstarki to species status is in agreement with Gippoliti (2017), who suggests treating baumstarki, as well as poliophaeus and pyrrhonotus, as species.

This species was treated in previous Red List assessments (1986 to 2008) under the genus Cercopithecus, but is now placed under Allochrocebus following Mittermeier et al. (2013). The genus name Allochrocebus was first used by Elliot in 1913 and later referred to as a geospecies by Grubb et al. (2003). The species is more terrestrial than any of the Cercopithecus taxa (Tosi et al. 2004, Oates 2011).

Booth (1955) and Napier (1981) treated this monkey as a subspecies of Cercopithecus campbelli within the C. mona group, but Kingdon (1997) made it a full species within his Cercopithecus mona superspecies. Groves (2001) followed Kingdon’s arrangement whereas Grubb et al. (2003) considered it a subspecies of C. campbelli. The latter treatment was followed for the 2008 Red List assessment. Groves (2005) continued to classify C. lowei as a distinct species, and that approach is followed by (Mittermeier et al. 2013) and in this assessment. However, such taxonomic splitting may be premature, because no rigorous genetic, morphological, or vocalization analyses have been applied to test species differences between the two taxa, and because individuals with pelage features of both putative species occur between the Cavally and Sassandra Rivers in eastern Côte d’Ivoire, as well as individuals with features intermediate between the two (Oates 1988).

Cercopithecus diana and C. roloway comprise the diana species group. In the 2008 IUCN Red List these taxa were treated as subspecies (C. d. diana and C. d. roloway) of a broader species-concept following Kingdon (1997) and Grubb et al. (2003). Groves (2005) elevated both to full species and that treatment is now followed here (based on Mittermeier et al. 2013). Not all assessors agree with this classification; Oates (2011) recognizes one species with two subspecies: diana and roloway.

Cercopithecus diana and C. roloway comprise the diana species group. In the 2008 IUCN Red List these were treated as subspecies (C. d. diana and C. d. roloway) of a broader species-concept following Kingdon (1997) and Grubb et al. (2003). Groves (2005) elevated both to full species and that treatment is now followed here (as in Mittermeier et al. 2013). Not all assessors agree with this classification; Oates (2011) treats roloway as a subspecies of C. diana.

authority: Hart, Detwiler, Gilbert, Burrell, Fuller, Emetshu, Hart, Vosper, Sargis & Tosi, 2012
taxonomicNotes: First described in 2012, Cercopithecus lomamiensis is closely related to, but distinct from, C. hamlyni based on morphological and molecular data (Hart et al. 2012, 2013).
Chan et al. (2010), suggested that the dubious records of Leptolalax gracilis from Gunung Tahan might actually represent this species.
Previously confused with Ansonia penangensis (Wood et al. 2008).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This species has been considered a subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius, Procolobus (Piliocolobus) pennantii, Procolobus (Piliocolobus) rufomitratus and Procolobus (Piliocolobus) kirkii, but is here treated as a full species, Piliocolobus gordonorum, following Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Grubb et al. (2003), Struhsaker et al. (2013), and Kingdon (1997, 2015).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Preuss’s Red Colobus was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) pennantii by Grubb et al. (2003), but as a distinct species by Kingdon (1997, 2015), Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), and Butynski and Kingdon (2013).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was formerly the nominate subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii that also included as subspecies parmentierorum, bouvieri, tholloni, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, lulindicus, langi, foai and semlikiensis (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) considered bouvieri and epieni to be subspecies of pennantii; Grubb et al. (2003) likewise, but also including preussi. Kingdon (2015) considered epieni to be a distinct species but maintained bouvieri as a subspecies of P. pennantii. Piliocolobus pennantii is here treated as a distinct monotypic species following Groves (2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) considered bouvieri and epieni to be subspecies of pennantii; Grubb et al. (2003) likewise, but also including preussi. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) considered that the Central African parmentierorum, bouvieri, tholloni, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, lulindicus, langi, foai and semlikiensis were also subspecies of pennantii. Kingdon (2015) treated epieni as a distinct species (but maintained bouvieri as a subspecies of P. pennantii). Groves (2007) treated epieni and bouvieri as distinct species, and pennantii as a monotypic. The study by Ting (2008) on vocalizations and mitochondrial DNA confirmed that P. epieni is not closely related to its closest geographic relatives (P. pennantii and P. preussi). The Niger Delta Red Colobus is here treated as a distinct monotypic species following Groves (2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, 2015; Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994; Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus semlikiensis is a little-known red colobus with an undecided and confusing taxonomic history. It has been treated as a synonym of ellioti Dollman, 1909, a subspecies of badius, of pennantii, of oustaleti (by implication), of rufomitratus (also by implication), and of foai, and, besides, a species in its own right. It was first described by Colyn (1991) as Colobus badius semlikiensis from the northern sector of Virunga National Park, east of the Semliki River. It was placed as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Groves (2001, 2005) considered it to be a subspecies of foai but, in his 2007 review of colobus taxonomy, he treated it as a full species. Grubb et al. (2003) treated semlikiensis as a synonym of a doubtfully valid subspecies ellioti, but did not ascribe ellioti to a species. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) treated ellioti (referring to it as the Semliki Red Colobus) as a subspecies of rufomitratus, but, citing Colyn (1993), noted that ellioti is a “highly variable subspecies and probably represents a large hybrid swarm involving langi and semlikiensis” (p.143). Kingdon (1997) considered both ellioti (from the Lubero Mts west of Lake George, and possibly a hybrid) and semlikiensis (a localised isolate in the Semliki Valley) to be subspecies of oustaleti, but in the second edition of his field guide (2015), he made no mention of semlikiensis but listed Piliocolobus oustaleti ellioti as the form from the Semliki River valley, implying as such that semlikiensis is a synonym. Groves (2007) believed that ellioti was described from a hybrid swarm that involved semlikiensis (in the east), langi (in the west) and oustaleti (in the north), and therefore not a valid taxon (a synonym of all three) and, contrary to Kingdon (2015), considered langi, oustaleti and semlikiensis to be the valid taxa (species) in the region. We follow Groves (2007) in treating P. semlikiensis as a valid species; however, we include in this taxon the populations that reside between Colyn’s (1991) semlikiensis (sensu stricto) and langi, all of which would have formerly been attributed to ellioti and may be part of a hybrid swarm. Further research needs to be done to resolve this taxonomy.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the olive colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011; Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the olive colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994; Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus lulindicus was recognised as a distinct taxon by Colyn (1991), who reviewed its nomenclatural history and resurrected the forms foai and lulindicus as subspecies of Colobus badius. He argued that the montane form foai (sensu stricto) in the east and lowland form lulindicus (sensu stricto) in the west are separated by an intermediate and possible hybrid lowland form, kabambarei Matschie. However, Groves (2007) considered both lulindicus and kabambarei as junior synonyms of Piliocolobus foai, noting continuous variation among these forms. The consensus at a workshop held in Rome in 2016 to update the African primate Red List assessments was that it would be expedient (precautionary) to continue to recognise lulindicus as a distinct taxon, considering the threatened status of all the red colobus monkeys. We include in this species Colyn’s (1991) lulindicus (sensu stricto) as well as the intermediate and potential hybrid populations that exist in the lowland regions to the west, with the western boundary being the Albertine rift where it is replaced by the montane form P. foai. Further research is needed to resolve this taxonomy.
Apparently closely related to A. superciliosa, A. zonorhyncha and A. poecilorhyncha. Monotypic.
Centropus chlororhynchos (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as C. chlororhynchus.

Previously included in Phodilus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) and shows some similarities to P. badius in plumage coloration, but shape of facial disc more heart-shaped and feathering of bill as in Tyto, leading to its treatment here in that genus as in Dickinson and Remsen (2013) and König et al. (1999). Monotypic.
Bubo blakistoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Ketupa.
Ramphiculus marchei (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Ptilinopus.

Afrotis afra (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Eupodotis.

Afrotis (Eupodotis) afra and E. afraoides (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) are retained as separate species contra Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) who included afraoides as a subspecies of E. afra.

Previously placed in Antigone (del Hoyo & Collar 2014), before which it was included within Grus, as it is once again (Handbook of the Birds of the World & BirdLife International 2021). 
Race gillae (misspelt gilliae in HBW [del Hoyo et al. 1996]) sometimes included in sharpii; fordi is a synonym. Possible subspecies luzonica (N Philippines, now presumed extinct) probably inseparable from sharpii. Three extant subspecies recognized.

Molecular data indicate that G. nigricollis is this species’ closest living relative (Krajewski & King 1996). Hybrids between this species and G. grus recorded on migration in NE China (Williams et al. 1992). Monotypic.

Laterallus spilopterus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously in the genus Porzana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). Stervander et al. (2019) found that Inaccessible Rail Atlantisia rogersi, Dot-winged Crake Porzana spiloptera and Yellow-breasted Crake Hapalocrex flaviventer nest within a clade of Laterallus crakes, with the first two grouped closely with Black Rail Laterallus jamaicensis. It thus appears appropriate to move all three species to the genus Laterallus, and this option is adopted by BirdLife.
Thinornis cucullatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as T. rubricollis; the name cucullatus has priority.
Buteogallus lacernulatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucopternis.
Urocissa whiteheadi and U. xanthomelana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as U. whiteheadi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lalage typica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina typica.
Lalage newtoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina newtoni.
Edolisoma ostentum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina ostenta.

Cichlopsis leucogenys, C. chubbi, C. peruviana and C. gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. leucogenys following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Cyornis brunneatus and C. nicobaricus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Rhinomyias brunneatus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Vauriella albigularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias albigularis.
Sturnornis albofrontatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus albofrontatus.
Zosterops melanocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Speirops melanocephalus.
Zosterops brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Speirops brunneus.
Previously listed as Garrulax sukatschewi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Monotypic.
Crithagra flavigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Serinus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cnemathraupis aureodorsalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Buthraupis following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Otus magicus and O. tempestatis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. magicus, and O. alfredi, O. siaoensis, O. enganensis, O. insularis and O. beccarii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were split from O. magicus following Widodo et al. (1999), Lambert and Rasmussen (1998), Andrew (1992) and Holt et al. (1999). Prior to that all these taxa were lumped in O. magicus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Recently discovered species; probably long overlooked as a result of morphological similarity and geographical proximity to G. jardinii, but vocally very distinct and also exhibits subtle but constant morphological differences. Probably most closely related to G. gnoma and G. costaricanum. Monotypic.
Celeus torquatus, C. occidentalis and C. tinnunculus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. torquatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Meiglyptes tristis and M. grammithorax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. tristis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Otidiphaps nobilis, O. aruensis, O. cervicalis and O. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. nobilis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Hylexetastes perrotii and H. uniformis were previously lumped as H. perrotii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and prior to that split into Hylexetastes perrotii (Ridgely and Tudor 1994), H. uniformis (Ridgely and Tudor 1994) and H. brigidai (da Silva et al. 1995). H. uniformis again regarded as a full species, with brigidai as a subspecies, following the genetic analyses of Azuaje-Rodríguez et al. (2020), who showed that despite close similarities in vocalisations, the genus is composed of three major lineages with diagnostic plumage differences (da Silva et al. 1995, Derryberry et al. 2012): perrotii, stresemanni, and uniformis. Two subspecies recognised.

Clanga hastata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.

Aquila pomarina (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into A. pomarina and A. hastata following Parry et al. (2002).
Previously included in Gallirallus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) but genetic analyses of Kirchman et al. (2021) indicate that it is better placed in its own monotypic genus. Monotypic.
Turnix varius and T. novaecaledoniae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Usually considered conspecific with small-billed subspecies (nominate and fraseri) of N. acunhae of Inaccessible I, but see related note/s. Cytochrome b sequence of present species appears identical to that of N. wilkinsi, but the two are highly distinct morphologically and behave as separate species, with separate vocal systems and no evidence of hybridization between them; treatment of present species as subspecies of N. acunhae (Dickinson and Christidis 2014) incompatible with genetic evidence of independent evolution on each island. Monotypic.

Nominate subspecies and fraseri formerly considered conspecific with N. questi of Nightingale I, but genetic evidence suggests independent evolution on each island. Subspecies of present species breed assortatively in coastal habitats, where large-billed dunnei and small-billed, drab nominate subspecies behave as distinct species (distinct songs, and territorial behaviour focused primarily on members of own subspecies); in contrast, all three subspecies interbreed in ecotone between Blechnum heath and Phylica woodland on the island’s plateau. Three subspecies recognized.
Formerly this species included Otomops martiensseni.
Previously this was included in H. turpis as H. turpis pendlebury. It has now been raised to species level.
Previously this was included in H. turpis as H. turpis alongensis. It has now been raised to species level.
This species was previously included in Hipposideros ater, but is now considered distinct following Douangboubpha et al. (2011).
This species has been split from Rhinopoma muscatellum by Hulva et al. (2007) and Benda et al. (2009).

Rhinolophus belligerator (Patrick, McCulloch, and Ruedas 2013) previously was included with R. arcuatus proconsulis by Hill (1988) based on a single specimen from the Tengah Province of Sulawesi. Subsequent analyses by Patrick and co-workers (2013) elevated this taxon to species status.
Records of Cardioglossa pulchra from Tchabal Mbabo (Amiet 1972) now refer to this species (Herrmann et al. 2004).

Lontra provocax had been considered a subspecies of L. canadensis (Davis 1978). It was placed in the genus Lontra by van Zyll de Jong (1987). Koepfli and Wayne (1998) and Bininda-Emonds et al. (1999) supported the separation of New World otters into genus Lontra from Lutra, except Pteronura.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011; Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

The form lulindicus, recognised by Colyn and Verhayen (1987), Colyn (1987, 1991), Grubb et al. (2003), and Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) (the last as a subspecies of Procolobus rufomitratus) was considered by Groves (2001, 2007) to be a junior synonym of Piliocolobus foai. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) placed all the Central African red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic], including lulindicus. Kingdon (1997, 2015) treated the Central African red colobus, including lulindicus, as subspecies of oustaleti. The consensus at a workshop held in Rome in 2016 to update the African primate Red List assessments was that it would be expedient (precautionary) to continue to recognise this species, considering the threatened status of all the red colobus monkeys.

Studies are needed to determine whether or not specimens from Cameroon and Togo belong to the same species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is currently unclear whether there are any Werneria species in Togo, but it has been suggested that if there is one, it could be either W. preussi or alternatively a different, distinct species, Werneria africanus, which would be an endemic species to Togo (see Segniagbeto et al. 2007).

Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here considered a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)). Rödel and Pauwels (2003) provisionally assigned records of L. albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to L. stevarti.
Iskandar (pers. comm.) has examined the type specimen, and considers that this species does not belong to the genus Oreophryne.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
We follow Rödel and Pauwels (2003) in provisionally assigning records of Leptodactylodon albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to this newly described species.

A.L. Silveira (pers. comm. 2010) considers this species a junior synonym of Tantilla pallida based on work in preparation to revise this widespread species complex. This work has still not been published as of 2019, and consequently this taxon is considered valid pending a formal taxonomic revision (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
The Atelognathus praebasalticus complex needs to be re-examined taxonomically. There are four known subspecies, some of which may constitute new species. Some of these subspecies may be extinct.

authority: Evans, Carter, Tobias, Kelley, Hanner & Tinsley, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species is considered to be the sister taxon of Xenopus wittei (Evans et al. 2008).

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

This taxon was previously considered as belonging to the otherwise central Ryukyu species Takydromus smaragdinus (Boulenger 1887), but is now recognized to be a distinct, phylogenetically rather distant species (see Lin et al. 2002, Ota et al. 2002).

Trionyx triunguis has been considered a single widespread, relatively uniform species for decades, with no subspecies or other taxonomic units recognized or proposed in recent years. Phylogeographic studies of regional variation have demonstrated different, partly conflicting results, but were based on generally limited sets of specimens and genetic markers (Gidis et al. 2011; Güçlü et al. 2011, 2015; Shanas et al. 2012). However, there is still uncertainty as to whether Mediterranean and African subpopulations may in fact represent genetically definable separate Management Units (O. Türkozan unpubl. data).

There are no recognized Trichechus senegalensis subspecies and limited genetic information indicates high genetic diversity (Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014). Anecdotal assertions of morphological differences between isolated inland populations and coastal populations persist, but there is no genetic or morphological evidence (Domning and Hayek 1986, Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014).

Current scientific review of the taxonomy of wild equids (Groves 1986) places Przewalski's Horse as a subspecies of the extinct Equus ferus. Although Przewalski's Horse (Equus ferus przewalskii) can hybridize with domestic horses (Equus ferus caballus) to produce fertile offspring (Ryder et al. 1978, Trommerhausen-Smith et al. 1979), the existence of 2n = 66 chromosomes in Przewalski's Horse identifies it as being more different from its domestic relatives (2n = 64) than are any two breeds of domestic horse (Ryder 1994). Furthermore, mitochondrial DNA research has shown that the Przewalski's Horse is not the ancestor of modern domestic horses (Vilà et al. 2001). Przewalski's Horse also show a number of consistent differences in their appearance as compared to domestic horse breeds: the mane is short and erect when in good body condition; forelocks are nearly nonexistent; the upper part of the tail has short guard hairs; a dark dorsal stripe runs from the mane down the spine to the tail; several dark stripes can be present on the carpus and generally the tarsus (Groves 1994). Przewalski's Horses grow a thick mane in winter, which contrary to domestic horses they shed each spring with the rest of their winter coat.

Other studies of the genetic differences between Przewalski's and domestic horses have indicated very little genetic distinction between them. Only four alleles at four separate serological marker loci have been identified as specific to Przewalski's Horse (Bowling and Ryder 1987); the vast majority of blood protein variants are present in both Przewalski's and domestic horses and even the fastest evolving DNA region known in mammals (the mitochondrial DNA control region), does not show significant differences between the two types of horse (Ishida et al. 1995, Oakenfull and Ryder 1998). Thus it is clear that Przewalski's and domestic horses are very closely related and have in the past interbred, but the fixed chromosomal number difference between them indicates that they are distinct populations (Oakenfull et al. 2000). A variety of molecular studies support their phylogenetic relationship as sister taxa (Steiner et al. 2012, Côté et al. 2013) diverging between 150,000 and 250,000 years ago (Goto et al. 2011, Steiner and Ryder 2011).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anaur, Grismer, Quah, Murdoch, Muin, Davis, Aguilar, Klabacka, Cobos, Aowphol & Sites, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This population represents a new species of karst-adapted Bent-toed Gecko from the Cyrtodactylus pulchellus complex. All the morphological and genetic data concerning this population has been evaluated and confirms its new species designation (Grismer et al. 2014)

Classically considered a single species, the Clouded Leopard has been split into two species. Based on analysis of mitochondrial DNA, microsatellites, chromosomal differences and skull and pelage characteristics, Neofelis nebulosa is restricted to mainland southeast Asia, and N. diardi, the Sunda Clouded Leopard, is found on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo (Buckley-Beason et al. 2006; Kitchener et al. 2006, 2007; Christiansen et al. 2008, 2009; Wilting et al. 2007; Wilting et al. 2011). Sundaland or the Sunda regions refer to the islands of Sumatra, Borneo, Java and Bali as well as to the Malay Peninsula. Although samples are limited from Peninsular Malaysia, it appears to be inhabited by the mainland Clouded Leopard N. nebulosa, rather than the Sunda Island type (Kitchener et al. 2007). The original type specimen of N. diardi originated from Sumatra, but it was initially recorded in error as from Java (Kitchener et al. 2006). As this type specimen described by Cuvier (1823) is not present in any museum, Christiansen 2009 designated a Neoptype (RMNH1981) from Palembang, Sumatra, which is housed at the National Museum of Natural History (Naturalis), in Leiden, the Netherlands. Clouded Leopard fossils have been found on Java, where it perhaps became extinct in the Holocene (Meijaard 2004). Based on analysis of genetic, skull and pelage characteristics, Wilting et al. (2011) recognized two distinct subspecies of N. diardi: the Sumatran Clouded Leopard N. d. diardi and the Bornean Clouded Leopard N. d. borneensis.

authority: Murphy, Berry, Edwards, Leviton, Lathrop & Riedle, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Gopherus morafkai, the Sonoran Desert Tortoise, was previously considered to be part of Gopherus agassizii (sensu lato), but was demonstrated to be morphologically, genetically, and ecologically distinct by Murphy et al. (2011) who described it as a new species. Further analysis demonstrated that G. morafkai was also a composite, and it was split further to separate and describe the Sinaloan Thornscrub Tortoise further to the south as Gopherus evgoodei (Edwards et al. 2016). This taxonomy of three species of desert tortoises has been accepted by the Turtle Taxonomy Working Group (TTWG 2017, 2021).

Thomson and Georges (2009) placed the taxon bellii in the genus Myuchelys, which they separated from Elseya, a classification followed in the revision by Georges and Thomson (2010) and Fielder et al. (2015). Molecular and morphological assessments have found no substantive differences among populations from the Gwydir, Namoi, and Border Rivers catchments (Fielder et al. 2012; Fielder 2013), with little evidence to support any taxonomic subdivision of M. bellii at the species or subspecies level, as suggested by Cann (1998) and Wells (2007). The generic name Wollumbinia (Wells 2002) has been rejected as unavailable for this taxon (Georges and Thomson 2010; Fielder et al. 2015).

This taxon was listed as Elseya sp. 1 in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists. It was incorrectly spelled Elseya belli on the IUCN Red List from 2002, but corrected in 2009 to E. bellii following Rhodin et al. (2008).

Elseya branderhorsti (Ouwens, 1914)1914 Emydura branderhorsti Ouwens, 1914, described from a live specimen, type either non-existent or lost (Leo Brongersma pers. comm. to John Goode 1967, 28 June 1963), from southern New Guinea. 1994 Elseya branderhorsti—Bour et al., in David, 1994. First use of combination. 
Commonly confused with Elseya novaeguineae because of its superficial resemblance. Original description states lack of a cervical scute as the diagnostic character, by which it can typically be distinguished from Elseya novaeguineae (recently split to recognise Elseya shultzei and Elseya rhodini). A prominent alveolar ridge on the triturating surfaces of the mouth is also diagnostic. DNA sequence data suggest affinities with the species of Elseya from northern Australia. No subspecies are recognised.

There are currently no recognized subspecies of Hydromedusa maximiliani. However, research suggests that northern and southern populations of the species may have diverged around 8 to 16 million years ago, during the Pliocene and Miocene periods (Souza et al. 2003). This indicates that some local populations of H. maximiliani could be genetically identified as a probable evolutionarily significant unit (Souza and Martins 2009).

This species was described in 1984 as Phrynops zuliae, based on seven individuals. It was subsequently assigned to the genus Batrachemys (McCord et al. 2001) and most recently considered within the genus Mesoclemmys (Bour and Zaher 2005). Ettmar (2019) mentioned that the type of Hydraspis maculata Gray 1873 (now considered a nomen oblitum, and a species that would correspond to what is currently known as M. wertmuthi, could be a juvenile specimen of Mesoclemmys zuliae. This assertion is unlikely. Very few European naturalists, if any, reached the southwestern lowlands of the Lake Maracaibo basin to collect biological samples during the first three quarters of the 18th Century. During that time the area of distribution of M. zuliae was hardly penetrable by foreigners due to the swampy nature of the region and the presence of notoriously hostile aboriginal people, not to mention the generally adverse political situation (independence war and subsequent military revolts). The type locality of Hydraspis maculata was thought to be Venezuela, but the type specimen surely comes from a still unknown locality in South America (Rivas et al. 2015). Most biological samples from Venezuela that reached European collections and museums during second half of the 19th century and the early 20th century came from the Venezuelan Andes and the Cordillera de la Costa (northern Cordillera) and were sent mainly to Germany, France and Switzerland and to a much lesser degree to the United Kingdom (see Rivas et al. 2023).
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the name Macroclemys temminckii. Was also treated by some authors under the generic name Macroclemmys.

Placed variously in Clemmys, Emys and Actinemys in recent years; the balance of opinion is split between Emys and Actinemys. Two subspecies were traditionally recognized, the typical A. m. marmorata (Baird & Girard, 1852), and A. m. pallida (Seeliger, 1945); some phylogenetic studies did not confirm this distinction and recommended abandoning the subspecies pallida (Spinks & Shaffer, 2005, 2009), but more recent work has now confirmed that these taxa are separate species (Spinks et al. 2014) and they are currently recognized as such (TTWG 2017). Additionally, an unnamed 'Baja California form' has been indicated based on morphological and molecular characteristics, but has not been formally described. Listed in the IUCN Red List from 1996 to 2006 under the name Clemmys marmorata.

Previously considered to encompass the Broad-headed Map Turtles inhabiting the Pascagoula and Pearl river systems, Graptemys gibbonsi was reduced in scope when the Pearl River form was described as a separate species, G. pearlensis Ennen, Lovich, Kreiser, Selman & Qualls, 2010.

Unpublished genetic analyses (L. Baretto, pers. comm.) do not support the proposal to consider this taxon as a subspecies of T. dorbigni but support the position of the most recent TTWG (2021) checklist that recognizes it as a valid species.

Cuora flavomarginata is generally considered to include the form evelynae as a subspecies (Ota et al. 2009), though Ernst et al. (2008) retained evelynae as a full species. The name sinensis has been applied to mainland Chinese populations as a subspecies, with the typical flavomarginata restricted to Taiwan, but recent reviews (Fritz and Havas 2007; Ota et al. 2009; TTWG 2010) have not recognised Taiwanese and mainland populations as taxonomically distinct.
