Cuora yunnanensis has been suggested to be an old example of an inter-specific hybrid, but a 1908 museum specimen was found to have unique mt-DNA indicating it to be a valid species status (Parham et al. 2004), and recent trade specimens of unreported origin agreed genetically with the 1908 specimen (He et al. 2007).

Hurtado-Gómez et al. (2024) analyzed phylogeographic structure and taxonomic limits within the genus Kinosternon.  In view of the deep divergence demonstrated within the genus, they proposed the recognition of three subgenera: Kinosternon, Cryptochelys, and Thyrosternum. The subgenus Cryptochelys was found to include K. angustipons, K. dunni, and K. leucostomum, with K. angustipons and K. dunni sister species. TTWG (in press) agrees with this proposed taxonomy.

Iverson et al. (2013) separated Kinosternon dunni and several other Kinosternon species into their new genus Cryptochelys based on morphology and genetics, but this was not corroborated by further genetic work by Spinks et al. (2014). Subsequently, Hurtado-Gómez et al. (2024) analyzed phylogeographic structure and taxonomic limits within the genus Kinosternon. In view of the deep divergence demonstrated within the genus, the authors proposed the recognition of three subgenera: Kinosternon, Cryptochelys, and Thyrosternum. The subgenus Cryptochelys was found to include K. angustipons, K. dunni, and K. leucostomum, with K. angustipons and K. dunni sister species. TTWG (in press) agrees with this proposed taxonomy.
Historically placed in Podocnemis. No subspecies are currently recognized.

The genus Peltocephalus is monotypic and although the only species has undergone nomenclatural changes, it has stabilized as Peltocephalus dumerilianus and so far, there are no known subspecies (Iverson and Vogt 2002; Gentil et al. 2021a).

Differences in the color of the cephalic blotches of Podocnemis erythrocephala between specimens of the Orinoco and Amazon populations have been noted (Castaño-Mora, 1997; Marín and Solórzano, 2015) and even suggested as indicative of the possible existence of two different species (Castaño-Mora, 1997). Michels and Vargas-Ramírez (2018) studied the phylogeography of this species and concluded that Orinoco populations are genetically different from those of the Amazon, enough to be recognized as a distinct Evolutionarily Significant Unit.

The most recent phylogenetic analysis by Pereira et al. (2017), based on 13 mitochondrial and nuclear gene loci, produced the following phylogenetic relationship: expansa (vogli (sextuberculata (unifilis (lewyana, erythrocephala)))); which was the same as that found by Vargas-Ramírez et al. (2008). A different relationship was produced by the analyses of Cadena et al. (2012): expansa (vogli (sextuberculata (erythrocephala (lewyana, unifilis)))), and by Iverson et al. (2007): erythrocephala (sextuberculata (lewyana (unifilis (expansa, vogli)))). These differences indicate the phylogenetic relationships between the species of the genus are still uncertain (Iverson et al. 2017). No subspecies are recognized.

Podocnemis unifilis Troschel 1848 has been universally accepted as the valid name for the Yellow-spotted River Turtle since its description, except for a very short time when the older name Emys cayennensis Schweigger 1812 was potentially considered the valid name due to its lectotype being a specimen of P. unifilis (Bour 2006). Further complicating the situation was that the name cayennensis had previously been widely but erroneously used for the Red-headed Side-necked Turtle, Podocnemis erythrocephala. As a result, Vogt et al. (2013) petitioned the ICZN (International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature) to conserve the name P. unifilis and to give it precedence over E. cayennensis, and in 2019 the ICZN ruled as such in agreement (ICZN 2019). No subspecies are recognized.
Placed by some as a subspecies under C. chitra.

Chelydra rossignonii was previously considered a geographically isolated subspecies of Chelydra serpentina. Phillips et al. (1996) elevated it and C. acutirostris to species level based on genetic differentiation. Chelydra rossignonii and C. acutirostris are sister species (Thomson et al. 2021).

This is the single living species and genus in this family which dates back to the Eocene. A number of synonyms have been published for the species, all obsolete and not used for a long time. The corrected but invalid spelling mawei has been supported by some taxonomists. Dermatemys mawii possesses 16 mitochondrial haplotypes throughout its distribution range and three major lineages. The first lineage, with a restricted distribution, is located at the Mexico-Guatemala border in the Sartún and Salinas rivers (upper Usumacinta River basin) and has an approximate origin of 1 million years ago (Martínez-Gómez 2017). The second group is restricted to the Papaloapan River in Veracruz, Mexico, and is surrounded by two geographical barriers (the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in Oaxaca and the Sierra de Santa Martha in Veracruz). The third group, with the widest distribution, spans the lower part of the Grijalva-Usumacinta system in the southeastern Gulf of Mexico to the Caribbean region, between Quintana Roo (Mexico) and Belize. Genetic differentiation among D. mawii populations (ƟST = 0.118) has been observed, and genetic diversity values can range from low to high depending on the locality (HO = 0.158-0.609) (González-Porter et al. 2013; Gallardo-Alvarez et al. 2019).  It has been suggested that the group located in the Sartún and Salinas rivers shows significant genetic differences, indicating the possible presence of a different species; however, preliminary morphological differences were not found (González-Porter et al. 2011). Despite this information, no taxonomic change has been conclusively determined or officially recognized (Turtle Taxonomy Working Group 2021).

Previously this species was known as Clemmys insculpta, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006; paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of insculpta and muhlenbergii into Glyptemys (Holman and Fritz 2001, Parham and Feldman 2002).

Previously this species was known as Clemmys muhlenbergii, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists until 2008. Paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of muhlenbergii and insculpta into Glyptemys.
Hybridization occurs with Graptemys ernsti in the Choctawhatchee River drainage of Alabama and Florida (Godwin et al. 2014).

Scientific debate of the taxonomy and number of species present in the genus Graptemys continues (Praschag et al. 2017) in contrast to Lindemann (2013) or the conclusions of Thomson et al. (2018). However, since its description there has been little debate regarding the unique characters and appropriate status as a distinct species for Graptemys caglei.

The Pearl River Map Turtle, Graptemys pearlensis, described by Ennen et al. (2010), was originally included as part of Graptemys pulchra Baur 1893 and then Graptemys gibbonsi Lovich and McCoy, 1992, with specimens from the Pearl River drainage referenced in both original descriptions of those taxa. This taxonomy has been accepted by Lindeman (2013) and TTWG (2021).

Currently considered to comprise six subspecies: Terrapene carolina carolina (Linnaeus, 1758), T. carolina bauri Taylor, 1895, T. carolina triunguis (Agassiz, 1857), T. carolina major (Agassiz, 1857), T. c. mexicana (Gray, 1849) and T. c. yucatana (Boulenger, 1895). The taxonomic status of the taxa yucatana and mexicana remains dynamic; they were treated as full species by Smith et al. (1996) and Stephens and Wiens (2003), but were treated as subspecies of carolina by Fritz and Havas (2007) and TTWG (2010). Butler et al. (2011) argued that the subspecies T. c. major is based on a phenotype resulting from introgression of genes of the extinct subspecies Terrapene c. putnami in eastern subspecies (mainly T. c. carolina) and does not warrant formal recognition.

Mertens and Wermuth (1995) suggested the taxon be considered a subspecies of Terrapene ornata. Iverson et al. (2007) proposed T. coahuila as the sister taxon to T. carolina. There are no subspecies and no synonymised taxa. Martin et al. (2021) interpreted their genetic results as showing T. coahuila to be a full species deep within the T. carolina clade, most closely related to the western population of T. c. major. TTWG (2021) agrees that T. coahuila is a distinct species.

Traditionally considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, recognised as full species by several authors, including Seidel (2002). Seidel (2002) placed two taxa as subspecies of T. gaigeae: T. gaigeae gaigeae (Hartweg, 1939), and T. gaigeae hartwegi (Legler, 1990).
This taxon has traditionally been considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta (Legler 1990), but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002).

This taxon was considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta but noted as sufficiently distinct to warrant species rank by Legler (1990), and formally elevated to full species by Seidel (2002). Molecular analyses of the genus Trachemys was performed by Jackson et al. (2008); Spinks et al. (2009); Parham et al. (2015); Seidel and Ernst (2016) and they were consistent in finding T. taylori to be monophyletic.

This taxon was traditionally considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002). According to Legler (1990), T. yaquia is closely related to T. ornata.

Traditionally placed in Chinemys, reevesii has in recent years been widely accepted as a species of Mauremys (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010). The species includes the forms Chinemys megalocephala Fang, 1934, Geoclemys grangeri Schmidt, 1925, and Damonia unicolor Gray, 1873, which have on occasion been considered as valid species or subspecies, but have in recent years been treated consistently as synonyms of reevesii (Guo et al. 1997, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010, Rhodin et al. 2021).
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of S. tuberilinguis.

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Brede, Hillers & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Hirschfeld, Brede, Emmrich, Kouamé, Hillers, Gonwouo, Nopper, Adeba, Bangoura, Gage, Anderson & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Hirschfeld, Brede, Bangoura & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

Feldhamer et al. (1988) and Geist (1998) included Dama mesopotamica as a subspecies of Dama dama, though it was regarded as a separate species by Haltenorth (1959), Ferguson et al. (1985), Uerpmann (1987), and Harrison and Bates (1991). We follow Pitra et al. (2004) and Randi et al. (2001) in treating D. mesopotamica as a separate species, based on a major study on the evolution and phylogeny of old world deer.
Prior to its naming, this species was confused with Epipedobates boulengeri and Epipedobates espinosai according Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz (2011 "2010").
This species was previously included in the genus Hyloscirtus, then to moved to the genus Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), and later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

authority: Guayasamin, Rivera-Correa, Arteaga-Navarro, Culebras, Bustamante, Pyron, Peñafiel, Morochz, & Hutter, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus alytolylax (Guayasamín et al. 2015). Museum specimens recorded as H. alytolylax should be reviewed as some may pertain to this species.

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012

taxonomicNotes: It has not been included in phylogenies based on genetic traits, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain. It has not yet been assigned to any group of species.
Brito et al. (2017) provided records of Pristimantis aff. gualacenio from Tinguichaca, Sambalán and Cisnian, Morona Santiago.
This species was previously considered as incertae sedis, however the validity of this species has now been confirmed (Jungfer et al. 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

Lötters et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence that this nominal species is a complex of species. The specimens from the Departamento Piura, Peru belong to an undescribed species (Coloma et al. 2000).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by McDiarmid (1971).

Coloma, Lötters and Salas (2000) redefined Atelopus ignescens and restricted the species to the north-central Andes of Ecuador. Populations in northern Ecuador (in Cachi Province), and adjacent southern Colombia (Narino Department), previously assigned to Atelopus ignescens are now considered to belong to an undescribed species.

The specimens in the lowlands may be a different species as they are based on old museum specimens and doubtful collecting localities. Tapia et al. (2017) excluded these records from the current known range of the species and therefore they are considered as Presence Uncertain in this reassessment until they can be reassigned to another taxon. Reports from Valle del Cauca Department in Colombia, refer to an unidentified, probably unnamed species and are excluded from this assessment.
Records other than from the type locality (e.g. Peters 1973) are considered here to refer to Atelopus planispina.

The taxonomic status of Atelopus planispina and A. palmatus was discussed by Coloma (1997). Records of A. palmatus from Napo Province actually belong to this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).

Gluesenkamp and Guayasamin (2008) this species is reported in the Sumaco Volcano, but in fact they are males of Osornophryne sumacoensis verified by Páez-Moscoso et al. (2011). The identity of the specimens from the northern part of Parque Nacional Llanganates requires confirmation.

Hyloxalus cevallosi and Leucostethus fugax are similar (as originally described in 1991 and 1993 respectively) and their type localities are from the same general area in Río Bobonaza, Provincia Pastaza. The description of H. cevallosi was based on a single male, with no mention of having a Finger III swollen and by having a brownish-grey venter. Whereas the L. fugax description was based on a series of specimens, of which the holotype was a male with a Finger III swollen and a uniform cream venter. After 1993, collections in the area have revealed specimens of only one species with a Finger III swollen in males and having tubercles in the eyelid (present also in other species of Leucostethus). The specimens with these unique two features have been identified in museum collections ambiguously either as L. fugax or H. cevallosi (e.g. QCAZ Bioweb). Until further verification of the identity of H. cevallosi is undertaken we treat H. cevallosi as occurring only from the localities mentioned in the original description (Coloma and Duellman in prep.).
The subpopulation from Pastaza Province reported by Coloma (1995) belongs to an undescribed species (L. Coloma pers. comm.)
This form probably contains a number of undescribed species, according to Rivero (1991).
This may represent a species complex.
This species needs a more detailed taxonomic review, as it may be a species confused with Hyloxalus maculosus (J.C. Sánchez pers. comm. 2021).

Its possible that this is a species complex, with the northern-most subpopulation appearing different from the subpopulation at the type locality in the Cordillera del Condor (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia and M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021).

The assignment of the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas to this species is tentative, but is justified by the absence of significant differences between the original description of Paruwrobates whymperi and these specimens. Paruwrobates erythromos (Vigle and Miyata 1980) is similar to P. whymperi and might be conspecific. However, comparison of P. erythromos and the type specimen of P. whymperi is complicated due to the bad preservation of the holotype of P. whymperi; differences in ventral colour patterns might be a preservation artefact. Comparison of P. erythromos and the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas reveal that they are not conspecific (Coloma 1995).

Santos et al. (2014) moved this species from Ameerega to Hyloxalus, then Grant et al. (2017) moved it to the current genus and suggest the possibility that it is the same species as Paruwrobates whymperi.
This species and Epipedobates anthonyi were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. tricolor to central Ecuador.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The genus Gastrotheca has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
This taxon represents a species complex (J.C. Sánchez pers comm. 2016).
Some subpopulations may be misidentifications (J.C. Sánchez, M. Yañez-Muñoz, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016).

This is a species complex and the only confirmed localities are Sigsig in the province of Azuay and Urdaneta in the province of Loja (Székely et al. 2017, Urgilés et al. 2017; M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2021). Urgilés et al. (2017) revised the species, recognizing Pristimantis cajanuma, from within the previous concept. Lynch (1979) states that this species occurs on the eastern Andean Cordillera from the Cuenca hoya to the Loja hoya in southern Ecuador. However, Urgilés et al. (2017). suggest that this distribution might be inaccurate and needs to be reviewed, as many of the records are probably erroneous belonging to very similar, but in fact different species.
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis ornatissimus following the split of the broader concept into this and Pristimantis ecuadorensis (Guayasamin et al. 2017).

The forms in the north (Imbabura and Pichincha) and south (Bolivar) of this range pertain to undescribed species (Rojas Runjaic 2012, Franco Mena 2020, Ecuador National Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Pristimantis riveti was described from a single specimen collected in Ecuador, El Mirador (Despax 1911). This species name was not associated with any population until Lynch (1969) incorrectly identified subpopulations of P. curtipes as “P. riveti” (Lynch 1979). Subsequently, Lynch (1979) provided a species account based on specimens collected near Cuenca, Azuay Province, in southern Ecuador, but remarkably, excluded the type locality from his account. Subsequent references to the species (e.g., Almendáriz and Orcés 2004, Székely et al. 2016) relied on the morphological characterization provided by Lynch (1979) and ascribed the binomen to subpopulations from Azuay, Cañar and Loja Provinces. 

Various species (e.g., P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi) have been mistakenly identified as P. riveti (Páez and Ron 2019). Therefore, this is a restricted concept of Pristimantis riveti following the split of the broader concept into this, P. gloria, P. lutzae, P. multicolor and P. chomskyi (Páez and Ron 2019).

Some previous authors referred to this species as Eleutherodactylus trepidotus (e.g., Lynch and Duellman 1980, Lynch 1984, Almendáriz et al. 2004, Stuart et al. 2008) until Pristimantis festae was deemed the senior synonym (Heinicke et al. 2007, Hedges et al. 2008).
It is a species complex.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).
The northern subpopulation could belong to an undescribed species.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).

In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus buenaventura is distinguished from other species of glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007).

In the genus Nymphargus following Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Guayasamin et al. (2006) indicate that the species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colouration differences and allopatric distributions. Guayasamin et al. (2006) adopt the Evolutionary Species Concept in their description of Nymphargus wileyi.

Frost (2021) indicates that this taxon was removed from the synonymy of Colostethus bocagei by Santos et al. (2003), by implication of their placement of this taxon in a phylogenetic tree away from C. bocagei, where it had been placed by Coloma (1995); but Coloma in Duellman (2004) suggested that C. maculosus remains a synonym of C. bocagei, which is contrary to the results of Santos et al. (2003). Páez-Vacas et al. (2010) considered this species to be part of the Hyloxalus bocagei complex, distinct from H. bocagei.
Atelopus petersi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
Formerly included within Leptodactylus pentadactylus; separated by Heyer (2005).
Atelopus onorei can be distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
It is possible that this species could be a taxonomic complex, however the current data cannot confirm this (Guayasamin et al., 2015).

authority: Arteaga, Pyron, Peñafiel, Romero-Barreto, Culebras, Bustamante, Yánez-Muñoz & Guayasamin, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Some subpopulations of Pristimantis walkeri in northwestern Ecuador belong to P. nietoi (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).

authority: Arteaga, Pyron, Peñafiel, Romero-Barreto, Culebras, Bustamante, Yánez-Muñoz & Guayasamin, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Subpopulations of Pristimantis walkeri in southwestern Ecuador belong to P. buenaventura (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). The Río Guayllabamba south of the two reserves appears to serve as a geographical barrier separating P. cedros from P. calcarulatus and its sister taxon, P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.

Páez and Ron (2019) identify that Pristimantis hampatusami (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2016) and Pristimantis prometeii (Székely et al. 2016) correspond to the same species and propose that P. prometeii is a junior synonym of P. hampatusami.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pristimantis cedros and P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015).

authority: Wood, Grismer, Grismer, Ahmad, Chan & Bauer, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Gonocephalus kuhlii was synonymized within G. chameleontinus by Barbour (1912), but this action has not been widely followed in recent literature (e.g. Das 2010, Manthey 2010).

authority: Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Chan, Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Savage, Grismer, Ahmad, Remigio & Greer, 2010
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Cnemaspis temiah was described based on a population of Cnemaspis from the Cameron Highlands that was long recognized but previously considered to belong to C. flavolineata (Grismer et al. 2014).

authority: (Wogan, Win, Thin, Lwin, Shein, Kyi & Tun, 2003)

taxonomicNotes: We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering this species to be distinct from Rana macrocnemis at the species level. It is confirmed through molecular data to occur in Çakıroluk (type locality) and Girdev Lake (U. Kaya pers. comm. December 2018).
This species is very similar to Liolaemus wiegmanni, and it has been suggested the two taxa may be conspecific (Etheridge 2000).

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of yak under Bos mutus, while the domestic form is considered under Bos grunniens (see Gentry et al. 1996).

Grubb (2005) lists mutus as a subspecies of grunniens, contrary to most authors.
This is a polymorphic species that presents different morphotypes adapted to aquatic or terrestrial environments (Cuello et al. 2008).

authority: Grismer, Belabut, Quah, Chan, Wood & Hasim, 2014

taxonomicNotes: There is unpublished morphological and genetic data suggesting that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (R. Bray unpubl. data). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Oligosoma lichenigerum.

The typical subspecies Aprasia rostrata rostrata was listed previously on the IUCN Red List, but as the other subspecies A. r. fusca Storr, 1979 is now recognized as a good species, the typical subspecies now becomes a full species.

The taxonomic history of Cyrtodactylus pulchellus is summarized by Grismer et al. (2016). This species was described from Pulau Penang based on a small number of characters by Cantor (1847), and the name was subsequently widely applied for populations on nearby islands and the Malay Peninsula (Grismer et al. 2016). Over the past decade, subpopulations outside Penang have been described as distinct species (summarized in Grismer et al. 2016), restricting C. pulchellus sensu stricto to this island.

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Mohamed, Chan, Sumarli, Loredo & Heinz, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012
Cobos, Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar & Muin, 2016

taxonomicNotes: The Bonobo is also known as the Gracile Chimpanzee; formerly it was known as Pygmy Chimpanzee and Dwarf Chimpanzee. Population genetics suggest that Bonobos have a stable population history (Eriksson et al. 2004, Schubert et al. 2013), and that gene flow between populations is constrained by the larger riverine barriers (although Bonobos regularly enter water, they do not swim).

Reviewed by McDowell and Bogert (1954), McDowell (1967), Mertens (1961) and Underwood (1957). Based on a study of the structure of the ears, McDowell (1967) considered the family to be closely related to the extinct Mosasauridae from the Cretaceous and Rieppel (1983) showed that the only living species in the family, Lanthanotus borneensis (Steindachner, 1878), exhibits no special similarities with primitive snakes in his study of cranial structure. Rieppel (1980) showed that the genus Lanthanotus Steindachner, 1878, forms the sister-taxon of Varanus, the two lineages together forming the sister-taxon of the New World Heloderma.

In a combined morphological and molecular analysis of the Eutropis multifasciata complex, Amarasinghe et al. (2018) concluded that Eutropis grandis represents a junior synonym of E. macrophthalma. This has implications for the distribution of this taxon; Amarasinghe et al. (2018) consider it likely that the E. macrophthalma type locality on Java is in error, and that the holotype - which falls genetically within samples of E. grandis from Sulawesi - was in fact collected on the latter island.

authority: Grismer, Huat, Siler, Chan, Wood, Grismer, Sah & Ahmad, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species is species complex, further research needed to clarify its species boundary (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

Populations that may be referrable to this species have been found in the southeast and central Arnhem scarp (Oliver and Parkin 2014, P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). The known specimens from these localities exhibit a degree of morphological differentiation from Strophurus horneri, and molecular data is required to confirm their identity (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). Pending further taxonomic work these records are excluded from this assessment.

The type specimen of Myron resetari was described in 2011 from a preserved specimen at the Queensland Museum labelled as M. richardsoni (Holotype:  QM J52861. Type Locality: Broome, Western Australia) (Murphy 2011). The type locality was not specific and only alluded to the vicinity of Roebuck Bay adjacent to Broome, WA (From Murphy 2011: “Known only from the type locality, Broome, Western Australia; but it may be more widespread. Given Myron’s use of mangroves and mudﬂats it seems likely this snake is from the Roebuck Bay area of the Dampier Peninsula.”). There were no live specimens recorded until October 2013 when Scott van Barneveld and Steve Wilson recorded an additional five specimens alive during nocturnal searches. Subsequent to this first record of live individuals Scott van Barneveld made a thorough search of the Roebuck Bay region of Broome and recorded a further 22 individuals between 2013 and 2016. Multiple specimens have since been reported from Roebuck Bay in the vicinity of Broome.

Myron resetari is distinguished from M. richardsonii by the presence of one preocular scale as opposed to two preoculars in M. richardsonii, and by 19 mid-body scale rows as opposed to 21 in M. richardsonii and its largest upper labial is the 5th compared with the largest upper labial of 6 or 7 in M. richardsonii.

The species status needs to be revisited (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). It exhibits very low genetic divergence and few morphological differences from two species occurring in nearby areas (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
Tamias bulleri is recognized under the genus Neotamias (Patterson and Norris 2016).

This species was revised by Wang et al. (1993). It is a well-defined species sharply distinct from the parapatric or marginally sympatric M. chrysogaster; see Grubb (1982).

Four subspecies are recognized by Grubb (2005):
M. b. berezovskii Flerov, 1929; Sichuan, Qinghai, Tibet
M. b. bjiangensis Wang & Li, 2003; northwestern Yunnan;
M. b. caobangis Dao, 1969; Yunnan, Guangxi, Guangdong, northern Viet Nam;
M. b. yunguiensis Wang & Ma, 1993; Yunnan-Guizhou highland, Hunan, Jiangxi; Wang (2003) lists an unnamed form as occurring in south Gansu, Ningxia, south Shaanxi, west Hubei and west Henan (Wang et al. 1993); Wemmer (1998).

Moschus anhuiensis has in the past been included in this species (Yang et al. 2003); it is still not clear whether or not the recognized subspecies are really part of this species. The subspecies M. b. caobangis is a good candidate for separate species status, but this has never been looked at (J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.). Until recently the Viet Namese population was considered to be M. moschiforus by Russian scientists (much literature follows this; J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanolanius madagascarinus and C. comorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. madagascarinus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hypsipetes parvirostris and H. moheliensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. parvirostris following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Larvivora akahige and L. tanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Erithacus and lumped as E. akahige following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hylocitrea bonensis and H. bonthaina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. bonensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Junco hyemalis and J. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as J. hyemalis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994).
Cyornis herioti and C. camarienensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. herioti following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Amarasinghe et al. (2014) recognized the Knuckles Range population of Calotes liocephalus as a new species C. pethiyagodai on morphological grounds. These authors cautioned that little material was available for either this species or C. liocephalus and that further research should be conducted to confirm this arrangement..

One of two Malaysian syntypes of Calotes floweri, taken from Gunung Tahan (Boulenger 1912), was assigned as the holotype of the new species Pseudocalotes dringi by Hallermann and Böhme (2000). The other appears to have been lost (Hallermann and Böhme 2000) but presumably also represents P. dringi. A record of P. floweri (Boulenger, 1912) from Kon Tum Province by Bain et al. (2007) was re-assigned to P. ziegleri by Hallermann et al. (2010).

authority: Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Orlov, Nguyen, Nazarov, Ananjeva & Ngoc Sang, 2007
Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Nguyen, Milto, Martynov, Konstantinov & Chulisov, 2014

taxonomicNotes: There is a need to review the taxonomic relationship between this species and Crytodactylus rufford, to determine whether they are synonymous (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Nguyen, Le, Van Pham, Ngo, Hoang, The Pham & Ziegler, 2015
Sumontha, Pauwels, Kunya, Nittikul, Samphanthamit & Grismer, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Nguyen et al. (2017) found that Cyrtodactylus cattiensis, which resembles C. thuongae morphologically, has a wider range than previously recognized in southern Viet Nam. As presently understood both species co-occur in this area, and molecular research is required to clarify taxonomic boundaries within both species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Hayden, Brown, Gillespie, Setiadi, Linkem, Iskandar, Umilaela, Bickford, Riyanto, Mumpuni & McGuire, 2008
Botov, Phung, Nguyen, Bauer, Brennan & Ziegler, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko thakhakhensis, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Luu, Calame, Nguyen, Le, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko bonkowskii, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).
Proposed taxonomic revisions would place this species and other North American skinks in the genus Plestiodon (Brandley et al. 2005).

There are unresolved taxonomic issues within Eremiascincus antoniorum and E. timorensis (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). 

It is unknown whether some or all of the undescribed Eremiascincus species reported by O'Shea et al. (2015) are conspecific to E. antoniorum. Greer (1990) assumed that records from lowland Timor represent this species based on morphological similarities, and suggested that this may also be the case for records of "E. emigrans" from other eastern islands in the Lesser Sundas, but neither he nor O'Shea et al. (2015) systematically investigated the taxonomy of this material.
The records form central Sulawesi need examination to determine whether it is the same species (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

The Lesser Sundas Python was formerly recognized in the genus Python, and later included in the genus Broghammerus (Hoser 2004) that is considered invalid as it lacked accompanying data and analysis (Kaiser et al. 2011). Reynolds et al. (2014) therefore erected the new genus Malayopython, that has since been supported (Barker and Barker 2015, Murray-Dickson et al. 2017, Barker et al. 2018), and includes the two species M. reticulatus and M. timoriensis.

A subpopulation on Rinca Island has been recorded that likely reveals a new sister species of M. timoriensis (Barker et al. 2018).

Boophis brachychir is sometimes confused with Boophis madagascariensis and was removed from synonymy with it by Glaw and Vences (1992). Subsequently, Glaw et al. (2010) removed Boophis entingae from synonymy with B. brachychir.

While Amiet (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of Hyperolius tuberculatus which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following expert consensus (R. Bell and S. Lötters pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

Several recent molecular studies have provided support for a monophyletic assemblage of South American endemic canids (Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010), with Chrysocyon and Speothos forming a sister-clade to the monophyletic south American foxes and Atelocynus. On the basis of morphology, Zunino et al. (1995) reviewed previous work and also supported clustering species within the two previous paraphyletic genera (Pseudalopex, Lycalopex) into a single monophyletic genus. They further argued that Lycalopex had priority over Pseudalopex, subsequently also supported by Zrzavý et al. (2004: 324). The only outstanding question would have been whether Dusicyon would have been a more appropriate name, since Perini et al. (2010) reported a close relationship between L. culpaeus and Dusicyon. However, we now know that Dusicyon is far outside this clade (Slater et al. 2009, Austin et al. 2013). Based on this evidence, the genus Lycalopex is used over Pseudalopex for all South American foxes, following Wozencraft's (2005) earlier treatment.
This is a split from the broader concept of Pithecopus azureus (Bruschi et al. 2014).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

authority: Ahmadzadeh, Flecks, Carretero, Mozaffari, Böhme, Harris, Freitas & Rödder, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Anderson (1999) suggested that the population from Mazanderan in the valley of the Rud-e Atrak of the Kopet Dagh may prove to be a distinct taxon. This form has subsequently been described as the new species Darevskia kopetdaghica by Ahmadzadeh et al. (2013).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean populations of Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group of skinks nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Unfortunately this author, who did not conduct a molecular study of Indian Ocean taxa, neglected to address an earlier recommendation by Rocha et al. (2006) that "Molecular data on these taxa [C. b. aldabrae, C. b. gloriosus and C. b. bitaeniatus] are crucial for any further assessment of their taxonomic status".

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but these authors do not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.


Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms (including the Comoran C. b. ater and C. b. mohelicus – F. Glaw pers. comm. June 2011) suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Both the provenance and the identity of three records of this species, from Woodleigh Station, have been questioned. These were reported from "limestone uplands with Acacia grasbyi scrub" in 1997 by Aplin et al. (unpublished), who noted that the specimens did not differ in size, characters or patterning from southern populations. Subsequent visits to the area have reported no limestone upland habitats in this area and tissue samples appear to have gone missing (G. Gaikhorst pers. comm. 2017). Genetic analysis is recommended should the specimens be recovered or additional records obtained from the Woodleigh locality (Alpin et al. unpublished, G. Gaikhorst and M. Cowan pers. comm. 2017).

Molecular, morphological and ecological work soon to be published has demonstrated that the Victorian and New South Wales populations of Liopholis guthega represent different species (Z. Atkins in prep.)
There has not been a formal synonymy, however, genetic data have suggested that Oreophrynella dendronastes is a synonym of this species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).

Originally described as Colostethus praderioi (La Marca 1997) and later transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006) on the basis of phylogenetic evidence combining molecular and phenotypic data. Kok (2010) redescribed the species with additional samples from Guyana. In the Anomaloglossus beebei species group sensu Grant et al. (2017).

This species was originally described on the basis of a single immature female (La Marca 1997). It was redescribed based on new material and direct comparison with the holotype by Kok et al. (2013). 

Like many other Anomaloglossus species, A. roraima displays an impressive intraspecific variation in color pattern. This phenotypic variability, coupled with the fact that the species occurs on different tepuis, could lead to inappropriate taxonomic decisions (i.e., describing subpopulations from different tepuis as new), which has been done in the past with other Pantepui taxa (Kok et al. 2013).

Jowers et al. (2008) demonstrated that the genus Phyllodytes is paraphyletic on the basis of evidence from mitochondrial gene sequences. These authors showed that the levels of divergence of Phyllodytes auratus and the Brazilian Phyllodytes were greater than the intergeneric distance within tribu Lophiohylini and erected the genus Phytotriades for the species then known only from Trinidad (= Phytotriades auratus). Recently Blotto et al. (2020) demonstrated that Phytotriades is the sister taxon of Itapotihyla, and together form the sister group of all other Lophyohylini, supporting its distinctiveness to Phyllodytes spp.

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010) but referred as unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). Their phylogenetic relationships within the genus remain unknown.
This is a split from the broader concept of Tepuihyla edelcae (Kok et al. 2015).
Groves (2011) considered that the two taxa of Ailuridae, Ailurus fulgens fulgens and A. f. styani, should be treated as two separate species.
Larvivora ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Symposiachrus sacerdotum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha sacerdotum.

We consider this species to be separate from Hynobius leechii, following Yang et al. (1997). This is also a restricted concept of this species now that H. unisacculus has been split from it by Min et al. (2016).

Chrysocolaptes lucidus, C. guttacristatus, C. stricklandi, C. strictus, C. haematribon, C. erythrocephalus and C. xanthocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. lucidus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

All members of genus Suthora now moved to the family Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Sinosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and prior to that listed in Paradoxornis, but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Two subspecies recognized.

authority: Greenbaum, Stanley, Kusamba, Moninga, Goldberg & Bursey, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Machlolophus nuchalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus nuchalis.

Due to the taxonomic confusion of this species and E. coqui, some lowland records of this species are thought to belong to E. coqui and are therefore excluded from this assessment (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment). Furthermore, all historical specimens from the Cordillera Central (up to Maricao) and any references to the extirpation of these subpopulations should be re-evaluated. Initial evidence based on morphology, osteology, bioacoustics, and ecology, reveals that records of E. portoricensis in this region may actually correspond to a presumable subspecies of E. coqui (Ríos-López et al. in prep.).

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice.Has been considered conspecific with either or both of H. certhiola and H. ochotensis, but differs in voice, morphology and ecology. Molecular data reveal intraspecific structure among populations assigned to present species, while simultaneously suggesting that H. ochotensis shows remarkably little divergence (Drovetski et al. 2004, Drovetski et al. 2015). Monotypic.
Previously placed in monotypic Chaetornis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to Schoenicola following Alström et al. (2018). Monotypic.

Calamonastides gracilirostris and C. bensoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Chloropeta gracilirostris following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Laticilla burnesii and L. cinerascens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Prinia burnesii following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The former separation into the Western subspecies Cricetus cricetus canescens is no longer valid due to recent genetic studies (Neumann et al. 2004, 2005; Stefen 2013; Schroder et al. 2014). Several genetic lineages exist within the species (Banaszek et al. 2010; Neumann et al. 2004, 2005).

In 2000, this taxon was assessed for The IUCN Red List under the name Spermophilus brunneus brunneus; it is has since been transferred to the genus Urocitelus (Helgen et al. 2009) and in 2017 it was also raised to species level, replacing the entry for Urocitellus brunneus that previously appeared on The IUCN Red List. Yensen (1991) and Gill and Yensen (1992) suggested the two subspecies, U. b. brunneus and U. b. endemicus, may be full species. Although Thorington and Hoffmann (2005) listed endemicus as a synonym, genetic studies by Hoisington-Lopez et al. (2012) confirmed species-level separation. Urocitellus brunneus and U. endemicus are now recognized as monotypic species.

Spermophilus canus and S. mollis formerly were included in S. townsendii. Baker et al. (2003) and Thorington and Hoffmann (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) recognized the three taxa as distinct species, noting their distinct cytotypes and lack of hybridization. This species is now recognized under a new genus, Urocitellus (Helgen et al. 2009).

Further research is required to confirm that Gekko ulikovskii is a junior synonym of G. badenii, as proposed by Nguyen et al. (2010) and accepted here. Other members of this species group are separated from one another by around 1-200 km, while the type localities of G. badenii and G. ulikovskii are separated by about 400 km2 (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Further material from the G. badenii type locality, and molecular data for G. ulikovskii, will be necessary to resolve the systematics of this taxon (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Molecular analysis shows Crocidura mdumai to be a member of the Crocidura monax clade (Stanley et al. 2015). Although C. mdumai is endemic to the Ngorongoro Crater, it is a member of a clade that includes the East and West Usambaras (C. tansaniana), the South Pares (C. usambarae), Mt Meru (Crocidura newmarki), Kilimanjaro and North Pare (Crocidura monax), and the middle Eastern Arc Mountains (EAM): Rubeho, Ukaguru, Uluguru, and Udzungwa (Crocidura munissii). This geographic distribution of members of the C. monax complex is significant as it spans two geologically distinct mountains groups the Northern Highlands and the EAM (Stanley et al. 2015).

Gopherus huecoensis † Strain 1966, described from the Pleistocene of Texas, is considered a synonym of G. flavomarginatus, reflecting the previous wider distribution of this species into the southwestern USA, including Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.

authority: (De la Riva, Aparicio, Soto & Ríos in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)
(De la Riva, Ríos & Aparicio in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).
This is a restricted concept of Zhangixalus dorsoviridis following the split of the broader concept into this and Zhangixalus pinglongensis (Mo et al. 2016).
The former species Lyciasalamandra billae, L. arikani, L. irfani and L. yehudai have been designated as subspecies under this new concept (Veith et al. 2016).

Johnson et al. (2006) and Eizirik et al. (submitted) placed the Borneo Bay Cat (Catopuma badia) with the Asiatic Golden Cat (C. temminckii) and Marbled Cat (Pardofelis marmorata) in the genus Pardofelis, representing one of the earliest felid radiations (O'Brien and Johnson 2007). The Borneo Bay Cat is not a small island form of the Asiatic Golden Cat, as previously thought, having diverged from its extant relatives approximately four million years ago, well before the separation of Borneo from the mainland (Johnson et al. 1999, O'Brien and Johnson 2007).

An evaluation of skull morphology by Sicuro and Oliveira (2011) revealed that skull structure in Pardofelis is quite different from that in Catopuma. Moreover, Pardofelis has a flexible ankle joint and elongated tail, presumably adaptations to arboreality, which are lacking in Catopuma. Based on these morphological differences and the early split of the Asiatic Golden Cat and the Borneo Bay Cat from the Marbled Cat in the Late Miocene (5.86 Mya), the Cat Classification Task Force of the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group retains both the Borneo Bay Cat and Asiatic Golden Cat in Catopuma (CCTF in prep.)

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Nothophryne broadleyi (Conradie et al. 2018).

authority: Rodriguez, Dugo-Cota, Montero-Mendieta, Gonzalez-Voyer, Alonso Bosch, Vences & Vilà, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Specimens assigned to this taxon were originally considered to be Eleutherodactylus glamyrus (Rodríguez et al. 2017).

authority: Sumontha, Chomngam, Phanamphon, Pawangkhanant, Viriyapanon, Thanaprayotsak & Pauwels, 2017
Waser, Schweizer, Haas, Das, Jankowski, Min & Hertwig, 2017

taxonomicNotes: Previously confused with Chaismocleis lacrimae and Chaismocleis capixaba according to the original publication.

authority: Forlani, Tonini, Cruz, Zaher & de Sá, 2017
Forlani, Tonini, Cruz, Zaher & de Sá, 2017
Guayasamin, Hutter, Tapia, Culebras, Peñafiel, Pyron, Morochz, Funk & Arteaga-Navarro, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis ornatissimus (Guayasamin et al. 2017). The sister species are elevational replacements of each other; the distribution of P. ornatissimus sensu stricto is limited to the Ecuadorian Chocó ecoregion (<1,100 m asl), whereas the P. ecuadorensis has only been found at Andean localities between 1,450–1,480 m asl (Guayasamin et al. 2017).

Previously thought to be a Vietnamese population of Gracixalus carinensis, G. sapaensis was described in 2017 as a distinct species on the basis of morphological differences (Matsui et al. 2017). True Gracixalus carinensis is likely restricted to Myanmar.
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is sometimes included in the synonymy of V. ursinii (see McDiarmid et al., 1999). This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
Phrynopus spectabilis was placed in the synonymy with Pleurodema marmoratum by Lehr (2006).
This species is part of the Vipera ursinii complex, and has often been included within Vipera eriwanensis.
The validity of this taxon has been questioned by some authors (e.g.. Baran et al. 2001; McDiarmid et al., 1999; Joger et al. 2003). This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).

The coordinates listed in Siler et al. (2007) for this species' type locality were found to be inaccurate and this has been corrected in the distribution map (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

It is unknown whether this species is distinct or whether it belongs to Philautus fasciatus, therefore further taxonomic work is warranted for verification (Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2017).

Further taxonomic work is required to verify whether both subpopulations are conspecific as other surveys between the two widely distributed localities have not produced any records, suggesting they are two different species (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Microhyla achatina (Matsui et al. 2013).

authority: Streicher, Hamidy, Harvey, Anders, Shaney, Kurniawan & Smith, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Rhacophorus catamitus by Streicher et al. (2014).

This is a split from the broader concept of Limnonectes kuhlii (Matsui 2015). Limnonectes sinuatodorsalis occurs syntopically with L. kuhlii in both of the known localities, possibly through ecological segregation by large body size difference between the two species (Matsui 2015).

The taxonomic placement of Alsophis ater into Hypsirhynchus was disputed by Grazziotin et al. (2012); who stated that the morphological characteristics used to place the species in Hypsirhynchus is based on morphological data provided by only a few specimens. This author places this species in Ocyophis, erected by Zaher et al. (2009).

Groves in Wilson and Reeder (1993) considered this to be a synonym of B. penicillata. See Nowak (1999) for other arguments. The Australasian Marsupial SG maintain this as a good species (Andrew Burbidge pers. comm).
There is a need to review the taxonomic relationship of populations from the Uluguru Mountains and the Udzungwa Mountains to determine if they are a single, or two distinct, species.
Generic synonym = Praesorex.
Crocidura nicobarica is separate from C. jenkinsi, which occurs on South Andaman Island, Indian Ocean.

The taxonomy of the Isoodon obesulus / auratus group has been confused. Pope et al. (2001) and Zenger et al. (2005) suggested that I. auratus is possibly conspecific with I. obesulus, but the two forms were allopatric even if the late Pleistocene subfossil material is included (McKenzie et al. 2008), and Westerman et al. (2012) showed that the two species were distinct. The status of subspecies of I. auratus has also been unclear, but Westerman et al. (2012) agreed that I. a. arnhemensis should be merged with I. a. auratus and that I. a. barrowensis was also close to I. a. auratus.

We have evaluated I. auratus as a single species with no subspecies and have evaluated I. peninsulae as a separate species.

Populations on Rintja and Padar are represented by modern samples, that from Flores by subfossil fragments recovered from sediments 4,000-3,000 years old (Musser 1981; undescribed material studied by Musser).
Will be transferred to family Nesomyidae.
Usually listed as a subspecies of M. surifer (Chasen 1940), but treated as a species by Musser et al. (1979) and retained as such by Corbet and Hill (1992).

Tate (1951) suggested a relationship between Melomys aerosus and the New Guinea M. levipes group, but cranial morphology indicates M. aerosus to be more closely related to Australian species of Melomys, especially M. cervinipes, than to the endemic Melomys of New Guinea (Musser and Carleton 2005).
In P. vexillarius?

This species was originally described from subfossil fragments (Musser 1981, Musser et al. 1986), but an extant specimen collected in tropical rainforest at 1,600 m from south central Flores was referred to this species by Kitchener et al. (1991), who suggested it is closely related to Sulawesian Bunomys.
McKenna (1962) considered vordermanni representative of an undescribed genus, but Muul and Thonglongya (1971) and Hill (1961) retained it in Petinomys.

Pithecheir melanurus is represented by few specimens collected before World War II. Bartels’ (1937) observations on habitat and habits remain the most complete report of this Javan endemic, which is a member of the suite of murine rodents unique to Java (Musser 1986).
This species is likely to be transferred to family Platacanthomyidae.
A taxonomic revision resulted in this species being split into Praomys hartwigi (endemic to Cameroon) and P. obscurus (endemic to Nigeria) (E. van der Straeten pers. comm. 2002).

No subspecies are recognised. Genetic analyses using mitochondrial DNA have shown that there are seven subpopulations and that each of the subpopulations is genetically isolated and distinct (Jerry et al. 1998, cited in DECC 2005). However, these subpopulations are not distinct subspecies.

Chasen (1940) listed lugens and mentawai each as a subspecies of R. rattus, but the Mentawai endemic is a morphologically distinctive species most closely related to R. adustus from Enggano island and R. simalurensis from the adjacent Simalur Archipelago, and both those two species along with R. lugens appear to be morphologically related to the R. tiomanicus complex (Musser 1986, Musser and Califia 1982, Musser and Heaney 1985).

Corbet and Hill (1992), Musser and Carleton (1993) and Agrawal (2000) following Musser and Heaney (1985), and Musser and Newcomb (1983) remark that it is most closely related to Rattus tiomanicus (Miller, 1900). It is known from only very few specimens in the original series
Corbet and Hill (1992) opined that its inclusion as a member of subgenus Rattus Fischer, 1803 is open to question. This distinctive species is known from very few specimens

The form simalurensis and its two synonyms were each listed as a separate subspecies of R. rattus by Chasen (1940), but simalurensis is distinct from R. rattus and in morphology represents larger-bodied island variants of R. tiomanicus (Musser 1986, Musser and Califia 1982, Musser and Heaney 1985); simalurensis, babi, and lasiae were included in R. tiomanicus by Corbet and Hill (1992).

Ellerman (1961) opined that stoicus “possibly represents Rattus palmarum; possibly as a member of the sabanus group, or perhaps a representative of the mulleri group”. Musser and Heaney (1985) redescribed this species. Corbet and Hill (1992) and Agrawal (2000) consider it as a distinct species.

The single species, R. suncoides, is known by five specimens from the Ruwenzori region of east-central Zaire and Rwanda. This species formerly was assigned to Sylvisorex, but Hutterer (1986) considered it to represent a distinct genus.
Sometimes this species is included within S. lowii (Chasen 1940).
Generic synonyms = Limnotragus, Boocerus, Strepsiceros, Taurotragus.
Powell and Henderson (2003) synonymized C. carraui as a synonym with C. w. warreni and rejected its recognition as a subspecies.
Taxonomic revision of Praomys hartwigi split the taxon into P. hartwigi (endemic to Cameroon) and P. obscurus (endemic to Nigeria) (E. van der Straeten pers. comm., June 2002).

Melomys talaudium is morphologically similar to Melomys leucogaster (Menzies 1996). Originally it was described as a species, but Rümmler (1938) and Ellerman (1941) treated talaudium as a subspecies of M. leucogaster, Musser and Carleton (1993) listed it in the synonymy of that species, and Laurie and Hill (1954) arranged it as a subspecies of M. fulgens. Tate (1951) recognized talaudium as a distinct species as have Flannery (1995) and Menzies (1996). It is sympatric with M. caurinus, which has a shorter tail relative to head and body length, suggesting that M. caurinus may be terrestrial and M. talaudium arboreal (Flannery 1995, Thomas 1921).

Niviventer cameroni was originally described as a subspecies of Rattus rapit (= Niviventer rapit) but differs from N. rapit in being much larger in all cranial and dental dimensions, especially the longer molar row, and lacking a conspicuously tufted tail. Whether N. cameroni is phylogenetically more closely related to N. rapit than to other species on the Sunda Shelf and in the Indochinese region needs to be determined using other morphological suites and gene sequences. Niviventer cameroni joins Maxomys inas and Pithecheir parvus as the three endemic murines occurring on the Malay Peninsula south of the Isthmus of Kra (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Pagès et al. (2011) confirmed that Rattus satarae and Rattus rattus are distinct species.

Originally described as a species, but Rümmler (1938) and Ellerman (1941) treated caurinus as a subspecies of M. leucogaster. Musser and Carleton (1993) listed it in the synonymy of that species, and Laurie and Hill (1954) arranged it as a subspecies of M. fulgens. Tate (1951) recognized caurinus as a distinct species as have Flannery (1995) and Menzies (1996). It is sympatric with M. talaudium, which has a longer tail relative to head and body length, suggesting that M. caurinus may be terrestrial and M. talaudium arboreal (Flannery 1995, Thomas 1921).

Due to low levels of genetic differentiation between members of the Uromastyx aegyptia species group (considered to include U. aegyptia, U. leptieni, U. microlepis and U. occidentalis), Wilms et al. (2007) recognize U. aegyptia as a single species with three subspecies: U. a. aegyptia, U. a. leptieni and U. a. microlepis.

The relationship of U. occidentalis, which was not included in genetic analysis, to U. aegyptia remains in need of clarification, however Wilms et al. (2007) continue to recognize it as a full species due to its geographical separation from the remaining U. aegyptia-group taxa.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris recommended by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the generic assignment of the species.

.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris recommended by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the status of the species.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris done by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the status of the species.

It has been suggested that Sphaerodactylus kirbyi may be a junior synonym applied to several populations of S. vincenti (Daudin and de Silva 2007, citing F. Providence pers. comm.) More recent research has validated the recognition of S. kirbyi as a distinct species (e.g. Hite et al. 2008).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

Populations in northern Hispaniola long attributed to Aristelliger lar have recently been found to represent either Aristelliger hechti or an undescribed taxon close to A. hechti (S.B. Hedges, in prep.).

Based on molecular evidence (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), two taxa previously considered subspecies of C. crusculus have been elevated to full species status (Henderson and Powell 2009). Celestus maculatus (Garman, 1888) occurs on Cayman Brac and Little Cayman and C. molesworthi (Grant, 1940) occurs along the northern coast of Jamaica, where it is allopatric with C. crusculus.

This taxon is treated as a full species on Caribherp; molecular evidence suggests that this is a distinct clade (S.B. Hedges unpubl. data) and morphological classifications have unhelpfully listed it as a subspecies of several related species.

Historical records of this species from Cuba and the United States have long been understood to be referrable to Sphaerodactylus elegans (Graham and Schwartz 1978); this name is however retained in error for numerous records within the GBIF database, and has been applied to specimens collected in the United States as recently as 1983. Unpublished sequence data suggests that S. cinereus is not closely related to S. elegans (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data).

Musser and Carleton (2005) include the extinct Pseudomys auritus as a synonym of this species. However, P. auritus was accepted as a valid species a few years ago via the work of Graham Medlin at the South Australian Museum (Medlin 2008).

Flannery (1995) suggested the holotype might be a chimera consisting of a mismatched skull from an individual of celebensis and a skin of a Pteropus hypomelanus. However, A. humilis has been shown to be a distinct species through the description of two more specimens by Feiler (1990) and the rediscovery of a living population by Riley (2001).

The first specimens of this taxon were assigned to the genus Cheirogaleus when originally described by Günther in 1875, but distinct cranial and dentition features ultimately elevated the species to the sole representative of its own genus (Petter-Rousseaux and Petter 1967, Yoder 1996).
Generic synonym = Lichanotus.

Hershkovitz (1949) divided the so-called “untufted capuchin monkeys” into three species, capucinus, nigrivittatus and albifrons, distinguishing them by the shape of the dark patch on the crown: albifrons rounded and nigrivittatus wedge shaped. On this basis, he considered trinitatis Von Pusch, restricted to the island of Trinidad, to be a subspecies of Cebus albifrons, despite the fact that it was completely isolated from albifrons by the various subspecies that he listed of the wedge-capped capuchins, Cebus nigrivittatus (now considered olivaceus), on the Guiana Shield in Venezuela, Brazil, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana.  Subspecies of Cebus albifrons in his taxonomic arrangement otherwise occurred south of the Rio Amazonas-Solimões in Brazil, and in the upper Amazon, north and south of the Rio Amazonas in Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia, west of the Andes in Ecuador and Tumbes, northern Peru, and in northern Colombia. The “nearest known relatives of trinitatis occur in the upper Orinoco region (albifrons) and in the Lake Maracaibo region (adustus)”, which indicated that trinitatis is an introduced population (Hershkovitz, 1949, p. 38). Hill (1960) and Groves (2001, 2005) followed Hershkovitz in listing trinitatis as a subspecies of C. albifrons.

In the first phylogenetic analysis of the genus, Cebus trinitatis and the form brunneus Allen, 1914, from northern Venezuela and considered by Hershkovitz to be a subspecies of C. nigrivittatus, were found to be very closely related, and in the albifrons clade rather than that of the wedge-capped capuchins (Boubli et al., 2o12).  Boubli et al. (2012) suggested that trinitatis might be a junior synonym. The two capuchin monkeys are, however, quite distinct in appearance, and evidence for the synonymy of trinitatis is as yet inconclusive (J. P. Boubli and J. Lynch Alfaro, pers. comm. February 2021). In fact upon subsequent morphological inspection, the C. brunneus sampled from the Smithsonian for the genetic study of Boubli et al. 2012, are not the same species as the type specimens of brunneus (which are olivaceus-like) at the American Museum of Natural History, despite their very close geographic provenance to those C. brunneus specimens; the samples from the Boubli et al. (2012) are more similar to C. adustus and C. leucocephalus in morphology, but extend the range of the albifrons-like monkeys to the east of the Andes on the Venezuelan coast. Thus, the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group maintains trinitatus as a separate taxon, with affinities to the Andes albifrons-like species.
Generic synonym = Lemur.

Johnson et al. (2008) did not find evidence to support Eulemur cinereiceps as a separate taxon from E. albocollaris, and that priority should be given to the senior synonym, E. cinereiceps, as the valid name.
Formerly considered a subspecies of Eulemur fulvus, but later raised to species level (Groves 2001).

Eulemur fulvus mayottensis (Schlegel 1886), described from the island of Mayotte is considered by Mittermeier et al. (2010) to be nothing more than descendants of E. fulvus which had been introduced to the island. Generic synonym = Lemur.

Formerly considered a subspecies of Eulemur fulvus, but later raised to species level (Groves 2001). Until recently Eulemur rufifrons was considered to be a junior synonym of E. rufus (e.g., Groves 2005), but genetic and preliminary morphological evidence suggest that rufifrons is distinct (Pastorini et al. 2003, Groves 2006).

This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of Eulemur macaco. After the elevation of all former E. fulvus subspecies to full species status (Mittermeier et al. 2006), E. macaco remained the only member of the genus that was divided into subspecies (E. m. macaco and E. m. flavifrons). Taking into account the consistency of the morphological differences between the Black Lemur and the Blue-eyed Black Lemur, the retention of this taxonomy is inappropriate. The pairwise genetic distances between macaco and flavifrons are 68–72 bp, which is in the same range as between the former E. fulvus subspecies (29–90 bp, according to Pastorini 2000). Some earlier authors suggested a geographical cline in subspecific traits over a relatively large area of their distribution border (Meyers et al. 1989, Rabarivola et al. 1991), but more recent surveys suggest that the zone of hybridization between the two taxa is restricted to the north-eastern part of the distribution of E. flavifrons (Andrianjakarivelo 2004; Schwitzer et al. 2005, 2006). Based on these findings, and in order to restore a consistent taxonomy of Eulemur, the Blue-eyed Black Lemur was raised to full species status by Mittermeier et al. (2008, 2010).

Most earlier authors recognized three species of bamboo lemur: Hapalemur griseus (with at least three subspecies); H. aureus, and H. simus. Groves (2001) elevated two subspecies of H. griseus to full species status (alaotrensis and occidentalis) and also transferred H. simus to the genus Prolemur. More recently, Rabarivola et al. (2007) described two additional subspecies of H. griseus, namely H. g. gilberti from Beanamalao, between the Onive and Nosivolo Rivers, and H. g. ranomafanensis, from the area of Ranomafana. Although colour details were mentioned in the type description of H. g. ranomafanensis, the diagnostic utility of this information is impossible to determine because at the same time no such details were given for H. g. griseus. The essence of the new subspecies was, in effect, that it is chromosomally polymorphic at Ranomafana and Ambongo (2n = 54, 55 or 56, whereas in H. g. griseus 2n = always 54), while at Ambolomavo, Bemaraha and Vatoalatsaka, also ascribed to this new subspecies, only 2n=56 occurs. A subspecies apparently based, at least on present evidence, on the occurrence of a polymorphism cannot be maintained (see Mittermeier et al. 2008). Mittermeier et al. (2010) recognized griseus and gilberti as full species, although the latter is treated here as a subspecies pending formal publication of the rank change with an expansion of supporting evidence.
Formerly included in Hapalemur, but included in Prolemur by Groves (2001).

Two subspecies have been proposed (Groves 2001), however, this is not supported by morphological (Zaonarivelo et al. 2007) or genetic (Brenneman et al. 2016) analysis, supporting the opinion that the two major colour forms are merely part of a clinal variation and not indicative of distinct taxa (Brenneman et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be distributed across south-western Madagascar, Lepilemur leucopus in Beza Mahafaly and Sud-Ouest-Ifotaka is now considered to represent a new species L. petteri (Louis et al. 2006, Lei et al. 2016).

Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively based on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. The original latin species name is here amended from the original description following Hoffmann et al. (2009).

Recent analyses of morphometric, genetic, and behavioural data has now resulted in the recognition of a second species of Mirza. Mirza coquereli is the larger of the two, with a distribution nucleus in southwestern Madagascar, while the newly described, smaller-bodied Mirza zaza is found in the Sambirano region of the far northwest (Kappeler et al. 2005).
Formerly a subspecies of Phaner furcifer, but regarded as distinct by Groves (2001).
Formerly a subspecies of Phaner furcifer, but regarded as distinct by Groves (2001).

Formerly included in Phaner furcifer, but treated as distinct by Groves (2001). The form occurring in the Loky-Manambato Protected Area and in the forests of the Manambato-Manambery and Manambery-Fanambana inter-river systems may represent a distinct species.

This species was first observed north of Vohémar in 1974 by Dr. Ian Tattersall, provisionally identified as a variant of the Silky Sifaka (then Propithecus diadema candidus; Tattersall 1982) and eventually described as a distinct species more than a decade later (Simons 1988) on the bases of its distinct appearance, morphometrics, karyotype, and vocalizations.

Formerly considered the nominate subspecies of Propithecus verreauxi (e.g. Groves 1993), but elevated to full species status by Groves (2001) and Mayor et al. (2004), along with several other former subspecies.
Formerly considered a subspecies of Propithecus verreauxi (e.g. Groves 1993), but elevated to full species status by Groves (2001) and Mayor et al. (2004).

Considered a subspecies of Propithecus verreauxi by Groves (1993) and of P. deckenii by Groves (2001). Thalmann et al. (2002) argued that it deserved species status, recently supported by the craniometric study of Groves and Helgen (2007) which found this species to have highly distinctive cranial features.
