Formerly included as a subspecies of Propithecus verreauxi (e.g. Groves 1993), or as the nominate subspecies of P. deckenii (e.g. Groves 2001), and genetically virtually indistinguishable from P. coronatus and P. verreauxi based on c. 2,400 bp of  mtDNA (Pastorini et al. 2001) or on complete mitochondrial cytochrome b sequences (Rumpler et al. 2011), but now generally considered a distinct species (e.g. Thalmann et al. 2002, Groves and Helgen 2007; but see Tattersall 2007). Former confusion over the distribution of this species and the closely related P. coronatus has been resolved by field studies by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014), however taxonomic field study is still needed to fully understand the relationship between the two species and the causes of the melanistic tendencies in these and other sifaka species (King et al. 2014, Rakotonirina et al. 2014).

In the forests of Tsinjoarivo in eastern central Madagascar (at the southern extreme of the species’ geographic range), an unusual population of what appears to be Propithecus diadema has been discovered. The animals are variably coloured, including all black individuals (several of which are known to have been born to parents with typical pelage), but preliminary genetic studies indicate that this population requires further study before subspecific status can be established (Mayor et al. 2004)

Formerly considered a subspecies of Propithecus diadema (e.g. Groves 1993), but elevated to full species status by Groves (2001) and Mayor et al. (2004), and supported by Groves and Helgen (2007). The latter authors provisionally raised the form P. holomelas to species level, but it may represent nothing more than an extreme melanistic morph of P. edwardsi. It is here provisionally retained as a synonym of P. edwardsi, pending further study.
Considered a subspecies of Propithecus diadema by Groves (2001), although Mayor et al. (2004) and Groves and Helgen (2007) considered it worthy of species status.
Formerly considered a subspecies of Propithecus diadema, but elevated to full species status by Groves (2001) and Mayor et al. (2004).

Taxonomic status for the genus Varecia have not been fully resolved at the genus or species level. Groves (2001) proposed full species status of Varecia variegata and Varecia rubra. As the most current analyses of Varecia variegata, Baden et al. 2014 presented evidence using microsatellite STR data that the genus Varecia variegata should only have two subspecies, V. v. editorum and V. v. variegata, stating that V. v. subcincta did not warrant subspecies/species status. Genomic level studies are currently underway, designed to resolve the taxonomic status and distribution of the genus Varecia using samples representing the entire range of all ruffed lemurs (E. Louis pers. comm.).

This species appeared in the 1996 Red List as a subspecies of Gorilla gorilla. Since 2001, the Eastern Gorilla has been considered a separate species (Gorilla beringei) with two subspecies: Grauer’s Gorilla (Gorilla beringei graueri) and the Mountain Gorilla (Gorilla beringei beringei) following Groves (2001).

The taxonomy of the genus Aotus has been a matter of academic dispute due to the wide number of different karyotypes reported without clear phenotypic distinctions between intra- and inter-population variations (Ruiz-Herrera et al. 2005, Defler and Bueno 2007). Fernandez-Duque et al. (2013), recognized 11 species, and 13 taxa. A preliminary study on the distribution of the Genus Aotus in the Southern Colombian Amazon confirms the presence of A. nancymaae in Colombian territory. The results suggest the existence of a historical distribution of A. nancymaae north of the Amazon River in Colombia, as well as of another population of A. nancymaae, not of historical lineage but probably introduced in Colombia in more recent times (Bloor et al. 2012). Ruiz-García et al. (2011) discuss interesting insights about the evolution of Aotus that is beyond the scope of this description of A. nancymaae. Nevertheless, their evidence suggests that (1) the red-necked/grey-necked split among the Aotus, posited by Hershkovitz (1983) is artificial, since Aotus nancymaae is more related to the grey-necked Aotus than to the other red-necked Aotus and that (2) Aotus vociferans is likely the origin of other modern Aotus species due to its high number of haplotypes and lowest number of chromosomes among the species of the genus.
Recognized as a distinct species by Rasloarison et al. (2000).
Listed as a distinct species by Groves (2000, 2001) in the Cheirogaleus major group.
Recently described in 2000, Avahi unicolor has been established as a valid species in multiple subsequent studies (Andriantompohavana et al. 2007; Lei et al. 2008).

authority: Andriantompohavana, Zaonarivelo, Engberg, Randriamampionona, McGuire, Shore, Rakotonomenjanahary, Brenneman & Louis Jr., 2006
taxonomicNotes: Olivieri et al. (2007) described the form Microcebus lokobensis also from Nosy Be Island. The type localities of M. lokobensis and M. mamiratra are the same, and the descriptions of the two forms are identical. Since M. mamiratra has priority, it seems best to consider M. lokobensis a synonym pending further investigation.

Based on the general metapopulation lineage concept and multiple sources of data, Groeneveld et al. (2009) clarified the exclusivity of three of the seven recognized dwarf lemur species: C. major, C. medius and C. crossleyi. These three species were found to be genealogically exclusive in both mtDNA and nDNA loci, and furthermore, they exhibit morphological distinctiveness. Molecular and morphometric data support the hypothesis that C. adipicaudatus and C. ravus are synonymous with C. medius and C. major, respectively. Since the last IUCN assessments, the “crossleyi” lineage has been broken down into several species, e.g., Cheirogaleus lavasoensis, C. andysabini, C. grovesi each with restricted geographical distributions. Thus, C. crossleyi occupies smaller areas than previously reported.

authority: Andriaholinirina, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Thalmann, Rabarivola, Ravoarimanana, Ganzhorn, Meier, Hilgartner, Walter, Zaramody, Langer, Hahn, Zimmermann, Radespiel, Craul, Tomiuk, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Lepilemur randrianasoloi was described by Andriaholinirina et al. (2006) with the name of Lepilemur randrianasoli, but being named after Georges Randrianosolo, the name should be randrianasoloi. Amended by Hoffmann et al. (2009) and in a re-description of the species by Andriaholinirina et al. (2017). The reason for the re-descriptions of this species was because the first description was published online before 2012 and the nomina were as such nomenclaturally unavailable.

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming.

Until recently Eulemur rufifrons was considered to be a junior synonym of E. rufus (e.g., Groves 2005), but genetic and preliminary morphological evidence now suggest that E. rufifrons is distinct (Pastorini et al. 2003, Groves 2006).

authority: Zaramody, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Andriaholinirina, Rabarivola, Norscia, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Molecular sequence data from studies led by Lei and Andriantompohavana may result in the discovery of three new species from this species (E.E. Louis Jr. pers. obs).

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively based on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. The original latin species name is here amended from the original description following Hoffmann et al. (2009).
The taxonomic validity of this species has been confirmed by Andriantompohavana et al. (2007) and Lei et al. (2008).

authority: Zaramody, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Andriaholinirina, Rabarivola, Norscia, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2006

Andriaholinirina, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Thalmann, Rabarivola, Ravoarimanana, Ganzhorn, Meier, Hilgartner, Walter, Zaramody, Langer, Hahn, Zimmermann, Radespiel, Craul, Tomiuk, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006) - inclusive of this species, Lepilemur aeeclis in Andriaholinirina et al. (2006) - were diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delmination analyses of mitogenomic data, that this species is valid despite allopatry.

Although this species was not recognized as distinct by Groves (2001), who retained it as a subspecies of Hapalemur griseus, its distinct status is supported by cytogenetic and molecular data (Fausser et al. 2002).

authority: Zaramody, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Andriaholinirina, Rabarivola, Norscia, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Although described as a subspecies of A. meridionalis by Zaramody et al. (2006), it is here treated as distinct following Andriantompohavana et al. (2007) who examined the taxonomy of Avahi according to the Phylogenetic Species Concept.

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes:
Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. An exception to this would appear to be L. jamesorum, which has been shown to have a diploid chromosome number of 2n = 26 and differs in six to 23 chromosomal rearrangements from all other karyotyped sportive lemur species (Andriaholinirina et al. 2006).  

The original Latin species name is here emended from the original description following Hoffmann et al. (2009).

authority: Olivieri, Zimmermann, Randrianambinina, Rasoloharijaona, Rakotondravony, Guschanski & Radespiel, 2007
Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006) (that were all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric) be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. This species primarily lives in allopatry with its distribution range is thought to be mostly limited to the Loky-Manambato (Daraina) region in northern Madagascar; however, it does exist in sympatry with L. ankaranensis in Andrafiamena (Anjahakely Protected Area). Nonetheless, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delimitation analyses of mitogenomic data, that this species is valid despite allopatry.

authority: Andriaholinirina, Fausser, Roos, Zinner, Thalmann, Rabarivola, Ravoarimanana, Ganzhorn, Meier, Hilgartner, Walter, Zaramody, Langer, Hahn, Zimmermann, Radespiel, Craul, Tomiuk, Tattersall & Rumpler, 2017
taxonomicNotes:
Zinner et al. (2007) examined conflicting results in the genetic analysis of sportive lemurs in northwestern Madagascar, those within the range of what once was considered to be Lepilemur dorsalis. Since the type localities of L. dorsalis Gray, 1871 and L. grandidieri Forsyth Major, 1894, were both “Northwest Madagascar”, the proper name of one or two of the new species from the region (sahamalazensis, grewcocki, mittermeieri, tymlerachsoni) could be either of these two. The true "dorsalis", as such, had not been identified, and no attempt has been made to identify grandidieri, formerly a junior synonym of dorsalis. Genetic analysis of the holotypes of dorsalis and grandidieri is needed to resolve this. Zinner et al. (2007) indicated, therefore, that tymerlachsoni and/or mittermeieri might be junior synonyms.

Lepilemur randrianasoloi was described by Andriaholinirina et al. (2006) with the name of Lepilemur randrianasoli, but being named after Georges Randrianosolo, the name should be randrianasoloi. Amended by Hoffmann et al. (2009) and in a re-description of the species by Andriaholinirina et al. (2017). Lepilemur aeeclis was re-described by Andriaholinirina et al. in 2017. Lepilemur sahamalaza was first described and named by Andriaholinirina et al. (2006), and was re-described and renamed as Lepilemur sahamalaza by Andriaholinirina et al. (2017).  The reason for the re-descriptions of these three species was because the first descriptions were published online before 2012 and the nomina were as such nomenclaturally unavailable.  The change in species name for the Sahamalaza Sportive Lemur from sahamalazensis to sahamalaza was required because it is a noun in apposition, and therefore grammatically invariable (Andriaholinirina et al. 2017)

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming.

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, in Lei et al. (2016), the authors subsequently established through delmination analyses of mitogenomic data that this species is valid despite allopatry.

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. 2006 (that were all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric) be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delimitation analyses of mitogenomic data that this species is valid despite allopatry.

authority: Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes:
The original Latin species name (tymerlachsoni) is a combination of different names of individuals from the Hawk family. The species has occasionally been incorrectly referred to as tymerlachsonorum (e.g. Hoffman et al. 2009) but the species should be referred to using the original Latin name.

Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006) that were all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delimtnation analyses of mitogenomic data that this species is valid despite allopatry.

Since the locations of holotype specimens for Lepilemur dorsalis and L. grandidieri have not been established other than “Northwest Madagascar”, taxonomic uncertainty still exists within the numerous sportive lemurs described in the mid-2000s (Andriaholinirina et al. 2006, Craul et al. 2007, and Louis et al. 2006). In Zinner et al. (2007), the authors examined conflicting conclusions based on the genetic analysis of sportive lemurs in northwestern Madagascar, specifically those within in the range of what once considered to be Lepilemur dorsalis. Since the type localities of L. dorsalis Gray, 1871 and L. grandidieri Forsyth Major, 1894, were both "Northwest Madagascar", the proper name of one or two of the new species from the region (L. sahamalazensis, L. grewcockorum, L. mittermeieri, and L. tymerlachsoni) could be either synonyms of these two sportive lemurs. The true locality of the Lepilemur "dorsalis", as such, had not been identified. Nor has the locality of L. grandidieri, formerly a junior synonym of dorsalis. Genetic analysis of the holotypes of dorsalis and grandidieri are needed to resolve this taxonomic question.

This species was formerly included as a subspecies of the Lepilemur septentrionalis complex, but eventually was proposed full species status from L. septentrionalis ankaranensis to Lepilemur ankaranensis based on cytogenetic data (Rumpler et al. 2001).  Lepilemur ankaranensis is now known only from Ankarana, Andrafiamena, and Analamerana.

authority: Louis Jr., Coles, Andriantompohavana, Sommer, Engberg, Zaonarivelo, Mayor & Brenneman, 2006
Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes: The original latin species name is here emended from the original description following Hoffmann et al. (2009).

authority: Andriantompohavana, Lei, Zaonarivelo, Engberg, Nalanirina, McGuire, Shore, Andrianasolo, Herrington, Brenneman & Louis Jr., 2007
Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney, & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes:
The original Latin species name is here emended from the original description following Hoffmann et al. (2009).


Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. (2006), all diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric, be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, in Lei et al. 2016, the authors subsequently established through delmination analyses of mitogenomic data that this species is valid despite allopatry, showing that L. manasamody is a junior synonym of L. grewcockorum. 


Since the holotype locations of Lepilemur dorsalis and L. grandidieri have not been established, taxonomic uncertainty still exists within the numerous sportive lemurs described in the mid-2000’s (Andriaholinirina et al. 2006; Craul et al. 2007; and Louis et al. 2006). In Zinner et al. (2007), the authors examined conflicting conclusions based on the genetic analysis of sportive lemurs in northwestern Madagascar, specifically those within in the range of what once considered to be Lepilemur dorsalis. Since the type localities of L. dorsalis Gray, 1871 and L. grandidieri Forsyth Major, 1894, were both "Northwest Madagascar", the proper name of one or two of the new species from the region (L. sahamalazensis, L. grewcockorum, L. mittermeieri, and L. tymerlachsonorum) could be either synonyms of these two sportive lemurs. The true locality of the Lepilemur "dorsalis", as such, had not been identified. Nor has the locality of L. grandidieri, formerly a junior synonym of dorsalis. Genetic analysis of the holotypes of dorsalis and grandidieri are needed to resolve this taxonomic question. Zinner et al. (2007) also indicated that L. manasamody, described by Craul et al. (2007), is probably a junior synonym of L. grewcockorum, as sampling sites were less than two km apart, with no evident geographic barrier.

authority: Louis, Engberg, McGuire, McCormick, Randriamampionona, Ranaivoarisoa, Bailey, Mittermeier & Lei, 2008
Louis, Engberg, McGuire, McCormick, Randriamampionona, Ranaivoarisoa, Bailey, Mittermeier & Lei, 2008

Radespiel, Olivieri, Rasolofoson, Rakotondratsimba, Rakotonirainy, Rasoloharijaona, Randrianambinina, Ratsimbazafy, Ratelolahy, Randriamboavonjy, Rasolofoharivelo, Craul, Rakotozafy & Randrianarison, 2008
Ramaromilanto, Lei, Engberg, Johnson, Sitzmann & Louis , 2009
Lei, Engberg, Andriantompohavana, McGuire, Mittermeier, Zaonarivelo, Brenneman & Louis, 2008
Lei, Engberg, Andriantompohavana, McGuire, Mittermeier, Zaonarivelo, Brenneman & Louis, 2008

taxonomicNotes: The genus Cheirogaleus is under taxonomic revision. C. medius was recognized as one of three distinctive lineages (along with C. crossleyi, C. major) by Groeneveld et al. (2009) based on molecular and morphometric data. More recently, this lineage has been broken down into: a- two newly described species: C. shethi from Ankarana, Analamerana and Loky-Manambato in the N, and C. thomasi from St Luce to Petriky, in the SE; b-four unconfirmed candidate species: from Ambanja/Ambato in the N, Anjiamangirana in the NW, Mariarano in the NW and Tsiombikibo in the NW; and c-one confirmed candidate species: Sambava in the NE (Frasier et al., 2016; Lei et al., 2014). Thus, although Cheirogaleus medius was previously known to have a broad geographic distribution in western dry deciduous forests, as well as littoral southeastern forests and northeastern forests, is now confined to a few western dry deciduous forests exclusively.

Based on the general metapopulation lineage concept and multiple sources of data, Groeneveld et al. (2009) clarified the exclusivity of three of the seven recognized dwarf lemur species: Cheirogaleus major, C.medius and C. crossleyi. These three species were found to be genealogically exclusive in both mtDNA and nDNA loci, and furthermore, they exhibit morphological distinctiveness. Molecular and morphometric data support the hypothesis that C. adipicaudatus and C. ravus are synonymous with C. medius and C. major, respectively. Since last IUCN assessments, genetic information became available for several populations of dwarf lemurs, some of which were confirmed to be C. major. It is likely that the “major” lineage will be broken down into more species in the near future.

Up until recently, the geographic range of Microcebus rufus was believed to extend throughout Madagascar’s eastern forests from Tolagnaro (= Fort Dauphin) in the south perhaps as far as the Tsaratanana Massif and the region of Daraina in the north. However, field work and analyses of molecular data resulted in the identification of several new species within this distribution, including the newly described M. lehilahytsara, M. mittermeieri, M. simmonsi, and M. jollyae (Louis et al. 2006).

This is the new taxonomic concept for M. irani. Previously collected specimens that were recorded as Microtus irani from southeastern Turkey were reevaluated by karyologically comparing different species distributed throughout southeastern Turkey. The taxonomic status of this species was raised to a new species, Microtus elbeyli sp. nov. (Yigit et al. 2016).

authority: Wang, Guo, Liu. Lyu. Wang, Luo, Sun & Zhang, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This represents a species complex that needs taxonomic revision (M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).
According to Pyron et al. (2016), a phylogeographic study may reveal cryptic species within this taxon, which is recognized as a species complex (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

Pyron et al. (2016) transferred Pseudotyphlops to the synonymy of Rhinophis, necessitating a new name for the species formerly known as Pseudotyphlops philippinus as R. philippinus was preoccupied. They determined that Uropeltis saffraganus was the oldest available name and coined the combination Rhinophis saffraganus.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Recently transferred from Homopus to Chersobius. The subspecies, Homopus s. signatus and H. s. cafer, are partially sympatric in the western Karoo (Boycott 1986; 1989, Bour 1988, Iverson 1992, Boycott and Bourquin 2000). Colour patterns used to distinguish the subspecies appear to relate to crypsis on different substrates. The status of a subpopulation from the Pofadder area requires further investigation (Daniels et al. 2010). Records of this species from Namibia (Mertens 1955, 1971) are referable to C. solus (Branch 2007).
No taxonomic issues, although may be confused with K. spekii as they are morphologically similar.

The genus Homopus was found to be paraphyletic warranting resurrection of the genus Chersobius to accommodate the five-toed Homopus species (C. boulengeri, C. signatus and C. solus (Hofmeyr et al. 2017).
No taxonomic issues.
The incorrect spelling Hylodes glabrus has had some use.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megaelosia goeldii by Giaretta et al. (1993), where it had been placed by Lutz (1930).

This species was resurrected from synonymy by Heyer (1985). There are taxonomic problems, and it may be synonymous with Vitreorana uranoscapa (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). According to Guayasamin et al. (2009), Vitreorana parvula and V. uranoscopa are hypothesized to be close relatives, and therefore synonymous, with V. eurygnatha.
Pacheco (2003) distinguished Thomasomys eleusis from T. cinereus and T. ischyrus, as a valid species. In addition, T. eleusis was found allied to T. incanus in the same clade.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.

Picoides ramsayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendrocopos. Dendrocopos maculatus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) has been split into D. maculatus and D. ramsayi following Collar et al. (1999), who initially placed it in the genus Picoides. Subsequently, the genus Dendrocopos has been used, following Winkler and Christie (2002). Because this split was made in a BirdLife publication, the justification is repeated here in full (but the references are not supplied). Both Hachisuka (1931-1935) and Voous (1947) treated ramsayi as a separate species, and indeed it is so distinctive as to be arguably closer to Sulawesi Woodpecker P. temminckii than it is to P. maculatus (this view is also expressed, with the comment that ramsayi is "the ancestor common to both", by White and Bruce 1986), and given the evident morphological proximity of Brown-capped P. moluccensis, Grey-capped P. canicapillus and Pygmy Woodpeckers P. kizuki to both maculatus (non-Sulu forms) and ramsayi, there is no compelling reason to combine the latter two as a single species. Sulu birds differ from other Philippine forms in: replacing all black or dark brown with a mid-brown; lacking virtually all white spotting on wings and coverts; lacking black or dark brown spotting or streaking on the undersides; showing an ill-defined yellow or yellowish-orange breast-band, plus (in the male) a far more strongly developed red area on the nape. The specific separation of ramsayi is all the more arguable for the geographically closest representative of maculatus - fulvifasciatus of Mindanao and Basilan showing the strongest pied effect. The notion that these two forms are "bridged" by maculatus, with a throw-away description of ramsayi as "aberrant" (Salomonsen 1953), not only fails to deal with the suggestion of Voous (1947) that ramsayi represents an early invasion of the Philippines, but also misses the point that maculatus is not geographically interposed between the two forms it is supposed to bridge. It is worth noting that in the paper in which both ramsayi and fulvifasciatus were first established, the formal description of ramsayi compared it to temminckii rather than to maculatus (Hargitt 1881).
Todiramphus cinnamominus, T. pelewensis and T. reichenbachii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. cinnamominus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Spermophilus townsendii nancyae  was included in S. townsendii. Yensen and Sherman 2003 and Yensen 2017 recognized S. t. nancyae as a distinct species , noting their differences in chromosome number (U. t. townsendii has 36 vs. 38 for U. t. nancyae). This species is now recognized under a new genus, Urocitellus (Helgen et al. 2009).
Hypsipetes siquijorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ixos siquijorensis.

Oroanassa magnifica (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Gorsachius magnificus (del Hoyo et al. 2014). 

Analysis of the Gorsachius genome reveals that White-eared Night-heron G. magnificus (del Hoyo et al. 2014) is more closely related to egrets Egretta than to Gorsachius and Nycticorax night-herons, and hence appears to need the resuscitation of the genus Oroanassa to be appropriately accommodated in the ardeid phylogeny (Zhou et al. 2016).

The morphological differences between G. magnificus and the two other members of the genus, G. goisagi and G. melanolophus, are so striking (length and shape of bill, pattern of head and neck, thickness of neck-plumage, pattern on belly, size of toes) that their congeneric status appears entirely improbable. The revival of Oroanassa is therefore accepted by BirdLife, albeit with the proviso that we have undertaken no research to check if the genus Oroanassa (Peters, 1931) takes precedence over any other genus name proposed in the past, noting that the species seems fairly similar to the South American Calherodius (Bonaparte, 1855) meaning that, if found also to be genetically fairly close, it would qualify instead to be treated as Calherodius magnificus.
Rhyticeros subruficollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aceros.
Birds of Polillo, supposedly larger, occasionally separated as subspecies mcgregori, but doubtfully valid. Monotypic.
Sarcophanops steerii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eurylaimus steerii.

Formerly in genus Spermophilus (Helgen et al. 2009). Yensen (1991) and Gill and Yensen (1992) suggested the two subspecies, Urocitellus b. brunneus and U. b. endemicus, could be full species. Although Thorington and Hoffmann (2005) listed endemicus as a synonym of brunneus, genetic studies by Hoisington-Lopez et al. (2012) confirmed the two are full species. U. brunneus and U. endemicus are now recognized as monotypic species.

This is not thought to be a valid species, as the only two known specimens appear to be referrable to Achalinus rufescens and the type has been lost (H. Shi to L. Ding pers. comm. 2022). It is not included in a recent book on Chinese snakes, but is recognised here pending formal taxonomic action.
Sylvia nigricapillus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lioptilus nigricapillus.
Ptilopachus nahani (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Chilabothrus argentum is a recently discovered species (Reynolds et al. 2016), unknown until July 2015. Species description was based on genetic and morphological analysis of six specimens, in the context of other Bahamian and West Indian boas. This species is divergent from other West Indian boas at an mtDNA locus and is readily distinguishable based on morphometric and morphological characteristics.

Previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) placed in the genus Alopecoenas and before that in the genus Gallicolumba but transferred to Pampusana on the grounds of the latter’s priority (Bruce et al. 2016).
Dendrocitta bayleii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as D. bayleyi.
Previously listed as Garrulax bieti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Has elsewhere been treated as conspecific with I. lunulatus. Monotypic.

Gracupica contra and G. jalla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus contra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Differs from G. contra in its uniform whitish-yellow bill vs two-tone orange/whitish-yellow bill (3); large naked orange face patch vs orange eyering (2); bare reddish vs white feathered lores (2). Differs further from G. c. contra in its browner back (ns1); whiter underparts (ns1); and shorter tail (effect size -1.63, score 1); from G. c. superciliaris in its lack of white streaks on frontal crown (ns2); whiter underparts (ns1); and longer wing (effect size 2.45, score 2). Differs from G. floweri in its lack of white streaks on crown (3 consequently discounting score of 2 for lores); browner back (ns1); and shorter tail (effect size -2.56, score 2). Monotypic.
Sittiparus varius, S. owstoni, S. olivaceus and S. castaneoventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura leucotis and P. emma (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucotis, under which P. griseipectus and P. pfrimeri were also formerly subsumed following (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993).

Lanius excubitor, L. borealis and L. meridionalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. excubitor following AOU (1998 and supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Based on mtDNA evidence,  A. cingulatum (sensu stricto) inhabiting the eastern Gulf Coastal Plain and the Atlantic Coastal Plain in northern Florida are distinct lineages; the Suwannee River and a large distributional gap separate them (Pauly et al. 2012). Further data are needed to determine whether these two lineages warrant recognition as different species (Pauly et al. 2012).
Molecular data suggest that this species might be conspecific with Anaxyrus canorus, but this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
Molecular data suggest that Anaxyrus exsul is possibly conspecific with this species, however, this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
This species is morphologically somewhat similar to Plethodon elongatus, however they are genetically distinct (Mahoney 2001, Mead et al. 2005).

Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

There has been historical confusion and controversy regarding the taxonomic status of various leopard frog populations in the region occupied by Lithobates onca (Jaeger et al. 2001). The Vegas Valley Leopard Frog, R. fisheri, (now considered extinct) previously was regarded as a subspecies of R. onca. Jennings et al. (1995) conducted morphological comparisons and concluded that R. fisheri and R. onca are distinct species. Jaeger et al. (2001) examined variation in mtDNA, genomic DNA, and morphology and concluded that certain leopard frog populations in the Virgin River/Black Canyon (Colorado River) region represent a species (Lithobates onca) distinct from the lowland leopard frog (L. yavapaiensis). The Relict Leopard Frog was also found to be quite distinct from the Las Vegas Valley Leopard Frog (L. fisheri; now considered extinct) based on a genetic analysis of archival samples of that species (Hekkala et al. 2011). The Relict Leopard Frog was moved from the genus Rana to Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006), although that taxonomic revision remains contentious.
This species is a member of the Typhlomolge clade of central Texas Eurycea (Hillis et al. 2001).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Lithobates areolatus by Case (1978) and Young and Crother (2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et. al (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.
Dubois et al. 20201 moved this species from the genus Lithobates to Aquarana.

Genetic studies showed that this form is distinct from populations of Lithobates capito and L. areolata, and has therefore been established as a separate species (Young and Crother 2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.

Jacobs (1987) found Eurycea junaluska to be genetically similar to E. aquatica and E. cirrigera and questioned the taxonomic status of E. junaluska. Sever (1989) found E. junaluska to be morphologically unique and genetically distinct from all sympatric Eurycea.
This is a broader concept of Eurycea latitans which includes E. tridentifera as a synonym (Devitt et al. 2019).

This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982), but was regarded as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (1994) and was formally described as Eurycea naufragia by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Most references to Eurycea neotenes in the literature involve populations that Chippindale et al. (2000) considered Fern Bank Salamanders (E. pterophila) or members of the E. latitans or E. troglodytes species complexes
This species was removed from synonymy with Eurycea neotenes by Chippindale et al. (2000). It remains poorly circumscribed taxonomically, and warrants further research.
This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982) and in previous publications. It was formally described as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Sweet (1984) concluded that this species apparently comprises a hybrid swarm resulting from the incorporation of occasional individuals of Eurycea tridentifera into a larger population of E. neotenes. Chippindale et al. (2000) considered additional data and regarded E. troglodytes as a valid complex of more than one species, and not as being of hybrid origin. They noted that the E. troglodytes complex is a heterogeneous group that probably includes several distinct species.

Gyrinophilus gulolineatus was formerly regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; it was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002) and Crother et al. (2000). Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus.

Some authors have regarded this species as conspecific with Gyrinophilus porphyriticus (Blaney and Blaney 1978), but the current consensus is that it is a valid species, based on morphometric analyses (Green and Pauley 1987).
Phillips (2017) found multiple distinct lineages within Eurycea wallacei, including high genetic diversity within multiple sampling sites.
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was split from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex.
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Bart et al. (1997) determined that the name Necturus alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage. For years, the name had been mistakenly applied to a more common species of waterdog that occurs in the coastal plain. Further taxonomic revisions involving this species are likely (Petranka 1998). See Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species.

Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae were formerly included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south, and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.
This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides flavipunctatus (Reilly and Wake 2019).

This recently discovered fully aquatic, paedomorphic species is morphologically, ecologically, and genetically distinct from its sister species Eurycea multiplicata with which it occurs syntopically (Steefen et al. 2014). It went undetected due to a lack of herpetological sampling within the confines of Lake Catherine State Park, Hot Spring County, Arkansas (K. Irwin pers. comm. August 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Desmognathus fuscus (Titus and Larson 1996, Tilley et al. 2008, Beamer and Lamb 2020).
Schistolais leontica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Prinia leontica.
Certhidea olivacea and C. fusca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. olivacea following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lybius leucocephalus, L. senex and L. leucogaster (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. leucocephalus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Apteryx australis, A. mantelli and A. rowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously treated as A. australis and A. mantelli (incorporating rowi) following Baker et al. (1995); prior to that all three taxa were lumped as A. australis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was previously confused with Hynobius leechii and H. quelpaertensis and finally described by Min et al. (2016).

authority: Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Records from Anamada in the Nelliyampathy Hills of Palakkad district (Afthab et al. 2018) require molecular studies to confirm its presence (N. Modak pers. comm. October 2020).

authority: Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Otus megalotis, O. everetti and O. nigrorum (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. megalotis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was redescribed by Kok et al. (2006).

Subpopulations from Suriname that were previously reported as belonging to this species, have now been assigned to Anomaloglossus surinamensis (Ouboter and Jairam 2012). Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analysis, a subpopulation from Itoupe Massif in French Guiana have been assigned to A. dewynteri, and subpopulations from northeast French Guiana have been assigned to A. blanci (Fouquet et al. 2018).
This species can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, tadpole morphology, advertisement call and ecological traits (Kok et al. 2006).

This species is known from the Cook Strait and the Coromandel Peninsula; genetic divergence and minor morphological differences suggest that more than one taxon my be included under the name Toropuku stephensi (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

Recent genetic evidence suggests that the east and west populations of this species diverged in the Miocene (Chapple et al. 2012). While this is not thought to have taxonomic implications, this finding indicates that the two populations should continue to be treated as separate management units and needs to be accounted for in captive breeding programs (Chapple et al. 2012).
Named after Sir Robert Falla (1901–1979), a prominent New Zealand naturalist (Gill and Whitaker 2001).

The taxonomy of Oligosoma infrapunctatum has until recently not been studied in detail, although multiple undescribed species have been informally recognized from within the complex (discussed in Melzer et al. 2019). Uncertainty surrounds the identity of 'true' O. infrapunctatum, whose type locality is unknown: an assumption that this was Stephens Island (Takapourewa) (McCann 1955) is now considered to be in error, as the species known from this island is not conspecific with the O. infrapunctatum holotype (Melzer et al. 2019). These authors combined morphological evidence with a previous molecular phylogeny of the species complex to revise the taxonomy of this group.
This is a recognized species complex; as presently defined a northern and southern clade are recognized as distinct (Whitaker et al. 2018).

The name Woodworthia brunnea (sometimes, incorrectly, W. brunneus) has been used informally to refer to a species recognized as distinct from Dactylocnemis pacificus and from Woodworthia maculata, for which the name Pentadactylus brunneus is thought to be available (Jewell 2008). This action was taken without providing the taxonomic justification for associating the new taxon with the P. brunneus holotype. Nielsen et al. (2011) describe the content of Woodworthia as including W. brunnea, but do not comment on this assignment and elsewhere refer to samples of this species as Hoplodactylus cf. brunneus. Subsequently Hitchmough et al. (2016) used the form Woodworthia cf. brunnea to refer to this taxon, and this usage is preferred pending a formal examination of the appropriate nomenclature (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson 2011

taxonomicNotes: Work is underway to clarify the systematics of this species complex (R. Hitchmough and D. van Winkel pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011
Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011
Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla was moved to the new genus Myersiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now been moved to the new genus Nesorohyla (Pinheiro et al. 2018).
This species boundaries with other described species that are supposed to occur throughout Amazonia (i.e. the Scinax garbei complex) remain ambiguous (A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2022).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

authority: Olivieri, Zimmermann, Randrianambinina, Rassoloharijaona, Rakotondravony, Guschanski & Radespiel, 2007
taxonomicNotes: The original Latin species name was mistakenly amended from the original description to Microcebus danfossorum (Mittermeier et al. 2008) in the mistaken belief that it was named after a husband and wife team, but it was not. It was named after a factory, hence it was a brand name and should be treated as a singular name not a plural.

authority: Thinh, Mootnick, Vu Ngoc Thanh, Nadler & Roos, 2010
taxonomicNotes: Recent genetic and vocal studies confirmed the specific identity of the species which separates it from its closest congener, Nomascus gabriellae (Thinh et al. 2010a, 2010b, 2010c; Blair et al. 2011; Roos et al. 2013).

A member of the Hyla circumdata group according to the original publication. Bokermannohyla vulcaniae is diagnosed by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De Vasconcelos and Giaretta 2003).

authority: Pansonato, Veiga-Menoncello, Mudrek, Jansen, Recco-Pimentel, Martins & Strüssmann, 2016
Grismer, Wood, Aowphol, Cota, Grismer, Murdoch, Aguilar & Grismer, 2016

taxonomicNotes: The Qinling Mountains population is a distinctive genetic cluster and is significantly different from other mountain populations (Lü et al. 2001, Zhang, B. et al. 2007), diverging ~0.3 million years ago, corresponding with the onset of the Penultimate Glaciation (Zhao et al. 2013). Some argue that it should be considered a separate subspecies (Wan et al. 2003, 2005), although subspecies designation is controversial and not widely accepted. Nonetheless, there is greater consensus that this population should be managed as a conservation unit to retain genetic structure and any localized adaptation.

Oreophrynella seegobini is genetically very similar to this species although morphology and ecology do differ, and further taxonomic studies need to be carried out (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017). This may indicate a very recent evolutionary split between the species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).

authority: Hou, Wu, Yang, Zheng, Yuan & Li, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachella liui, and is now considered a sister species.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Pachytriton xanthospilos has been removed from synonymy of this species (Wu et al. 2012).

authority: Yan, Zhao, Jiang, Hou, He, Murphy & Che, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton chinensis (Yuan et al. 2014). No record of P. chinensis currently exists from the same locality as P. qixilingensis (Yuan et al. 2014).

This is a split from the broader concept of Tylototriton wenxianensis. The subspecies of T. wenxianensis from the north Dabie Mountains in Henan Province has been elevated to T. dabienicus according to Shen et al. 2012. Tylototriton anhuiensis was previously confused with this species, so subpopulations from Anhui Province that were previously attributed to T. dabienicus are now assigned to T. anhuiensis (Qian et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus (Wei et al. 2009).

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus dugritei (Li et al. 2012).

It was moved from the genus Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
Removed from synonymy with Cynops cyanurus by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2012).

This species was removed as a synonym of Bufo burmanus by Yang and Rao (2008) where it had been placed by Yang et al. (1996) (according to Rao et al. (1998)). Frost (2019) notes that these authors either disagreed with or missed that Bufo burmanus was placed in the synonymy of Bufo pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). This species was previously listed on the IUCN Red List as a synonym of Bufo pageoti (J. Luedtke pers. comm. August 2015).

This species was previously described as Odorrana chapaensis by Ngo et al. 2006 and Che et al. 2007, Amolops chapaensis by Bain and Nguyen, 2004 and Rana sp. ‘‘Cao Bang’’ (ROM 26476) by Chen et al. 2005.

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus hui (Li et al. 2012). This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
Quasipaa robertingeri was synonymized with this species by Che et al. (2009) and Zhang et al. (2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pachytriton changi, which has been removed from synonymy with this species (Wu et al. 2012).
Because this species was recently described, it is sometimes referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura bakeri or Enyaliosaura bakeri, the sister species it was split from.
Specimens from Itatiaia, and by implication any records from Serra da Mantiqueira, referred to as Hylodes aff. sazimai, belong to an undescribed species (C. Haddad pers. comm. 2021).

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus greeri and L. nigrofasciolatus are now placed in the genus Epibator.
Populations in the north at Rivière Nehoué and the Kaala massif are genetically divergent and may represent distinct taxa.

Bauer et al. (2012) in a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the giant geckos found that the few subpopulations of Rhacodactylus trachyrhynchus sampled were strongly divergent from one another and a specimen from Îlot Môrô near the Île des Pins is especially distinctive. This specimen and others examined from Îlot Môrô are morphologically assignable to the species described by Boulenger in 1878 as Chameleonurus trachycephalus (and later treated as a subspecies of R. trachyrhynchus) and is now recognized as a full species (Bauer et al. 2012).

The genetic study (Sadlier 2014) revealed the presence of two clearly differentiated lineages within what has previously been regarded as a single species, Nannoscincus mariei. Although the geographic range of samples available for the genetics study is not as extensive as that represented by museum specimens it is, in combination with morphological data, sufficient to indicate that the samples represent two parapatric taxa: N. mariei Bavay (Mt. Koghis south to the Goro Plateau, including Rivière Bleue), and N. fuscus (the Chaîne Centrale at Mt. Mou, Mt. Dzumac and Mt. Vulcain).

Recent genetic data indicates that populations at Île des Pins and on the islets near there and the east coast of Grande Terre that were earlier assigned to Bavayia crassicollis are not this taxon and that all geckos in the Îles Loyauté that were previously assigned to Bavayia cyclura are in fact Bavayia crassicollis.

There is a moderate level of genetic and morphometric differentiation between the widely disjunct groups of populations in the north and south of the species' range, and there is also a consistent difference in colouration between the population on the Panié massif and Koniambo. In the absence of data on the occurrence of the species between these groups of populations these differences are insufficient for taxonomic distinction.

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the K. viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is polyphyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. ciliatus and R. sarasinorum are sister taxa but are not part of the same clade as the other giant geckos hence the generic name Correlophus has been resurrected for them (Bauer et al. 2012).

Populations of Oedodera on the Poum and Kaala massifs are genetically and morphometrically divergent from O. marmorata from Dôme de Tiébaghi. They are treated as potentially distinct taxa under description and hence are not included in this assessment for Oedodera marmorata.
The low-elevation specimens (Vavouto) are likely to be another species (on-going studies by A. Bauer and R. Sadlier pers. comm.).

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is not monophyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. chahoua forms a distinct clade separate from Rhacodactylus sensu stricto and hence a new genus, Mniarogekko has been created to accommodate R. chahoua. Genetic data  also shows that the subpopulations in northern Grande Terre and on the Iles Belep are highly distinct and are hence described as a new species M. jalu (Bauer et al. 2012) which is assessed separately.

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the K. viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial  introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).

Recent genetic data show that, as presently defined, Bavayia sauvagii sensu (Boulenger, 1883) comprises a complex of at least nine cryptic species that appear to mostly have relatively confined, allopatric ranges.

Recent genetic data show that, as presently defined, Bavayia cyclura sensu Günther 1872 comprises at least ten cryptic species all of which have relatively confined, largely allopatric ranges. The data also show that material from the Îles Loyauté that was previously assigned to Bavayia cyclura is in fact Bavayia crassicollis.

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is polyphyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. ciliatus and R. sarasinorum are sister taxa but are not part of the same clade as the other giant geckos hence the generic name Correlophus has been resurrected for them (Bauer et al. 2012). Genetic substructuring has been detected between the population at Mt Koghis and those in the Prony district but this does not warrant specific distinction.
There is significant genetic divergence between the known populations on Mt Panié and Tchingou.

Recent genetic data shows that, as presently defined, Bavayia montana sensu Roux, 1913 comprises a complex of at least six cryptic species all of which have relatively confined, largely allopatric ranges.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus maruia and L. tillieri are now placed in the genus Phasmasuarus.

Amarasinghe et al. (2014) recognized the Knuckles Range population of Calotes liocephalus as the new species Calotes pethiyagodai on morphological grounds. These authors cautioned that little material was available for either this species or C. liocephalus and that further research should be conducted to confirm this arrangement.

authority: Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama, 2006
taxonomicNotes: There has been considerable controversy over the priority of the names Cophotis dumbara Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama, 2006 and Cophotis dumbarae Manamendra-Arachchi, de Silva & Amarasinghe, 2006, with both names being published at very close dates. Hallermann and Böhme (2007) reviewed this issue, and determined that Cophotis dumbara (published on November 25, 2006) should take priority over Cophotis dumbarae (published on December 6, 2006). Following an application to the ICZN by the authors of C. dumbarae (considered to have been based on the absence of a reply) this issue now appears to be settled, with C. dumbara accepted as the correct name (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Melanophidium khairei was described from populations previously understood to represent a northern isolate of Melanophidium punctatum (Gower et al. 2016).
This species was previously synonymized with Cyrtodactylus rubidus (Blyth, 1861) (which is now restricted to the Andaman Islands).

Lygosoma ashwamedhi was originally described as Riopa ashwamedhi by Sharma in 1969. A molecular phylogentic analysis has confirmed the validity of this species but concluded that it should be transferred to Eutropis (Srinivasulu et al. 2016).
This species was formerly the only member of the genus Balanophis but is now treated under Rhabdophis.
Batuwita (2019) re-described this species, referring the majority of records to other species.
Previously incorrectly thought to be a separate species, Hypnale walli is now treated as junior subjective synonym of Hypnale nepa (Maduwage et al. 2009).

Amarasinghe and Campbell (2016) resolved longstanding confusion surrounding the identity of the holotype of Cnemaspis podihuna and fixed the type locality. These authors' redescription of the holotype it did not discuss the broader distribution of this taxon, which has also been controversial. The most recent characterization of this species' distribution (Batuwita and Udagampala 2017) is followed here, but beyond describing a new species (Cnemaspis kandambyi) previously confused with it and providing a distribution map, these authors did not discuss taxonomic problems with C. podihuna in detail. Ongoing molecular and morphological research indicates that C. podihuna is likely to be a species complex, and that C. podihuna sensu stricto is likely to have a much more restricted range than presently recognized (S. Karunarathna and S. Kannishka pers. comm. 2019).

In a morphological review of Lankascincus, Batuwita (2019) found that characters described as being diagnostic for L. munindradasai could not reliably distinguish it from the similar L. taprobanensis. This author consequently synonymized L. munindradasai with L. taprobanensis on both morphological and biogeographic grounds.

Taxononomic uncertainty persists with regard to the relationship between this species and R. punctatus (Pyron et al. 2016 and references therein; M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).

Taxononomic uncertainty persists with regard to the relationship between this species and R. punctatus (Pyron et al. 2016 and references therein; M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).

Pyron et al. (2016) suggest a comprehensive phylogeographic study of this species, which has the imprecise type locality "Sri Lanka", and to clarify whether this apparently widespread species represents a species complex once its type locality has been restricted.
Records of Rhinophis blythii, a species otherwise known only from the Central Hills, from southwestern Sri Lanka are likely to represent this species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2009).
This name may be comprised of more than one species (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Agarwal et al. (2017) synonymized Cnemaspis clivicola and within C. upendrai. The holotypes of these two species differ genetically from one another by only 0.1% using ND2.
Historical records of this species outside the known range were found to represent different species by Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007), who also referred Cnemaspis ranwellai to its synonymy.
Cnemaspis ingerorum was previously confused with Cnemaspis kumarasinghei. It was found to be genetically distinct by Agarwal et al. (2017) and formally described by Batuwita et al. (2019)
Records of this species from Borangamuwa represent the newly-described species Cnemaspis anslemi.
Records of Cnemaspis aliwisi from the south of the species' currently known range represent a separate, recently-described species, C. hitihami.

No distinct morphological characters were provided in the original description that can reliably distinguish this species from the Calotes liolepis species complex, which which it is sympatric (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Based on molecular analysis C. desilvai is a valid species (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019), but further taxonomic resolution within the C. liolepis complex is needed to clarify range limits within this group and identify diagnostic characters for C. desilvai (Karunararathna et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax hamidi (Matsui et al. 2014) – currently Leptobrachella hamidi.

The new species of diplodactylid gecko, Bavayia nubilaa, was described in 2012 from forests at two sites in the drainage of the Tontouta Valley in the ultramafic ranges of southeastern New Caledonia. The new gecko is the sister species of the much smaller Bavayia goroensis; both species are basal within the B. cyclura clade.

Caledoniscincus constellatus (described in 2012) has a bold, white midlateral stripe, a feature which distinguishes it from most other species of Caledoniscincus except the regionally sympatric C. haplorhinus (Günther) and C. austrocaledonicus (Bavay), from which it can be distinguished by a unique pattern of contact between the pale midlateral stripe and the ear. DNA sequence data for the ND2 mitochondrial gene identifies a high level of genetic differentiation between the new species and all other Caledoniscincus, further supporting its distinctiveness as an independent evolutionary lineage.

Caledoniscincus pelletieri was described in 2014 from the far north-west region of New Caledonia. It has a bold, white mid-lateral stripe on the body, a feature which distinguishes it from most other species of Caledoniscincus except the regionally sympatric Caledoniscincus haplorhinus (Günther) and Caledoniscincus austrocaledonicus (Bavay), and the recently described Caledoniscincus constellatus Sadlier, Whitaker, Wood & Bauer just to the south. The new species can be distinguished from these taxa in features of scalation and colouration, most notably in lacking an extension of the pale midlateral stripe between the ear and forelimbs and in having more lamellae on the underside of the fourth toe. The differences in morphology between C. pelletieri and the other members of the genus are complemented by a high level of genetic differentiation, further supporting its distinctiveness as an independent evolutionary lineage warranting recognition as a distinct species. The DNA sequence data for the ND2 mitochondrial gene identifies the new species as the sister to C. constellatus and these two taxa as the sister to all Caledoniscincus.

Correlophus belepensis (described in 2012) is a large diplodactylid. It differs from C. sarasinorum in possessing a prominent crest of spinose scales extending from behind the orbit to the shoulder region. It is most similar to its sister taxon C. ciliatus, but may be distinguished from it by its homogeneous dorsolateral trunk scalation and (in three of the four types) its possession of a series of small whitish tubercles on the lower back and/or tail base.

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is not monophyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. chahoua forms a distinct clade separate from Rhacodactylus sensu stricto and hence a new genus, Mniarogekko has been created to accommodate R. chahoua. Genetic data showed that the subpopulations in northern Grande Terre and on the Iles Belep are highly distinct and are hence described as M. jalu (Bauer et al. 2012).

Mniarogekko jalu is a large (to 140 mm SVL) diplodactylid. It may be distinguished from its sister taxon M. chahoua by its much lower number of precloacal pores in males typically arranged in three, rather than four rows. Colour comparisons between the two species of Mniarogekko are difficult to make. There are relatively few wild caught M. chahoua in museum collections and captive animals have been bred for particular colour patterns (de Vosjoli et al. 2003) so ‘wild type’ coloration, which is itself already quite variable is difficult to characterize. Ventral body coloration in the new species seems to be uniformly a pale yellowish green, whereas M. chahoua is often white or cream, with a greenish tinge localized to some parts of the venter.

The genetic study (Sadlier 2014) revealed the presence of two clearly differentiated lineages within what has previously been regarded as a single species, Nannoscincus mariei. Although the geographic range of samples available for the genetics study is not as extensive as that represented by museum specimens it is, in combination with morphological data, sufficient to indicate that the samples represent two parapatric taxa: Nannoscincus mariei Bavay (Mt. Koghis south to the Goro Plateau, including Rivière Bleue), and Nannoscincus fuscus (the Chaîne Centrale at Mt. Mou, Mt. Dzumac and Mt. Vulcain).

Nannoscincus koniambo was described in 2014 (Sadlier, 2014). It is part of the N. mariei group, is restricted to the Koniambo massif and can be distinguished from all other members of the genus a combination of characters: frontoparietals fused; loreal single; left oviduct lost in females; lower labials five; lower eyelid with a semi-translucent window; ear opening minute; body scales smooth; adult dorsal color two toned; ear opening positioned two scales posterior to lower secondary temporal; presacral vertebrae 32; phalangeal formula for manus 2.3.4.4.3.; phalangeal formula for pes 2.3.4.5.3.

Bauer et al. (2012) in a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the giant geckos found that the few subpopulations of Rhacodactylus trachyrhynchus sampled were strongly divergent from one another and a specimen from Îlot Môrô near the Île des Pins is especially distinctive. This specimen and others examined from Îlot Môrô are morphologically assignable to the species described by Boulenger in 1878 as Chameleonurus trachycephalus (and later treated as a subspecies of R. trachyrhynchus) and is now recognized as a full species (Bauer et al. 2012).

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a Sigaloseps lineage of three taxa from the interior ranges of the southern ultramafic New Caledonia region: one representing populations on the adjacent peaks of Mt Ouin and Mt Humboldt formerly included under S. ruficauda and described as S. ferrugicauda; one representing the type population of S. ruficauda sensu stricto from Mt Mou; and one representing a taxon from Mt Humboldt that is morphologically very distinct but shows a low level of genetic differentiation from S. ruficauda and is described as S. balios.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a taxon formerly included within Sigaloseps deplanchei sensu lato and represented by populations from the southeast of the southern ultramafic region at Rivière Bleue and Pourina River and here described as S. conditus.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a Sigaloseps lineage of three taxa from the interior ranges of the southern ultramafic New Caledonia region: one representing populations on the adjacent peaks of Mt Ouin and Mt Humboldt formerly included under S. ruficauda and described as S. ferrugicauda; one representing the type population of S. ruficauda sensu stricto from Mt Mou; and one representing a taxon from Mt Humboldt that is morphologically very distinct but shows a low level of genetic differentiation from S. ruficauda and is described as S. balios.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a taxon formerly included within Sigaloseps deplanchei sensu lato and represented by populations in the central (Tontouta valley) and northern (Pic Ningua) areas of the southern ultramafic region, and coastal ultramafic ranges in the east-central region (Nakéty) and here described as Sigaloseps pisinnus.

Included in Manis by several authors (with Smutsia sometimes considered a subgenus) and referred to Phataginus by Grubb et al. (1998), but here included in the genus Smutsia, along with Temminck's Pangolin, S. temminckii, following Gaudin et al. (2009).
Populations in the Philippines formerly attributed to this species were separated under the name Manis culionensis by Feiler (1998) and subsequently by Gaubert and Antunes (2005).

Included in Manis by most authors (with Smutsia usually considered a subgenus) and referred to Phataginus by Grubb et al. (1998), but here included in the genus Smutsia, along with the Giant Pangolin (S. gigantea) following Gaudin et al. (2009). The preferred common name (as accepted by the African Pangolin Working Group and the IUCN Species Survival Commission Pangolin Specialist Group) is Temminck’s Pangolin. No subspecies are recognised.
