This species has previously been assigned to the genus Nesionixalus.
No notable taxonomic issues.
No notable taxonomic issues.
Accepted as Rhampholeon nebulauctor (Branch et al. 2014). No notable taxonomic issues.

Rhampholeon tilburyi is found in the lower elevation forests on Mt Namuli. Phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. tilburyi is a separate taxon to an undescribed species (R. sp. nov. 'namuli2') that is found in the high elevation forests (K.A. Tolley unpub. data 2019). The holotype of R. tilburyi was collected from Ukalini Forest on Mt Namuli, but it was not included in the phyologenetic analysis that lead to the species description (Branch et al. 2014). The only material included was from the Cha Madal tea estate and these samples form a monophyletic clade with those from Ukalini Forest. Samples of Rhampholeon collected from Manho Forest, which is higher in elevation, are in a different clade (K.A. Tolley unpub. data 2019). Recent records from Mt Ribáuè, Mt Mepalué and Mt Socone were confirmed as Rhampholeon tilburyi using a phylogenetic analysis (K.A. Tolley unpub. data).
Populations from mainland Africa assigned to this species are now considered to be Leptopelis rufus.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys.  Dubois et al. (2021) recognized that Panophrys is proccupied and employed Boulenophrys as the generic name rather than Tianophrys under the Principle of First Revisor. This assessment retains it under Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018). 

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Mahony et al. (2018) assigned to Megophrys cf. periosa specimens found in the state of Manipur State in India at Pangkava ju in the Ukhrul district, and in the state of Kachin in northern Myanmar at Hepu Stream in Hepu village in the Myitkyina district, at 820 m asl, but their relation to M. periosa requires further taxonomic investigation (S. Mahony pers. comm. September 2020).
Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

taxonomicNotes: This species from Parque Nacional El Chico in the state of Hidalgo was long assigned to Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rabb 1958, Wake and Lynch 1976).

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys minor (Wang et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton wenxianensis and T. dabienicus, so subpopulations from Anhui Province that were previously attributed to these species are now assigned to T. anhuiensis (Qian et al. 2017).

authority: Li, Xu, Lv, Jiang, Wei & Wang, 2018

taxonomicNotes: Bertola et al. (2018) reported a population related to Phyllurus gulbaru from The Pinnacles, while recognising that this represented an evolutionarily significant unit whose taxonomic status was in need of further investigation. Subsequent morphological and molecular research confirmed that this population should be regarded as a distinct species despite moderately low mtDNA differentiation Hoskin et al. (2019), and these authors accordingly described it as the new species Phyllurus pinnaclensis.

taxonomicNotes: This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Sarcohyla bistincta by Campbell et al. (2018) where it had been placed by Duellman (1964). Additionally, Campbell et al. (2018) synonymised S. calthula and S. ephemera with this species.

Lynch (1976) elevated this taxon to species status with no further comment. Lynch, Ruíz-Carranza and Ardila-Robayo (1994) redescribed the species, and noted a possible synapomorphy with Pristimantis cremnobates.

Python bivittatus was recently recognized as a full species (Jacobs et al. 2009), having previously been considered a subspecies of P. molurus. The subspecies P. b. progschai has been erected to describe populations from Sulawesi (Jacobs et al. 2009).

authority: Tapley, Cutajar, Mahony, Chung, Dau, Nguyen, Luong & Rowley, 2017
taxonomicNotes:
This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys kuatunensis (Tapley et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Genus change from Platymantis to Cornufer (Brown et al. 2015). Adults of this species resemble juveniles of Cornufer papuensis and individuals could be misidentified in the field.

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar. Praschag et al. (2009) further assessed the genetics and taxonomic status of a Cambodian relict subpopulation and eastern Peninsular Malaysian subpopulations and described them as the new subspecies B. affinis edwardmolli, with B. a. affinis occurring in western Peninsular Malaysia and Sumatra. Moll et al. (2015) reviewed the range-wide conservation biology and conservation status of the species.

Two subspecies are recognized, Chitra chitra chitra Nutphand, 1986 occurring in western Thailand and presumably Peninsular Malaysia, and Chitra chitra javanensis McCord & Pritchard, 2003 recorded from eastern Java and possibly extending to Sumatra.
Taxonomic research is needed, particularly regarding subspecies and northeast Indian status.

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all Fijian banded iguanas were lumped together as a single species (Brachylophus fasciatus). The Gau Banded Iguana, Brachylophus gau, was newly described in 2017 (Fisher et al. 2017) as being morphologically distinct from the Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus) and from the Central Fijian Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula).
This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops larutensis (Chan et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Amolops larutensis, which it was previously confused with (Chan et al. 2018).

Stöck (1999) suggested that Batrachuperus gorganensis was a synonym of this species. However, (T. Papenfuss pers. comm. September 2008) argued that molecular analysis demonstrated that Paradactylodon gorganensis should be treated as a distinct species. They were assessed separately for the Red List up until 2008, and both were then transferred to the genus Iranodon. They have subsequently been transferred back to Paradactylodon by Stöck et al. (2019) with gorganensis being placed into synonymy under P. persicus.
Confused with Adenomera araucaria prior to its naming according to the original publication (Carvalho et al. 2019). This concept may be a complex of several undescribed species.
Molecular analyses suggest close relationship with A. furcatus, A. hellmayri and A. bogotensis, and may form a clade with these species and A. chii, A. correndera and A. antarcticus. Monotypic.
Poodytes albolimbatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Megalurus albolimbatus.
Sclerurus scansor and S. cearensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. scansor following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Genus change from Liophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017).
Pyrrhula nipalensis and P. waterstradti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. nipalensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Megalurulus grosvenori (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that in Cichlornis but reassigned to Cincloramphus following Alström et al. (2018). Until recently treated as conspecific with C. llaneae, C. turipavae and C. whitneyi, but differs from first two in characters given under those species and from C. whitneyi by its broader, longer, blacker mask, encompassing eye and extending to rear ear-coverts (2); longer, thicker tarsus (allow 2); shallower and less curved culmen (1); less graduated tail (1); and dark brown vs black legs (1). Monotypic.

Puffinus newelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into P. newelli and P. myrtae (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) found molecular evidence that Newell’s Shearwater Puffinus newelli and Townsend’s Shearwater P. auricularis are conspecific. Although they mention the morphological analysis in del Hoyo and Collar (2014: p386) which gave a Tobias score of 7 to newelli, these authors did not consider the characters in question: larger size (an effect size of 3.29 on tail length yielded a score of 2; new data in Shirihai et al. [2017] yields an effect size of 2.41, thus again a score of 2); cleaner-cut head pattern (score 1); bolder, squarer neck mark (score 2); all-white undertail-coverts (score 2); plus darker upperparts (scored 1 but uncounted).

(These characters and scores are revised below.)

Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also mentioned that ‘Howell (2012) proposed a separate treatment based on their differences in morphology, breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; Bourne et al. 1988), and breeding ecology (Spear et al. 1995)’ [NB these citations in quotation marks are not in the reference list below]. Thus it appears that there are behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa in addition to the morphological ones. Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) cited the case of Charadrius dealbatus as one in which morphological characters are strong but genetic ones non-existent, but they did not mention that del Hoyo and Collar (2014) accepted the morphological characters despite the genetic evidence. In the present case it seems appropriate to continue to consider that two species are involved, pending confirmation of the authors’ molecular work, clarification of the accuracy of the scoring used to maintain the split of newelli in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), and evidence of the behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa.

However, Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also found that P. n. myrtae, ‘Rapa Shearwater’, is genetically more distinct from newelli than newelli is from auricularis. On this basis they propose that myrtae be treated as a full species. Such an arrangement is supported by Shirihai et al. (2017), who noted:

Rapa Shearwater is much smaller (in all biometric characters) than the other two taxa…, and is furthermore highly distinctive in having a unique combination of white undertail-coverts (vs. dark in both newelli and auricularis) and whitish inner webs to the remiges, as well as a white face.

There is a contradiction here with del Hoyo and Collar (2014), where the undertail-coverts of newelli, compared to auricularis, are given as ‘white vs white-edged grey’. Further consideration of this point, by examining images online and Plate 16.1 in Howell (2012: 147), indicate that auricularis has marginally more extensive black undertail-coverts than newelli. However, the information contained in Howell (2012) and the references he cited, plus that conveyed in Howell’s Plate 16.1, lead to somewhat differently scored and parsed characters for newelli vs auricularis:  larger size (effect size 2.41 [see above]: 2);  cleaner-cut and blacker head- and neck-sides (2);  more white on undertail-coverts (1); darker upperparts (1); somewhat different feeding ecology, using less upwelled, more stratified waters with more turbulent meteorological features (Spear et al. 1995; allow 1); breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; no score allowed).

By this means newelli continues to achieve species rank under the Tobias criteria. We therefore retain P. newelli as a separate species from P. auricularis until independent genetic analysis supports Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) and/or until a new full assessment of morphological characters, and of the behavioural/ecological evidence, can be undertaken.

There is significant population genetic differentiation between all three extant subspecies of Black Rhinoceros (hereafter Black Rhino) recognised by the IUCN SSC African Rhinoceros Specialist Group (AfRSG) (Harley et al. 2005), and the differences are consistent with them being considered subspecies although it is unlikely that outbreeding depression would occur in any mix of these populations (E. Harley pers. comm. 2016).

Subsequent classification analyses of RhoDIS DNA samples (originally undertaken primarily for forensic purposes) also strongly supported use of the current three surviving subspecies classification at a continental level. It also indicated that Diceros bicornis minor samples could be further subdivided into those of Zambesi, KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) or mixed Zambesi/KZN origin (Emslie 2018, Harper et al. 2018). Moodley et al. (2017) also found this partitioning of D. b. minor. The populations founded with KZN animals were found to be less genetically diverse than ones derived from Zambesi animals due to a relatively recent severe bottleneck (Emslie 2018, Harper et al. 2018). Data indicates that most of the genetic diversity has been recovered in the large mixed KZN/Zambesi founded population in the Kruger National Park (C. Harper pers. comm. 2018).

Strong support for continuing to use the three remaining subspecies/management units also comes from  independent work on different DNA datasets by Moodley et al. (2017) and Le Roex (2018).  Moodley et al.'s (2017) analyses were based on wide sampling of rhino DNA from existing populations as well as from 217 museum specimens worldwide (covering many areas where Black Rhino have since been extirpated). This work found that that 69% of the species' mitochondrial genetic variation has been lost. Based on nuclear and mitochondrial data from Moodley et al. (2017) four surviving Evolutionary Significant Units (ESU's) were identified for Black Rhino. Three of these ESU's (SC, EA and CE haplogroups/populations) were found to be co-occurring with secondary contact having occurred in East Africa. An East African Community Rhino Management Group meeting which had a focus on African rhino genetics (and was also attended by some IUCN SSC AfRSG and Conservation Specialist Group members) recommended that due to this co-occurrence, these three ESU's in East Africa should constitute and be managed as a single Eastern Black Rhino Management Unit Cluster (equivalent to D. b. michaeli). While Moodley et al.'s (2017) data also indicated there was  a single surviving Evolutionary Significant Unit in Southern Africa, microsatellite data further indicated  this Southern ESU should be subdivided  into South Western and South Eastern Black Rhino Management Unit Clusters. These two southern African Management Unit Clusters are equivalent to D. b. bicornis (SW haplogroup) and D. b. minor (SE and SN haplogroups) subspecies respectively).

Moodley et al.'s (2017) study also found that the historic range of the Western Black Rhino (D. b. longipes) that has been declared Extinct extends into an inter-crossed predominantly D. b. michaeli population in the Masai Mara (CV haplogroup). However, very few individuals with this CV haplotype probably survive. 

Thus there was agreement across different studies that used different data sets and different analytical methods that the three recommended Management Unit Clusters mapped closely onto and supporting the existing three surviving Black Rhino subspecies classification.

All studies found that differences were  greatest between D. b. michaeli and the other two southern African subspecies  D. b. minor and D. b. bicornis. Putative subspecies boundaries in current species plans also in part reflect climatic and habitat differences as well as taking into account potential barriers to movement such as the “Transkei gap”. 

Based on very small sample sizes, Moodley et al.'s (2017) results suggested that perhaps the original historical Black Rhino that used to occur in Zambia but which had been wiped out by poaching by 1995 might be better classified as D. b. michaeli than D. b. minor. However, on account of the small sample sizes, and given that the species was reintroduced with D. b. minor founders, and that historically Zambia had been considered D. b. minor range, and climate and habitats are more similar to some D. b. minor range; reviewers recommended that historical pre-1995 Zambian animals should continue to be allocated to D. b. minor  for this Red List revision (as has historically been the case). With further data this may change in future. As there were still significant numbers of Black Rhinos in Zambia in the early 1970s how these animals are allocated influences the D. b. minor subspecies Red List assessment which would change to Endangered under criteria A2 and A4. The D. b. michaeli assessment remains the same whether or not the historical animals are classified as D. b. minor or D. b. michaeli.
Setophaga flavescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements).

authority: Monteiro, Condez, Garcia, Comitti, Amaral & Haddad, 2018
Almendáriz C., Brito-M., Batallas-R., Vaca-Guerrero & Ron, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Craugastor podiciferus by Arias et al. (2019) where it had previously been placed by Taylor (1952).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor podiciferus (Arias et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hemiphractus fasciatus (Hill et al. 2018).
This species was previously confused with Ischnocnema oea.

authority: Taucce, Canedo, Parreiras, Drummond, Nogueira-Costa & Haddad, 2018

taxonomicNotes: Alexandrinus eques (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula eques (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established, including Alexandrinus for P. krameri, P. eques and P. exsul.

authority: De la Riva, Cortez F. & Burrowes, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was originally included within Dendrobates flavopictus (Gans 1960) and later allocated to Ameerega picta by Silverstone (1976). After re-examination of the original material the frogs were subsequently included within Ameerega braccata (Morales 2001). Prior to their description as a full species, Lötters et al. (2007) provisionally restored the massif populations in Ameerega flavopicta.
This species was confused with Cryptotriton veraepacis prior to its naming by Rovito et al. (2015).

In this assessment, Cercocebus torquatus is equivalent to what some classifications have called C. t. torquatus; that subspecies is only valid if the more westerly populations (lunulatus and atys) are recognised as part of a C. torquatus species concept. The Primate SG currently recognises C. atys, C. lunulatus, and C. torquatus as separate species, as do Oates (2011) and Ehardt (2013).

Recent studies have placed Cnemidophorus abaetensis in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended it should remain in Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review of Brazilian species is concluded. Nonetheless the Sociedade Brasileira de Herpetologia and this evaluation follow Harvey et al. (2012).

Recent studies listed Cnemidophorus nativo within the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested that it should remain within Cnemidophorus until a more extensive revision is completed. Following common usage among workers in the area where this species occurs, this evaluation follows Harvey et al. (2012) and Arias et al. (2014) in treating this species within Ameivula.

Leposternon octostegum was described in 1851 from a specimen now archived in the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, in Paris, with uncertain locality (Brèsil). Other specimens were lost due to uncertain taxonomic status; destroyed during World War II (Deutsches Museum Bonn, Germany), or deposited in unknown collections (Barros-Filho et al. 2013). It was rediscovered in 2003 from five subpopulations (Barros-Filho et al. 2013), and was subsequently re-described in detail by Barros-Filhos et al. (2019).

authority: (Rocha, Bamberg Araújo, Vrcibradic & Mamede Da Costa, 2000)
taxonomicNotes: A recent study listed Cnemidophorus littoralis under the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested it remain under Cnemidophorus before a more extensive revision is completed.

authority: (Colli, Costa, Garda, Kopp, Mesquita, Péres, Valdujo, Vieira & Wiederhecker, 2003)
taxonomicNotes: Morphological and molecular studies have shown that Ameiva parecis belongs within Ameiva, and not Cnemidophorus as in its original description (Arias et al. 2011, Harvey et al. 2012, Giugliano et al. 2013).

A recent study (Hedges and Conn 2012) separated the species previously, included in Mabuya, in a different genus. Vrcibradic et al. (2006) analysed the complex M. agilis, M. caissara, and M. heathi, and found that the genetic distances between them were small. They suggested that the three may represent a single species, but indicated the need for further data.

authority: de Freitas, Strüssmann, de Carvalho, Kawashita-Ribeiro & Mott, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Gainsbury and Colli (2003) included this population within Bachia cacerencis. De Freitas et al. (2011) confirmed it represented a new species, which they named Bachia didactyla.

authority: Rodrigues, De Freitas, Santos Silva & Viña Bertolotto, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. pseudotigrinus Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.

The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. nasofrontalis Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.

Harvey and Smith (1993) pointed out that Rhinella echinodes, described by Reynolds and Foster (1992), is a synonym of R. quechua. There is an unconfirmed record in Parque Nacional Cotapata in La Paz (Cortez 2001). This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
Harvey (1996) synonymized Cochranella flavidigitata with N. bejaranoi.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was rediscovered by J. Aparicio and S. Reichle in 1997 at the type locality.

De la Riva et al. (2000) registered a slight doubt as to the taxonomic validity of the species. Faivovich and De la Riva (2006), however, continue to recognize it as a valid species, pending a revision of subpopulations associated with the name Hyloscirtus armatus. In the Hyloscirtus armatus group according to Faivovich and De la Riva (2006).
This species was formerly considered a synonym of Pristimantis fenestratus by Lynch (1980), but it was elevated to species status by Köhler (2000).

This species was formerly considered to be a synonym of Telmatobius marmoratus (Vellard 1970). It was resurrected as a full species by De la Riva et al. (2000). Telmatobius ifornoi is included as a synonym of this species, following De la Riva (2005).
This species is a complex of more than one species.
We follow De la Riva et al. (2000) in considering this species to be separate from Telmatobius marmoratus, and also follow De la Riva (2004) in considering T. jahuira as a synonym of T. verrucosus.

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

Previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius marmoratus, T. hintoni was elevated to species category by De la Riva (2005) based on morphological and colour differences.

In addition to the holotype, the type series of T. hintoni is comprised of three specimens from Calacoto, La Paz, but these specimens are not conspecific with the holotype, and they were correctly identified as T. marmoratus by Vellard (De la Riva 2005).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva, 2007).

authority: (Muñoz, Aguayo & De la Riva in De la Riva, 2007)
(De la Riva & Padial in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). It seems that there are two different subpopulations of this species; however, it is not known whether these are conspecific with each other (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008, 2019)

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De la Riva 2005). It is possible that the two subpopulations are not conspecific, so further taxonomic studies are needed (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

authority: (De la Riva, Reichle & Bosch in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns, saltatorial behaviour and advertisement call features (De la Riva 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). There are probably two species contained within this taxon (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Bolitoglossa meliana (Vazquez-Almazán and Rovito 2014).
Acrocephalus caffer, A. musae and A. longirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caffer following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Calidris pygmaea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Eurynorhynchus as E. pygmeus.

Blossomcrown Anthocephala floriceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into Santa Marta Blossomcrown and Tolima Blossomcrown A. berlepschi (which see) following the finding of reciprocal monophyly between the two (Loranzo-Jaramillo et al. 2014), supported by subsequent assessment of morphological differences in museum specimens, albeit with a sample size of only three for floriceps.
The specific name was incorrectly spelt on earlier Red Lists as kempi.

Eclectus Parrot Eclectus roratus has been split into Moluccan Eclectus E. roratus, Sumba Eclectus E. cornelia, Tanimbar Eclectus E. riedeli and Papuan Eclectus E. polychloros. Extensive museum work confirmed the four groups proposed as species on molecular data (Braun et al. 2017) do exceed the threshold of 7 under the Tobias criteria (Tobias et al. 2010) and are therefore accepted as species.

Eclectus Parrot Eclectus roratus has been split into Moluccan Eclectus E. roratus, Sumba Eclectus E. cornelia, Tanimbar Eclectus E. riedeli and Papuan Eclectus E. polychloros. Extensive museum work confirmed the four groups proposed as species on molecular data (Braun et al. 2017) do exceed the threshold of 7 under the Tobias criteria (Tobias et al. 2010) and are therefore accepted as species.
The species blandingii has generally been placed in Emydoidea in recent years, but has also been argued to belong in the genus Emys, based on molecular phylogeny results.

Pelecanoides georgicus has been split into South Georgia Diving-petrel P. georgicus and Whenua Hou Diving-petrel following the application of the Tobias et al. (2010) criteria by Fischer et al. (2018) to a new form of South Georgia Diving-petrel, upon which it emerges as a species on the basis of a score of 8 in comparison with the population of P. georgicus from the South Atlantic Ocean and a score of 9 in comparison with that from the South Indian Ocean. 

There is a technical problem with the authors’ scoring of the two biometric characters, because they could be said to co-vary with the greater size of NZ birds. However, their data indicate that the bill of NZ birds is actually slightly shorter than those of birds from other populations, so the depth could be interpreted as independent of body size and the other character used. The authors appear to have used standard errors rather than standard deviations in their calculations. However, converting SE to SD yields scores of 1 as they indicated. While the scores for plumage differences in the original description are possibly on the generous side, the taxon is clearly valid, but much more study is needed to demonstrate the strength and consistency of the diagnostic characters. With these reservations, its status as a species is nonetheless accepted here.

Santa Marta Screech-owl Megascops gilesi is recognised as a species, having first been noted to differ from the rest of the series of M. choliba seen by Todd and Carriker (1922), and finally described by Krabbe (2017). Genetic analysis indicates that it is indeed distinct from other Megascops, with a minimum uncorrected genetic distance of 6.1% (from M. watsonii usta) higher than that recovered between other Megascops species (Dantas et al. 2016). 

Unfortunately the detail of the vocal analysis is unclear as the five taxa for which measured parameters overlap do not appear to be identified, and the differences are not scored (Krabbe 2017). Equally only a description of the plumage is given, rather than a treatment that assesses the differences between taxa. However the sonogram suggests at least a moderately distinctive song, and the phylogenetic position indicated by Dantas et al. (2016) is strong reason to accept that the distinction is indeed a valid full species.
Calliope obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Krabbe, Salaman, Cortés, Quevedo, Ortega & Cadena, 2005
taxonomicNotes: Genetically and vocally distinct, and a relatively old species, though only fairly recently described (Krabbe et al. 2005); most closely associated with S. robbinsi of SW Ecuador and S. stilesi of N part of C Andes of Colombia. Newly described form yariguiorum fairly distinctive vocally and in biometrics, though less so in plumage; considered an incipient species (Donegan et al. 2013). Two subspecies recognized.
Sporophila maximiliani (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oryzoborus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Sternula lorata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Pyrrhura melanura has been split into P. melanura and P. chapmani following an assessment of the latter by Donegan et al. (2018), in light of the previous split of Maroon-tailed Parakeet into P. melanura and P. pacifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). While Donegan et al. (2018) are mistaken in scoring two covarying measurements twice, and only 1 is allowed for habitat difference, which in any case is not accepted here as too vague (the elevational difference may well be responsible for the increase in body size). However, in reviewing the photographs used to illustrate these differences it certainly appears that the blue primaries and the darker crown merit 2 each, the buffy nuchal region perhaps only 1 (3 seems extreme), but the size difference vs. melanura (mean wing 136.8 vs 126.6, tail 125.2 vs 109.9 in Table 1 in Ridgely & Robbins 1988, Wilson Bull. 100: 173-182) clearly scores 2, on which basis the form reaches and is accepted here as holding species rank. Monotypic.
Callaeas cinereus and C. wilsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cinereus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Psittiparus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019), though this taxon was not included in that analysis. It had formerly been placed in Paradoxornis.
Formerly considered conspecific with P. gularis. Monotypic.
Hypotaenidia owstoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Gallirallus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.

Krishnamurthy and Shakunthala (1993) reported this species from Karnataka, India. Dutta (1997) rejected the species' presence in India, but notes that there is an unspecified form of Fejervarya in Karnataka and Maharashtra that is closely related to F. greenii (S. Dutta pers. comm.).

The subpopulations in Sri Lanka have been assigned to Indosylvirana serendipi and Hydrophylax gracilis (Biju et al. 2014). These species have all been moved from Indosylvirana and Hydrophylax back to Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus procax to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus hoffmani to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering this species to be separate from Philautus microtympanum, and belonging to the genus Philautus, rather than Polypedates.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus pleurotaenia that now includes all the records from P. hoipolloi, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus papillosus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus nanus (Günther 1869) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species was moved to the genus Philautus from Theloderma by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

This species is known only from the holotype which has been lost. It is not currently possible to match this name to any known species in the wild. It was removed from the synonymy of Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is currently considered distinct from Pseudophilautus macropus following Ellepola et al. (2021). However, further taxonomic studies on this species are required.
This species was previously placed in the genera Rhacophorus and Polypedates.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).
Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).

authority: Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the Oligosoma infrapunctatum species complex but had been recognized as a candidate species by multiple authors, under the informal names Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Chesterfield" (a name properly applied to the sister species Oligosoma salmo) or Oligosomaa aff. infrapunctatum "Alborn".

This taxon, previously included within Oligosoma infrapunctatum, has been informally treated as a part of distinct species by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "southern North Island" (and further split by van Winkel et al. 2018, who restricted its distribution to Hawke's Bay under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Hawke's Bay"). Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, coining the name Oligosoma auroraensis later emended to O. aurorarense.

This taxon has previously been included within the O. infrapunctatum species complex, although since its discovery in 1993 it has been recognized as a candidate species under the common name 'Chesterfield skink' and, scientifically, by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Chesterfield". Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, and coined the name Oligosoma salmo for this taxon.

Uncertainty surrounds the identity of 'true' Oligosoma infrapunctatum, whose type locality is unknown: an assumption that this was Stephens Island (Takapourewa) (McCann 1955) is now considered to be in error, as the species known from this island is not conspecific with the O. infrapunctatum holotype (Melzer et al. 2019). Melzer et al. (2019) resurrected the name Oligosoma newmani for the Takapourewa population. The concept applied by these authors encompassed the majority of South Island populations previously included within O. infrapunctatum, but they cautioned that significant morphological differences between island and mainland populations suggest that taxonomic issues are likely to remain within this clade despite relatively low genetic divergence.

This taxon, previously included within Oligosoma infrapunctatum, has been informally treated as a distinct species by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "crenulate". Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, and resurrected the name Oligosoma robinsoni for this taxon (excluding a genetically and morphologically distinct population from Granity and Hokitika in the South Island). These authors note morphological differences between mainland and island populations.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy 2016) provisionally lists the following subspecies: Balaenoptera musculus musculus (Linnaeus, 1758) - Northern Blue Whale (found in the North Atlantic and the North Pacific); B. m. intermedia (Burmeister, 1871) - Antarctic Blue Whale; B. m. indica (Blyth 1859) - Northern Indian Ocean Blue Whale; B. m. brevicauda (Ichihara, 1966) - Pygmy Blue Whale; and B. m. un-named subspecies - Chilean Blue Whale.

The nominate subspecies B. m. musculus refers at least to the North Atlantic Blue Whale which was the basis for the first description of the species by Linnaeus. Animals in the North Pacific are similar in size and morphology to North Atlantic Blue Whales and are also regarded as B. m. musculus, pending a genetic comparison of these populations. The Antarctic form B. m. intermedia is distinguished by its large body size and Antarctic distribution in summer. The Pygmy Blue Whale B. m. brevicauda has a number of morphological characteristics that distinguish it from B. m. intermedia and B. m. musculus. It occurs in the Indian Ocean, excluding the Antarctic, from Africa and Madagascar across to Indonesia and Australia, and in the southwestern Pacific, including Tasmania and New Zealand. Blue Whales in the northern Indian Ocean have been tentatively assigned the name B. m. indica, but a clear distinction between B. m. indica and B. m. brevicauda has not yet been established.

Blue Whales in the southeastern Pacific are intermediate in size between B. m. intermedia and B. m. brevicauda (Branch et al. 2007a) and are genetically differentiated from both groups (LeDuc et al. 2017). They are provisionally designated as an unnamed subspecies with the common name Chilean Blue Whales. Chilean Blue Whales are genetically most similar to Blue Whales in the northeast Pacific (LeDuc et al. 2017); investigations into the genetic and morphological distinction between these two groups are ongoing. The respective winter ranges of Blue Whales from the eastern South Pacific (Chilean Blue whales) and from the eastern North Pacific may overlap in the eastern equatorial Pacific but their breeding seasons are probably six months out of phase (LeDuc et al. 2017).

The Arabian Tahr was removed from the Hemitragus genus and assigned the monotypic genus Arabitragus following research by Ropiquet and Hassanin (2005), which showed a weak genetic relationship with other Hemitragus species. The Arabian Tahr is most closely allied with the Ammotragus genus which has one living member, the Aoudad Ammotragus lervia. Ancestors of the Aoudad and Arabian Tahr are thought to have diverged around 4–7 Mya in North Africa and/or Arabia (Ropiquet and Hassanin 2005). This period coincides with the onset of Northern Hemisphere glaciations, and cooler, drier, and more variable climates (Peizhen et al. 2001).
Hydrornis gurneyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta gurneyi.

Mannophryne olmonae is not closely related to Mannophryne trinitatis (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011), as was previously thought (Murphy 1997). Chromosome banding pattern data clearly allow a distinction between M. olmonae and Trinidadian M. trinitatis (Kaiser et al. 2003). These two species are not sister taxa; the sister taxon of M. olmonae is Mannophryne riveroi from the Peninsula de Paria, Venezuela (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011).

authority: Mallik, Achyuthan, Ganesh, Pal, Vijayakumar & Shanker, 2019
Sunyer, Wake, Townsend, Travers, Rovito, Papenfuss, Obando & Köhler, 2010
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019

Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Ninox squamipila, N. hypogramma, N. hantu and N. forbesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. squamipila following Norman et al. (1998), and before then were also lumped with N. natalis as N. squamipila following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Formerly considered conspecific with N. squamipila (which see), but separable on morphological and plumage details, molecular differences and perhaps voice (Norman et al. 1998). Monotypic.

Athene jacquinoti, A. granti, A. malaitae and A. roseoaxillaris (HBW and BirdLife International 2024) were previously included within Ninox (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), prior to which all were considered conspecific with N. jacquinoti following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). They were moved to the present genus on the basis of molecular studies (Gwee et al. 2017, Salter et al. 2020). Differs from malaitae in its smaller size (allow 1); solidly orange-cinnamon underparts with only vague barring (3); buffy vs white eyebrows (2); cinnamon-rufous vs brown upperparts (2) (Dutson 2011). Mittermeier et al. (2018) confirmed the split. Monotypic.

This species was treated for a time as a subspecies of Hemiphyllodactylus typus until Bauer and Das (1999) showed it to be a distinct species. These authors' concept for H. aurantiacus it as a single, widespread species, which was subsequently shown to be a species complex and revised by Agarwal et al. (2019).
Hemidactylus satarensis was described based on specimens collected from Chalakewadi, Satara District, Maharashtra (Giri and Bauer 2008) .

This species was described based on two specimens from Yercaud. Recent surveys have revealed the presence of two additional species within the Shevaroys, partitioned along an elevational gradient, which had previously been understood to represent this species, and also additional populations atop nearby peaks (Kolli Hills, Pachamalai Hills) (Ganesh and Arumagam 2016, Agarwal et al. 2019).

Calotes aurantolabium was described by Krishnan in 2008 based on two female specimens collected from Kalakkad-Mundunthurai Tiger Reserve, Agasthyamalai Hills, Western Ghats, Tamil Nadu, India. Calotes andamanensis reported from mainland India by Ishwar and Das (1998) based on specimens collected from Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve are misidentified Calotes aurantolabium (Krishnan 2008). It was subsequently recognized as a distinct genus based on a distinct phylogenetic position by Pal et al. (2018).

This species was incorrectly synonymized with Schistometopum gregorii, and was resurrected by Wilkinson et al. (2004). Measey et al. (2012) assigned specimens from Ngaya forest-Nyambne Hills in Meru North to this species, which were included in its 2012 reassessment. However, these specimens were later described as Boulengerula spawlsi (Wilkinson et al. 2017).

Recent molecular studies (Geurgas et al., 2008) indicate that the taxonomic diversity within Coleodactylus is largely underestimated, resulting from ancient vicariant events started back in the late Cretaceous (64.2 - 75.2 mya). The genus includes a large number of cryptic species, and Coleodactylus natalensis is nested within a clade including undescribed species currently assigned to C. meridionalis. Further taxonomic studies are necessary for describing the real diversity within this genus. Despite the overall ancient nature of divergence within the genus, molecular data indicate a relatively recent (1.9 ± 1.3 mya) divergence between C. natalensis and undescribed species allocated to C. meridionalis.

authority: Verrastro, Veronese, Bujes & Martins Dias Filho, 2003

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Dendropsophus tritaeniatus (Jansen et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Isthmura belli, of which it was previously considered a subspecies (Rovito et al. 2015).

Two allopatric subspecies of Mountain Zebra have traditionally been recognized, the nominate race Equus zebra zebra (Cape Mountain Zebra) and E. z. hartmannae (Hartmann's Mountain Zebra). Groves and Ryder (2000) proposed that the two be treated as distinct species, and Groves and Bell (2004) presented morphological evidence for separating the two subspecies as distinct species based on the diagnosability criterion of the phylogenetic species concept. Recent genetic analyses indicate that the two populations have a high incidence of mitochondrial haplotype sharing; the hypothesis that Cape and Hartmann's Mountain Zebra mitochondrial lineages were reciprocally monophyletic was not supported (Moodley and Hartley 2005). However, the presence of private alleles at nuclear loci rendered the two subspecies genetically distinct evolutionary significant units. We continue to recognize Mountain Zebra as a single species comprising two subspecies.
This species was on the 2000 IUCN Red List as Isothrix picta (DD). The Rodent Specialist Group note that Echimys pictus is the correct name. Now listed by IUCN as Callistomys pictus.

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Megastomatohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Although Physeter catodon is still occasionally used in the literature, P. macrocephalus is recommended (Rice 1989). Both names are listed on the same page of the original description by Linnaeus (1758), and priority is unclear. However, P. macrocephalus is preferable because it is used much more frequently, and this will support nomenclatural stability.
The taxonomic validity of this species is not clear (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).

Based on allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the most distinct species of Mexican ambystomatids. It was previously thought to be a species complex, however, this was resolved by Weisrock et al. (2006) and this is not the case.

This species was treated in previous Red List assessments (1988 to 30 June 2008) under the genus Cercopithecus, but is now placed under Allochrocebus following Butynski (2013). Along with A. solatus and A. lhoesti, it forms part of the Allochrocebus preussi geospecies (Grubb 2006). There are two subspecies, C. preussi preussi and C. p. insularis, following Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994; Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Rahm (1970) placed all the 14 red colobus that he recognised as subspecies of Colobus badius. Napier (1985) did likewise except for Colobus kirkii, considered as a distinct species. Groves (2007) treated most of the geographically separated populations of red colobus monkeys (variously regarded by different authors as subspecies or species) as distinct species, but he made an exception for the forms badius and temminckii in West Africa, treating them as subspecies of Piliocolobus badius on the grounds that they show a gradual transition in pelage colour from north to south. Oates (2011) followed Groves’s treatment in this case. While Groves and Ting (2013) treated P. badius and P. temminckii as separate species, here we follow Groves (2007) and Oates (2011) in regarding badius and temminckii as subspecies of P. badius.
Crax fasciolata and C. pinna (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as Crax fasciolata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Described by Fischer (1804), this species was treated as a junior synonym of either Tarsius spectrum or T. tarsier until it was resurrected by Groves and Shekelle (2010).

The taxonomy of this genus has been discussed over a long period by a number of authors, as there has been a degree of confusion and disagreement among scientists. Descriptions, range maps and assessment of conservation status in the literature vary because sources differ on nomenclature and specific/sub-specific status of the various taxa. This re-assessment follows the taxonomy of Mori et al. (2019) which recently and firstly used the total mitochondrial genome of all taxa and confirmed the existence of four species of Capricornis as follows:

  • Capricornis crispus - Japanese Serow (restricted to Japan);
  • Capricornis rubidus - Red Serow (restricted to Myanmar and southwest China);
  • Capricornis sumatraensis - Mainland Serow, including the Sumatran Serow (C. s. sumatraensis; restricted to Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand); Chinese Serow (C. s. mildneedwardsii; restricted to China and southeast Asia countries); and Himalayan Serow (C. s. thar; restricted to the Himalayan range);
  • Capricornis swinhoei - Formosan Serow (restricted to Taiwan).

Chilabothrus schwartzi is a recently elevated boa species (Reynolds et al. 2018). The species was originally described as Epicrates chryogaster schwartzi by Donald W. Buden in 1975 based on four type specimens collected by locals on Crooked and Acklins islands. Individuals were not recorded again in the literature (and no additional specimens were secured) until Reynolds et al. (2018) recorded four individuals on Crooked Island in 2017. Subsequent analyses of DNA, morphology, and comparison to the types by Reynolds et al. (2018) provided support for the elevation of the lineage to the specific level within the West Indian endemic genus Chilabothrus on the basis of diagnostic and divergent morphological and genetic characters.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This taxon was previously included in Nycticebus menagensis, but was described as a separate species by Munds et al. (2013). The species description was based on facemask variation between existing sample photographs and museum specimens formerly described as N. menagensis.

This taxon was considered to be Nycticebus menagensis, but was described as a new species by Munds et al. (2013). The species description was based on facemask variation between existing sample photographs and museum specimens previously believed to be N. menagensis. Nycticebus bancanus is characterized by a deep chestnut coloured facemask and a diffuse-edged upper circumocular patch. The lower part of the circumocular patch never extends below the zygomatic arch, it has a wide interocular stripe, the crown patch is also diffused, the ears are hairy, and the preauricular hair band is narrow. The species is also characterized by a distinct crimson red dorsal pelage (Munds et al. 2013).

When assessing this species in 1937, Sody, on the basis of 146 specimens, wrote the darkness of the ventral side was sufficient reason therein to accept Lyon’s race bancanus. He also pointed out that the temporal ridges do not meet in adults and that the Banka animals never possess four upper incisors, placing them closer Bornean species than to those from Sumatra.

This taxon was previously included in Nycticebus menagensis, but was described as a separate species by Munds et al. (2013). The species description was based on facemask variation between sampled photographs and museum specimens previously classed as N. menagensis.

Described as a distinct subspecies in 1902, this taxon was later grouped with Nytcicebus coucang. Lydekker (1904) described this much redder and larger form as having a brightly rufescent chestnut colour slightly washed with grey, with a dorsal stripe and crown-patch being a deeper rufous, faintly bordered with brown. When working with lorises confiscated in trade originating from Sumatra, Nekaris and Jaffe (2007) were struck by two forms in a sample of 25 individuals. Nine individuals possessed the characteristics described by Stone and Rehn (1902), and were so statistically distinct, that Nekaris and Jaffe suggested that they be elevated to a species, N. hilleri. They reported the following average morphometric parameters for N. hilleri that were larger than those of N. coucang: weight: 689 g; head length 61 mm; muzzle length 21 mm; head breath 39 mm; head body length 278 mm; hand span 51 mm; foot span 68 mm; ear length 18 mm (Nekaris and Jaffe 2007).

authority: Frasier, Lei, McLain, Taylor, Bailey, Ginter, Nash, Randriamampionona, Groves, Mittermeier & Louis Jr., 2016
taxonomicNotes: Described in 2016, Cheirogaleus shethi was previously thought to be a population of C. medius. However, Frasier et al. (2016) showed that this species is in fact genetically distinct to all other Cheirogaleus species. There are also significant morphological differences between C. shethi and C. medius (Frasier et al. 2016).

authority: Lei, McLain, Frasier, Taylor, Bailey, Engberg, Ginter, Nash, Randriamampionona, Groves,  Mittermeier & Louis Jr, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Thiele et al. (2013) identified a Cheirogaleus lineage from Montagne d’Ambre that grouped closely with individuals spanning a large range throughout the north and east of Madagascar. Although genetically distinct, this subgroup was retained within C. crossleyi pending more data. An expanded dataset permitted the description of C. andysabini from Montagne d’Ambre by Lei et al. (2015) who showed that this species is genetically distinct from other species within the C. crossleyi group. There are also significant differences in pelage between C. andysabini and C. crossleyi (Lei et al. 2015).

This species was previously described as Cheirogaleus crossleyi-like by Hapke et al. (2005), but later named as C. lavasoensis by Thiele et al. (2013). It is geographically restricted to very small forest fragments on the southern slopes of the three main part of the Lavasoa mountains: Grand Lavasoa, Petit Lavasoa and Ambatotsirongorongo. Most recently Lei et al. (2014) extended the northern range of this species to the Kalambatritra (Sahalava) forest (dwarf lemurs previously assigned to the species C. crossleyi).
First described in 2013, initially considered as Microcebus murinus.

A full account of the taxonomic history of is provided by Groves (2000). After various reassignments, the species had been described as Opolemur thomasi by Forsyth Major. It was then assigned to Cheirogaleus adipicaudatus by Groves (2000). In 2014 Cheirogaleus thomasi was resurrected (Lei et al. 2014).

authority: Hotaling, Foley, Lawrence, Bocanegra, Blanco, Rasoloarison, Kappeler, Barrett, Yoder & Weisrock, 2016
taxonomicNotes: The species has been assigned to Microcebus murinus but has separated from M. murinus and described as a distinct species in 2016 (Hotaling et al. 2016).

authority: Hotaling, Foley, Lawrence, Bocanegra, Blanco, Rasoloarison, Kappeler, Barrett, Yoder & Weisrock, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Microcebys manitatra includes a subpopulation of mouse lemurs, formerly referred to as M. murinus from the southeastern region of Madagascar that is disjunct from the broader range of M. murinus across western and southern Madagascar. It is also distinct from the nearby mouse lemur subpopulation of Bemanasy. This species forms a monophyletic group in the mtDNA gene tree, is assigned to a distinct nuclear cluster in population structure analyses and is strongly supported with coalescent-based Bayesian species delimitation tests (Hotaling et al. 2016). This recent description confirmed previous comprehensive surveys of mtDNA of M. murinus across the southeastern region that revealed divergent geographic clades in close geographical proximity with no evidence of haplotype sharing (Weisrock et al. 2010, Hapke et al. 2012).This species is named for the Malagasy ‘manitatra’ meaning ‘range expansion’ to reflect the divergent distribution of this mouse lemur from the primarily western distribution of M. murinus.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
See Chambers et al. (2012) for a brief review of recent literature concerning the status of this species, which they considered a full species, as does this assessment.

The relationship between P. interscapularis and P. sogdianus is unclear. The latter taxon has been listed both as a subspecies of P. interscapularis (Milto and Barabanov 2012) and as a full species (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008, Melville et al. 2009) in recent literature. Solovyeva et al. (2014) found "only insignificant" genetic differentiation between the two taxa and suggested that the status of P. sogdianus, which they retained as a full species, warrants further investigation.

authority: Lourenço-de-Moraes, Dias, Mira-Mendes, Oliveira, Barth, Ruas, Vences, Solé & Bastos, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Molecular phylogenetic studies confirmed the monophyly of the genus Adelophryne and revealed three main clades located in northern Amazonia, northern and southern Atlantic Forest (Fouquet et al. 2012). A. michelin is phylogenetically related to species from the northern clade of the North Atlantic Forest (Lourenço-de-Moraes et al. 2018). In Bahia, A. michelin occurs in sympatry and syntopy with A. mucronata and Adelophryne sp. 2 (species not yet described for the genus), species from which it is morphologically distinguished (Lourenço-de-Moraes et al. 2018).

Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), seven species were recognised under this concept. The distribution of D. brevipollicatus was then restricted and D. lauroi and D. imitator were revalidated, and four new species were described; D. haddadi, D. izecksohni, D. jureia and D. davori.
Following a taxonomic revision of Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus by Cruz et al. (2019), this species has been revalidated.

authority: Mângia, Koroiva, Nunes, Roberto, Ávila, Sant’Anna, Santana & Garda, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Confused with Proceratophrys cristiceps prior to its naming according to Mângia et al. (2018).

authority: Senevirathne, Samarawickrama, Wijayathilaka, Manamendra-Arachchi, Bowatte, Samarawickrama, & Meegaskumbura, 2018

taxonomicNotes: It is doubtful that the current taxonomy provides a true picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterized 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially follows the revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms.

Lutra sumatrana was first described by Raffles in 1822 as Lutra barang; by Gray in 1865 as Barangia sumatrana; and Lutra lovii by Gunther 1876. Pohle (1919) identified three species L. sumatrana in Sumatra, Malay Penisula and Thailand, L. lovii and L. brunnea in Borneo. Pocock 1941 compiled three species to L. sumatrana including in Vietnam. Recent genetic studies have confirmed it as a single species related to Lutra lutra (Koepfli et al. 2008).

The species was named as Lutra perspicillata by Geoffroy 1826 and as Lutrogale perspicillata by Gray 1865. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) L. p. perspicillata - in northeast and southern India, Myanmar and Sumatra; and (2) L. p. sindica - in north and northwestern India and Pakistan. Another subspecies L. p. maxwelli, whose current status is uncertain, is reported from the marshes of southern Iraq (Mason and Macdonald 1986).

The spelling of the species epithet as 'cinerea' was incorrect; the genus name 'Aonyx' is masculine and hence the adjectival species name should be 'cinereas'. The species is now correctly named as A. cinereus (Illiger, 1815).

The species has also been referred to as Amblonyx cinereus (Illiger, 1815), Amblonyx concolor Rafinesque, 1832 and Amblonyx cinerea Pocock 1941.

Two subspecies have been reported (Pocock 1941):
(1) A. c. concolor in northeast India, Myanmar extending to Sumatra, and
(2) A. c. nirnai in the hill ranges of southern India (Hussain et al. 2011).

There are no recognized subspecies of Sylvilagus robustus (Hall 1981). Sylvilagus robustus was formerly considered a subspecies of S. floridanus, but has been shown to be an independent species (Ruedas 1998, Lee, Pfau and Ammerman 2010, Ruedas and Dowler 2018).

No subspecies. Only three specimens definitively identified as Sylvilagus tapetillus exist. The Rio de Janeiro Dwarf Cottontail was originally described as an independent species, and later subsumed as a subspecies of the Tapetí (S. brasiliensis). Recently, on the basis of a comprehensive morphological evaluation, cytochrome-B data, and karyotypic attributes, it was classified as independent and removed from synonymy from brasiliensis (Bonvicino et al. 2015, Ruedas et al. 2017).
There are no recognized subspecies of Sylvilagus cognatus, which was formerly included as a subspecies of S. floridanus (Hall 1981).

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: No notable taxonomical issues.
This taxon has been moved to the genus Paradactylodon (Zhang et al. 2006).
Taxonomic research is ongoing to determine whether all subpopulations are conspecific (Rajkumar K.P. pers comm. October 2020).

There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004). We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois et al. (2021), who moved this species to the genus Blaira, on the basis that it was only published as Ghatophryne in an electronic-only journal prior to 2012. This assessment retains it in Ghatophryne, as it is the name registered with ZooBank.
Many museum specimens assigned to Bufo beddomii are misidentifications (Biju 2001).
Records from Kerala are misidentifications (Dinesh et al. 2009).
This species has been moved from the genus Xanthophryne to Beduka by Dubois et al. (2021).

Biological subpopulations from Ngengpui Wildlife Sanctuary, Dampa Tiger Reserve and Tura in the Garo Hills of Meghalaya previously reported under this nominal form are now considered to be an undescribed species (Deuti et al. 2012). They have not been included in the assessment of this restricted range species to avoid over estimating its range.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Several species might be currently confused under this name. Specimens collected in the northern part of its range have been found to belong to Fejervarya pierrei Dubois, 1975 (Biju 2001).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the reallocation of syntypes, previously assigned to this species, to Indirana sarojamma (Dahanukar et al. 2016). Records from Maharashtra have been re-assigned to Indirana chiravasi (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus elegans, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.
Some records attributed to this species might not belong to it (India Red List Assessment Workshop 2004).

The original description of this species, as Nyctibatrachus hussaini (Krishnamurthy et al. 2001), did not provide any information about the type specimen. Hence, its taxonomy and nomenclature required further investigation and amendments (Biju 2001, Das and Kunte 2005, S.K. Dutta pers. comm.). Dinesh et al. (2007) provided the replacement name Nyctibatrachus karnatakaensis.
This species was designated a lectotype and its range redelimited by Biju et al. (2011).
Biju et al. (2011) has revised the taxonomy of this species and designated a lectotype.
The holotype of this species is lost, hence Biju et al. (2011) designated a specimen collected in 2007 at Kempholey, Hassan district, Karnataka State as a neotype.

Research into the species validity needs to be prioritised. The key recommended conservation measures include taxonomic research on the generic allocation of this taxon (Das 1998, Chandramouli 2017, Harikrishnan and Vasudevan 2018).
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).

Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, subsequent studies indicate that both species are distinct (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021).
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.
While considered a taxonomically valid species its relationship with Philautus garo needs to be investigated (K. Deuti and M. F. Ahmed pers comm. October 2020).

Garg et al. (2021) compared the two known specimens of Raorchestes thodai morphologically with this species and found there was no clear distinction between the two taxa. In addition despite further surveys over the previous decade, no further specimens of Raorchestes thodai have been collected and no observations of individuals, which further supports the likelihood that Raorchestes thodai is a junior synonym of this species (Garg et al. 2021).

Raorchestes punctatus and R. melanensis (collected by Rao in Karnataka) are considered to be synonyms of this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001), but further studies are required to confirm this relationship (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This taxon was transfered to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).
Transferred from Kaloula to Uperodon (Portik et al. 2023).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Giri, Roelants, Nagaraju & Bossuyt, 2007

taxonomicNotes:
The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. In 2008 it was assessed. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is still some taxonomic uncertainty regards this species, and in particular the range limits need to be determined (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. 2020).

authority: Sengupta, Hussain, Choudhury, Gogoi, Ahmed & Choudhury, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Assignment to Amolops based on association of topotypic larvae that were not grown to adulthood; the generic assignment is therefore provisional (Frost 2020). Molecular analyses are expected to show that some specimens assigned to this species may belong to a different taxa, although this has not been confirmed (S. Jayaditya pers. comm. September 2020).
This species has undergone a name change from Xanthophryne tigerinus, which was deemed invalid as it was published in an electronic journal only prior to 2012 (Dubois et al. 2021).

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys parva (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys boettgeri (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Nyctibatrachus beddomii by Biju et al. (2007).

authority: Khatiwada, Wang, Ghimire, Vasudevan, Paudel, & Jiang, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Minervarya rufescens (as Fejervarya rufescens) by Garg and Biju (2017).
This species was recently removed from the synonymy of Kaloula baleata (Chandramouli and Prasad 2018).
This species could be a synonym of Allopaa hazarensis (India Red List Assessment September 2020).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. 

Micrixalus narainensis and M. swamianus have been synonymised with this species by Biju et al. (2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Nyctibatrachus anamallaiensis which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Biju et al. 2007).
This species was designated a lectotype, its range redelimited, and Nyctibatrachus sholai was synonymized within it by Biju et al. (2011).

authority: Dung, Giao, Chinh, Touc, Arctander & MacKinnon, 1993
taxonomicNotes: This species is in a highly distinctive monotypic genus with uncertain affinities within the Bovidae (Gatesy and Arctander 2000, R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2006).

Temminck originally described the African Wild Dog (hereafter Wild Dog) in 1820 from a specimen collected in coastal Mozambique, which was originally thought to be species of hyaena and was classified as Hyena picta (Creel & Creel 2002). Later, in 1930, it was placed in the subfamily Canidae (Creel & Creel 2002) and today, Wild Dogs belong to the family Canidae. DNA sequencing suggests that Wild Dogs are phylogenetically distinct from other wolf-like canids (such as wolves and jackals) (Creel & Creel 2002). Thus, they are considered to be a monotypic genus where they are the only remaining representatives of the genus Lycaon (Mills et al 1998; Creel & Creel 2002).
Generic synonym = Capromys.

This species was initially classified in the genus Bradypus, as it was thought that it was related to South American sloths, due to the absence of the two first upper incisors. Debate persists as to whether this species should be in the mono-specific genus Melursus, or in Ursus (Pagès et al. 2008, Krause et al. 2008, Kitchener 2010).

Two subspecies have been recognized. There is some evidence that they are distinct genetic clades (Fain et al. 1994). Melursus ursinus inornatus only occurs on the island of Sri Lanka and is physically smaller with shorter and sparser hair than its mainland (M. u. ursinus) counterpart.

The principal colour phase is black, with a white or cream/yellow crescent on the chest. Rusty brown phases are also known. The species is often confused with the Asiatic Black Bear (Ursus thibetanus), due to similar appearance.

authority: Ojala-Barbour, Pinto, Brito M., Albuja V., Lee Jr. & Patterson, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Rousettus obliviosus was previously considered to be a subspecies of R. madagascariensis (e.g., Peterson et al. 1995), but the two forms have been shown to be distinct species (Kock 1978, Goodman et al. 2010a).

Seven subspecies have been recognized, many of which have been corroborated as distinct genetic clades (Kim et al. 2011, Yusefi 2013, Wu et al. 2015).

This species was previously included in the genus Selenarctos (meaning moon bear). The principal colour phase is black, with a white or cream/yellow “crescent moon” on the chest. Rare brown phases are also known, and a rare blond colour phase was discovered in Cambodia, Thailand, and Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Galbreath et al. 2000). One case of a wild Asiatic Black Bear–Sun Bear (Helarctos malayanus) hybrid has been reported in Cambodia (Galbreath et al. 2008).

authority: Fan, He, Chen, Ortiz, Zhang, Zhao, Lio, Zhang, Kimock, Wang, Groves, Turvey, Roos, Helgen & Jiang, 2017
