taxonomicNotes: This taxon is monotypic; it was formerly considered a population of H. leuconedys. The previous generic name, Bunopithecus, was changed by Mootnick and Groves (2005) to Hoolock (Haimoff  1984).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus tholloni was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Grubb et al. (2013) and Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), on the other hand, considered it a subspecies of P. rufomitratus. Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Groves and Ting (2013). Kingdon (2015) treated tholloni as a distinct species.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Colyn (1991) and Groves (2007) suggested that oustaleti is one of between three (Groves 2007) and five (Colyn 1991) forms contributing to what is commonly regarded as a hybrid population of red colobus that occurs immediately to the south of the range of P. oustaleti and extends to the southern forest – savanna ecotone in eastern DRC, at about 4°S. Groves (2007) referred this intergraded taxon as “ellioti”.

As its synonyms indicate, this population of red colobus monkeys has been classified under a number of different names, sometimes regarded as a species, a subspecies, or just as a local population of a subspecies. In the last edition of the Red List, it was treated as a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, which included the subspecies rufomitratus, semlikiensis, foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) continue to place it as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai. langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni.

Kingdon (1997), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Kingdon (2015) maintained the same classification, expect that he placed semilikiensis as a synonym of ellioti.

Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) regarded P. oustaleti as a complex of six forms, three west of the Ubangui (P. oustaleti sensu stricto with synonyms umbrinus Matschie, and nigrimanus Trouessart, and an undescribed form from the vicinity of the Lobaye River, a tributary of the lower Ubangui, Central African Republic) and three to the east (shubotzi Matschie, powelli Matschie, and brunneus Lönnberg with synonym multicolor Lorenz). Piliocolobus oustaleti is known to be highly variable in coat colour (Colyn 1993, Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). Ting (2008) found considerable mitochondrial genetic diversity among populations included within P. oustaleti sensu lato and suggested that either oustaleti might consist of numerous taxa, or that there have been past introgressions of mitochondrial lineages between neighbouring forms.

Grubb et al. (2003) considered oustaleti as a subspecies but did not assign it to species. Its synonyms included brunneus Lönnberg, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, and schubotzi Matschie. 

Groves (2007) treated oustaleti as a monotypic species, but with four “types”: 1) a dark brown type (oustaleti, powelli and, most extreme, umbrinus and schubotzi); 2) a raw sienna type in the Ubangui/Lobaye basins in the Central African Republic (unnamed and possibly the unnamed form mentioned by Gautier-Hion et al. 1999); 3) a brownish-fawn type from the Uele gallery forest region in DRC (brunneus) in the east; and 4) a red type (nigrimanus in the west. Groves (2001) placed oustaleti as a subspecies of foai, but also mentioning the four types as described in his 2007 revision.

For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating this evidently diverse taxon as a single taxonomic entity. However, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form remains fluid (Struhsaker 2010).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Grubb et al. (2003) and Kingdon (2015) treated rufomitratus as a monotypic species. Considering vocalisations and pelage colour patterns, however, Grubb et al. (2013) noted that tephrosceles, ellioti (semlikiensis a synonym), oustaleti, langi, lulindicus, foai, parmentieri and tholloni were similar, if isolated, forms, and placed them all as subspecies of rufomitratus. Excepting lulindicus (a synonym of foai) and ellioti (possibly a three-way hybrid swarm), Groves (2007) treated all, including semlikiensis, as species.
This new species is a member of the Hipposideros bicolor group.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus parmentieri is little known, and its classification is inconsistent due to the significant complexity and debate in the taxonomy of red colobus monkeys (Groves 2001, Grubb et al. 2003, Struhsaker 2010, Grubb et al. 2013). Colyn and Verheyen (1987) noted that parmentieri differed strongly from tholloni and placed it as a subspecies of the polytypic rufomitratus. Colyn (1991) considered the Lomami Red Colobus to have a stable phenotype, supporting a distinct taxonomic status for the population. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) treated it as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic]. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) on the other hand identified it as one of nine subspecies of rufomitratus: foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles, lulindicus, ellioti (semlikiensis a synonym), and tholloni. Groves and Ting (2013) elevated seven of the nine rufomitratus subspecies to distinct species; the subspecies ellioti and lulindicus were not recognised as distinct taxa. Kingdon (2015) treated it as a subspecies of oustaleti, along with foai, langi, lulindicus, elliotiand tephrosceles. Groves (2001, 2005) treated it as a subspecies of foai, along with ellioti, oustaleti, and semlikiensis, but in his 2007 review of the taxonomy of the African colobines he classified it as a separate species. The current assessment follows Groves (2007) in recognising parmentieri as a distinct species.

Gautier-Hion et al. (1999), Groves (2001, 2005) and Kingdon (2015) altered the epithet to the plural—parmentierorum, but Groves (2007) argued that it was possible (and more expedient) to maintain parmentieri.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Red Colobus).

The taxonomy of this form is complicated and not fully resolved. Piliocolobus langi was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Kingdon (2015) considered it to be subspecific to Piliocolobus oustaleti. Colyn (1991) suggested that P. langi and P. semlikiensis (which he referred to as a subspecies of Colobus badius) of the eastern Congo Basin were major contributors to a population of polymorphic red colobus that he characterised as a large zone of intergradation between the ranges of the two taxa. Groves (2007) recognised langi and semlikiensis as valid species, and assigned the name “ellioti” to what he referred to as a three-way hybrid swarm between semlikiensis, langi and oustaleti, bound in the north by the Aruwimi River (with populations of P. oustaleti ranging north of that) and to the west by P. langi and east by P. semlikiensis, without apparent barriers to dispersal separating them. Genetic surveys to determine the origins and composition of red colobus populations over this zone of intergradation, and their relation to the proposed parental forms, have not been conducted. Based on mitochondrial DNA analysis, Ting (2008) suggested that, P. langi should be considered a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, along with (among others) the forms tholloni, oustaleti, parmentieri, foai and ellioti (which he treated as the senior synonym for semlikiensis). This classification is also largely accepted by Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), who stated that P[rocolobus]. r[ufomitratus]. ellioti “probably represents a large hybrid swarm involving langi and semlikiensis”. While we use Groves’ (2007) nomenclature here, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form is not well settled.

While Grubb et al. (2003) did not list any subspecies of Lophocebus albigena, Groves (2001, 2005), building on his earlier work (Groves 1978) recognized three subspecies: L. a. albigena, L. a. johnstoni and L. a. osmani. After further studies of the cranial morphology of this group, Groves (2007) upgraded these three subspecies to species rank, and recognised a fourth, Lophocebus ugandae (Matschie 1912). This classification is followed by Mittermeier et al. (2013). However, at a Red List assessment workshop in 2016, experts from the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group were not in agreement about a four-species taxonomy and decided to retain a one-species, four-subspecies arrangement for the purposes of the current Red List.
Grubb et al. (2003) recognized two subspecies, L. a. aterrimus and L. a. opdenboschi, in contrast to Groves (2001, 2005) who considered the two as worthy of recognition as distinct species.

authority: Lavrenchenko, W. Verheyen, E. Verheyen, Hulseman & Leirs, 2007
taxonomicNotes: Lophuromys chercherensis forms part of the L. flavopunctatus species complex (Lavrenchenko et al. 2007). Data show that L. chercherensis is differentiated from all known and newly recognised taxa of Ethiopian L. flavopunctatus (Lavrenchenko et al. 2004, Lavrenchenko et al. 2007).

Cercopithecus hamlyni, along with the recently discovered Lesula (Cercopithecus lomamiensis), form a clade of highly terrestrial monkeys restricted to lowland and montane forests of eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Outside DRC, only one small isolated population of C. hamlyni is known from western Rwanda (Easton et al. 2011). Two subspecies have been named (see Grubb et al. 2003, Groves 2005, Hart et al. 2013): C. h. kahuziensis, characterized primarily by its lack of a prominent white nose stripe, is described from an area of the bamboo forest zone of Mount Kahuzi, DRC. C. h. hamlyni, is the form found throughout the remainder of the species' range. The range of C. h. kahuziensis, purportedly limited to a very small area between 2000 and 3000 m in Kahuzi-Biega National Park, is poorly defined and adjoins, without evident barriers, the range of the nominate form (Maruhashi et al. 1989). Recent surveys in Kahuzi-Biega identified C. h. hamlyni, with prominent white nose stripes, in areas reported to represent the range of C. h. kahuziensis (Hart and Kaleme, personal observation 2002). In addition, the nose stripe appears to be variably present in populations across the species’ range (Hart et al. 2013). The recent publication (Hart et al. 2012) of a photo of a young animal, kept as a pet, and collected east of Kisangani, about 350 km from the reported range of of C. h. kahuziensis, had no evidence of a nose stripe and resembles photographed animals described as C. h. kahuziensis in the publication of the taxon by Colyn and Rahm (1987). The subspecies, C. h. kahuziensis, is not treated further here, pending confirmation of its taxonomic status.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was long regarded as a subspecies of the Western Red Colobus P. badius, along with temminckii (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Grubb et al. 2003; see Oates and Ting 2015). Dandelot (1971) and Groves (2007) treated waldroni as a full species and, although Ting (2008a) continued to treat it as subspecies of badius, in his thesis Ting (2008b) indicated that it should be a species (see Oates and Ting 2015).

Groves (2007) used the name waldronae for this monkey; however, Brandon-Jones et al. (2007) argued that waldroni is the correct epithet, as it was first named.
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms (including the Comoran C. b. ater and C. b. mohelicus – F. Glaw pers. comm. June 2011) suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Although considered a subspecies of badius by Rahm (1970) and of pennantii by Delson et al. (1982), all recent taxonomic appraisals have treated the Zanzibar Red Colobus as a monotypic species (Dandelot 1971, Napier 1985, Oates 1986, Kingdon 1997, 2015; Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Grubb et al. 2013), Groves and Ting (2013), and Siex and Struhsaker (2013).
It is likely that this form consists of two separate species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
Listed as a separate species from Colobus polykomos following Oates and Trocco (1983) and Groves (2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Pternohyla which was synonymized with Smilisca (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla thorectes (Grünwald et al. 2019).

A single subadult specimen (FMNH 64646) from the northeastern slopes of the Cordillera de Montecillos, Depto. Comayagua, was tentatively assigned to Bolitoglossa celaque sensu lato by McCranie and Wilson (2002), and, based on the presumed provenance of the specimen (ca 25 km NNE of the nearest locality for B. copinhorum), this specimen is tentatively referred to as B. copinhorum (Itgen et al. 2019).

The genus Oryctolagus appeared in the fossil record (Middle Pliocene) before any other modern leporid genus. Oryctolgus cuniculus was widespread across much of the Mediterranean area and central Europe in the Late Pleistocene, but following the maximum glacial period and Early Holocene it became confined to its current range in the Iberian Peninsula and adjoining areas in France (López-Martínez 2008).

Two subspecies are recognized: O. c. cuniculus and O. c. algirus. The latter is only present in the Iberian Peninsula and some islands, while the former occurs in most of the species’ introduced range. Based on genetic evidence they have apparently evolved independently beginning approximately 2 mya during the Quaternary glaciations (Ferrand 2008). The independence of these two subspecies has been reinforced by data on parasitology, behaviour, reproduction, and morphology (e.g. Gonçalves et al. 2002, Ferreira et al. 2015). Due to their genetic incompatibilities and reproductive isolation in their zone of contact in the middle of the Iberian Peninsula (e.g. Carneiro et al. 2010), some feel that they should be considered separate species (Delibes-Mateos et al. 2018). The domesticated rabbit originates from O. c. cuniculus.

authority: Shekelle, Groves, Maryanto, Mittermeier, Salim & Springer, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Acrocephalus caffer, A. musae and A. longirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caffer following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011; Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Kingdon (1997, 2015), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Grubb et al. (2003) considered tephrosceles be a subspecies but did not assign it to a species. Considering vocalizations and pelage colour patterns, Grubb et al. (2013) placed tephrosceles as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai, langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, oustaleti and tholloni.

Groves (2007) treated tephrosceles as a monotypic species, with gudoviusi Matschie as a junior synonym. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating tephrosceles as a monotypic species.
Acrocephalus rimitarae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as A. rimatarae. See A. vaughani. Monotypic.

Previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) placed in the genus Alopecoenas and before that in the genus Gallicolumba but transferred to Pampusana on the grounds of the latter’s priority (Bruce et al. 2016). Closely related to P. jobiensis, P. xanthonura and P. erythroptera; this group also has somewhat more distant affinities with P. sanctaecrucis, P. stairi and P. salamonis. Formerly considered a subspecies of P. xanthonura. Monotypic.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The taxonomy of this species remains confused and its identity is unclear (S.P. Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Specimens from the state of Espirito Santo have been reassigned to Hypsiboas pombali by Weber (2009).
This is a restricted concept of Thoropa lutzi following the split of T. bryomantis by de Assis et al. (2021).

This species has taxonomic problems. It was previously confused with Melanophryniscus tumifrons prior to its description by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002). Subpopulations from Misiones, Argentina, formerly associated with this species (and included in its 2004 assessment) were believed by Baldo and Basso (2004) to pertain to Melanophryniscus aff. tumifrons and were excluded from the 2010 assessment. However, a study not yet submitted found strong evidence that this species needs to be synonymised with M. tumifrons (P. Colombo pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomedusa fimbriata by Cruz (1985).
This is a reduced concept of Phrynomedusa marginata as many individuals previously assigned to this species have now been assigned to the newly described species P. dryade (Baêta et al. 2016).
This species was removed from synonymy (as a subspecies) of Scinax catharinae by Peixoto (1988).
This species belongs to the Scinax ruber group of Pombal et al. (1995).

In the Scinax catharinae group of Faivovich et al. (2005). Many species in this group - including this one - require further taxonomic work to clarify the identity of certain records and the boundaries of their distributions.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus orophilus, according to the original description.

Records from the Serra da Jibóia, municipality of Amargosa, Bahia State over 500 km to the southwest have been proposed as belonging to this species (V.G. Dill Orrico pers. comm. 2021). However, there are questions about the validity of these records owing to the distance from the type locality. They are excluded from this concept pending confirmation of their identity.

authority: Segalla, Berneck, Canedo, Caramaschi, Cruz, Garcia, Grant, Haddad, Lourenço, Mângia, Mott, Nascimento, Toledo, Werneck & Langone, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This concept previously bore the name Cycloramphus carvalhoi (Heyer 1983). Following the accidental confusion between Zachaenus carvalhoi and Cycloramphus carvalhoi due to changes made by Dubois et al. (2021), C. carvalhoi has been renamed as C. heyeri (Segalla et al. 2021).

Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Records from Paraná and São Paulo States could be another species instead of Cycloramphus izecksohni (Brazil Red List Assessment 2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Cycloramphus asper by Heyer (1983).

The 2004 assessment reported that this concept "might be a complex of more than one species." Since that time, the 2004 distribution, which extended from the state of Rio de Janeiro to the northeastern corner of the state of Santa Catarina has been revised and records reassigned to species in the Hylodes nasus and H. lateristrigatus groups. For example, inland Rio de Janeiro state records belong to H. lateristrigatus (de Sá et al. 2015); other coastal records from Rio de Janeiro and northeastern São Paulo states belong to H. asper (Canedo and Pombal-Jr. 2007); southeastern São Paulo and eastern Paraná states belong to H. cardosoi (Lingnau et al. 2008); records from Santa Catarina state belong to H. perplicatus (Lingnau et al. 2008).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Phyllodytes tuberculosus (Caramaschi and Peixoto 2004).
Brachycephalus alipioi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Pombal and Gasparini 2006).
Brachycephalus pombali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colour features (Alves et al. 2006).

A member of the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication. It can be differentiated from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Weber et al. 2006).
In the Scinax perpusillus group. Scinax peixotoi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and distinct advertisement call (Brasileiro et al. 2007).
In the Cycloramphus eleutherodactylus group. It can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Brasileiro et al. 2007).
In the Chiasmocleis leucosticta group according to the original publication. Chiasmocleis sapiranga is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).
In the Scinax perpusillus group according to the original publication. Scinax faivovichi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

In the Crossodactylus gaudichaudii group according to the original description. Crossodactylus cyclospinus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Nascimento et al. 2005).

authority: Boubli, Byrne, da Silva, Silva-Júnior, Costa Araújo, Bertuol, Gonçalves, de Melo, Rylands, Mittermeier, Silva, Nash, Canale, Alencar, Rossi, Carneiro, Sampaio, Farias, Schneider, & Hrbek, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Anumara forbesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Curaeus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

authority: Suwannapoom, Sumontha, Tunprasert, Ruangsuwan, Pawangkhanant, Korost & Poyarkov, 2018

taxonomicNotes: The subpopulation in the "South Island" of Haiti may likely comprise a new taxon, currently under study (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021). Therefore, the true distribution of Osteopilus vastus may exclude Haiti and the southern portion of the Dominican Republic. However, for the purposes of this assessment, this subpopulation is included in the current assessment until such time as it is formally described.
The subpopulations on the Tiburon Peninsula probably represent an undescribed species (R. Thomas pers. comm.).
This species can be distinguished from similar species by a combination of morphometrics, body colouration, advertisement call features and habitat association (Rios-López and Thomas 2007).

authority: Díaz, Incháustegui, Marte, Köhler, Cádiz & Rodríguez, 2018
taxonomicNotes: It is suspected that this taxon represents a species complex (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
Two of the subspecies of Peltophryne longinasus (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).
Two of the subspecies of Peltophryne longinasus (dunni and ramsdeni) have been elevated to species status (Hedges et al. 2019).

authority: Pham, Sung, Pham, Le, Ziegler & Nguyen, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species is similar to Proceratophrys cristiceps and P. goyana according to the original description.

In the Scinax ruber clade according to the original publication. Scinax cabralensis is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and a distinct advertisement call (Drummond et al. 2007).
No taxonomic issues.

This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla pentheter (Kaplan et al. 2020). Campbell et al. (2018:378) assigned the only known specimen (IBH 138072) of S. floresi from Estado de Mexico (then S. pentheter) to S. hapsa “based on distribution and morphology,” but did not report which characters they examined. Kaplan et al. (2020) found that this specimen has the diagnostic characters of S. floresi, and thus assign it to that species.

Pristimantis charlottevillensis differs from other Caribbean and South American members of the genus by its vocalizations, morphology, sexual size dimorphism, and chromosome complement. This is a presumed sister taxon to P. terraebolivaris (Kaiser et al. 1995).
Apalis porphyrolaema and A. kaboboensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. porphyrolaema following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Trichoglossus haematodus, T. forsteni, T. capistratus, T. weberi, T. rubritorquis, T. moluccanus and T. rosenbergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. haematodus following Christidis and Boles (1994), and before then were split as T. haematodus and T. rubritorquis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species was previously considered as belonging to an indeterminate subspecies of Bufo verrucosissimus (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Historical records in Iran assigned to Bufo bufo may also represent this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Iranian records are included in this assessment on the basis that their affinities are uncertain, but probably don't represent true Bufo bufo (Litvinchuk et al. 2008).
Pycnonotus bimaculatus and P. snouckaerti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. bimaculatus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Largen (2001) emended the name from Afrixalus clarkei to Afrixalus clarkeorum. However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.6, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2013).
Alophoixus bres, A. frater and A. tephrogenys (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. bres following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This is a split from the broader concept of Alcalus baluensis by Brown et al. (2015), who recognised this species as distinct and placed it in this genus (it was previously known as Ingerana baluensis - Inger and Tan 1996).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Allobates brunneus by Silverstone (1971).
Most of the recent publications have treated this as a species of Spinophrynoides (Gower et al. 2012).

authority: Serrano-Rojas, Whitworth, Villacampa-Ortega, von May, Gutiérrez, Padial & Chaparro, 2017

taxonomicNotes: A member of the Trachypithecus obscurus group, that also includes T. obscurus and T. barbei, a sister clade to the T. cristatus group (Roos et al., 2007). Groves (2001) grouped T. obscurus and T. phayrei, but he was unsure of the affiliation of T. barbei and placed it in the T. cristatus group, suspecting (p.266), however, that it should in fact be allied with T. obscurus. Roos et al. (2007, 2020) defined this group phylogenetically (mtDNA haplotypes), confirming Groves’ (2001) suspicion and including T. barbei as a sister species to phayrei. Napier (1985) and Groves (2001) placed crepusculus Elliot, 1909, and shanicus Wroughton, 1917, as subspecies of phayrei. Leidigk et al. (2009) and Roos et al. (2019, 2020), however, showed that crepusculus was in fact the earliest branch of the francoisi group. Roos et al. (2020) found that phayrei comprised three clades that diverged about 1 Mya: besides phayrei, shanicus, which they synonymized with melamera Elliot, and a third previously unnamed form that they called popa—each as full species.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
Geokichla interpres (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera interpres.

This species can only reliably be distinguished from Anodonthyla boulengerii with detailed morphological examination. It is therefore impossible to establish with certainty which historical records of A. boulengerii refer instead to this recently-diagnosed species (M. Vences pers. comm. December 2010).
Anodonthyla vallani was recognised as a distinct species by Vences et al. (2010), having previously been confused with A. nigrigularis.

Blossomcrown Anthocephala floriceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into Santa Marta Blossomcrown and Tolima Blossomcrown A. berlepschi following the finding of reciprocal monophyly between the two (Loranzo-Jaramillo et al. 2014), supported by subsequent assessment of morphological differences in museum specimens, albeit with a sample size of only three for floriceps. The authors merely refer to ‘morphological differences that led to their recognition as different subspecies’ without itemising what these differences are. Possibly this relates to the paucity of museum material of floriceps. In our own attempt to follow up the proposition that two species might be involved only three adult males of this form were found in eastern American and western European museums visited (vs 10 of berlepschi). Nevertheless, the results of this data-poor assessment are indicative. Always accepting that n=3 is far too small for genuine confidence, berlepschi differs by its white vs dull buff tail-tips (3); dull glossy bottle-green vs bronzy undertail (2); larger, whiter forehead (2); lack of rufous tinge to buff-grey belly (ns[2]); longer bill (20.5 vs 18.4 mm; at least 1). In this unsatisfactory case the combined evidence points more strongly towards species rank rather than subspecies rank for the form berlepschi, and this status is accepted here. Monotypic.
The species is found at high elevation and has a highly fragmented distribution. Potentially more than one species are under this name (IUCN Red Listing Tanzania Group pers. comm. July 2024).

This species was treated as belonging to Arthroleptis adolfifriederici prior to its formal description (Perret, 1966; Amiet, 1975). Confusion may also have occurred with A. variabilis (Blackburn et al. 2009).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. Given taxonomic uncertainties, individuals collected outside of the East Usambaras are not referrable to Arthroleptis xenodactylus (J. Poynton and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012), but to the more widespread species A. xenodactyloides or currently undescribed species.
Barkudia insularis was described by Annandale in 1917 based on a single specimen collected from Barkuda Island, Chilka Lake, Orissa (Smith 1935, Das 1999).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).
This species is part of the C. nasutum/fallax complex, and there are other populations which have not yet been assigned, and might yet be referable to vohibola (Gehring et  al. 2011)
We follow Jdeidi et al. (2001), Plötner and Ohst (2001) and Plötner et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Pelophylax bedriagae.
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Mertensiella lushchani. It has now been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This is a restricted concept of Tylototriton vietnamensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Tylototriton pasmansi (Bernades et al. 2020).

authority: Rosa, Crottini, Noel, Rabibisoa, Raxworthy & Andreone, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is some doubt as to the taxonomic assignment of the subpopulations from Yoro and Olancho Departments, based on differences in habitat and biogeographic patterns (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
In the Craugastor alfredi group. Craugastor cyanochthebius differs from all other species in the group by a combination of morphological characters (McCranie and Smith 2006).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Cryptobatrachus remotus (Infante-Rivero et al. 2009 "2008"), could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015, Meza Joya pers. comm. August 2016).

Subpopulations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).
The validity of this species has been questioned, but it is currently considered a good species (R. Jenkins pers. comm. June 2011, C. Raxworthy pers. comm. Jan 2011).

Records of this species from Ambohijanahary are attributable to Furcifer willsii (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). Records from Parc National Tsingy de Bemaraha may represent this taxon,. F. willsii, or an undescribed form; due to uncertainty about the correct assignment of these records the Bemaraha records are not included in the assessments for either F. petteri or F. wilsii.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species belong to the Gephyromantis asper group and was previously confused with Gephyromantis ambohitra (Frost 2015).

G. mukutense has been recently described and differs from all other species of the Gongylosoma genus in having a single, enlarged, posterior temporal; chinshields of equal size, and a thin nuchal band that contacts a vestigial vertebral stripe (Grismer et al. 2003).
Gymnobucco calvus and G. vernayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. calvus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus larinopygion (Coloma et al. 2012).
Acridotheres grandis and A. javanicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. grandis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
We follow Perret (1985) and Rödel et al. (2002) in considering this to be a species distinct from Kassina cochranae.
According to Amiet (2007), this species was removed from the synonymy of Kassina maculosa.
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax dringi (Matsui et al. 2014). This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachium abbotti (Hamidy and Matsui 2014).
This species was confused with Leptobrachium hasseltii prior to its naming (Brown et al. 2010 "2009")
Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here treated as a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)).
Crithagra concolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Neospiza following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Additional genetic comparisons are needed between specimens from Nosy Be and the mainland to determine the status of Lygodactylus madagascariensis petteri at Montagne d'Ambre, and some morphological differences between this subpopulation and that from Manongarivo have been reported (Glaw and Vences 2007, Puente et al. 2009).
Normally considered probably closest to A. melanopogon, although genetic data are contradictory on this point (Arbabi et al. 2014, Fregin et al. 2009). Monotypic.
Elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2009).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nothophryne baylissi, and N. ribauensis (Conradie et al. 2018).
Additional work differentiating this species from nearby populations of Ambystoma velasci is needed (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is a very distinctive salamander (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.). The Ambystoma salamanders occurring in other natural lakes around Alchichica are not closely related to this species.

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the more differentiated of the Mexican Ambystoma species; morphologically, it has evolved a superficially similar body plan to the distantly related A. dumerilii from Lago Pátzcuaro (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.
Specimens of this species have been included in Pseudoeurycea smithi by some previous authors (Parra-Olea et al. 2005).
The sister taxon of, and previously confused with, Oedipina gephrya according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is the only Philautus species known on Mindoro Island, but additional records of Philautus-like specimens were made during surveys at Mount Calavite, Mount Halcon, Mount Baco, Abra de Ilog, Sablayan, and Blue Mountain between 2005-2017; these are tentatively assigned to this species but require analysis and confirmation of their identity as they may represent undescribed species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

authority: Ofori-Boateng, Leaché, Obeng-Kankam, Kouamé, Hillers & Rödel, 2018

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Phrynobatrachus steindachneri (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is probably a synonym of Phrynobatrachus werneri (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).
Pionus menstruus and P. reichenowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. menstruus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).

The holotype of Hynobius stejnegeri Dunn, 1923, the name for this species for almost 100 years, was found by Matsui et al. (2017) to be a member of the species known as H. yatsui Oyama, 1947, taking priority over that name and requiring a new name for this species, namely H. ikioi.

Three subspecies are recognized:

Pyxis arachnoides arachnoides Bell, 1827
Pyxis arachnoides brygooi (Vuillemin & Domergue, 1972)
Pyxis arachnoides oblonga Gray, 1869
This species was formerly classified as Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).
This species is assigned to the festae species group (Moravec et al. 2014).
This is likely to represent a species complex (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
The sister species of Rhombophryne testudo according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful, and it might be a complex of several species (F. Andreone, F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
It is not clear that the populations on the mainland of Madagascar belong to the same species as those on Nosy Be and Nosy Komba (M. Vences, F. Glaw, F. Andreone and C.J. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
This species has been split from the broader concept of Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014).

authority: Fuiten, Welton, Diesmos, Barley, Oberheide, Duya, Rico & Brown, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

authority: Klages, Glaw, Köhler, Müller, Hipsley & Vences, 2013
Glaw, Vallan, Andreone, Edmonds, Dolch & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Removed from synonymy under Stumpffia psologlossa by Köhler et al. (2010).
Hynobius tenuis was synonymized with this species by Matsui et al. (2002).

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa et al. 2013).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Onychodactylus japonicus until it was described by Yoshikawa and Matsui (2013).
This species was considered a subpopulation of Glandirana rugosa prior to its description by Sekiya, Miura and Ogata (2012).
The population on Amami Island formerly identified as Odorrana ishikawae has been identified by Kuramoto et al. (2011) as a separate species named O. splendida.
According to Kuramoto et al. (2011) this species was confused with Odorrana ishikawae prior to its naming.

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011).

This is the only surviving species of an ancient lineage from the early evolutionary history of the endemic family Mantellidae. It is therefore evolutionarily distinct and should be a high priority for efforts preserving Malagasy amphibian biodiversity.

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus eysoole, X. kobeli and X. ruwenzoriensis), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable scientific interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidization (Loumont and Kobel 1991).

There is no observed genetic distinction between Z. laticaudatus and Z. anelanelany in the south-east and further studies are needed using a larger sample size (only two individuals of Z. anelanelany have been included in comparisons), and from a wider area, than has been previously undertaken to clarify whether this is a real effect (Raselimanana et al. 2009). The two species are morphologically distinct, and therefore introgression or hybridization may account for the lack of genetic differences (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

Previously placed in Garrulax as Ashy-headed Laughingthrush (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Common name changed to Ashy-fronted Babbler as name Ashy-headed Babbler already in use. Monotypic.
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
Monotypic.

Hylatomus galeatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been demonstrated by Benz et al. (2015) and Lammertink et al. (2016) to be a mimic of American species in the genus Hylatomus, and is actually appropriately placed within Celeus. All members of Hylatomus were previously placed in the genus Dryocopus.
The Marine Iguana (genus Amblyrhynchus) is a single species, with 11 subspecies after taxonomic revision by Miralles et al. (2017).
Calendulauda albescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Certhilauda albescens.
Biton et al. (2013) removed this species from the genus Discoglossus and placed it into the fossil genus Latonia.

Sister to H. ruddi (Alström et al. 2013a). Morphological, vocal and genetic analysis recently demonstrated that form sidamoensis, treated as a species in HBW, belongs in present species, and may not even be subspecifically distinct; a new population in E Ethiopia simultaneously shown also to belong to nominate (Spottiswoode et al. 2013).We follow Donald & Alström (in prep) in treating Liben Lark as monotypic.
Aerodramus elaphrus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Collocalia as C. elaphra.

Two subspecies have been described and these persist in theory (Meester et al. 1986). Felis nigripes nigripes, the nominate genotype form described by Burchell, was first described from near Kuruman in the Northern Cape. Its range includes present-day south eastern Namibia, Botswana, Northern Cape, North West, Gauteng, Limpopo and marginally into Mpumalanga. Felis nigripes thomasi (Shortridge 1931) is described from a specimen collected near Grahamstown in the Eastern Cape. Its range includes the present-day Eastern Cape, westwards to the southern regions of the Northern Cape and the Free State.

However, Smithers (1971) doubted the validity of two subspecies, and his thought is shared by Sliwa (2013) who suggests that the species may be polymorphic in the centre of its range but does exhibit on some geocline variations towards the extremes of its range. The northern race typically tends to be paler with less distinct striping whereas the southern race has a more tawny appearance with bolder patterning. However, since there are no obvious geographical or ecological barriers between the ranges which are the leading causes of genetic drift and speciation (Hoskin et al. 2005), it is likely that the subspecies status is invalid (Wilson 2016).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).

Otus magicus and O. tempestatis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. magicus, and O. alfredi, O. siaoensis, O. enganensis, O. insularis and O. beccarii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were split from O. magicus following Widodo et al. (1999), Lambert and Rasmussen (1998), Andrew (1992) and Holt et al. (1999). Prior to that all these taxa were lumped in O. magicus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Leistes defilippii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Sturnella following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Geotrygon purpurata and G. saphirina (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. saphirina following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Premnoplex tatei and P. pariae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. tatei following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Closely related to C. moluccensis. Monotypic.

authority: Krabbe, Agro, Rice, Jacome, Navarrete & Sornoza, 1999

taxonomicNotes: Closely related to C. galerita and C. ophthalmica. Previous recognised taxon included subspecies citrinocristata (del Hoyo & Collar 2014), but this now split as Citron-crested Cockatoo (which see). Subspecies abbotti strikingly large (except in bill size) (3), with small, pale brownish-yellow ear-covert patch (2). Subspecies djampeana and occidentalis generally regarded as synonyms of nominate subspecies and parvula, respectively, but new evaluation indicates real morphological differences and even possible subspecific division within djampeana (Collar & Marsden 2014). Five subspecies recognized.
Geotrygon caniceps and G. leucometopia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. caniceps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Geotrygon caniceps and G. leucometopia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. caniceps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Zentrygon carrikeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Geotrygon.

Previously, Geotrygon lawrencii (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) had been split into G. lawrencii and G. carrikeri following AOU (1998).

Amazilia cyanifrons and A. alfaroana (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) were previously lumped as A. cyanifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), but A. alfaroana is now recognised as a good species following Kirwan and Collar (2016), who examined the sole specimen and found species-level differences from cyanifrons and no evidence of characters suggesting that it is a hybrid, with the conclusion that - subject to any future molecular analysis - it is best treated as a separate species. It differs from cyanifrons in having a slightly longer bill, paler blue crown, more continuously green chin to belly, richer russet uppertail-coverts, and bluish-black undertail-coverts with narrow whitish edges. Monotypic.

The taxonomy follows the view of the IWC Scientific Committee and the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy which now recognize Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as three distinct species in the genus Eubalaena, namely E. glacialis (North Atlantic Right Whale), E. japonica (North Pacific Right Whale), and E. australis (Southern Right Whale) (IWC 2004), based mainly on the mtDNA phylogenetic findings of Rosenbaum et al. (2000).

The North Atlantic Right Whale was included in previous Red Lists together with the North Pacific Right Whale under the species name E. glacialis (Baillie and Groombridge 1996).

Rice (1998) classified Right Whales in the North Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Hemisphere as the single species Balaena glacialis, in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. While not all cetologists accept that the three Right Whale taxa qualify as full biological species, their clear geographical separation means that their treatment as separate taxa for conservation purposes is appropriate.

Previously listed as Megalurulus rufus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Trichocichla rufa but reassigned to Cincloramphus following Alström et al. (2018). Has been placed in monospecific Trichocichla, or sometimes with C. rubiginosus in Ortygocichla. Despite its rather long legs, however, it has many features typical of present genus. Two subspecies recognized.
Capra walie is here treated as a distinct species from Capra ibex and Capra nubiana, following Grubb (2005).
This species has been separated from Alytes obstetricans (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003, Martínez-Solano et al. 2004, Fromhage et al. 2004).
Telmatobius albiventris and T. crawfordi were synonymized with this species by Benavides, Ortiz and Sites (2002).
Onychoprion aleuticus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. aleutica.
Synthliboramphus hypoleucus and S. scrippsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. hypoleucus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang, with which there is a small hybridization zone in peninsular Thailand. Based on genetic evidence, it was elevated to species level by Roos (2003). Considerable variation exists in body size (850–2,100 g), genetics and coat colour (white to crimson red; absence of head forks to possession of light head forks) in this taxon, which may lead to at least three new taxa being described.
Probably most closely related to C. thoracicus and C. pecuarius; often considered conspecific with latter. Monotypic.
Drepanis coccinea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Vestiaria following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris loveridgei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris rufipennis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Coracopsis nigra, C. barklyi and C. sibilans (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. nigra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Closely related to A. arausiaca, the two forming a Lesser Antillean clade (Russello and Amato 2004). Monotypic.
Mentocrex beankaensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Canirallus. This cryptic species was described by Goodman et al. (2011).

Nesoenas picturata and N. mayeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. picturata following Cheke (2005), and before that N. picturata and N. mayeri were present in the genus Streptopelia following Johnson et al. (2001), and before that were present in the genus Columba following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Closest to A. amazonica (Russello and Amato 2004). Monotypic.

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Poicephalus robustus and P. fuscicollis (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) were previously lumped as P. robustus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), but have been split following work by Collar and Fishpool (2017) who showed that the form robustus reached species rank under the Tobias criteria on morphological scoring alone, with the difference augmented by voice (7+3 = 10). The newly-defined P. robustus is monotypic, while P. fuscicollis is polytypic, including the races fuscicollis and suahelicus.
Psittacara chloropterus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aratinga as A. chloroptera.

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pica nutalli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. nuttalli.
Psittacara euops (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aratinga.

Butynski and De Jong (2018) provide a detailed account of the taxonomic history of this species. Although described by Thomas (1885) as a subspecies of Colobus guereza, De Rochebrune (1887) considered it sufficiently distinct to be a species; a classification that was accepted by most other taxonomists at that time. Schwarz (1929), however, designated all the black-and-white colobus monkeys to just one species, Colobus polykomos (Zimmermann 1780) with 20 subspecies, caudatus one of them. Pocock (1935) argued that there were four species of black-and-white colobus, and his proposition was taken up by Dandelot (1965, 1968, 1974), resulting in the acceptance of five species today—polykomos, vellerosus, guereza, satanas and angolensis—but caudatus was left behind as a subspecies of guereza. Using the Phylogenetic Species Concept, Butynski and De Jong (2018) argued that caudatus should be considered a species on the basis of its geographic isolation, distinctive cranial morphology and coat colour patterns, and its calls—Oates et al. (2000; p.444) found significant differences in the loud call of caudatus from Mt Meru, Tanzania, when compared with Colobus guereza occidentalis.
This species is "not particularly distinct" from African members of the genus (Rocha et al. 2009), and its validity as a full species is uncertain (Kopeczky and Gemel 2016).

We follow Smith and Wallach (1994) in including this species in the monotypic genus Lycognathophis, rather than in Scopelophis, as proposed by Dowling (1990). This is supported by more recent molecular studies, which confirm its placement within Natricidae (e.g. Pyron et al. 2013, Zaher et al. 2019). Genetic evidence indicates that this species belongs to an ancient lineage, having diverged from African relatives around 35 million years ago (Deepak et al. 2021).

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. The two nominal species in this genus are frequently treated as a single species, J. braueri, following Cheke (1984) and a series of subsequent resurrections and re-synonymizations (Bowler et al. 2006). The first genetic study on this genus suggests greater divergence than is represented by a two-species model, with at least three lineages on Silhouette alone (Harris et al. 2015). These authors recommend recognizing considering Janetaescincus as a single species complex under the name J. braueri, pending further taxonomic research.

For the sake of taxonomic stability, these assessments retain the two-species approach adopted in prior Red List assessments pending clarification of species boundaries, with the caveat that neither a one- nor a two-species model accurately reflects our current understanding of diversity in this group (S. Rocha and J. Harris pers. comms. 2020).

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. The two nominal species in this genus are frequently treated as a single species, J. braueri, following Cheke (1984) and a series of subsequent resurrections and re-synonymizations (Bowler et al. 2006). The first genetic study on this genus suggests greater divergence than is represented by a two-species model, with at least three lineages on Silhouette alone (Harris et al. 2015). These authors recommend recognizing considering Janetaescincus as a single species complex under the name J. braueri, pending further taxonomic research.

For the sake of taxonomic stability, these assessments retain the two-species approach adopted in prior Red List assessments pending clarification of species boundaries, with the caveat that neither a one- nor a two-species model accurately reflects our current understanding of diversity in this group (S. Rocha and J. Harris pers. comms. 2020).

In a range-wide review of the two Seychelles species of Trachylepis, Gerlach (2005) referred the doubtful subspecies Trachylepis wrightii ilotensis to the synonymy of T. sechellensis on morphological grounds.

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to P. nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria. The two species hybridize in a broad contact zone in the east of the coastal plain of El Taref (Berrihane and Lac des Oiseaux) and in the west in Guerbes-Foret des Senhaja (Djendel, Skikda) (Escoriza et al. 2016).

Goral Naemorhedus spp. taxonomy was recently clarified by Mori et al. (2019) based on mitochondrial DNA. Three goral species are now recognised: long-tailed goral Naemorhedus caudatus, red goral Naemorhedus baileyi and Himalayan goral Naemorhedus goral. Only one species of red goral has been confirmed, all current and earlier references to Naemorhedus cranbrooki should be considered as N. baileyi.
Pipilo maculatus and P. socorroensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. maculatus following AOU (1998 and supplements); Stotz et al. (1996).
Thamnophilus bernardi and T. shumbae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sakesphorus bernardi following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Coeligena bonapartei, C. consita and C. eos (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. bonapartei following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Setophaga angelae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Hedydipna pallidigaster (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Anthreptes following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hemimacronyx chloris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Anthus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Louis Jr., Coles, Andriantompohavana, Sommer, Engberg, Zaonarivelo, Mayor & Brenneman, 2006

taxonomicNotes: Sister to M. bicolor on molecular evidence (Burns et al. 2014, Burns et al. 2016). Monotypic.
Ammospiza caudacuta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Ammodramus and listed as A. caudacutus following AOU (1998 & supplements).
Foudia eminentissima, F. consobrina and F. aldabrana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. eminentissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) placed in the genus Alopecoenas and before that in the genus Gallicolumba but transferred to Pampusana on the grounds of the latter’s priority (Bruce et al. 2016). A distinctive form of uncertain affinities, apparently sister to all other members of genus (Jonsson et al. 2011). Has alternatively been considered an early derivative of P. jobiensis stock. Monotypic.
Geokichla guttata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera guttata.

Formerly placed in genus Erolia. Specific name formerly listed as testacea, but ferruginea has priority. Form described as C. paramelanotos (“Cox’s Sandpiper”) shown to be a hybrid between present species and (almost certainly) C. melanotos; C. (Pisobia) cooperi (“Cooper’s Sandpiper”) probably a hybrid between present species and C. acuminata. Monotypic.

Has been treated as conspecific with A. rimitarae and A. taiti, but basic differences in sequence and pattern of leucistic plumage among the three taxa suggest differentiation at species level; present species and A. taiti are sister taxa, but A. rimitarae belongs to a separate clade (Cibois et al. 2011). Monotypic.

Molecular studies conducted by Santos et al. (2020), report the cryptic status of the northern subpopulation of this species, naming it "Rupirana cardosoi Lin-B" but did not describe it as a separate species. This subpopulation is retained in the current concept of R. cardosoi until further work confirms its identity as a distinct species.
This species was previously within the genus Strabomantis but has been moved to the genus Haddadus (Amaro et al. 2013).

The validity of this species has been "seriously questioned" by recent systematic research (Leviton et al. 2018). This is based on the finding by Siler et al. (2013) that there is very little to no genetic divergence between this species and Lycodon alcalai, and Leviton et al. (2018) suggest that the two taxa may be conspecific.

Apteryx australis, A. mantelli and A. rowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously treated as A. australis and A. mantelli (incorporating rowi) following Baker et al. (1995); prior to that all three taxa were lumped as A. australis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
The genus Chrysomma has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Three subspecies recognized.

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of N. concolor, however, the light-cheeked gibbons were subsequently separated (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986; Ma et al. 1988) and then further divided into the four taxa currently recognized with the separation of N. gabriellae (Groves 1993), then N. siki (e.g. Groves 2001; Mootnick 2006; Geissmann 2007; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010a; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010b; Mootnick and Fan Pengfei 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2011) and finally with the recent description of N. annamensis (Van Ngoc Thin et al. 2010c). Nomascus leucogenys was previously considered to overlap with N. concolor in Viet Nam and Yunnan, China (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986), however, there seems to be insufficient evidence to currently conclude this (Fooden 1996; Geissmann et al. 2000; Rawson et al. 2011).
Aerodramus sawtelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Collocalia.

This species belongs to bicolor species group. This species was listed under Hipposideros bicolor (Temminck, 1834), but is now considered distinct (Hill et al. 1986, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012). Based on morphology and bacular structure, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu (2018) upgraded the taxon gentilis Andersen, 1918 to specific rank, and suggested that H. pomona Andersen, 1918 sensu stricto is restricted to southern India, and H. gentilis sensu lato occurs from northeast India to Southeast Asia.
Coracornis sanghirensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Colluricincla sanghirensis.
Monotypic.
Setophaga chrysoparia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Clibanornis rufipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Automolus rufipectus.

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here.

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here.

Hoskin (2019) revised the taxonomy of the Oedura monilis species complex and found that it consisted of four morphologically distinct species. He did not provide genetic data, but indicated that then-unpublished work demonstrated "substantial divergence" in both mitochondrial and nuclear DNA between the identified clades. He consequently described three new species: O. elegans, O. lineata and O. picta.
Monotypic.
Sitta pusilla and S. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. pusilla following AOU (1998 & supplements), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Amazona autumnalis, A. diadema and A. lilacina (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. autumnalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Laterallus spilonota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as L. spilonotus.
Geokichla cinerea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera cinerea.
The subspecies Aneides flavipunctatus niger was raised in rank to a full species by Reilly and Wake (2019).

authority: Chandramouli, Vasudevan, Harikrishnan, Dutta, Janani, Sharma, Das & Aggarwal, 2016

taxonomicNotes:
McGuire et al. (2019) review in detail the status of the all-white taxon occidentalis, which although formerly given species status (‘Great White Heron’ [GWH]) has long been considered a subspecies of Great Blue Heron [GBH] Ardea herodias, in great part because the two taxa interbreed with regularity. However, given that the evidence points to assortative mating where possible, they conclude that occidentalis is indeed better treated as a species:

it is separated by diagnostic plumage (white vs. blue), behaviour (mate choice and timing of mating) and habitat (saltwater-island vs. fresh/brackish water mainland).

There are, in fact, a few additional morphological considerations, with GWH having a shorter occipital plume but longer bill, tarsus and middle toe than GBH (supplementary material online with measurements not accessed). Applying the Tobias criteria to the situation, the taxonomic status of GWH involves a consideration of its

·       all-white vs grey/blue plumage (an exceptional difference: score 4);
·       shorter occipital plume (seemingly fairly distinctive from the authors’ Figure 3: allow 1);
·       longer tarsus (apparently the most distinctive of the longer characters measured, but perhaps insufficient to be allowed a score: ns);
·       timing of mating or habitat choice (only one of these permitted as a score: 1);
·       narrow hybrid zone (not more than 50 km as measured on Google Earth: 2).

On this basis BirdLife accepts Ardea occidentalis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) as a separate species.

authority: Khatiwada, Shu, Wang, Zhao, Xie & Jiang, 2020

taxonomicNotes: Chaetura vauxi has been split into Vaux's Swift C. vauxi, including form aphanes from NE Venezuela, and Ashy-tailed Swift C. andrei following a review of the relationships within Chaetura and investigation of the morphological characters within the group (Chesser et al. 2018). Monotypic.
Hypotaenidia okinawae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Gallirallus.

Tanygnathus sumatranus (with its longer-tailed subspecies sangirensis) and T. everetti (with its larger subspecies burbidgii; race duponti synonymised with nominate) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) have been split from T. sumatranus (del Hoyo & Collar 2014). Arndt et al. (2019) found that in both sexes Philippine forms differ by their larger bills (effect size of everetti vs sangirensis 1.62 and vs sumatranus 1.15; effect size of burbidgii vs sangirensis 1.75 and vs sumatranus 2.02; as burbidgii is here treated as conspecific with everetti, the lower values for everetti must be considered, hence score 1); blood-red or orange-red vs yellowish-white irides (3); pale matt royal blue in place of slightly glossy turquoise-blue lower back and rump (2); paler green head (ns1); and duller green underparts (ns1). Moreover, in males the Philippine forms further differ by their absence of blue in the carpal feathers and scapulars (2); and much darker green mantle (ns2). Additionally, phylogenetic reconstruction identified the Philippine and Indonesian clades as being as genetically distinct as T. lucionensis and T. megalorynchos.
