Cebus cesarae comprises populations in northern Colombia (i.e. in the northern parts of the Magdalena and Cesar departments, and southwestern part of La Guajira Department), except for the northern Colombian coast, where it is replaced by Cebus malitiosus. The geographic delimitation between the Varied White-fronted Capuchin (C. versicolor) and the Rio Cesar White fronted Capuchin (C. cesarae) is not well understood, and further research is needed in this region.

Genetic analyses by Boubli et al. (2012) and Lima et al. (2017) have indicated that the following forms of white-fronted capuchins that were recognized as subspecies of Cebus albifrons by Hershkovitz (1949) should be considered distinct species: albifrons, yuracus, unicolor, cuscinus, cesarae, malitiosus, leucocephalus, aequatorialis, and versicolor

While it has been suggested that this species likely hybridizes with the Red-shanked Douc Langur, Pygathrix nemaeus, where their distributions meet in Viet Nam and Cambodia this has yet to be confirmed by genetic analysis.

This species is here considered monotypic (Groves 2001).

The different records of Trachypithecus hatinhensis across its range show wide variation in morphology in terms of the pattern of white hairs on the head (especially so in Lao PDR). Published description of the different species included in the François’s-group vary (the morphologically closest being T. francoisi, T. hatinhensis, [T. ebenus], and T. laotum). It has been suggested that [T. ebenus] was a distinct species from T. hatinhensis (Brandon-Jones, 1995) but has also been considered to be a melanistic variant of T. hatinhensis (Nadler 2009). The taxonomic position of [T. ebenus] remains unresolved due to lack of evidence from DNA analysis.

The two named forms living closest by are T. hatinhensis and [T. ebenus] (see Timmins and Khounboline 1996; Walston and Vinton 1999; Nadler et al. 2003). The former is conventionally seen as having a bold white facial stripe including moustache and white marks on the nape, the latter an all-black head (e.g. Brandon-Jones 1995, Francis 2008). Moreover, Nadler et al. (2003) stated that T. (f.) hatinhensis shows a white moustache but T. (f.) francoisi, otherwise similar in head pattern, lacks one.

Simia mauritius Griffith was for many years considered to be a Long-tailed Macaque, Macaca fascicularis from Mauritius. Brandon-Jones (1995), however, established its identity as a west Javan Ebony Leaf Monkey, a subspecies of what he referred to as the Semnopithecus auratus superspecies. The type specimen was evidently destroyed, but he assigned a type locality: Jasinga (6°29'S 106°27'E), Banten Province, Java, Indonesia. It was considered a subspecies of T. auratus by Groves (2001, 2005) and Brandon-Jones et al. (2004), but Roos et al. (2008) determined that it was a distinct species.

authority: Roos, Helgen, Miguez, Thant, Lwin, A.K. Lin, A. Lin, Yi, Soe, Hein, Myint, Ahmed, Chetry, Urh, Veatch, Duncan, Kamminga, Chua, Yao, Matauschek, Meyer, Liu, Li, Nadler, Fan, Quyet, Hofreiter, Zinner & Momberg, 2020
Schüßler, Blanco, Salmona, Poelstra, Andriambeloson, Miller, A., Randrianambinina, Rasolofoson, Mantilla-Contreras, Chikhi, Louis Jr., Yoder, & Radespiel, 2020
Louis Jr., Engberg, Lei, Geng, Sommer, Randriamampionona, Randriamanana, Zaonarivelo, Andriantompohavana, Randria, Prosper, Ramaromilanto, Rakotoarisoa, Rooney & Brenneman, 2006
taxonomicNotes:
The original Latin species name (ahmansoni) stems from the naming of the species after a man, Robert Ahmanson. The species has occasionally been incorrectly referred to as ahmansonorum (e.g. Hoffmann et al. 2009) and ahmansorum but the species should be referred to using the original Latin name.

Tattersall (2007) has cautioned that the Lepilemur species reported by Louis et al. 2006 (that were diagnosed exclusively on genetic distance and all allopatric) be treated with extreme caution until supporting data are forthcoming. However, Lei et al. (2016) subsequently established through delimitation analyses of mitogenomic data, that this species is valid despite allopatry.

The three presently recognized subspecies (roxellana, hubeiensis, qinlingensis) differ from one another mainly in tail length, as well as in certain features of skeletal structure and width of dental arch (Groves 2001). No genetic separation into distinct clades and therefore the sub-specific designation.

There are several localities in Mozambique (Mt. Namuli, Mt. Mabu) which were originally suspected to contain populations of Rhampholeon chapmanorum (Tilbury 2010). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. chapmanorum is endemic to remaining forest fragments on Malawi Hill, and the Mozambican localities are home to separate species of Rhampholeon (Branch et al. 2014).
Neomorphus geoffroyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as N. geoffroyi and N. squamiger following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
No subspecies or geographic variants have been described.

Originally described from Qudeni and Nkandla forests (Raw 1978), although the Nkandla subpopulation was later described as Bradypodion nkandlae (Raw and Brothers 2008). This was based on juvenile specimens which lacked clear diagnostic morphological differences with which to distinguish it from the Qudeni subpopulation. Phylogenetic studies showed a lack of divergence between chameleons from these two forests and as a result B. nkandlae was referred to the synonymy of B. nemorale (Tilbury and Tolley 2009). The species is now known from three forest patches, which has been confirmed by genetic studies (K.A. Tolley, unpubl. data 2019). There is also a morphologically distinct but closely related undescribed species near Greytown.

Recent genetic studies show that this species is part of the Bradypodion melanocephalum species complex. Based on mitochondrial DNA markers, there is low but diagnosable differentiation between these species (da Silva and Tolley 2017).
No taxonomic issues.
Although there are no notable taxonomic issues, the range of Lygodactylus methueni may overlap with that of L. nigropunctatus, and these two species can be difficult to distinguish from each other.

Raw (1973) assigned specimens from the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands to Scelotes guentheri, but these specimens were later described as S. bourquini (Broadley 1994). A photograph of an individual from Qudeni (KwaZulu-Natal Province) has been assigned to S. bourquini (Broadley 1994). Raw (2020) described this subpopulation as a separate species (S. farquharsoni), but this requires confirmation. Although Raw (2021) suggests that S. bourquini should be synonymised with S. guentheri, this conclusion was based on limited evidence and requires further data to confirm the result.

Although there appears to be genetic divergence between this species and the morphologically similar Scelotes montispectus (Bauer et al. 2003), further investigation of the species boundaries between these taxa and related forms is required. A molecular phylogeny (Heideman et al. 2011) suggested that the subpopulation of S. kasneri at Elands Bay may represent a distinct species, requiring a taxonomic revision.
No taxonomic issues.
Genetic studies show that subpopulations from all three forests (Dlinza, Ntumeni and Ngoya) belong to this taxon (Tilbury and Tolley 2009).

The closely related subpopulation at Mkambati in the Eastern Cape Province appears to be a grassland ecomorph of this otherwise forest-dwelling species (K.A. Tolley unpubl. data 2019), but more research is needed to assess the taxonomic status of this population.
No outstanding taxonomic issues.

Recent phylogenetic analyses suggest that Bitis albanica, B. armata, B. inornata and B. rubida are within a closely related species complex (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa are worthy of further investigation.

A recent phylogenetic study suggests that Bitis albanica, B. armata, B. inornata and B. rubida form a closely related species complex (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa is worthy of further investigation. In addition, the taxonomic status of an isolated subpopulation near Langebaan should be investigated.

Although there are no notable taxonomic issues (Tolley et al. 2004, 2006; Tolley and Burger 2007), this species is sometimes confused with Bradypodion caffer, which occurs further north along the coastline.
No notable issues.

There are no taxonomic issues. However, because the distribution overlaps with the congener Hemicordylus capensis which is morphologically similar, there could be a number of misidentifications in the existing records.

authority: Guayasamin, Cisneros-Heredia, Maynard, Lynch, Culebras & Hamilton, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species belongs to the silenus species group, and was formerly known as Macaca maurus. It hybridizes with M. tonkeana in areas where their ranges overlap at the base of the Toraja Highlands (Tempe depression).

Pygmy Slow Lorises are distinct from other slow loris taxa on the basis of their relatively small size (360–580 g); naked black ears; black nose; the fur on the crown patch of the head is orangish to light brown and is diffuse to ears with eye patches rather than sharply forked. The form intermedius is here considered a synonym of Nycticebus pygmaeus. There is no evidence of hybridization, either in the wild or in museum specimens, between N. bengalensis and N. pygmaeus from localities where the two are sympatric. A distinct form of Pygmy Slow Loris has been identified in the south of Viet Nam, but more studies need to be done to confirm the taxonomic status of this subpopulation.
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus silvaticus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
We depart from the taxonomy on Amphibians of the World, and consider Pseudophilautus silus to have been synonymised with this species as in Ellepola et al. (2021).
This is a broader concept of Psudophilatus hankeni that now includes all the records from P. dilmah, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).

authority: Firneno, Itgen, Jacobs, Mcdaniels, Luque-Montes, Wilson & Townsend, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hypopachus barberi based on molecular and morphological differences (Firneno Jr. et al. 2021).

This species is assigned to Dendropsophus minuta species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is distinguished from other species of the genus by its noticeably smaller size (2.26 cm), homogeneously dotted back, presence of interdigital palms, smooth dorsal skin, and cloaca with fleshy fold, among others. A survey conducted by the Ministry of Ecosocialism in 2011 reports D. minutus, D. minusculus, D. microcephalus and D. luteoocellatus for the locality (González-Fernández and Nieves 2011), species that noticeably differ from the description of the holotype. However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary.
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

The nomenclatural history of this species was detailed by Lötters et al. (1998) and Lötters and La Marca (2001). This species was redescribed by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004) after the discovery that the original type material represented Atelopus varius of Central America. The former junior synonym Atelopus vogli is considered to be a distinct species following (Lötters et al. 2004)

Until now, this species had not been included in any phylogenetic study, and its relationships with Rhinella alata and the others members of Rhinella margaritifera group are still unknown (dos Santos et al. 2015). The records of “Bufo typhonius alatus” from Curimagua (Falcón state) and Bejuma (Carabobo state) by Rivero (1961, 1964) may correspond to Rhinella sclerocephala.
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
In the Centrolene prosoblepon group according to Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1991), and Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006).
Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) reallocated this species in the genus Vitreorana.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the new genus Celsiella to reallocate two endemic species – C. revocata and C. vozmedianoi - from the northern mountain system in Venezuela.

Based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies and some morphological characteristics, this species was assigned to Vitreorana, and designated as the type species of this genus (Guayasamin et al. 2009).
This species had been included in phylogenetic studies by Guayasamin et al. (2008, 2009), and Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2014).

In the genus Hyalinobatrachium based on morphological and behavioral characteristics (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005, Guayasamin et al. 2009). Until now this species has not been included in any phylogenetic study.

Originally described in the genus Centrolenella (Rivero, 1985). Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) transferred this species to Hyalinobatrachium, and posteriorly to the genus Cochranella (Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch 1998). Based on a molecular phylogeny of the family Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the genus Celsiella to reallocate this species (as the type species of the genus) and other endemic glass frog from the northern mountain system in Venezuela: C. vozmedianoi.

This species is assigned to the genus Anomaloglossus based on the phenotypic synapomorphies of this clade that is the presence of the median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006). Other features, such as morphological characters, differentiate this species from most species of the genus (La Marca 1998).

Originally assigned to Phyllobates (Test 1956) but subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971), and to Allobates by Grant et al. (2006). In both cases, taxonomic changes were based only on morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position and its relationships with other Allobates species are unknown as this species has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

Originally assigned to Prostherapis by Rivero (1961) and later transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971). Grant et al. (2006) did not include this species in their phylogenetic hypothesis, however, agree with La Marca (2004) in that its phylogenetic relationships remain enigmatic, and refer it as insertae sedis within Aromobatidae.
Misidentified specimens of Allobates humilis reported by Barrio-Amorós and García Porta (2003) from Táchira State actually represent A. algorei (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009).

Originally described as a member of Phyllobates (Schmidt 1932) but subsequently transferred to Prostherapis (Rivero 1961), Colostethus (Edwards 1971), and finally to Allobates (Grant et al. 2006) where is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Although the last change was made in the contexts of an exhaustive phylogenetic study (Grant et al. 2006) this species was not included in the analyses and its reallocation was only based on its overall morphological similarity with other Allobates. Therefore, its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and its generic position should be considered provisional and pending corroboration.
This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, so its relationships are unknown (Grant et al. 2017).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide new information for this species and suggest that the subpopulation in Colombia referred as Aromobates saltuensis by Grant et al. (2006) is an unnamed species most closely related to Aromobates cannatellai. Also, these authors have doubts about the Colombian references of Anganoy-Criollo (2012) of A. cf. saltuensis.

This species is assigned to monophyletic genus Allobates based on its phenotypic synapomorphies (Grant et al. 2006). A conspicuous nonglandular pad thickening and melanosis above the wrist of A. undulatus males (Myers and Donnelly 2001) is not present in other species of this genus (Grant et al. 2006).

This species is recovered in various places throughout the dendrobatine phylogeny, either as sister to the genus Adelphobates or to all other dendrobatines aside from Phyllobates and C. ruthveni (see Frost 2020 for a complete review of the systematic of this taxon). Currently, Minyobates is a monotypic genus, but additional phylogenetic research is needed (La Marca 2016).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Hyloxalus collaris by Boulenger (1912) (misspelled Hylixalus). Successively moved to Prostherapis and Colostetus by Rivero (1961) and Edwards (1971), respectively, and finally allocated in Mannophryne by La Marca (1992), where still remains. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).
Since its description (La Marca 1994) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Santos et al. 2014, Grant et al. 2017).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Prostherapis neblina by Test (1956) and subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971) and to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been recently corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
Mannophryne larandina is suspected to be a junior synonym of this species (Manzanilla et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, J. Manzanilla pers. comm. 2020).

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but without supporting evidence.

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Rivero (1980). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and most recently reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Dole and Durant (1972). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and lastly reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) suggested that the type material of Aromobates orostoma requires additional examination to confirm its status, and its relationship with A. inflexus should be evaluated.
It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by the skin co-ossified with the skull and transverse occipital ridge bearing spinous elevations (Duellman 1980).

It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by triangular dermal calcar present on heel and triangular dermal process present on margin of eyelid (Duellman 1980). It could be a junior synonym of Gastrotheca williamsoni, so its taxonomic status requires further investigation (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Faivovich et al. (2013) reexamined the holotype of Myersiohyla loveridgei and based on its morphological similarity with M. aromatica suggested the possibility of a senior synonym. More samples of M. aromatica and M. loveridgei are needed for further phylogenetic analyses of the genus, and a reevaluation of their taxonomic status.

Originally described as a member of Hyla by Rivero (1961) and then transferred to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position was corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018) using molecular data. Centrolenella estevesi Rivero, 1968 is a junior synonym of this species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Originally described as a subspecies of Hyla vilsoniana by Rivero (1961) and later elevated to the species level by Duellman (1989), who also assigned it to the labialis group. It was moved to the genus Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of molecular phylogenetic evidence. According to Guarnizo et al. (2012), D. pelidnus could be a junior synonym of this species but it is still considered valid for this assessment.

Originally described under the genus Hyla by Mijares-Urrutia and Rivero (2000). It was transferred to Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) based only on morphological similarity and remained unassigned to any species group. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) assigned it to the Dendropsophus parviceps species group, but also on the basis of its overall similarity with the other species in that group. Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

This species was transferred to Agalychnis by Faivovich et al. (2010), but was not assigned to any species group. Until now this leaf frog is still missing in phylogenetic analyses and its evolutionary relationships are unknown.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guiana Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008). This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and has not been assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

Originally described in the genus Hylodes by Peters (1863), and subsequently transferred to Eleutherodactylus by Stejneger (1904) and Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007) where it is currently placed (Frost 2020). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). Its evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis are unknown as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis. According to Lynch and La Marca (1993), Eleutherodactylus lancini Rivero 1961, E. racenisi Rivero 1961, and E. williamsi Rivero 1961, are junior synonyms of this species. Lynch and La Marca (1993) further suggested that Eleutherodactylus rozei Rivero 1961 could be an additional junior synonym of Pristimantis reticulatus, but this must be evaluated.

The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007); Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis, which includes Pristimantis boconoensis. Recent genetic studies confirm the distinctiveness of the group, but does not guarantee its full genus status (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Paramophrynella for this and related species. This genus had been considered a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008), and later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reinforced this synonym with molecular data. Not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

The species was named in 1965 by Roberto Donoso Barros as Eleutherodactylus lancinii, but the formal description was published later (Donoso-Barros, 1968). Other descriptions are in Rivero (1982) and La Marca (2007). La Marca (2007) created the new genus Mucubatrachus for this and related species, that was afterwards regarded as a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008) and later confirmed by molecular data (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2013).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Myers and Donnelly, 1996), neither in the molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). The phylogenetic relationships of this species are totally unknown.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014) also listed this species as part of Pristimantis but did not assign it to any species group as it was not included in their phylogenetic analyses. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown.

This species is assigned to the unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), based on its morphological characteristics, although it has not been assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

There are two available descriptions for this frog: Eleutherodactylus vanadise by La Marca (1984) and that of its synonym Eleutherodactylus cerasoventris (Rivero 1984 “1982”). Even though these descriptions were based on 29 and 36 specimens respectively, the variation in nature was not fully represented. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reported four chromotypes, based on 98 specimens. In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original publication (La Marca 1984) and Hedges et al. (2008); not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

This species is assigned to Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (de Sá et al. 2014). This species is known only from the Cerro Socopó region in Venezuela. There are no other described species having toe fringes and lacking dorsolateral folds in the area where the Venezuelan states of Falcón, Lara and Zulia converge (de Sá et al. 2014). However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary, considering several populations in Venezuela and Colombia (Magdalena and Maracaibo basin) could not be assigned to diagnosable species (Heyer 1994).

This species was the first endemic salamander described from Venezuela. It was described by Trapido in 1942 using a single specimen collected in the vicinity of the Borburata River Valley in Carabobo state. This author suggested that a specimen from Río San Esteban, Carabobo state, was B. borburata and not B. altamazonica as previously suggested by Dunn (1926). Specimens reported from Falcón state (Linares 1974, Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000) and Yaracuy state (Barrio-Amorós 1999, Lotzkat 2007) might represent a different taxon (Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). We tentatively consider the populations from Yaracuy as part of the same taxon although a taxonomic assessment is required. The phylogenetic position of this species is unclear. Parra-Olea et al. (2004) assigned this species to the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

Schargel et al. (2002) mentioned that this species is morphologically more similar to B. adspersa, B. borburata, B. savagei, B. taylori, and B. vallecula than the geographically close species, B. orestes. Apparently, such difference is also applicable to the most recently described species B. mucuyensis, which is the sister species of B. orestes (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). This species was tentatively assigned to the B. adspersa group by Schargel et al. (2002). Parra-Olea et al. (2004) placed B. guaramacalensis in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group of Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Pristimantis conspicillatus group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Pantepui, and noted several unnamed species.

This species was originally described in the genus Mucubatrachus by La Marca (2007). Hedges et al. (2008), however, placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

The species was originally described within the genus Paramophrynella, which Hedges et al. (2008) placed in synonymy with Pristimantis. Pristimantis jabonensis belongs to a group of small-sized páramo frogs usually found in sympatry with members of another group of frogs to which Pristimantis lancinii belongs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020). The latter group of species, originally placed in the genus Mucubatrachus (also currently in synonymy with Pristimantis) are larger frogs with a unique derived character that was used as a synapomorphy for the group (La Marca 2007). Further molecular genetic studies are needed to ascertain the phylogenetic relationships among those frogs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis thyellus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
Pristimantis flabellidiscus can be distinguished from other similar species by very expanded discs and a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).

Described originally in genus Eleutherodactylus (Barrio-Amorós and Molina 2006), subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon. The diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019 and Frost 2019 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (direct-developing frogs).

This species was originally described as Colostethus caribe, but a year later was moved to the genus Allobates based on its morphological characteristics (Lötters et al. 2007).

Lötters et al. (2007: 60) in an apparent transcription mistake made reference to this species as Anomaloglossus caribe.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis rhigophilus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position within Mannophryne has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2008), but listed as unassigned to a species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) but later referred as not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis remain unknown, but its validity is not questioned. Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2013) amended its definition and described the variation in its external morphology.

Its phylogenetic position has been inferred by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2015). Its phylogenetic relationship with Cryptobatrachus pedroruizi Lynch, 2008 must be assessed in order to determine if these two species are conspecific, as both are geographically close and morphologically similar.

Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) noted that it shares morphological similarities with the Pristimantis lentiginosus species group of Rivero (1984). Padial et al. (2014) recognized P. lassoalcalai as part of Pristimantis but as unassigned to species group. Heinicke et al. (2015) moved it to Tachiramantis.

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Rödder and Jungfer 2008) or in Padial et al. (2014). The specimens mentioned as Pristimantis cf. yuruaniensis by Rödder and Junger 2008) from the Kukenán-tepui correspond to P. aureoventris (Jablonski et al. 2017). In a recent exploratory molecular analysis of the phylogenetic relationships within the genus Pristimantis in the Guiana Shield, Kok et al. (2018) considered this species to be in the “unistrigatus” group.

Originally described by Rivero (1968) as Centrolenella orocostale. Cannatella and Lamar (1986) considered this species as a junior synonym of Centrolenella orientalis, and later Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) placed it in the genus Hyalinobatrachium. Based on phylogenetic analysis and new natural history data, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009) removed this species from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium orientalis. More recently Jowers et al. (2014) reanalyzed the phylogenetic relationships of this species and its closely related sister species Hyalinobatrachium fragile, and H. orientale (from Venezuela mainland, and Trinidad and Tobago).

Fermin et al. (2012) synonymized Bolitoglossa spongai (described by Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos in 1999), also from Sierra La Culata, under B. orestes based on molecular evidence (16S, cytb and cox genes sequence analysis) and morphological data. Specimens from Sierra Nevada de Mérida, previously considered as B. orestes, are actually specimens of its sister species, B. mucuyensis (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). Bolitoglossa orestes was placed in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group by Parra-Olea et al. (2004).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) and then corroborated in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) and then corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), and in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Since its description (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2012) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).

authority: García-Gutiérrez, Escalona, Mora, de Pascual & Fermin, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Specimens of this species were previously identified as B. orestes (Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos 1999, García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). The molecular and morphological analyses of Fermin et al. (2012) shed light on the species diversity and its known distribution in the vicinity of Mérida city. Thus, B. mucuyensis was described from La Mucuy region, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida, and B. orestes was restricted to the Sierra La Culata, the close parallel mountain chain (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). It is unclear if specimens from the road Mérida-El Morro, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida (stored at the Museo de Historia Natural La Salle, MHNLS), belong to B. mucuyensis. B. mucuyensis is the sister species of B. orestes and it is member of the B. adspersa group (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019) based on total evidence analyses.
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015). With the adult male measuring 13 mm, this species may be the smallest frog species in Venezuela and rank among the smallest in South America.

Pristimantis phoxocephalus was formerly considered a single highly polymorphic species (e.g., Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1997, Duellman and Lehr 2009). Páez and Ron (2019) showed that most subpopulations previously ascribed to P. phoxocephalus represent other species (e.g., Pristimantis atillo, P. jimenezi, P. teslai sp. nov., P. torresi sp. nov., P. totoroi sp. nov., P. verrucolatus sp. nov., Pristimantis sp. (CCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS2), Pristimantis sp. (UCS3)). This is the new narrower concept of Pristimantis phoxocephalus.

Classically considered a single species, the Clouded Leopard has been split into two species. Based on analysis of mitochondrial DNA, microsatellites and morphology, Neofelis nebulosa is restricted to mainland Southeast Asia, and N. diardi is found on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo (Buckley-Beason et al. 2006, Kitchener et al. 2006, Wilting et al. 2007). The subspecific classification of Neofelis nebulosa needs further analyses (Kitchener et al. 2017). In addition to the nominate form two subspecies of Mainland Clouded Leopard have been described: N. n. macrosceloides (Hodgson in Gray, 1853, pl. 38) from Nepal, Northeast India, and Bhutan and (the presumably extinct) N. n. brachyura (Swinhoe, 1862, 352, pl. 43) from Taiwan. However, the recent review of wild cat taxonomy felt there was insufficient evidence for these two subspecies and proposed to keep N. nebulosa as monotypic until there was further evidence for subspecification (Kitchener et al. 2017).

Erythropitta erythrogaster, E. inspeculata, E. caeruleitorques, E. palliceps, Erythropitta celebensis, E. rufiventris, E. rubrinucha, E. macklotii, E. meeki, E. gazellae, E. splendida and E. novaehibernicae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pitta erythrogaster following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Previously placed in family Accipitridae but moved to current family based on the phylogeny of Starikov and Wink (2020). Monotypic.

Previously placed in Arborophila but moved to Tropicoperdix following Chen et al. (2015, 2018). Other taxonomic sources have considered it conspecific with T. chloropus, but differs in absence of buffy-tan band around lower throat/upper breast (3); presence of bold black necklace from lower throat to neck-sides (3); upper breast and sides of neck chestnut vs dingy grey-brown (3); lower breast more boldly barred (ns2); and remaining underparts a shade darker (ns1). Arborophila charltonii, A. tonkinensis, and A. graydoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014: see related notes) were previously lumped as A. charltonii following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Validity of subspecies atjenensis has been questioned (Wells 1999). Two subspecies currently recognized.

authority: Alves da Silva, Magalhães, Thomassen, Leite, Garda, Brandão, Haddad, Giaretta & Carvalho, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Split from Leptodactylus spixi by Alves da Silva et al. (2020), who placed it in the L. mystaceus complex, L. fuscus group.
Xiphorhynchus fuscus and X. atlanticus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. fuscus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Two subspecies have been recognized: Bungarus multicinctus multicinctus and Bungarus multicinctus wanghaotingi. The latter is treated here as a full species following Leviton et al. (2003). It is probable that both members of this species group contain additional cryptic forms (Leviton et al. 2003). In an investigation of the systematics of this group, Chen et al. (2021) recovered three lineages corresponding to the recognized names B. candidus, B. multicinctus and B. wanghaotingi, supporting the recognition of the latter as a distinct species.

Hofmann et al. (2015) reviewed the evidence used by Peng et al. (2014) to describe Thermophis shangrila, and found that both morphological and molecular evidence were insufficient to reliably distinguish this species from Thermophis zhaoermii. These authors took no taxonomic action due to the small sample sizes available, but further sampling may reveal that T. shangrila is a junior synonym of T. zhaoermii (Hofmann et al. 2015).
The two known specimens of Indotyphlops lazelli were originally attributed to the widespread Ramphotyphlops albiceps (Wallach and Pauwels 2004).

Hofmann et al. (2015) reviewed the evidence used by Peng et al. (2014) to describe Thermophis shangrila, and found that both morphological and molecular evidence were insufficient to reliably distinguish this species from Thermophis zhaoermii. These authors took no taxonomic action due to the small sample sizes available, but further sampling may reveal that T. shangrila is a junior synonym of T. zhaoermii (Hofmann et al. 2015).
Rheinardia nigrescens formerly regarded as a subspecies of this species but is split following Davison et al. (2020). Monotypic.

authority: Patton, Apodaca, Corser, Wilson, Williams, Cameron & Wake, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Aneides aeneus (Patton et al. 2019).

Cebuella was proposed by Gray (1866) as a subgenus of Hapale (later Callithrix), and soon after as a distinct genus (Gray, 1870). Rosenberger (1981), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), and Natori (1994) argued, on morphological terms, that the Pygmy Marmoset should correctly be included in the genus Callithrix. This was not maintained in Rosenberger et al. (1990), although Barroso (1995), Barroso et al. (1997), Moreira et al. (1996), Schneider et al. (1996), Schneider and Rosenberger (1996), Tagliaro et al. (1997), Porter et al. (1997a), and Canavez et al. (1999a) also argued for this arrangement on the basis of molecular genetics. The argument that Cebuella should be included in the genus Callithrix centres on the conclusion, from both morphological and genetic studies, that the Pygmy Marmoset is more closely related to the Amazonian marmosets (the argentata group of Hershkovitz [1977]) than the latter are to the Atlantic forest marmosets (the jacchus group of Hershkovitz [1977]). Schneider et al. (1993) and Schneider and Rosenberger (1996) also concluded that their molecular genetic data are compatible with jacchus and pygmaea being congeneric. Groves (2001, 2005) places the species in the genus Callithrix, subgenus Cebuella. Although closely related to the Amazonian marmosets, we believe that Cebuella pygmaea deserves generic status. The species shows very distinct features, unique among the callitrichids, involving not only its diminutive size, but also the tree-gouging specialization not observed to nearly the same extent in its Amazonian sister group.


If Cebuella is maintained as a separate genus, then the group would be paraphyletic unless the argentata group marmosets and the jacchus group marmosets are placed in different genera. This was the option adopted, with the Amazonian marmosets being placed in the genus Mico Lesson, 1840 (see below). This decision was also based on the clear identity of the three genera shown in all morphological and molecular studies available.


In 1940, Lönnberg described the subspecies Cebuella pygmaea niveiventris from Lago Ipixuna, south bank of the Rio Solimões, based on its sharply contrasting whitish chest, belly, and inner surface of arms and legs. The ventral surface of C. p. pygmaea is ochraceous. Cruz Lima (1945) and Napier (1976) also recognized and described the two subspecies. Hershkovitz (1977) argued that the colour of the underparts is individually and locally variable and not justifying the subspecific status of niveiventris. However, Van Roosmalen and Van Roosmalen (1997) presented evidence for the validity of the two subspecies based on field observations and captive specimens of C. p. niveiventris, and confirmed its presence in the interfluvium of the Rios Purus and Madeira.


A phylogenetic study by Boubli et al. (2018), which included the mtDNA cytochrome b gene and a reduced representation genome sequencing approach (ddRADseq) for geographically representative samples from Brazil, showed that the forms pygmaea Spix (from the north of the Solimões-Amazonas) and niveiventris Lönnberg (from the south of the Solimões-Amazonas) were distinct species. Porter et al. (2020) confirmed the conclusions of Garbino et al. (2019) and Boubli et al. (2021) for Ecuador and Peru.
Presbytis canicrus was previously included as a subspecies of P. hosei, but it is now recognised as a separate species (Roos et al. 2014). This is a monotypic species.

Blue-throated Hillstar, described by Sornoza-Molina et al. (2018), is accepted as a species diagnosable and scorable against O. stolzmanni on the Tobias criteria by its blue vs green throat in male (4); greener, brighter upperparts in male (1); dark greyish vs whitish base colour to chin and throat in female [see Sornoza-Molina et al. (2018) Appendix Figure 11] (1); slightly smaller size, albeit sample sizes are small (1). Monotypic.

Previously regarded as a subspecies of C. largipennis (HBW/BirdLife International 2018) but split following Lopes et al. (2017, 2020). Differs from largipennis by its smaller size (effect size −2.73 for male tails in Lopes et al. [2017: 6, Table 1]; score 2); longer ‘LTTs’ (light tail-tips) (effect size 2.01 for male LTT2 in same source; score 2); totally different habitat (1); totally different voice, with the song a high tittering trill, quite unlike anything on Xeno-canto for largipennis (at least 4). The map in Lopes et al. (2017) shows collecting localities for calcirupicola and diamantinensis that are only 25 km apart. It seems reasonable that this should be considered evidence of parapatry. Differs from C. diamantinensis by its smaller size (effect size −4.02 for male tails in Lopes et al. [2017: 6, Table 1]; score 2), larger white tips to tail (effect size 2.39 for male LTT2 in same source; score 2) and parapatric distribution (3). It is arguable also that the nesting in caves should be scored, but it is not clear that this habit is not shared by diamantinensis. It is worth noting, however, that the limited vocal evidence now available suggests that the voices of the two taxa are very similar. Monotypic.

Edolisoma tenuirostre, E. insperatum, E. nesiotis, E. monacha, E. rostratum, E. meyerii, E. obiense, E. grayi, E. remotum and E. salomonis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina tenuirostris following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hynobius leechi (Borzée and Min 2021).

Some specimens from Brazilian Amazonia were previously confused with both Atelopus pulcher (e.g., Gascon 1989, Zimmerman and Simberloff 1996) and Atelopus spumarius, both of which differ in morphology and advertisement call, and now belong to a separate species, Atelopus manauensis (Jorge et al. 2020).
This species was previously confused with both Atelopus pulcher and Atelopus spumarius (both of which differ in morphology and advertisement call), according to Jorge et al. (2020).

Previously considered a subspecies of C. sulphurea. Collar & Marsden (2014) used the Tobias criteria to evaluate the taxonomic status of the subspecies citrinocristata from Sumba of the Yellow-crested Cockatoo Cacatua sulphurea. They found that it met the criteria (scoring 7) against every other taxon except C. s. parvula, against which it scored only 6 as a result of the latter’s surprisingly long tail (by comparison with other Wallacean yellow-crests). This may have been a case of an overly strict application of the criteria, and the decision was ignored by Eaton et al. (2016) who readily split the ‘Sumba Cockatoo’. With the further disclosure that fledgling citrinocristata have black bills and fledgling sulphurea of all known forms have pale bills, we have further evidence of a distinction between Sumba birds and the others, we reverse the decision in Collar & Marsden (2014) to keep citrinocristata lumped and now regard it as a full species. Monotypic.

authority: Melo-Sampaio, Prates, Peloso, Recoder, Vechio, Marques-Souza & Rodrigues, 2020

taxonomicNotes: Previously split by del Hoyo & Collar (2016) into three species, Black-winged Myna A. melanopterus in most of Java except the far east, Grey-backed Myna A. tricolor in far eastern Java and Grey-rumped Myna A. tertius on Bali. However, genetic analysis by Sadanandan et al. (2020) established that these taxa are very weakly distinguishable genetically, and that the darker coloration of tertius may be due to introgression from Javan Myna A. javanicus. Their recommendation to lump the three species is accepted here. Sometimes placed in genus Sturnus, but appears behaviourally and vocally closer to present genus. Three subspecies recognised. Prior to the 2016, this concept, including the three subspecies as detailed above, was recognised following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Although, Correa et al. (2017) synonymized Eupsophus altor with E. migueli extending the range of E. migueli south to the Lingue River, Suárez-Villota et al. (2018) hypothesized that both are good species restoring the previous taxonomic arrangement. The taxonomic criteria used by Cuevas and Sanhueza (2020) agrees with the results obtained by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018), recognizing this taxon as a specific taxonomic unit different from E. altor.

Eupsophus queulensis was synonymized with E. septentrionalis by Blotto et al. (2013). Correa-Quezada et al. (2017) then placed E. septentrionalis in synonymy with E. roseus, but the more recent proposal by Suárez-Villota et al. (2018) restored the previous taxonomy, resurrecting E. septentrionalis as a valid species.

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.
Rhinolophus hilli has been recognized as a distinct species (Fahr et al. 2002, Simmons and Cirranello 2021).

Rhinolophus hillorum was originally recognized as a subspecies of R. clivosus in 1989 (Koopman 1989) and was elevated to species-level in 2002 (Cotterill 2002). There are at least two questionable records from Sudan and another from Sapoba Forest Reserve in Nigeria that are not included in this assessment. While the specimen from Sudan has characteristics similar to R. hillorum (Fahr 2013), it was reported as R. clivosus keniensis (Koopman 1975). The specimen from Sapoba Forest Reserve (Fedden and Macleod, 1986 – as R. clivosus) is from a lowland habitat almost 400 km away from the nearest mountain range, leading to calls for re-examination (Fahr 2013). Upon re-examination, the Sapoba specimen, it was re-assigned to R. cf. hillorum as it separated in a PCA of craniodental characteristics from other six specimens collected from Cross River National Park, Nigeria (Tanshi et al. 2021).
Clanga clanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.

This taxon was classified as a subspecies of the Phayre’s Langur (Trachypithecus phayrei). Genetic data suggest that this species is a product of ancient hybridisation between the ancestors of the francoisi- and the obscurus-group (Liedigk et al. 2009). More recent genetic studies indicate that the genetic material acquired from the obscurus-group is specifically from the Tenasserim Langur (T. barbei) and not from T. phayrei (Roos, unpubl.).

There is some geographic variation. Individuals from the northeastern part of the distribution tend to be darker, particularly on the limbs and tail.

Although it is now accepted as a valid species (T. crepuscula), the taxon is still listed as a subspecies on The IUCN Red list because the revised taxonomic concept of T. phayrei has not yet been assessed by the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group.

Three elephant taxa remain from the sixteen elephant-like species that are known from across the planet in the Pleistocene: Asian Elephant (Elephas maximus), African Savanna Elephant (Loxodonta africana), and African Forest Elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis) (Faurby and Svenning 2015, Malhi et al. 2016). The Asian and African ancestral lineages diverged approximately seven million years ago, and the African Savanna and African Forest ancestral lineages began diverging approximately one million years later (Rohland et al. 2010, Brandt et al. 2014, Roca et al. 2015, Meyer et al. 2017, Palkopoulou et al. 2018). The Third Edition of ‘Mammal Species of the World’ (Wilson and Reeder 2005) was the first to formally designate the African elephant as these two separate species. Recent genetic findings also support this designation (Roca et al. 2007, Ishida et al. 2011, Mondol et al. 2015, Palkopoulou et al. 2018, Kim and Wasser 2019). Hybridization between the two species appears restricted and evident at only 14 of the more than 100 localities recently examined across the vast forest-savanna ecotone. In nine of these 14 localities, hybrid individuals occurred alongside non-hybrid individuals of either one species or the other and not both (i.e., three localities had hybrids and African Forest Elephants only and assigned as this species; six localities had hybrids and African Savanna Elephants only and assigned as this species). For the IUCN Red List assessments, a distribution map published in Mondol et al. (2015) and recent data by Kim and Wasser (2019) are used to assign localities as range of either L. africana or L. cyclotis.

authority: Neira-Salamea, Ofori-Boateng, Kouamé, Blackburn, Segniagbeto, Hillers, Barej, Leaché & Rödel, 2021

taxonomicNotes: Gyps rueppelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as G. rueppellii.
This is a split from the broader concept of Litoria littlejohni (Mahony et al. 2020).
Proposed subspecies pileatus differs only in size, which varies clinally, increasing from small in W to large in E and S; no longer recognised (Barlow et al. 2020). Monotypic.
Chlamydotis undulata and C. macqueenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. undulata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Bubo scandiacus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as B. scandiaca.
Fringilla teydea and F. polatzeki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. teydea following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Presbytis percura was described by M.W. Lyon, Jr. in 1908 based on specimens collected from near Siak Kecil River, Makapan, Kompei, Pulau Rupat, and Salat Rupat (Lyon 1908). It was later regarded as a subspecies of P. femoralis, along with P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni (Groves 2001, Meyer et al. 2011, Groves and Roos 2013, Roos et al. 2014). However, genetic data suggested that at least P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni were different species (Ang 2010, Nijman 2019) which was also in agreement with their morphological characters.

Resolving all subspecies-level boundaries within banded langurs required data for P. f. percura, which was the least studied among the three taxa and only found in the Riau Province in Sumatra (Rizaldi et al. 2019). Complete mitochondrial genomes were later obtained for P. f. percura in the wild, and based on multiple species delimitation algorithms (PTP, ABGD, Objective Clustering) applied to a dataset covering 40 species and 43 subspecies of Asian colobines, all three subspecies of banded langurs were resurrected to species (Ang et al. 2020).

Presbytis percura is mainly blackish above, with a grey head and a white underside (Lyon 1908, Aimi and Bakar 1992). White underside is narrow but extends horizontally across chest, down inner sides of limbs in thin stripes to wrists and ankles, and to cheeks and chin. The tail is black and not bicolour, but part of the ventral surface of the basal third of the tail is indistinctly white. Its throat and face are grey, and there are narrow, pale eye-rings. One (sometimes two) whorls are set well back on its crown. Hairs on the chest are directed backward.

The foetuses are white with a black stripe from the head to the tail, intersected by another black stripe along the outer surfaces of both forearms, forming a distinctive cruciform (cross-like) black pattern on the dorsum.

Macaca leucogenys was first described by Li et al. (2015) based on photos captured by camera traps, and its full species status was confirmed based on DNA extracted from skin specimens (Fan et al. 2017).

Macaca leucogenys is distinguished from all potential sympatric macaque species (M. mulatta, M. thibetana, M. assamensis, and M. munzala) based on a suite of pelage characteristics including relatively uniform dorsal hair pattern, hairy ventral pelage, relatively hairless short tail, prominent pale to white side- and chin-whiskers creating a white cheek and round facial appearance, dark facial skin on the muzzle, long and thick hairs on its neck, and a round rather than arrow-shaped male genitalia.

Re-evaluated and re-established as a valid taxon by Dandelot and Prévost (1972) and recorded from the Bale Mountains National Park by Carpaneto and Gippoliti (1994). Listed by Grubb et al. (2003) as a subspecies of grivet Chlorocebus aethiops, but here treated as a species following Pocock (1907), Elliot (1913), Lernould (1988), Yalden et al. (1996), Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013). Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) include this taxon in Chlorocebus, in contrast to Grubb et al. (2003) who retained it in Cercopithecus. Taxonomic history reviewed in Butynski et al. (2013). Two subspecies are recognised here: djam-djam monkey C. d. djamdjamensis and Bale Mountains monkey C. d. harennaensis.

Mekonnen et al. (2018c) found two distinct mitochondrial DNA clusters within C. djamdjamensis, one in the Bale Mountains and one in forest fragments in the Sidamo Highlands, central southern Ethiopia. These authors confirm hybridization with C. aethiops and report one phenotypic C. djamdjamensis x vervet C. pygerythrus hybrid. They also indicate that gene flow between C. djamdjamensis in the Bale Mountains and in the Sidamo Highlands is uncommon.

In 2020, Gippoliti proposed the name ‘C. djamdjamensis harennaensis’ for the form in Harenna Forest, Bale Mountains. As the Bale Mountains and Sidamo Highland populations demonstrate strong genetic differentiation (Mekonnen et al. 2018c), and differ phenotypically (Mekonnen et al. 2012), ecologically, behaviourally (Mekonnen et al. 2017, 2018a,b), and in gut microbiota (Trosvik et al. 2018), we provisionally recognise C. d. djamdjamensis and C. d. harennaensis. Further studies are required to better understand the genetic and morphological diversity, phylogenetics, and evolutionary history within C. djamdjamensis.

This taxon was considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang but elevated by Groves and Maryanto (2008). This is further supported by morphological studies by Nekaris and Jaffe (2007) and Nekaris and Munds (2010) and genetic studies by Roos (2003) and Wirdateti et al. (2006). Two distinct forms regularly occur in bird markets and further research is needed (Nekaris and Jaffe 2007). Care should be taken in taxonomic studies however due to translocation of individuals from markets into forests and gardens throughout the island (Schulze and Groves 2004). The distinct black and white long-haired appearance of subadults and juveniles also might be mistaken as separate species, for example, in museum specimens or from photos only (KA. Nekaris et al. pers. comm. 2012).
Phapitreron amethystinus, P. maculipectus and P. frontalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. amethystinus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The taxonomy of Cacajao was reviewed by Hershkovitz (1987), who recognised four subspecies of bald-headed uakaris: Cacajao calvus calvus; C. c. rubicundus; C. c novaesi; and C. c. ucayalii.  Based on new information on the geographic distribution, molecular phylogenetic analyses, and the examination of museum specimens, the four subspecies recognised by Hershkovitz (1987) were raised to the species level – therefore, Cacajao calvus, C. rubicundus, C. novaesi, and C. ucayalii (Silva et al., 2022). The population of white uakaris from the Tarauacá river basin, in Brazil, was described as a new species: Cacajao amuna. Therefore, five species of bald-headed uakaris are currently recognized (Silva et al., 2022).

Four species of Lion Tamarins are recognized. Coimbra-Filho (1990) suggested that Leontopithecus caissara was a subspecies, or colour variant of L. chrysopygus. Burity et al. (1999) and Perez-Sweeney et al. (2008) concluded that this was not so, and that L. caissara is a valid species. Perez-Sweeney et al. (2008) concluded that there are three unambiguous clades revealed by phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA control region sequences: Leontopithecus chysomelas, L. caissara and L. chrysopygus/L. rosalia. According to these authors, L. chysomelas occupies a basal phylogenetic position. Here we follow the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012).

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) marcai. The species was described only from three specimens in the Museu Nacional, Rio de Janeiro, and was not recorded in the wild until 2012. Until then it was only known from the type locality, “Foz do Rio Castanho (= Rio Roosevelt), left influx into Rio Aripuanã, Amazonas State, Brasil” (Alperin 1993, 2002). Silva et al. 2014 reported the rediscovery of the species in the confluence of Roosevelt and Aripuanã Rivers. Garbino (2014) described the resemblance of the pelage pattern between M. manicorensis and M. marcai and proposed M. manicorensis as a junior synonymous of M. marcai. Silva et al. (in prep.) are reassessing the taxonomic status of the marmosets from Aripuanã and Madeira/Ji-paraná interfluve based on molecular and morphological analysis.

Andersen (1908, 1912) originally described Pteropus pelewensis of Palau and Pteropus yapensis of Yap as distinct species. They were subsumed as subspecies of P. mariannus by Kuroda (1938) and treated as such for a number of decades (e.g., Mickleburgh et al. 1992, Koopman 1993, Wiles 2005). Flannery (1995) was among the first to reclassify both as separate species, but did so without providing supporting evidence. This treatment was provisionally followed by Simmons (2005). Recent genetic analyses have confirmed P. pelewensis and P. yapensis as distinct from P. mariannus (Brown et al. 2011, Almeida et al. 2014), with Almeida et al. (2014) regarding P. pelewensis and P. yapensis as conspecific under the name P. pelewensis and recognizing the two taxa as different subspecies: P. p. pelewensis and P. p. yapensis.

Additionally, Almeida et al. (2014) combined a formerly recognized subspecies, P. mariannus ulthiensis from Ulithi Atoll 160 km east of Yap, with P. p. yapensis based presumably on the physical similarity of the two taxa, but did not offer rationale for this determination.

Traditionally treated as a subspecies of P. bicalcaratum, but differs in size and morphology. Male katsumatae differ from males of other taxa in P. bicalcaratum in their smaller size (effect size on wing 8.57, score 3); brilliant red and more extensive vs dirty grey to pale yellow and less extensive facial skin (3); green vs purplish ocelli, with a somewhat different shape (2); lack of elongate crown feathers (1); darker crown (1); more densely and neatly vermiculated body plumage (ns1); browner vs greyer overall coloration (ns1) (Collar 2009, Davison et al. 2012, Pilgrim et al. 2009). Iris colour may also be a character, and the taxa are in fact not each other’s closest relatives, bicalcaratum being sister to P. chalcurum with P. inopinatum sister to this pair (Chang Jiang et al. 2008, Davison et al. 2012). Monotypic.

Speybroeck et al. (2020) summarised the results of phylogenetic and taxonomic work investigating the Vipera ursinii over the preceding decade. They concluded that Vipera renardi and V. graeca warrant continued recognition as valid species following Ferchaud et al. (2012) and Mizsei et al. (2017) respectively. Conversely, they concluded that Vipera lotievi and - through inference based on its similarity to V. lotievi, as genetic data were unavailable - V. shemakhensis should be regarded as junior synonyms of V. ursinii. Subsequently Freitas et al. (2020) found that V. shemakhensis exhibited little genetic divergence from V. eriwanensis.

The species has four presently recognised subspecies one of which - V. u. moldavica - includes Danube Delta populations assigned by some authors to a dubious subspecies of Vipera renardi (Speybroeck et al. 2016).

Passer domesticus and P. italiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. domesticus following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Christidis and Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977–1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996); Turbott (1990).

Previously listed as Turdinus calcicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but Cai et al. (2019) found it more closely related to Malacocincla and revived the genus Gypsophila for this and allied species. Formerly treated as conspecific with G. crispifrons following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), but differs in its tawny central belly with white shaft streaks vs grey belly with white-and-dark-brown streaks (3); smaller, more organized black arrowheads on white throat (1); paler upperparts, wings and flanks (1); shorter wing (mean of 3 males 73.7 mm vs 15 male nominate 78.6; mean of 2 females 69 vs 15 female nominate 77.5; at least 1); song a short (0.7–1.5 s) phrase of 3–6 notes vs a much more protracted (4–30 s) phrase of at least 16 notes, commonly many more (at least 2) (Boesman 2016). Monotypic.
Lophura erythrophthalma and L. pyronota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. erythrophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was described by Hernández et al. (2000), but the name first appeared in Barbadillo et al. (1999) and this is therefore the correct authority.

authority: Lymberakis, Poulakakis, Kaliontzopoulou, Valakos and Mylonas, 2008

taxonomicNotes: The Vipera ursinii species complex has a large distribution area from eastern France to western China, which was shaped by the last three glacial periods (Ferchaud et al. 2012). In the last two decades some V. ursinii subspecies have been elevated to distinct species level based on molecular and morphological analyses (V. renardi, V. anatolica, and V. eriwanensis). The Greek Meadow Viper (Vipera ursinii graeca) was described as a subspecies of Vipera ursinii by Nilson and Andrén (1988) based on morphological analyses. Ferchaud et al. (2012) proposed that V. u. graeca should be elevated to species level, according to the results of mitochondrial DNA phylogenetic analyses. Based on a mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analyses Mizsei et al. (2017) provided further support for this arrangement in an analysis of combined mitochondrial and nuclear DNA, recognising it as a full species Vipera graeca in order to resolve polyphyly in the Vipera ursinii–renardi complex.
Carpococcyx radiceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as C. radiatus.

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylax shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is distinct from P. lessonae. The species belongs to “lessonae” group and it is sister species to P. lessonae - based on mtDNA and ND3 sequences, 1378 b.p. (Plötner et al. 2012).

This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).
Myotis lucifugus does not include occultus. This species hybridizes with M. yumanensis in some areas; see Parkinson (1979). Apparently it is closely related to M. thysanodes.
Struthio camelus and S. molybdophanes (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. camelus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poodytes punctatus and P. caudatus (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as Bowdleria punctata following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).
Pternistis camerunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.

Rice’s Whale (Balaenoptera ricei) is a distinct evolutionary lineage closely related to Eden’s Whale (Balaenoptera edeni edeni), Bryde’s Whale (B. e. brydei) and Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) (Rosel et al. 2021). Previously considered an undescribed subspecies of Balaenoptera edeni and referred to as the Gulf of Mexico Whale or the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s Whale, a recent morphological study of Rice’s Whale has revealed diagnostic differences in the shape and size of bones in the skull in comparison to the two subspecies of B. edeni. This morphological evidence reinforced earlier findings of significant genetic divergence and fixed DNA differences found in several mitochondrial DNA genes; together, these data supported the description of the new species B. ricei. With elevation of Rice’s Whale to species status, there is still uncertainty as to whether Eden’s Whale and Bryde’s Whale, each of which is clearly distinct, represent subspecies of B. edeni or full species.
Chlamydotis undulata and C. macqueenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. undulata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mirafra africana and M. sharpii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. africana following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Athene jacquinoti, A. granti, A. malaitae and A. roseoaxillaris (HBW and BirdLife International 2024) were previously included within Ninox (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), prior to which all were considered conspecific with N. jacquinoti following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). They were moved to the present genus on the basis of molecular studies (Gwee et al. 2017; Salter et al. 2020). Differs from N. granti in its smaller size (allow 1); dark vs pale eyes (3); much darker underparts with finer barring (3); rufous-buff spotting on upperparts (2); probably deeper voice (ns). Monotypic.
Thryophilus sernai (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Lara et al. (2012).

authority: Chaves-Portilla, Salazar, Gil-Acero, Dorado-Correa, Márquez, Rueda-Almonacid & Amézquita, 2021

taxonomicNotes: Todiramphus veneratus and T. youngi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. veneratus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Sometimes placed in genus Dryolimnas. Closely related to L. mirifica and L. pectoralis; on occasion regarded as subspecies of L. pectoralis, but differs in its much smaller wing (score estimated at 3); much reduced streaking on crown and hindneck (2); upperparts with sparser, narrower streaking (1); barring on upperwing-coverts reduced (1). Monotypic.
Artisornis moreaui and A. sousae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. moreaui following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
The distribution of Emballonura serii comprises five widely separated islands, with unknown taxonomic relationships. It was split from Emballonura furax (Flannery 1994).

Rhinolophus montanus was originally described as a subspecies of philippinensis (Goodwin 1979), but was recently elevated to species status (Csorba 2002). This taxonomy is generally accepted and followed (Csorba et al. 2003, Simmons 2005).

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Chaerephon jobensis (Felten 1964, Hill 1983) but has been recognised as a distinct species since its treatment by Flannery (1995). The taxonomy is considered stable (Simmons 2005) despite the absence of full taxonomic enquiry.

Woodman (1993) notes that many mammalian generic names ending in -otis use the wrong gender for specific names. If this advice is to be followed, the species name should be M. pruinosa. The Chiroptera SG advise keeping the names as they are for now while a decision is still to be made on these.
This species is closely related to Myotis pruinosus that occurs in mainland Japan (Kawai et al. 2003, Abe et al. 2005).
Aratinga solstitialis and A. maculata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. solstitialis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Has sometimes been thought to be closely related to S. serinus, S. canaria and S. canicollis, but recent DNA analyses recovered this species as sister to S. pusillus (Zuccon et al. 2012). Monotypic.

Pteropus ennisae is considered a distinct species from P. capistratus following Almeida et al. (2014), based on a 4.7% sequence divergence in cytochrome-b and the species differs morphologically, having less distinct facial markings than P. capistratus (Flannery and White 1991, Flannery 1995, Bonaccorso 1998, Almeida et al. 2014, Lavery 2019).
Xanthomixis apperti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bernieria apperti.
Rhabdotorrhinus exarhatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Penelopides.

Trichoglossus haematodus, T. forsteni, T. capistratus, T. weberi, T. rubritorquis, T. moluccanus and T. rosenbergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. haematodus following Christidis and Boles (1994), and before then were split as T. haematodus and T. rubritorquis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cercopithecus dryas is one of Africa’s least known and most enigmatic monkeys. Its nomenclature has been disputed, and its phylogenetic affinities are uncertain. The type specimen, the skull and skin of a captive juvenile male from the early 1930s, is from an unknown source population in central Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), most likely in the Lomela region in what is currently Sankuru Province (Schwarz 1932). The species was not reported again until 1977, when Kano and Kuroda acquired two hunter-killed animals in the Wamba research area 300 km north of Lomela town (Kuroda et al. 1985). One of these animals became the type specimen for a new species: Cercopithecus salongo Thys van den Audenaerde 1977. Subsequent re-examination of the C. dryas type and Wamba specimen indicated that these represented the same species with age-related differences in colouration, thus sinking salongo into dryas (Colyn et al. 1991). Sarmiento (2002) disputed this assessment. However, the current treatment follows Groves (2001, 2005), Grubb et al. (2003), Butynski (2013), and Healy (2013) in accepting the synonymy of the two forms. Following the collections by Kano and Kuroda, C. dryas was confirmed in the Kokolopori area to the east of Wamba (Lokasola 2008). Lokasola (2008) suggests that Kano and Kuroda’s 1977 specimen likely came from this same population.

In 2014, the species reappeared again, 400 km southeast of Kokolopori/Wamba near Bafundo, in Maniema Province, less than 15 km west of the Congo (Lualaba) River. Field staff from the Lukuru Foundation’s TL2 Project collected photos of a fresh hunter-killed adult female and later collected a hunter-killed adult male from this same area (Hart 2014). Subsequently, the species was seen at two sites ~31 km west of Bafundo near the Lomami River, and two sites ~75 km west of the city of Kindu (Alempijevic et al. 2018). Both sexes of the Lomami-Lualaba interfluve population are characterized by striking rufous cheeks and upper ventrum, a feature not mentioned in the published descriptions of C. dryas sensu lato, as all publications describe specimens with white- or cream-coloured facial hairs and ventrum (Schwarz 1932, Thys van den Audenaerde 1977, Kuroda et al. 1985). Nevertheless, a photo of a monkey taken in 2011 at Iyondji in the Kokolopori/Wamba region by R. Mittermeier clearly shows these animals have rufous cheeks. Subsequently, S. Kuroda (comment posted online in 2016 in Hart 2014) confirmed that his 1977 Wamba specimens looked like the Bafundo animals. Tail colouration, in particular the shape and location of the triangular dark grey ventral patch at the base of the tail, in both sexes, has also been a source of confusion (e.g. C. dryas illustration, Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).
