The prominent blue perineum and scrotum in adult males (Hart 2014) has not been mentioned in previous published accounts of the species, but this feature likely fades in death, as in C. lomamiensis, and may not be evident in all hunter-killed animals and dry museum skins (Hart et al. 2012). Additional field surveys and population genetics studies are needed to assess the level of variation present among known populations, as this monkey occurs in very small, widely-separated populations over a very large area, and with no evident contact between them.

Cercopithecus dryas is currently assigned to its own species group, the Cercopithecus dryas-group (Groves 2001, Butynski 2002), where it is the smallest species within the genus Cercopithecus (Butynski 2013). However, recent phylogenetic analyses based on the mitochondrial genome of the type specimen (finger tip) show C. dryas clustering within the genus Chlorocebus (Guschanski et al. 2013). Groves suggested possible affinities between C. dryas and Chlorocebus after initial assessment of the skin and skull of the type specimen (1972 pers. comm. cited in Thys van den Audenaerde 1977), however he later concluded that C. dryas is a distinct species within the genus Cercopithecus based on the cranial morphology of the type specimen and a photograph of an adult skull in Kuroda et al. (1985).

A study of the morphology by Gilbert et al. (2021) confirmed the results of Guschanski et al. (2013) in treating the dryas monkey as a member of the genus Chlorocebus, not Cercopithecus (as per Groves 2001). Note also that the phylogenomic study of Guschanski et al. (2013) placed Allochrocebus solatus (Harrison, 1988) of Gabon as basal to the Chlorocebus clade.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii that included as subspecies parmentierorum, bouvieri, tholloni, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, lulindicus, langi, foai and semlikiensis (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) considered bouvieri and epieni to be subspecies of pennantii; Grubb et al. (2003) likewise, and also included preussi.

With the revisions and reviews of sportive lemurs located in northwestern Madagascar between 2006 and 2007, the distribution of Lepilemur dorsalis and other sportive lemurs in this region remained uncertain. Zinner et al. (2007) showed that the three teams that described new Lepilemur species in 2006 and 2007, Andriaholinirina et al. (2006), Louis et al. (2006) and Craul et al. (2007) had each submitted three alternative concepts of the holotype locality for L. dorsalis and that the validity of L. tymerlachsoni and L. mittermeieri depended on which concept turned out to be correct. The type locality of Lepilemur dorsalis was thought to be either Mourountsang (=Anorontsangana, 13°55’S, 47°55’E) or Passandava (=Ampasindava, about 13°40’S, 48°15’E). If the former was correct, then L. tymerlachsonorum is a synonym of L. dorsalis and L. mittermeieri is valid; and if the latter, then L. mittermeieri is the synonym and L. tymerlachsoni is valid. The species found at Nosy Bé is also found on Anorontsangana (Zinner et al. 2007). Further, the holotype L. grandidieri (Forsyth Major 1894) was attributed to a specimen from northern Madagascar, which may prove to be a senior synonym of one of the species described in 2006/2007. Therefore, it was recommended that as a priority research and conservation study, genetic material from the holotypes for L. dorsalis and L. grandidieri be acquired and comparable sequence data generated to determine the taxonomy and distribution of L. dorsalis and the other sportive lemurs of north-west Madagascar.

Recent phylogenetic studies by Roos et al. (2021) confirmed that L. mittermeieri and L. grandidieri Forsyth Major, 1894, are both junior synonyms of L. dorsalis Gray, 1871. The authors sequenced the complete mitochondrial genomes of the L. dorsalis and L. grandidieri (currently recognized as a synonym of L. dorsalis) type specimens and compared the sequences with those of samples with known provenance from the different Inter-River Systems (IRSs). The two type specimens of L. dorsalis and L. grandidieri are identical and cluster closely with samples collected in IRS V (between the rivers Andranomalaza and Sambirano), indicating that the type locality can be fixed to IRS V. Consequently, L. dorsalis occurs in IRS V, and L. grandidieri and L. mittermeieri are junior synonyms of L. dorsalis.

Blanford (1887) suggested that Simia aygula Linnaeus, 1758 was a langur from Java. Napier and Groves (1983), however, showed that aygula was in fact a crab-eating macaque, and Weitzel and Groves (1985) established the name comata (Desmarest, 1822) instead.

While it is correct that based on pelage characteristics P. comata and P. fredericae can be “strikingly different” (Groves 2001) when considering specimens of P. comata from the westernmost part of their range (e.g., Ujung Kulon, Mts Halimun; entirely white venter and light or medium dark grey overall) and P. fredericae from the easternmost part of its range (Mt Merbabu, Mts Dieng: small amounts of white ventrally and dark grey to black overall), these differences become clinal when intermediate populations are considered. In addition, there is considerable within population variation (Nijman 2001; Nijman, Setiawan & Karyanto, unpubl. data). Hence, based on this, Nijman (1997a) was of the opinion that the differences between the two taxa were clinal. Meyer et al. (2011), comparing 1,800 bp of mitochondrial genes from specimens from Mts Halimun and Mt Slamet, likewise found clear differences between the two, and estimated their divergence at 1.06 (0.63−1.51) million years ago. However, when additional genetic samples were included, albeit of shorter length, these mitochondrial DNA differences suggested a case of Isolation by Distance, whereby populations that are geographically more distant from each other show more genetic differences rather than a two-species arrangement (V. Nijman, unpublished data). Finally, Meyer et al. (2012) found clear differences between the acoustic structure of male loud calls of a wide range of Presbytis species that supported their earlier molecular findings, i.e., species that are genetically different also differ markedly in their vocalisations. Unfortunately, no calls of P. fredericae were included in their study. Nonetheless, Nijman (2001) reported the loud calls of males on Mts Halimun, Mt Salak, Mt Gede-Pangrango, Mt Sawal (all within the putative range of P. comata) to be qualitatively similar to those on Mt Slamet, Mts Dieng and Mt Lawu (all part of the putative range of P. fredericae). Bartels (1937), who had observed and heard P. comata calls from throughout western Java, i.e., throughout the putative range of P. comata, noted that when hearing the calls of P. fredericae from Mt Slamet, these were immediately recognisable as possibly a subspecies of P. comata, again suggesting limited differences in vocalisations between the two taxa. Finally, Geissmann et al. (2007) compared 40 vocal characters of the male loud calls of P. comata from Mt Pancar (north of Mt Gede-Pangrango) with those of P. fredericae from Mts Dieng and found minimal differences, leading them to conclude that, in light of their vocal data, a two-species arrangement appeared unlikely.

While P. comata and P. fredericae are treated here as two separate species, further research (morphological, behavioural and molecular) is urgently needed to clarify their taxonomic arrangement. For now, the main basis of grouping populations in either P. comata or P. fredericae is based on pelage characteristics. Given that these are variable within populations (amount of white, amount of black or dark grey, black or grey of arms and legs), the boundary between these two species has to be drawn somewhat arbitrarily. We here present two scenarios, one whereby population in the easternmost part of the province of West Java (Mt Ciremay, Kuningan) and the westernmost part of the province of Central Java (Mts Pembarisan) are included in P. comata and one whereby these are included in P. fredericae (we refer to this area as Ciremay-Kuningan-Pembarisan, acknowledging that other forest areas to the south may have to be included as well).

While it is correct that based on pelage characteristics P. comata and P. fredericae can be “strikingly different” (Groves 2001) when considering specimens of P. comata from the westernmost part of their range (e.g., Ujung Kulon, Mts Halimun; entirely white venter and light or medium dark grey overall) and P. fredericae from the easternmost part of its range (Mt Merbabu, Mts Dieng: small amounts of white ventrally and dark grey to black overall), these differences become clinal when intermediate populations are considered. In addition, there is considerable within-population variation (Nijman 2001; Nijman, Setiawan & Karyanto, unpubl. data). Hence, based on this, Nijman (1997a) was of the opinion that the differences between the two taxa were clinal. Meyer et al. (2011), comparing 1,800 bp of mitochondrial genes from specimens from Mts Halimun and Mt Slamet, likewise found clear differences between the two, and estimated their divergence at 1.06 (0.63−1.51) million years ago. However, when additional genetic samples were included, albeit of shorter length, these mitochondrial DNA differences suggested a case of Isolation by Distance, whereby populations that are geographically more distant from each other show more genetic differences rather than a two-species arrangement (V. Nijman, unpublished data). Finally, Meyer et al. (2012) found clear differences between the acoustic structure of male loud calls of a wide range of Presbytis species that supported their earlier molecular findings, i.e., species that are genetically different also differ markedly in their vocalisations. Unfortunately, no calls of P. fredericae were included in their study. Nonetheless, Nijman (2001) reported the loud calls of males on Mts Halimun, Mt Salak, Mt Gede-Pangrango, Mt Sawal (all within the putative range of P. comata) to be qualitatively similar to those on Mt Slamet, Mts Dieng and Mt Lawu (all part of the putative range of P. fredericae). Bartels (1937), who had observed and heard P. comata calls from throughout western Java, i.e., throughout the putative range of P. comata, noted that when hearing the calls of P. fredericae from Mt Slamet, these were immediately recognisable as possibly a subspecies of P. comata, again suggesting limited differences in vocalisations between the two taxa. Finally, Geissmann et al. (2007) compared 40 vocal characters of the male loud calls of P. comata from Mt Pancar (north of Mt Gede-Pangrango) with those of P. fredericae from Mts Dieng and found minimal differences, leading them to conclude that, in light of their vocal data, a two-species arrangement appeared unlikely.

While P. comata and P. fredericae are treated here as two separate species, further research (morphological, behavioural and molecular) is urgently needed to clarify their taxonomic arrangement. For now, the main basis of grouping populations in either P. comata or P. fredericae is based on pelage characteristics. Given that these are variable within populations (amount of white, amount of black or dark grey, black or grey of arms and legs), the boundary between these two species has to be drawn somewhat arbitrarily. We here present two scenarios, one whereby population in the easternmost part of the province of West Java (Mt Ciremay, Kuningan) and the westernmost part of the province of Central Java (Mts Pembarisan) are included in P. comata and one whereby these are included in P. fredericae (we refer to this area as Ciremay-Kuningan-Pembarisan, acknowledging that other forest areas to the south may have to be included as well).

Until recently, Trachypithecus margarita was included in T. germaini. Genetic data (mtDNA studies) and phenotypical characters supports separate species status, though additional study will be needed for confirmation, since the study was based on a few samples from Cambodia and Viet Nam (including samples from animals of unknown origin) and no samples from Lao PDR (Roos et al., 2008). It is considered to be part of the cristatus group (T. cristatus, T. auratus, T. mauritus, T. germaini and T. selangorensis) (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012, Nadler and Brockman 2014, Nadler et al. 2005, Roos et al. 2008).

The taxonomy of Cacajao was reviewed by Hershkovitz (1987), who recognised four subspecies of bald-headed uakaris: Cacajao calvus calvus; C. c. rubicundus; C. c novaesi; and C. c. ucayalii.  Based on new information on the geographic distribution, molecular phylogenetics analyses, and the examination of museum specimens, the four subspecies recognised by Hershkovitz (1987) were raised to the species level – therefore, Cacajao calvus, C. rubicundus, C. novaesi, and C. ucayalii. The population of white uakaris from the Tarauacá river basin, in Brazil, was described as a new species: Cacajao amuna (Silva et al., 2021). Therefore, five species of bald-headed uakaris are currently recognized.
Apparently closest to S. speluncae (Bornschein et al. 1998) (which see) and S. gonzagai. Monotypic.

Three genetically distinct subpopulations of this species occur in the Brazilian states of Sergipe, Bahia, Espírito Santo and Rio de Janeiro (Moraes-Barros et al. 2002, 2006; Lara-Ruiz et al. 2008). The northern (in southern Bahia and Sergipe) and southern subpopulations (Espírito Santo and Rio de Janeiro) should be considered distinct evolutionary units (Lara-Ruiz et al. 2008, Schetino et al. 2017), although indistinguishable from the others in external morphology (A. Chiarello pers. comm. 2010). A recently published study (Miranda et al. 2022) proposes to split the species into Bradypus torquatus (Bahia and Sergipe) and Bradypus crinitus (Rio de Janeiro and Espirito Santos).

The Maned Sloth was occasionally classified as a subgenus of Bradypus or placed in his own genus, Scaeopus (Hayssen 2009, Wetzel and Ávila-Pires 1980) due to its morphological distinctiveness. A growing number of molecular studies supports this differentiation (Gibb et al. 2016, Schetino et al. 2017, Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2020), but additional studies are needed to confirm this.
Bradypus pygmaeus has only recently been described by Anderson and Handley (2001) as a separate species.

Zanda baudinii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Calyptorhynchus. Original note from Illustrated Checklists: Closely related to Z. funerea and Z. latirostris. Long considered conspecific with latter, but currently treated as separate species because ecology quite different, and bill significantly longer; difficulty in field identification, compounded by long history of conspecific treatment, has led to uncertainty regarding limits of range in area of overlap, and to publication of some inaccurate maps. Present species has also, on occasion, been lumped in Z. funerea. Confusion over bill size of specimen used in original description led to proposal of subspecies tenuirostris, but this name shown to be synonymous with baudinii (Schodde and Mason 1997). Monotypic.
Monotypic.

There is marked genetic differentiation between populations on central and eastern islands in the archipelago, indicating that they have evolved in relative isolation for a long time (Salgueiro et al. 2004).
Unidentified Pipistrellus bats found in the Azores have recently been proposed to belong to this species, but this awaits confirmation.
Identified as a new species by genetic analyses, this species combines morphological features of both P. austriacus and P. auritus.

Here we refer to P. teneriffae as the population of the Canary Islands. Northwest African populations previously assigned to P. teneriffae are currently included in P. gaisleri, and Balkan populations are assigned to P. austriacus. The taxonomic status of the species was confirmed by Spitzenberger et al. (2006). There are no significant genetic differences between populations on the islands of the Canary Archipelago where this species is found (Juste et al. 2004).
Cyclopsitta diophthalma and C. coxeni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Nunes, Guimarães, Moura, Pedrozo, Moroti, Castro, Stuginski & Muscat, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Prior to its description, this species was confused with Brachycephalus ephippium (Nunes et al. 2021).

authority: Mahony, Hines, Mahony, Moses, Catalano, Myers & Donnellan, 2021
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Assa darlingtoni (Mahony et al. 2021). The original description also includes some localities for which the identity of specimens are still uncertain. For this assessment they have been kept within Assa darlingtoni.
Lophorina victoriae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ptiloris victoriae.
Lophura erythrophthalma and L. pyronota (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. erythrophthalma following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010

taxonomicNotes:
Gallirallus conditicius (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), known only from the type reputedly collected in the Apiang Group of the Gilbert Islands, Kiribati, in 1861, is not recognised as a separate species but is treated as a synonym of H. sylvestris (Greenway 1952, Olson 1992).


Hypotaenidia sylvestris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Gallirallus.
Psephotellus chrysopterygius (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Psephotus.

Zanda latirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Calyptorhynchus. Original note from Illustrated Checklists: Closely related to Z. funerea and Z. baudinii. Long considered conspecific with latter, mainly on account of identical plumages (Juniper and Parr 1998), but currently treated as separate because present species’ ecology quite different and bill significantly shorter than that of Z. baudinii; difficulty in field identification, compounded by long history of conspecific treatment, has led to uncertainty regarding limits of range in area of overlap, and to publication of some inaccurate maps. Exhaustive analysis of all available specimens of taxa in present genus suggested that latirostris was so similar to South Australian Z. funerea that it might perhaps be treated as subspecies of latter. Monotypic.
Pternistis swierstrai (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.

Zapornia atra (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Porzana. In the past sometimes assigned to monotypic genus Nesophylax. Closely related to Z. tabuensis and Z. monasa. Monotypic.

The type specimens for Felis bieti are mounted skin and skull collected by Prince Henry d’Orleans (~1889) and kept at the National Museum of Natural History, Paris, France. The type locality is described as “Tatsienlu, Central Szechwan” by Milne-Edwards (1892), restricted by Pousargues (1898) to “environ de Tongolo et de Ta-tsien-Lou”, and verified to be Dong E Luo (=Tongolo) Village, Xinduqiao Township, Kangding (=Tatsienlu or Tatsienlou) County, Garzê Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan, China.

Three subspecies were once proposed, but two were considered misidentifications, therefore, the Chinese Mountain Cat is currently considered monotypic.
  • Felis bieti bieti Milne-Edwards, 1892, the nominate subspecies distributed in E Qinghai, NW Sichuan, and Gansu, (includes pallida Buchner, 1892, Kweito and S Tatung Mts, Kansu = Guide and Datongshan range, E Qinghai; and subpallida Jacobi, 1923, Songpan, NW Sichuan);
  • F. b. vellerosa Pocock, 1943; type locality near Yulinfu (=Yulin) on the borders of Ordos (Inner Mongolia) and N Shaanxi; also named the Ordos Cat, but suggested by Haltenorth 1953 as F. silvestris, and by Groves 1980 as F. catus; and
  • F. b. chutuchta Birula, 1917; no type locality, possibly around the Goizso area of the Gobi Desert in Inner Mongolia or NW Ningxia; also named the Gobi Cat, synonym with F. bieti by Allen (1938), Pocock (1943, 1951), but suggested by Haltenorth (1953) and Groves (1980) as F. silvestris.
The taxonomy of the species in relation to other wildcat taxa has not reached a unanimous agreement, though molecular phylogeny and population genetics are revealing a much clearer evolutionary and systematic pattern. The Chinese Mountain Cat has traditionally been considered a species (F. bieti). However, Haltenorth (1953) and Corbet (1978) stated that, once more specimens became available, analysis would show the Chinese Mountain Cat to be a subspecies of Felis silvestris. Driscoll et al. (2007) provided genetic evidence to indicate F. bieti to be a subspecies of F. silvestris, whilst Kitchener et al. (2009, 2017) attributed its species status again, based on morphological distinction and its potential sympatry with the Asiatic wildcat (F. s. ornata). Most recently, Yu et al. (2021) conducted a genome-wide analysis to render support of the Chinese Mountain Cat as equidistant with the Asiatic wildcat, and hence should be recognized as a wildcat subspecies, F. s. bieti. This study was based on whole genome sequencing and uniparentally inherited mitochondrial genome and Y-chromosome haplotypes of the Chinese Mountain Cat, Asiatic wildcat, and domestic cats, together with publicly available partial genomic data.

Yu et al. (2021) calculated the coalescence time of F. s. catus, F. s. bieti, and F. s. ornata at around 1.5 million years ago during the Middle Pleistocene, results consistent with estimations from Li et al. (2016) and Johnson et al. (2006). Given the relatively deep divergence of the wildcat taxa, Yu et al. (2021) also proposed an alternative approach to resolve the conflict between the genomic pattern and current taxonomic nomenclature, which is to elevate all wildcat lineages, including the Asiatic wildcat (F. s. ornata) and African wildcat (F. s. lybica), to independent species, or F. ornata and F. lybica, respectively, thus retaining the Chinese Mountain Cat as F. bieti to be consistent. This proposition would however require a comprehensive analysis of whole genome data from all wildcat taxa, especially those from F. s. silvestris and F. s. lybica.

The IUCN SSC Cat SG follows the revised taxonomy of Kitchener et al. (2017) until there is an update of this revision. Therefore, the Chinese Mountain Cat is currently treated as a separate species and assessed as such.

Subspecies status formerly suggested for mainland and Japanese breeding populations, based on differences in vocalization patterns; some variation between these populations in morphology, coloration and egg size, but preliminary DNA analysis has shown no significant genetic distinction. Monotypic.

Since 1930 commonly treated as a subspecies of C. auriceps, and clearly the two are closely related; present species differs, however, in its considerably larger size, with mean male wing 128.2 (n=6) vs 109.9 (n=10) (Forshaw 1989) (at least 2), its lack of red line between frons and eye (2), outer webs of flight-feathers greenish-blue vs violet-blue (2), and more yellowish underparts (1). Has hybridized extensively with C. novaezelandiae chathamensis, to the extent that it was almost eradicated by genetic swamping (Chan Chi-hang et al. 2005, Chan Chi-hang et al. 2006, Triggs and Daugherty 1996). Monotypic.
Petroica macrocephala and P. dannefaerdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. macrocephala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), Turbott (1990).

Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae and H. chathamensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as H. novaeseelandiae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Usually considered conspecific with H. novaeseelandiae, but differs in its grey vs blue-green rump and primary wing-coverts (3); matt blackish-grey vs glossy dark green crown, throat, breast and neck-sides (3); reduced dull maroon carpal area (2); dark green vs whitish undertail-coverts (ns2); darker tail (ns1); much stouter bill (not measured, but estimated at 2); also modest genetic divergence (Goldberg et al. 2010). Monotypic.

Has frequently been considered a subspecies of H. unicolor or of H. ostralegus; differentiation relatively weak, and species status perhaps questionable. Recent study of mtDNA, however, supported treatment as a separate species (Banks and Paterson 2007). Form H. ostralegus finschi has on occasion been associated with present species. Monotypic.

Exhibits high levels of genetic variability, but without constant geographical patterns (McLennan and McCann 2002); also shows a degree of morphological variability along latitudinal and altitudinal gradients; further study required. Senior synonym A. maxima apparently unused for more than a century, now recommended for formal suppression (Palma et al. 2003). Monotypic.

Apteryx australis, A. mantelli and A. rowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously treated as A. australis and A. mantelli (incorporating rowi) following Baker et al. (1995); prior to that all three taxa were lumped as A. australis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Nominate subspecies further divides into two genetically well-separated populations, based respectively on Haast R (plumage distinctively rufous) and Fiordland (plumage grey-brown) (Burbidge et al. 2003, Herbert and Daugherty 2002). Two subspecies currently recognized.

The evolutionary relationship of Tomistoma with other crocodilians was debated for many years, and the species was usually aligned with the true crocodiles (Crocodylidae) based on morphological evidence (Norell 1989, Tarsitano et al. 1989, Brochu 1997). Molecular studies since the 1980s suggest a closer relationship to Gavialis (Densmore 1983, Densmore and Dessauer 1984, Gatesy and Amato 1992, Harshman et al. 2003, McAliley et al. 2006). A recent molecular study found that Tomistoma shares gene sequences with Gavialis which are absent from Crocodylus, Mecistops (see Shirley 2010) and Osteolaemus, suggesting Tomistoma should be placed within the family Gavialidae (Willis et al. 2007).

Six subspecies have been described (Ansell 1972; summarized in Cassinello 1998). However, apart from the fact that the morphological differences between them are not well defined, and there are several apparent zones of hybridization, relying exclusively on morphological traits is an obsolete and inadequate criterion to define subspecies. Therefore, and in order to re-evaluate aoudad subspecies distinction, a comprehensive genetic analysis of individuals from all the distinctive populations should be carried out. This would allow to properly identify genetic units that help redefining subspecific criteria and eventually allow undertaking proper conservation actions to protect the species (Cassinello 2015).

While taxonomy of serow has been confusing, this assessment follows Mori et al. 2019, which recognises C. rubidus as a full species of Capricornis. The Red Serow (as C .s. rubidus) was listed as Endangered (A2cd) in the 1996 IUCN Red List of Threatened Animals (IUCN 1996). However, this assessment probably included the red form of Himalayan Serow which was often attributed to this species, but it is currently included in C. sumatraensis (Duckworth and Zaw 2008).

Genetic (Rosel et al. 1995) and morphological (Brownell et al. 1987) data suggest that Vaquitas are most closely related to porpoises in South America. Genetic data suggest divergence from two sister taxa (Burmeister’s Porpoise, Phocoena spinipinnis and Spectacled Porpoise Australophocaena dioptrica) in the Pleistocene (i.e., at least 2.5 million years ago).
This recently described species was previously considered as an isolated subpopulation of Bradypodion damaranum (Tolley et al. 2022).

The intraspecific taxonomy of the Tiger (Panthera tigris) has been recently debated due to inconsistent results from various methodologies (Luo et al. 2004, Wilting et al. 2015, Kitchener et al. 2017, Liu et al. 2018). Luo et al. (2004) identify six subspecies on the analysis of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) while Wilting et al. (2015) classified Tigers into two subspecies based on data sets of several traits [morphological (craniodental and pelage), ecological, molecular]. These inconsistencies were partly attributed to the lack of genetic samples across the Tiger range. However, Liu et al. (2018) used whole-genome sequencing analyses from 32 voucher specimens that resolve six statistically robust monophyletic clades. The higher resolution of data obtained from nuclear genomes highlights little admixture and gene flow between the six subspecies. Nevertheless, there is incomplete congruence between mitochondrial and nuclear DNA results for P. t. amoyensis, suggesting the inclusion of more samples in future analysis to confirm its relationship with P. t. jacksoni.

Liu et al. (2018) concluded that six extant subspecies exist based on genome-wide analysis:

  • Amur Tiger (P. t. altaica): Russian Far East and northeastern China.
  • Northern Indochinese Tiger (P. t. corbetti): Indochina north of the Malayan Peninsula.
  • Malayan Tiger (P. t. jacksoni): Peninsular Malaysia.
  • Sumatran Tiger (P. t. sumatrae): Sumatra.
  • Bengal Tiger (P. t. tigris): Indian sub-continent.
  • South China Tiger (P. t. amoyensis), although this subspecies has not been directly observed in the wild since the 1970s and is possibly extinct.


Three subspecies previously recognised based on morphology are extinct:

  • Bali Tiger (P. t. balica Schwarz, 1912): Bali.
  • Javan Tiger (P. t. sondaica (Temminck, 1844)): Java.
  • Caspian Tiger (P. t. virgata (Illiger, 1815)): dry river valleys of the Takla Makan, western slopes of the Tianshan mountains, Amudarya and Syrdarya river valleys, shores of the Caspian Sea, Elburz mountains, eastern Turkey, Tigris and Euphrates River valleys.


However, given the varied interpretations of existing data, the taxonomy of this species is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.
Microcebus berthae is the name given to the diminutive Rufous-colored Mouse Lemur from Kirindy/CFPF, originally called M. myoxinus by Schmid and Kappeler (1994).

Presbytis femoralis formerly was regarded as a subspecies of P. melalophos (Thorington and Groves 1970, Medway 1983, Napier 1985, Oates et al. 1994), but later was recognized as a species with three subspecies: P. f. femoralis, P. f. percura and P. f. robinsoni (Groves 2001, Meyer et al. 2011, Groves and Roos 2013, Roos et al. 2014).

Genetic data suggested that at least P. f. femoralis and P. f. robinsoni were different species (Ang 2010, Nijman 2019), which also agreed with their morphological characters. However, resolving all subspecies-level boundaries within banded langurs required data for P. f. percura, which was the least studied and only found in the Riau Province in Sumatra (Rizaldi et al. 2019). Complete mitochondrial genomes were later obtained for P. f. percura in the wild, and based on multiple species delimitation algorithms (PTP, ABGD, Objective Clustering) applied to a dataset covering 40 species and 43 subspecies of Asian colobines, all three subspecies of banded langurs were resurrected to species (Ang et al. 2020).

Presbytis femoralis was described by Martin (1838) based on specimens collected by Raffles (1821) from Singapore. However, Martin (1838) gave the distribution as "Sumatra etc.", not mentioning Singapore explicitly, resulting in some confusion over the actual type locality (Miller 1934, Low and Lim 2015). Miller (1934) determined Singapore as the actual type locality, and the secretariat of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature confirmed the authorship of P. femoralis as Martin, the year of publication as 1838, and the type locality as Singapore (Low and Lim 2015).

Presbytis femoralis is uniform black on the dorsum with a white band traversing down the chest and abdomen, the inside of the humeri from the axilla, and the inside of the thighs (Raffles 1821, Martin 1838, Groves 2001). In contrast to the adult pelage, infants are born with a white coat with a broad black band from the head, along the spine, to the tail, and intersected by a black band passing along the shoulders to the outer surfaces of both forearms, forming a distinctive cruciform (cross-like) black pattern on the dorsum. A faint black line runs from the dark spinal stripe along the hind legs to the feet. The crown and facial hair are completely white from the frontal view. The forehead is slightly dark compared to the pale colour of the face (Pocock 1928, Ang et al. 2010).

authority: López-Luna, Cupul-Magaña, Escobedo-Galván, González-Hernández, Centenero-Alcalá, Rangel-Mendoza, Ramírez-Ramírez & Cazares-Hernández, 2018
taxonomicNotes: López-Luna et al. (2018, 2021) described and characterized this range-restricted mud turtle (Kinosternon vogti) from the coastal Bahía de Banderas region of Jalisco, Mexico. Based on morphologic and genetic analysis it is most closely related to K. cora, K. chimalhuaca and K. hirtipes.

The use of Lutra for four New World otter species (L. felina, L. canadensis, L. longicaudis, L. provocax) has been widespread in the past. Van Zyll de Jong (1972, 1987) separated this group into the genus Lontra based on morphological criteria, which was confirmed by Wozencraft (1993). Koepfli and Wayne (1998) and Koepfli et al. (2008) re-confirmed this classification based on molecular data. Thus, nowadays the generic name Lontra should be accepted as valid for all New World otters (except Pteronura).
Rhinopithecus brelichi was formerly considered a subspecies of Rhinopithecus roxellana, but is now accepted as specifically distinct (Groves 2001).

authority: Cusi, Gagliardi-Urrutia, Brcko, Wake & von May, 2020
taxonomicNotes: Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Bolitoglossa awajun is the sister taxon to the clade composed of B. altamazonica and B. peruviana (Cusi et al. 2020). Additionally, B. awajun is morphometrically similar to these species yet it exhibits several morphological and color differences.
Probably sister to S. petrophilus (Whitney et al. 2010); see also S. novacapitalis and S. speluncae. Monotypic.

Scytalopus gonzagi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Maurício et al. (2014). Appears to be closest to S. speluncae (which see) and perhaps S. iraiensis (Maurício et al. 2014). Monotypic.

A second species of Hypogeomys is known from the subfossil record. Hypogeomys australis was still extant 4,400 years ago, and once occurred from southeastern Madagascar north to at least the Antsirabe region (Goodman and Rakotondravony 1996).

Previously (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) placed in the genus Alopecoenas and before that in the genus Gallicolumba but transferred to Pampusana on the grounds of the latter’s priority (Bruce et al. 2016). Affinities unclear: may be close to P. beccarii and P. johannae, and the three appear also to be related to the P. jobiensis complex; alternatively, may be related to P. hoedtii, and more distantly to P. beccarii, P. johannae, P. sanctaecrucis and P. stairi. Monotypic.
Closely related to C. galerita and C. sulphurea. Monotypic.
Otidiphaps nobilis, O. aruensis, O. cervicalis and O. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. nobilis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Formerly placed in genus Lobiophasis, but recent genetic work found no evidence that Lophura as currently constituted is polyphyletic (Randi et al. 2001). The same work identified five clades within Lophura, one of which is formed by the present species alone (Randi et al. 2001). Monotypic.

authority: Simmons, Flanders, Fils, Parker, Suter, Bamba, Douno, Keita, Morales, & Frick, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Species first described in 2021 after two individuals were caught in the Nimba Mountains in January 2018 as part of a biodiversity assessment. While Myotis nimbaensis shares similar features with three other large Myotis (subgenus Chrysopteron) species with orange dorsal fur occur in Africa (M. tricolor, M. welwitschii, and M. morrisi), it is easily distinguishable due to its body size and various color patterns (Simmons et al. 2021).

Until recently considered conspecific with P. insularis, but differs in its smaller size (mean male tail, n=5, 55 mm vs 60.55, n=18, in insularis (Kirwan 2008); at least 1); (in male) paler, shorter throat patch (2); whitish vs smudgily grey-black upper breast below throat patch (2); bold white wingstripe (white tips of median coverts) (2); narrower black eyeline (ns1); paler grey crown and upperparts with weaker black streaking (ns1); almost pure white vs pale grey underparts (ns1); and (in female) no trace of grey throat patch of female insularis (ns1). Monotypic.

Pica pica, P. mauritanica, P. asirensis and P. hudsonia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. pica following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Christidis and Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This recently discovered species is endemic to the highest montane forests on the island of Taliabu. It is most similar to Chestnut-backed Grasshopper-warbler L. castanea of Sulawesi, Seram and Buru (now split into endemic species on each of these three island groups; see below), but it differs in inevitably subtle plumage features, in particular in being darker brown above than any adjacent forms (Rheindt et al. 2020). It is also distinct vocally, its song differing more from surrounding forms of L. castanea than from the much more distant Friendly Grasshopper-warbler L. accentor. Patterns of genetic divergence support species-level recognition and suggest it is most closely related to L. disturbans from Buru. Monotypic.
Lipaugus conditus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Tijuca condita.
Spalax antiquus and S. istricus were previously considered to be synonyms of S. graecus, however they are now recognised as separate species.

Spalax istricus was previously listed as a subspecies of S. graecus but has since been recognized as a separate species due to recent molecular genetic and detailed morphological studies (Németh et al. 2013).

The three known subpopulations, separated by the Carpathian Mountains, can be regarded as separate species, and assigned to already described taxa, this includes the Oltenia Blind Mole-rat.

This new species was described by Irham et al. (2020) from Alor Island, Indonesia. It is most similar to M. kuehni but differs in plumage, voice and genetics. This new species differs from M. kuehni as follows: deeper red on head (1), less extensive red on hood (3), greyer breast (1), well-documented distinctive call (at least 2) and apparently song (a further score, insufficient evidence at present). Monotypic.

M. portoricensis and M. grandis were previously lumped and listed as Pyrrhulagra portoricensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that in the genus Loxigilla following AOU (1998 and supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996). However, Pyrrhulagra now appears to be a junior synonym of Loxigilla, so the name Melopyrrha is adopted. P. grandis is again recognised as a full species following Garrido and Wiley (2003) and formal approval by the North American Classification Committee in 2021. Monotypic.

Edolisoma tenuirostre, E. insperatum, E. nesiotis, E. monacha, E. rostratum, E. meyerii, E. obiense, E. grayi, E. remotum and E. salomonis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina tenuirostris following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Until relatively recently, this species was classified as a subspecies of Macaca nemestrina. There is some hybridization with M. nemestrina in a small area of southern peninsular Thailand, and on the  islands of Phuket and Yao Yai (Groves 2001).

Assigned to the nemestrina species group including M. nemestrina, M. leonina, M. silenus, M. pagensis. Restricted hybridization with M. nemestrina where their ranges are contiguous in peninsular Thailand. (Between 8° and 9°N) at the southern end of Isthmus of Kra.

Until recently, the silvered langurs of Indochina were considered conspecific with the Sundaic Silvered Langur (Trachypithecus cristatus), which was thought to be widely distributed across parts on Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Myanmar. During the past few years, genetic analyses have supported the assignment of all non-Sundaic populations to the species T. germaini, and subsequently called for a further division of the Indochinese taxon into two species (Groves 2001, Nadler et al. 2005, Roos et al. 2008). The Indochinese populations occurring west of the Mekong River in Viet Nam, Cambodia, Lao PDR, Thailand, and Myanmar have been  attributed to T. germaini, or the Indochinese Silvered Langur, while populations occurring east of the Mekong River in Viet Nam, Cambodia, and Lao PDR have been attributed to T. margarita, or the Annamese Silvered Langur (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012a, Nadler and Brockman 2014, Nadler et al. 2005, Roos et al. 2008, Roos et al. 2014). Recent data based on a study of populations separated by the Mekong River provide support for the species split but indicate that the Mekong, while limiting gene flow, is not an impermeable barrier (Moody 2018). Furthermore, this analysis revealed that a population in north-eastern Cambodia was distinguishable compared to other study populations, both west and east of the Mekong. This may be indicative of a species barrier farther east of the Mekong that extends into Viet Nam but additional sampling of populations in both Lao and Viet Nam are critical to better understanding the limits between these species (Moody 2018). Thus, taxonomic analyses should be expanded outside of Cambodia with the aim of clarifying the boundary between these taxa and the limits of their distribution.

Byrne et al. 2016 have separated the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (Torquatus group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (Cupreus + moloch groups sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002 and Callicebus (personatus group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Cheracebus includes six species, C. torquatus, C. lugens, C. lucifer, C. purinus, C. regulus and C. medemi.

Hill (1953) listed six subspecies of Loris tardigradus. Groves (1989) recognized a single species, L. tardigradus, with three “sharply distinct” subspecies in Sri Lanka and two in India (see Schulze and Meier 1995). In 1998, however, Groves argued for two species: the very small and narrow snouted monotypic red form (L. tardigradus) from the wet zone of Sri Lanka, and the larger grey or ashy form (L. lydekkerianus) in India (two subspecies) and Sri Lanka (two subspecies). This taxonomy was followed in Groves (2001, 2005) and Brandon-Jones et al. (2004).

A phylogenetic analysis by Pozzi et al. (2015) and a morphological study by Gamage et al. (2017) also confirmed the validity of the two species. In 2004, Nekaris and Jaywardene showed that nycticeboides, also from the wet zone of Sri Lanka, is a subspecies of tardigradus, contra Groves (2001, 2005) and Brandon-Jones et al. (2004), who placed it as a subspecies of lydekkerianus. Gamage et al. (2017) argued that the slender loris from Mirigama, Gampaha District, Western Province of Sri Lanka was unique in its facial features, and cranial and post-cranial morphology, and distinct as such from L. t. tardigradus south of its range. They named it L. t. parvus. They also found evidence for a distinct, high-altitude (above 800 m) taxon in the southwestern wet zone in the Deniyaya-Rakwana mountains, which they declined to name pending more information. As such in 2017, L. tardigradus was believed to comprise three subspecies: L. t. tardigradus, L. t. nycticeboides, and L. t. parvus all from Sri Lanka. This is the taxonomy that is followed by the Primate Specialist Group.

Gamage et al. (2019) subsequently carried out a phylogenetic analysis, which they believed largely confirmed this arrangement for the Sri Lankan lorises, but this was shown to be insufficient by Nijman et al. (2020). As such, more robust genetic studies are needed.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra, as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and more recently several researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) have treated most of them as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. darwini as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

This species was described based on a record from Phong Nha-Ke Bang misidentified as Trimeresurus kanburensis (Orlov et al. 2004). Grismer et al. (2008) suggested that the species should be transferred to Viridovipera on the basis of morphological evidence. This change is supported by the molecular analysis of Dawson et al. (2008), who specifically investigated the phylogenetic position of this species and provided more detailed justification for transferring the species to Viridovipera. Subsequently moved back to Trimeresurus.

Li (1999) referred records from the Liaoning Peninsula to this species, describing them as the distinct subspecies Gloydius shedaoensis qianshanensis). Shi et al. (2016) notes that this action was subsequently neglected, with later authors regarding G. shedaoensis as being endemic to Snake Island. These authors revalidated G. s. qianshanensis, extending the range to the adjacent mainland. This action is accepted here however it is not mentioned by Wang et al. (2021), who consider the species endemic to Snake Island.
This a species described from the highlands of Peninsular Malaysia (Vogel et al. 2004) from within the Trimeresurus popeorum complex.
This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. It has sometimes been confused with T. venustus and T. purpureomaculatus (see David et al. 2004; Malhotra and Thorpe 2004).

Liu et al. (2012) conducted a molecular phylogenetic analysis of Protobothrops maolanensis and concluded that genetic evidence supports its recognition as a full species by Yang et al. (2011). Guo et al. (2016) subsequently conducted a phylogenetic study of the genus which supported its recognition as a species distinct from, but sister to, the morphologically similar Protobothrops trungkhanensis (which had not been included in the genetic analysis of Liu et al. 2012).

This species was recently described based on southern Vietnamese records formerly attributed to Cryptelytrops macrops (Malhotra et al. 2011) [now Trimeresurus macrops]. The identity of a Vietnamese record from Phu Quoc of a viper in the T. macrops complex requires clarification, as this subpopulation may belong to either T. cardamomensis or T. rubeus. Although this record is not included in either this account or that for T. cardamomensis pending clarification, biogeographic affinities suggest this record is most likely to represent T. cardamomensis (B. Stuart and L. Grismer pers. comm. September 2011).
This species was formerly classified as Atropoides occiduus following recommendations by Castoe et al. (2005) but was designated as a separate species following Smith and Ferrari-Castro (2008).

Arnold et al. (2008) revised the taxonomy of this species, formerly considered the only endemic species of Hemidactylus on Cape Verde and including the subspecies Hemidactylus bouvieri boavistensis (Boavista and Sal) and H. b. razoensis (Santo Luzia and Raso) in addition to populations from Fogo and São Nicolau unassigned to any subspecies. These authors re-elevated H. b. boavistensis to full species status and described the Fogo population as a new species, H. lopezjuradoi. The São Nicolau population was retained within H. bouvieri on the basis that available material is too poorly-preserved to permit morphological description, but was found to be genetically distinct from typical H. bouvieri. Arnold et al. (2008) consider that once better material becomes available this form will warrant description as a distinct taxon.
Thrasops schmidti was elevated to specific status by Broadley and Wallach (2002) on morphological and biogeographical grounds, having previously been considered a subspecies of T. jacksonii.
Phylogeographic studies are recommended to clarify whether the isolated western record from the Ruwenzori Mountains is conspecific with Cnemaspis elgonensis (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014).

The status of Shinisauridae, erected by Ahl (1930), as a distinct, monotypic family was supported by Macey et al. (1999). Ziegler et al. (2008) determined that morphological and mitochondrial genetic differentiation among extant subpopulations was insufficient to justify the recognition of Chinese and Vietnamese subpopulations as separate taxa or subspecies, despite an apparent geographical separation of at least 500 km.

This long-known but only recently described (Fjeldså et al. 2021) species is a member of a group of four species variously labelled ‘montane’, ‘plain-backed’ and ‘duetting’ cisticolas, the others being C. chubbi, C. hunteri and C. nigriloris, which replace one another in different highlands in eastern Africa and Cameroon. C. bakerorum differs from these by its smaller size yet longer, slightly decurved bill, paler plumage with whitish (vs dusky or blackish) lores, prominent white preocular supercilium, and mostly whitish underparts with breast and flanks washed cinnamon-buff. Its duets involve the presumed male singing 3‒5 alternately pitched notes (first note always low) backed by a cluster of buzzy notes from the presumed female, the whole phrase differing in various elements from those produced by other members of the group. The species is sister to Black-lored Cisticola C. nigriloris and differs (uncorrected parsimony distance) by 7.6% at the ND2 locus. Monotypic.

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into seven genera, with P. magellanicus, P. bougainvilliorum, P. atriceps, P. verrucosus, P. carunculatus, P. chalconotus, P. onslowi, P. campbelli, P. ranfurlyi and P. colensoi moved into Leucocarbo (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). In past, often considered to include L. chalconotus and L. onslowi; these three were sometimes treated as conspecific with P. campbelli complex (campbelli, ranfurlyi and colensoi). Monotypic.

Synonym = Testudo leithii Günther, 1869 (non Testudo leithii Carter, 1852)). The species was classified into the subgenus Pseudotestudo by Loveridge and Williams (1957). This subgeneric name is nonapplicable for T. kleinmanni because the taxon was based on juvenile characters not retained into adulthood (Bour 1989).
Usually considered to be closest to D. pacifica, D. oceanica and D. aurorae. Monotypic.
This species was described from material that included records attributed to Cnemaspis dickersonae by Spawls et al. (2018).
This species was described from material that included records attributed to Cnemaspis africana by Spawls et al. (2018).
This species was described from material that included records attributed to Cnemaspis dickersonae by Spawls et al. (2018).
This species was described from material that included records attributed to Cnemaspis dickersonae by Spawls et al. (2018).
This species was described from material that included records attributed to Cnemaspis dickersonae by Spawls et al. (2018).

Nisaetus philippensis and N. pinskeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Haring et al. (2006), which before then was placed in the genus Spizaetus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Aerodramus bartschi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Collocalia. Collocalia inquieta (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into C. bartschi following Browning (1993) and AOU (1998) and C. inquieta following Browning (1993).
See A. vaughani. Monotypic.
Well established, distinct monotypic species (Kitchener et al. 2017).
C. wallichii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as C. wallichi. Hybridization in the wild with Lophura leucomelanos has been reported (Rasmussen and Anderton 2005). Monotypic.

Cyrtodactylus jeyporensis was described by Beddome in 1877 based on specimens collected from Pathinge Hill, Jeypore, Orissa (Smith 1935). Molecular phylogenetic data reveal that Geckoella is embedded within Cyrtodactylus, and this placement is now widely accepted and hence followed here.
Monotypic.

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic group distribution presented in Steinfartz et al. (2000). See also Burgon et al. (2021).

The identity of some subpopulations of Salamandra species reported from western Anatolia (Türkiye) require further investigation and are not included within this concept, although Frost (2022) notes that it is expected to occur there.

Three regional subspecies originally described by Wilson et al. (1991) have been confirmed by Cronin et al. (1996): Enhydra lutris lutris (Linnaeus, 1758) from Japan in the southwest Pacific throughout the Asian range of the Kuril Islands to the Kamchatka Peninsula and the Commander Islands, E. l. kenyoni from the western Aleutian Islands to Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA, along the Pacific coast of Canada and into Oregon state in the continental USA, and E. l. nereis (Merriam, 1904) from central to southern California, USA.
Lalage leucomela and L. conjuncta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. leucomela following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Specimens from Sulawesi assigned to the previously recognized Pteropus arquatus and P. argentatus are now recognized as Acerodon celebensis (Musser et al. 1982, Flannery 1995).
Manucerthia mana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oreomystis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Varela-Soto, Abarca, Brenes-Mora, Aspinall, Leenders & Shepack, 2022

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included within Pristurus rupestris, but was found to be a separate species, with its description in preparation (S. Carranza pers. comm. September 2022). The species is sympatric with P. rupestris.
Loxops coccineus, L. ochraceus and L. wolstenholmei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. coccineus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chloropipo flavicapilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Xenopipo flavicapilla.
Hemignathus wilsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as H. munroi following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. Placed in Prionailurus according to genetic analysis (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). No modern analysis of subspecies available.

It has been argued, on the basis of mandibular measurements, that Crocidura canariensis should be treated as a subspecies of C. sicula (Sarà 1996). However, other morphological, ecological, palaeontological and molecular evidence supports specific status (Michaux et al. 1991, Hutterer et al. 1992). Genetic distances suggest that C. canariensis and C. sicula diverged approximately five million years ago (Vogel et al. 2003), and both share karyotype with C. tarfayaensis (Vogel et al. 2006).

Macaca fascicularis is a wide-ranging macaque with a patchy distribution in Southeast Asia (Eudey 2008, Gumert, 2011). According to a variety of descriptions (Raffles 1821; Fooden 1995, 2006; Groves 2001), as well as the assessors’, they are not distinguished by any distinct phenotypic features; however, they are one of the smaller macaques, and are named for their long tail, which approximates the length of their body and head combined. From a distance, the dorsal pelage is generally greyish or brown, with a whitish underbelly, as well as distinct black and white highlights around the crown and face. For example, their eyelids are often white, their crowns are bordered by white or black, and distinct white spots often occur on the skin in front of their ears. Closer inspection of the pelage reveals a mottled or speckled pattern, due to the individual hairs being of different colour. This hair patterning produces variation in shading between individuals and across populations. Hair shading includes yellowish, golden brown, reddish brown, brown, whitish, and blackened. Their skin colouration varies and includes white, pink, black, and brown tones. Under harsh sunlight, their facial skin easily tans. Adults are usually bearded on and around their face; however, around their snout and eyes, hair is short and sparse. Older females typically exhibit the fullest bearding, while for males it is more whisker-like. They exhibit a lateral cheek crest that usually runs vertically along the face, but among some subspecific variations the crest runs horizontally, bisecting the middle of the cheek.

The species is highly variable. Groves (2001) and Fooden (1995) have divided Macaca fascicularis into ten subspecies; however, as of recent, the most eastern subspecies, M. f. philippinensis has come under dispute. (Smith et al. 2014). Consequently, it has been tentatively removed from Red List assessment and is currently included with M. f. fascicularis. Along the northern part of their range, M. fascicularis regularly hybridizes with the rhesus macaque, M. mulatta (Fooden 1964). They have also long been known to hybridize with pig-tailed macaques, M. nemestrina (Bernstein 1966). Hybrids can occur across subspecies too (Bunlungsup et al. 2016, Gumert et al. 2019).

In regards to synonyms*: Simia aygula Linnaus 1758,  Simia cynomolgus Schreber 1775, Simia fascicularis Raffles 1821, Macacus carbonaria Cuvier, 1825, Macaca irus Geoffroy 1826, Semnopithecus kra Lesson 1830, and numerous others names have been ascribed using the above genera, as well as genera assignments that have also included Macac, Pithecus and Cynomolgus.

*There are numerous historical synonyms and mistaken names for this species. Early uses are highlighted here, but for a more complete historical listing and discussion please refer to Napier and Groves (1983), Groves (2001), and Fooden (1995).
Formerly considered as a subspecies of Sicista subtilis, but now recognized as a separate species based on caryotype and DNA data (Kovalskaya et al. 2011, Lebedev et al. 2020).

Molecular data suggest that this taxon might in fact consist of two species, although further research is required to confirm this (Kryštufek et al. 2007). Genetic data clearly indicate that the Balkan Snow Vole is composed of three historically isolated, independently evolving sets of subpopulations that can be regarded as evolutionarily significant units (ESUs).

For a long time, the westernmost representatives of the genus Spalax were identified as a single species, Spalax graecus. According to the recent studies (Németh et al. 2013, Csorba et al. 2015) the three known subpopulations, separated by the Carpathian Mountains, represent separate species which can be assigned to described taxa. One of them is Spalax antiquus Méhely’s Blind Mole-rat. The separation of Méhely’s Blind Mole-rat as a distinct species is highly supported by the combined evidences of morphology, multilocus phylogeny, biogeographical evidences and species congruence with past tectonic and climatic events (Németh et al. 2013).

According to present taxonomic knowledge, four subspecies are distinguished by Helgen et al. 2009: S. c. citellus; S. c. gradojevici with synonyms karamani and macedonicus; S. c. istricus with synonyms laskarevi and S. c. martinoi which has balcanicus and thracius as synonyms. In a detailed revision of palearctic rodents (Kryštufek and Vohralík 2012) distinguish only three subspecies: s. c. citellus with synonyms istricus, laskarevi and probably also martinoi and balcanicus; s. c. gradojevici with synonyms thracius and macedonicus; and s. c. karamani. The validity of some subspecies should be considered as uncertain until detailed genetic studies are performed.

There are two chromosome races of this species: Spermophilus suslicus odessanus (36 chromosomes) and Spermophilus suslicus sensu stricto (34 chromosomes). These are separated by the Dnieper River. Sometimes considered as separate species, genetic and acoustic data support the integrity of both races into one species (Matrosova et al. 2016).

The species was described as Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840, but for a long time was considered as subspecies of Sicista subtilis sensu lato (Sicista subtilis nordmanni). Now this taxon elevated to species level following Zagorodniuk and Selyunina (2009) and Cserkész et al. (2016).

Sicista nordmanni (Keyserling & Blasius, 1840) is synonym as it was pointed at by Chaworth-Musters (1934). Nomenclature was revised by Zagorodniuk (2009), and current name “Sminthus loriger Nathusius in Nordmann, 1840” listed as synonym of “Sicista nordmanni Keyserling et Blasius, 1840. Sicista loriger is geographically separated from Sicista subtilis s. str. (Zagorodniuk 2011).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015). The species has not been seen since the 1940s and is only known from the type locality, which is somewhat vague and now seems to all be converted to sugarcane fields (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).

As early as in the 1980s, taxonomic research on the ‘races’ of the genus Cebus confirmed the hypothesis that variations in the size and morphology of the tufted capuchins, could serve as important systematic and taxonomic criteria for intra-generic and intraspecific classification (Torres de Assumpção 1983, 1986; Torres 1988).

Further studies completed in the last two decades have confirmed this hypothesis. According to Wallace (2008), Silva Jr. (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered a two separate genera, Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 for the tufted capuchins.

Here, the taxonomy of the tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) follows Silva Jr. (2001), who did not recognize any subspecific forms. Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins as follows: C. apella apella (Linnaeus, 1758); C. apella fatuellus (Linnaeus, 1766); C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus (Goldfuss, 1809); C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (see also Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005). In this aseessment C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829, also listed by Groves (2001) is referred to as Cebus cay following Silva Jr. (2001).

The latest information resulting from genetic studies (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012a, 2012b) on the species of the genus Cebus confirmed the separation between tufted (robust) capuchins, and untufted (gracile) capuchins. Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012a, 2012b) thus consolidated the separation into two genera (Sapajus and Cebus) suggested earlier by Silva Jr. (2001).

This assessment follows the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012) and Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012a, 2012b), which present the nomenclature for nine tufted capuchin monkeys: genus Sapajus (S. apella, S. macrocephalus, S. libidinosus, S. cay, S. flavius, S. nigritus nigritus, S. nigritus cucullatus, S. robustus and S. xanthosternos).  However, more recent studies that included genetic samples of S. cay from Paraguay and Brazil showed that S. cay formed a clade with S. apella and S. macrocephalus from the southwestern Amazon, to the exclusion of S. apella and S. macrocephalus from the northern Amazon (Lima et al. 2018), and that S. cay from Paraguay and southern Mato Grosso state, Brazil were genetically allied with S. apella from Rondônia state, Brazil by the Bolivian border, while S. cay from Chapada dos Guimarães, Mato Grosso formed a clade with S. apella from Alta Floresta, also in Mato Grosso state, Brazil (Lima et al. 2017). Additionally, Nieves et al. (2021) have shown that captive S. cay in facilities in Argentina show three distinct morphotypes, and that these morphotypes have a distinct geographic pattern and are related to genetic and karyotypic differences. The S. cay individuals with provenance from northwest Argentina and Bolivia were distinctively different from eastern Argentinean S. cay, and more studies are needed to better understand the diversity within this taxon (Nieves et al. 2021).

Considering molecular, morphological and biogeographic evidence, Byrne et al. (2016) proposed new genus-level systematics for the former arrangement of Callicebus species from Hershkovitz (1990): Cheracebus Byrne et al. 2016 genus for the species in the Orinoco, Negro and upper Amazon basins; Callicebus Thomas, 1903 genus for the species in the Atlantic Forest; and Plecturocebus Byrne et al. 2016 genus for the species in the Amazon basin and Chaco.

Plecturocebus vieirai was described in 2012 from three localities in Pará State, Brazil (type locality: Renato River, a tributary of the right bank of the Teles Pires river, near the city of Cláudia, Mato Grosso; 11° 33' 00.15" S, 55° 10' 59.98" W) (Gualda-Barros et al. 2012), in an area formerly attributed to P. moloch sensu Hershkovitz (1990). The Vieira’s titi monkey is currently known to occur west of the Xingu River, east of the Iriri and Teles Pires rivers, southward to the headwaters of the Xingu and Teles Pires rivers, until the border between Amazonia–Cerrado biomes (Costa-Araújo et al. in press), and it is sister taxon to P. moloch (Boubli et al. 2019).

authority: Costa-Araújo, Silva-Jr., Boubli, Rossi, Hrbek & Farias, 2021
taxonomicNotes: Mico schneideri was described in 2021 for pseudo-cryptic marmosets endemic to the northern Juruena–Teles Pires interfluve, Mato Grosso State, Brazil. Marmosets from this region were stored in the Museu Paraense Emílio Goledi and known to scientists since 1995. They were, however, confounded with M. emiliae due to inadequacy of previous taxonomic assessments––entirely based on pelage colour of a few specimens––until new morphological, molecular and distribution data had shown that they are in fact morphologically diagnosable, form a fully supported clade and are allopatric, without evidence of distribution, morphological or genomic overlap with M. emiliae or another known species of Mico (Costa-Araújo et al. 2021).

Three elephant taxa remain from the sixteen elephant-like species that are known from across the planet in the Pleistocene: Asian Elephant (Elephas maximus), African Savanna Elephant (Loxodonta africana), and African Forest Elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis) (Faurby and Svenning 2015, Malhi et al. 2016). The Asian and African ancestral lineages diverged approximately seven million years ago, and the African Savanna and African Forest ancestral lineages began diverging approximately one million years later (Rohland et al. 2010, Brandt et al. 2014, Roca et al. 2015, Meyer et al. 2017, Palkopoulou et al. 2018). The Third Edition of ‘Mammal Species of the World’ (Wilson and Reeder 2005) was the first to formally designate the African elephant as these two separate species. Recent genetic findings also support this designation (Roca et al. 2007, Ishida et al. 2011, Mondol et al. 2015, Palkopoulou et al. 2018, Kim and Wasser 2019). Hybridization between the two species appears restricted and evident at only 14 of the more than 100 localities recently examined across the vast forest-savanna ecotone. In nine of these 14 localities, hybrid individuals occurred alongside non-hybrid individuals of either one species or the other and not both (i.e., three localities had hybrids and African Forest Elephants only and assigned as this species; six localities had hybrids and African Savanna Elephants only and assigned as this species). For the IUCN Red List assessments, a distribution map published in Mondol et al. (2015) and recent data by Kim and Wasser (2019) are used to assign localities as range of either L. africana or L. cyclotis.
Chlorodrepanis stejnegeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Hemignathus and listed as H. kauaiensis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: O'Neill, Lane, Kratter, Capparella et al., 2000

taxonomicNotes:
This taxon was formerly treated as a subspecies of the Macaca nemestrina group, which comprised M. n. nemestrina, M. n. leonina, and M. n. pagensis (Fooden 1975, Rosenblum et al. 1997).

The boundary zone between M. leonina and M. nemestrina is not well defined and lies at the Surat Thani-Krabi depression (8-9°30'N) where ranges overlap and hybridization is likely to occur (Malaivijitnond et al. 2012). Formerly, there were reports of hybridization with M. leonina in a small area in southern mainland Thailand and on the islands of Phuket and Yao Yai (Fooden 1975, in Groves 2001), however more recent reports do not provide conclusive evidence of presence of a M. nemestrina population on Phuket (iNaturalist 2022, S. Malaivijitnond, pers. comm.). Hybridization of M. nemestrina with M. fascicularis also occurs in Sepilok, Sabah (Gilhooly et al. 2021) and is occasionally observed in other parts of Malaysia (N. Ruppert, pers. obs.).

Molecular clock analysis suggests that M. nemestrina arrived in the Malay Peninsula about 0.32 million years ago; and the Bornean populations are suggested to be the first extant lineages to have separated from the other examined lineages of M. nemestrina, M. leonina, M. pagensis, and M. siberu in Southeast Asia (Abdul-Latiff and Md-Zain 2021).

The population from Perak (west Peninsular Malaysia) is reported to differ genetically from other extant populations based on phylogenetic and population genetic analyses, indicating a possible subspecies distributed in the state of Perak (Abdul-Latiff and Md-Zain 2021).
Zosterornis nigrorum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris nigrorum.
Hydrornis baudii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta baudii.
Trochalopteron yersini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax yersini.
Eurostopodus mystacalis, E. nigripennis and E. exul (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as E. mystacalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophia viridis, P. dextralis and P. obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Jønsson et al. (2018) establish that Cerulean Paradise-flycatcher Eutrichomyias rowleyi, Drongo Fantail Chaetorhynchus papuensis, Natewa Silktail Lamprolia klinesmithi and Taveuni Silktail L. victoriae belong in a separate ancient family, Lamproliidae, sister to the Rhipiduridae. This finding is accepted here.

Lamprolia victoriae and L. klinesmithi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. victoriae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ninox philippensis, N. spilocephala, N. leventisi, N. reyi, N. rumseyi, N. spilonotus and N. mindorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. philippensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).

The currently accepted taxonomy recognizes two subspecies: the whitish, depigmented and blind Proteus anguinus anguinus (“White Proteus”), and the dark-colored, eyed P. a. parkelj (“Black Proteus”). The subspecies P. a. parkelj was considered to be of doubtful validity (Goricki and Trontelj 2006).

The White Proteus is distributed throughout the entire range of the species, the Black Proteus is only known from a few sites in the region of Bela Krajina in southeastern Slovenia.

Recent molecular studies revealed that the species is deeply subdivided into nine lineages supported by both mitochondrial DNA and microsatellites (Gorički and Trontelj 2006, Trontelj et al. 2009, Trontelj and Zakšek 2016, Vörös et al. 2019). The Black Proteus constitutes one of those lineages. Their ranges are mostly allopatric, although they are touching or even overlapping in some areas (Gorički et al. 2017).

The assessment of the exact taxonomic and conservation status of the Proteus lineages is the subject of ongoing research (Bizjak Mali and Sket 2019), but they should be treated as evolutionary significant units, to ensure the survival of diversity in this threatened species.

Two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern one) were formerly recognised, however, more recent data challenges the distinct nature of these two clades (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. 2022).

authority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001
taxonomicNotes: Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).

Triturus cristatus was formerly considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. cristatus dobrogicus; T. cristatus karelinii; and T. cristatus carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species under the Triturus cristatus superspecies. On the basis of results of molecular genetic analyses, Triturus carnifex has been split into Triturus carnifex s.l. and Triturus macedonicus.
Falco araeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as F. araea.

This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

The three main recognised phyloclades are highly differentiated from each other, despite relatively small geographical distances among them (Veith et al. 2020). The Kasos Island subpopulation is genetically differentiated from those on the other two islands (Eleftherakos et al. 2007).
Psophia viridis, P. dextralis and P. obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

A. cygnoid (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as A. cygnoides but internal evidence does not justify this emendation (Dickinson and Remsen 2013). Sometimes placed in monospecific genus Cygnopsis. Monotypic.

This species was formerly regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos (Greece); However, recent evidence based on complete mitogenome sequencing showed that individuals from Karpathos and Rhodos form a well-supported monophyletic group with very low genetic distance between them, thus placing the Rhodos population to P. cerigensis and not to P. bedriagae (Toli et al. 2023). The species should be considered endemic to the islands of Karpathos and Rhodos.

Although neither Speybroeck et al. (2020) nor Frost (2024) consider the Karpathos Frog as a separate species (considered a synonym of Pelophylax ridibundus (Pallas, 1771)), recent phylogenetic analysis based on complete mitogenome sequences support the taxonomic distinctiveness of P. cerigensis (Toli et al. 2023). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.

authority: Plötner, Baier, Akın, Mazepa, Schreiber, Beerli, Litvinchuk, Bilgin, Borkin & Uzzell, 2012
taxonomicNotes:
This species had previously been confused with Pelophylax bedriagae (Plötner et al. 2012).

The taxonomic identity of the species is not accepted by the Taxonomic Committee of the Societas Europaea Herpetologica (Speybroeck et al. 2020):
"Using allozymes and mtDNA, a detailed analysis of gene flow patterns across the contact zone of the northern Anatolian lineage and the Balkan lineage of the Pelophylax ridibundus–bedriagae complex in northern Greece revealed the existence of a wide hybrid zone, with introgression detectable over more than 200 km (Hotz et al. 2013). This suggests that the European and Anatolian lineages are conspecific (contra SBC 2010). Since the European lineage splits from a node basal to the diversification of Anatolian lineages with respect to mtDNA according to Plötner et al. (2012), it further suggests that most lineages of this complex are conspecific, with the possible exception of the populations from Syria and Jordan (possibly the ‘true’ bedriagae, see Plötner et al. 2012). On the other hand, Plötner et al. (2010) suggested hybrid breakdown between some of these lineages, indicating incipient speciation.

While undoubtedly the last word on this subject has not been written, the TC felt that it was premature to suggest taxonomic changes, especially as a large taxonomic paper based on genomic variation patterns is in preparation (G. Mazepa pers. comm.). The same applies to the newly proposed P. cypriensis, which was found to be placed between the European and the Anatolian lineages in mtDNA, but grouped with P. cretensis (albeit with very low support) in nuclear DNA (Plötner et al. 2012). For the moment, we thus suggest no change to the taxonomy adopted in SBC2010 for European Pelophylax."
Prosobonia cancellata and P. parvirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cancellata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Marmota is divided into four species groups, including the caudata group which contains M. caudata and M. menzbieri. These species have been shown not to be sister species (Steppan et al. 2011). There are two recognised subspecies of M.  menzbieri (Marmota menzbieri menzbieri and Marmota menzbieri zachidovi), each subspecies has its own geographic isolate (Krystufek and Vohralik 2013). Morphological differences are slight, but relatively deep genetic divergence was reported in this species (Steppan et al. 2011).
